headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Higher Sales Posted By Ciba and Sandoz
abstract: The Swiss pharmaceuticals giants Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz, which have agreed to  merge, both reported sales growth for the first half of the year and said they were confident they would receive approval to proceed with their merger. Ciba-Geigy reported that first-half sales grew by 4 percent, to 11.43 billion Swiss francs ($9.1 billion), and Sandoz said its six-month sales rose by 7 percent, to 7.87 billion Swiss francs ($6.24 billion).          Ciba reported that sales gained significant momentum in the second quarter,  helped in part by a weaker franc. In addition, its chief financial officer, Rolf Meyer, said that the company expected the stronger growth to continue and that it expected to report higher full-year sales and profits.   (Reuters)

headline: Allied Irish Banks Posts 14% Profit Gain
abstract: Allied Irish Banks reports 14 percent jump in half-year profits to record $326 million, and says second-half figures may also outstrip last year's (S)

headline: Sprint to Offer Internet Service to Residential Customers
abstract: Sprint Corp to gradually begin offering low-cost Internet service to its residential customers later this year; will offer free service to some customers to test capacities (M)

headline: World News Briefs;Czech Premier Appoints A Coalition Government
abstract: Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus of the Czech Republic formally submitted a proposed new coalition Cabinet to President Vaclav Havel today, a step toward forming a minority Government after inconclusive elections.         After meeting with Mr. Havel, Mr. Klaus, a conservative economist, said he hoped to submit his new Government's program to Parliament for a confidence vote "around July 16 or 17."

headline: Erskine Childers, 68, Former U.N. Official
abstract: Erskine Childers, long-serving United Nations official who devoted last years of his life to promoting reform of organization, dies at age 68 (S)

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: CHARTER POWER SYSTEMS INC., Plymouth Meeting, Pa., which produces and markets integrated reserve power systems, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 500,000 shares, or 7.7 percent of the company's common stock outstanding.     GLENBOROUGH REALTY TRUST INC., San Mateo, Calif., a real estate investment trust, filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 4 million common shares. As of May 10, the company had 5.75 million shares outstanding.     STEINWAY MUSICAL INSTRUMENTS INC., Elkhart, Ind., a maker of musicial instruments, known for its Steinway pianos, said it had sold about 3.57 million common shares for $19 a share, or $67.8 million, in an initial public offering yesterday.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF IOMEGA SLIDE ON DISAPPOINTING EARNINGS
abstract: The shares of the Iomega Corporation plunged 19 percent yesterday after the disk drive maker's second-quarter earnings disappointed some analysts and investors. In addition, Iomega told analysts yesterday on a conference call that third-quarter sales, especially in Europe, could be weak. European sales declined in the second quarter, Iomega said. Iomega's stock fell $5.50, to $22.50, in Nasdaq trading of almost 18.3 million shares yesterday. Iomega said late on Thursday that sales of its popular Zip and Jaz disk drives had pushed second-quarter profit to $14.1 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with a loss of $1.9 million, or 2 cents, in the period a year earlier.

headline: North Korea Opens the Door, a Crack, to Capitalism
abstract: North Korea claims its three-day conference aimed at luring foreign investors to its new free trade zone was success; creation of zone in Rajin and Sonbong, in remote northeastern corner of country, could mark beginning of transformation for North Korea, which remains one of most closed and rigid societies on earth; for now, its central planning and lack of experience with credit make it difficult place to do business; foreign businessmen are restricted in their travel, and new trade zone is five-hour drive from nearest airport with regular jet service; American companies are barred from most business in North Korea under Trading With the Enemy Act; North Korea hopes American companies will push to have embargo lifted, as they did with Vietnam; photos; maps (L)

headline: Fearful Kurds Huddle at Iran's Closed Door
abstract: Penjwin, Iraq, located near border with Iran is grim home for estimated 50,000 Kurdish refugees fleeing forces loyal to Pres Saddam Hussein; nearly all have direct ties to Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, which held sway in Sulaimaniya region until defeat by forces of Kurdistan Democratic Party; photo (M)

headline: India Deadlocks Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty
abstract: Plans by Clinton Administration and dozen other governments to imminently finish work on nuclear test ban treaty collapse in Geneva as India, supported by Iran, blocks all efforts to close negotiations and open pact for signing (M)

headline: JOBLESS RATE FELL TO 5.1% IN AUGUST, LOWEST IN 7 YEARS
abstract: Labor Dept reports that nation's unemployment rate fell to seven-year low of 5.1 percent in Aug and hourly earnings posted their second healthy increase in three months; says employers added 250,000 workers to their payrolls in Aug; Pres Clinton hails figures as showing that economy is 'on the right track'; graph (M)

headline: MARKET WATCH;Beware The Risk Of Seeking Protection
abstract: You survived the plunge in stocks, and you didn't panic. Maybe you took a long lunch on Tuesday and didn't even see the worst of the slide until it was over. And now stocks have made up a significant part of what was lost. Congratulations.         But you're still a little nervous, and you wonder if there isn't a way to take out a little insurance, to be sure your portfolio won't melt the next time  worry sets in.

headline: How to Land a Promising 'Huge Cap' Stock
abstract: Guidance on investing in behemoth companies according to dividend yield; analyst Melissa R Brown discusses her finding that 'huge cap' stocks with highest yields easily bested stocks with little or no yield; graph of top dividend yielders aong 50 biggest US corporations (S)

headline: Gencor of South Africa Posts 47% Profit Rise
abstract: Gencor Ltd, one of South Africa's three biggest mining companies, says earnings before one-time items rose 47 percent in latest fiscal year; income before one-time items was 1.49 billion rand ($328 million) in year ended June 30, up from 1.02 billion rand in previous fiscal year (S)

headline: Qantas and Union Reach a Pay Deal
abstract: Qantas Airways Ltd reaches agreement with Transport Workers Union of Australia for 8% wage increase over two years for 5,500 Qantas workers (S)

headline: USA WASTE SERVICES ACQUIRES SOLID WASTE BUSINESS
abstract: Philip Environmental Inc sells its municipal and commercial solid nonhazardous waste business in Michigan, Ontario, and Quebec to USA Waste Services Inc for $118 million (S)

headline: World News Briefs;Colombia Announces Major Cabinet Shake-Up
abstract: The Government announced today that Foreign Minister Rodrigo Pardo had resigned and would be replaced by the Education Minister, Maria Emma Mejia. No explanation was given for Mr. Pardo's resignation.         The Cabinet change came a month after Colombia's Congress exonerated President Ernesto Samper of all responsibility in illegal donations to his 1994  presidential campaign by leaders of the Cali drug cartel. That decision, which met with widespread skepticism, further eroded the popularity of Mr. Samper and  of the Congress in local polls.

headline: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS TO SELL DEBT SECURITIES
abstract: Electronic Data Systems Corp files with Securities and Exchange Commission to sell as much as $2 billion of debt securities (S)

headline: WAL-MART EXPECTS $464 MILLION FROM SALE OF PLANTS
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores Inc says it expects about $464 million from its sale of six photo-finishing plants to Fuji Photo Film USA and long-term deal with Fuji (S)

headline: Bozell Files to Offer Stock in Its Poppe Unit
abstract: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt sets $50 million initial public stock offering for its Poppe Tyson unit; seeks Nasdaq listing for unit; Safecyle names Poppe Tyson to handle advertising and public realitons for its fluid-waste management device for use in operating rooms (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SAN DIEGO DEVELOPER TO SELL MOST OF ITS REAL ESTATE
abstract: Mission West Properties, a real estate developer, said yesterday that it had  agreed to sell substantially all of its real estate assets to DMB/SVP California Investments L.L.C. for $42 million in cash. Mission West, which is based in San  Diego, said it would use the proceeds to repay outstanding mortgage debt of about $31.3 million on the assets. After completion of the transaction, which is expected in late August, Mission West said it would distribute to shareholders a substantial portion of the remaining cash proceeds, after paying corporate taxes and transaction costs.

headline: Sale Planned for Shares in Florida Panthers
abstract: H Wayne Huizenga to sell almost half the ownership of Florida Panthers hockey franchise to the public, cutting back his stake in team that wins games but loses money; Florida Panthers Holding Inc will sell 7.3 million class A common shares for about $10 each (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;WANG LABORATORIES PLANS TO ACQUIRE I-NET
abstract: Wang Laboratories Inc., the computer software maker, announced yesterday that it was buying I-NET Inc., a computer network services company, for $167 million. Wang plans to pay I-NET $100 million in cash and a $66.7 million one-year interest-free note. It plans to also assume about $40 million of existing I-NET  debt. The acquisition would add more than $300 million to Wang's revenues in the 1997 fiscal year, the company said. I-NET specializes in network computing services, one of the fastest-growing segments of the data technology services market. Wang, based in Billerica, Mass., also said that it earned $34.6 million, or 13 cents a share, in its fourth quarter, which ended on June 30, compared with earnings of $33.3 million, or 9 cents, in the period a year earlier.

headline: Police Suspect Link to Sex Ring : Belgians See Break In Politician's Killing
abstract: BRUSSELS—  In 1991, Andre Cools, a former deputy prime minister, was gunned down outside his girlfriend's apartment, the opening chapter of an intrigue that has cast a pall of suspicion over Belgium's entire political class.

headline: Behind Rally, an Optimism That Mystifies
abstract: Market Place column on puzzlement of some stock strategists as Dow Jones industrial average returns to near-record levels, despite less than optimal market conditions; one reason for rebound is that sentiment of bull market persists; bull-market view means that many uncertainties that have made stocks volatile this summer are still being seen through rose-colored glasses; graph (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.13   5.17   5.90        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.02   5.04   5.43        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.09   5.08   5.44        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.57   6.47   6.54        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.78   6.69   6.89        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.86   7.70   7.80        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   5.84   5.80   6.32          *Estimated daily average, source Telerate  **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: In Moscow, Scapegoating at a Congress of Poor Losers
abstract: Major representatives of Russia's Communist Party meet for first time since defeat of leader Gennadi A Zyuganov by Boris Yeltsin in Presidential election; disoriented and chastened by huge loss, many refuse to acknowledge decision of voters; most publicly pledge loyalty to Zyuganov on eve of huge assembly where dozens of leftist groups will once again form coalition to oppose Government in Parliament and in crucial gubernatorial elections later in year (M)

headline: The Prisoner of Japan's Great Expectations
abstract: Japan's Crown Princess Masako, once symbol of new Japanese career woman, has not only virtually vanished from sight, but is also measured by a standard that is thousands of years old: her ability to bear a son; but without a son in sight, people are openly discussing the succession; after Emperor Akihito, the throne goes to Crown Prince, Naruhito, but if he dies without leaving a son, it will go to his younger brother, Prince Akishino; Akishino has only two daughters now; after him, there is no male descendant; Japanese imperial-watchers are debating possibility of seeing Chrysanthemum throne go to a daughter; last female emperor--the title of empress is reserved for emperor's wife--reigned for seen years until 1770; photos (L)

headline: Russia's Top-Flight Cardiology Hospital
abstract: Cardiology Center in Moscow, where Pres Boris Yeltsin will likely undergo heart surgery, has high success rates comparable to those in many American hospitals; Dr Michael DeBakey says head surgeon Renat S Akchurin trained with him in Houston and performed bypass surgery on Prime Min Viktor Chernomyrdin about four years ago; center's director is Dr Yevgeny I Chazov, former Soviet health minister who has gotten funds for good equipment; Yeltsin's precise heart condition is not clear (S)

headline: Journalist as Broker in Mixed Marriage Next Week of Microsoft and NBC News
abstract: Today, Merrill Brown may be stepping around paint cans and sawhorses in the MSNBC studios still under construction in Fort Lee, N.J., dressed in the white shirt, rep tie and conservative suit of a network television executive.         Tomorrow he may be strolling the leafy campus of Microsoft in Redmond, Wash., in a T-shirt and jeans.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Bertelsmann-Kirch Accord on Decoder
abstract: Bertelsmann A.G. and Kirch Group, rival German media giants, said today that  they would develop a common decoder standard for digital television, ending a long battle over which technology would dominate.         The two companies had been pursuing separate, incompatible decoder technology.

headline: Price Report Shows No Sign Of Inflation
abstract: price report shows no sign of inflation**Labor Department reports prices of finished goods remained flat in July, aided by third monthly decline in energy prices; with energy component excluded, prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent; report notes that over last 12 months, producer inflation has been at an overall rate of 2.6 percent; says rate is only 1.5 percent without energy or food; economists hail readings, noting inflation is nowhere to be found; graph on producer prices (M)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;New Yorker Goes to Deutsch
abstract: The New Yorker magazine, owned by Advance Publications, has named Deutsch Inc. in New York to create a trade campaign. Billings were not disclosed. The print and outdoor campaign, which is scheduled for early fall, will focus on "the impact of The New Yorker, what happens when something appears in the magazine," said Thomas A. Florio, president of The New Yorker. The magazine has  not run a trade campaign for more than two years. Its most recent previous agency of record was the Ammirati Puris Lintas unit of the Interpublic Group of  Companies in New York, which conducted research for The New Yorker in 1995.

headline: In a Far-Flung Empire, Some Winners, Losers and Works in Progress;Fox TV Network Raises Concern
abstract: Rupert Murdoch's empire spreads across six continents and includes books, magazines, newspapers, broadcasting, satellite televison, cable and a movie studio. The following is a glimpse at how some parts of that empire are doing as Mr. Murdoch engages in a frenzy of new expansion aimed at locking up both programming and distribution outlets around the world.         Around the edges of the remarkable success story that is Rupert Murdoch's Fox television network, there are lately a few notes of concern.

headline: John Paul Barringer, 93, Envoy Who Owned a Meteorite Crater
abstract: John Paul Barringer, business executive, former Foreign Service officer and owner of Barringer Crater in Arizona, dies at age 93 (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF SUNGLASS HUT INTERNATIONAL DECLINE 15%
abstract: The shares of Sunglass Hut International Inc. fell 15 percent yesterday as investors reacted to fears about declining same-store sales and earnings, analysts said. Shares in the company, a retailer of prescription and nonprescription sunglasses that is based in Coral Gables, Fla., fell $1.875, to  $10.75, in trading of 6.74 million shares, more than six times the three-month daily average. It was its lowest closing price since January 1995.

headline: Michelin Sales Advance by 5.4%
abstract: Michelin, tire maker, says first-half sales rose 5.4 percent, to 34.91 billion francs ($6.8 billion), up from 33.11 billion francs in 1995 period (S)

headline: COMPANY PLANS A $22.4 MILLION CHARGE
abstract: Raytheon Co says it will take aftertax charge of $22.4 million in third quarter as its Amana appliance division tries to sell manual-cleaning-oven business; if no buyer is found, it will close plant and dismiss 265 workers and dispose of assets (S)

headline: U S West Has Rise in New-Service Orders
abstract: U S West Communications Inc. said it recorded record growth in new-service orders and new lines during the first half of 1996, while making strides in improving service.         The regional Bell, which is based here, said that orders for new service through the first half of the year rose 34 percent, to 8.2 million orders from 6.1 million in the corresponding period last year.

headline: Time Warner and Turner to Meet F.T.C.
abstract: Meetings have been scheduled for next week between Time Warner Inc., the Turner Broadcasting System and members of the Federal Trade Commission as the companies seek approval for the planned sale of Turner Broadcasting to Time Warner.         Though such meetings generally signal the end of the regulatory process, in this case not all issues have been resolved, people close to the companies said  yesterday.

headline: France to Cut a Third of Its Army Regiments
abstract: France will disband 38 of its 129 army regiments, including 11 stationed in Germany, and close barracks, army hospitals and air bases around the country as  part of a plan to cut the uniformed armed forces from 500,000 to 350,000 by 2002, the Defense Ministry announced today.         After a series of complaints from German officials that France had not adequately consulted them on the moves, including a plan to end military conscription here starting next year, Defense Minister Charles Millon said that  the cuts affecting Germany had been carried out "in full consultation with Germany."

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Digital Posts $433 Million Deficit in Quarter
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation posted a $433 million deficit in its fiscal fourth quarter today after taking a $492 million charge to pay for 7,000 job cuts and plant closings.         Digital, the nation's third-largest computer maker, warned analysts earlier this month that it would take a restructuring charge to cover an 11 percent cut  in its 60,900-member work force and close 3.5 million square feet of space at manufacturing plants and distribution sites.

headline: Auto Workers Union Close to Choice for Final Talks
abstract: United Automobile Workers union officials say they will soon announce whether they will hold final round of talks with General Motors or Ford Motor Co aimed at producing national labor contract that union would then try to apply across the industry; current contract expires on Sept 14; union said to be leaning toward Ford, unless GM improves its contract offer immediately; job security seen as union's main issue in this year's labor negotations (M)

headline: Yeltsin's Health Hurts Mark; Dollar Gains on Rate Outlook
abstract: Dollar rises against German mark after Pres Boris N Yeltsin of Russia says he will have heart surgery; signs of political instability in Russia help dollar and hurt mark because Germany is Russia's biggest creditor and trading partner (M)

headline: Turner Broadcasting Earnings Down 47.9% in 2d Quarter
abstract: Turner Broadcasting System Inc reports second-quarter net income fell to $11.3 million, down 47.9 percent from $21.7 million in 1995 period; table (S)

headline: ARCHER DANIELS TO BUY STAKE IN MEXICAN COMPANY
abstract: Archer Daniels Midland Co will buy 22 percent stake in Mexican corn products company Gruma SA for $258 million (S)

headline: Key Anniversary for Protestants Brings Tension in Ulster to a Boil
abstract: The British Government refused today to rescind a police order that has led to three days of demonstrations and violence by thousands of Protestants in Northern Ireland.         The demonstrators in this predominantly Protestant British province say they  feel the police order, which is blocking an annual patriotic march, insults their heritage.

headline: Chief of Apple Computer Soothes the Jittery Faithful
abstract: About 50,000 Mcintosh computer enthusiasts attend Macworld convention, Boston, Mass; hear Apple's new chief executive, Gilbert Amelio, express confidence for future of company; judging from crowds and standing ovation Amelio received after outlining his plan to restore company's cachet, Apple still has loyalty of its core clientele (M)

headline: EUROPE APPROVES OIL COMPANIES' JOINT OPERATIONS
abstract: British Petroleum PLC and Mobil Corp win European Commission approval to combine their oil refining and marketing operations in Europe (S)

headline: Kurdish Suicide Bomber Kills 9 Turkish Soldiers
abstract: On Friday, less than 48 hours after the head of Turkey's Islamic Party, Necmettin Erbakan, took office as Prime Minister, Kurdish rebels sent him a harsh message.         As Turkish soldiers were marching in a military parade through the eastern town of Tunceli, an apparently pregnant woman stepped from the crowd. She turned out to be carrying a bomb under her dress, and when it went off, she and nine soldiers were killed. More than 20 others were injured.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Higher Sales Posted By Ciba and Sandoz
abstract: The Swiss pharmaceuticals giants Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz, which have agreed to  merge, both reported sales growth for the first half of the year and said they were confident they would receive approval to proceed with their merger. Ciba-Geigy reported that first-half sales grew by 4 percent, to 11.43 billion Swiss francs ($9.1 billion), and Sandoz said its six-month sales rose by 7 percent, to 7.87 billion Swiss francs ($6.24 billion).          Ciba reported that sales gained significant momentum in the second quarter,  helped in part by a weaker franc. In addition, its chief financial officer, Rolf Meyer, said that the company expected the stronger growth to continue and that it expected to report higher full-year sales and profits.   (Reuters)

headline: Allied Irish Banks Posts 14% Profit Gain
abstract: Allied Irish Banks reports 14 percent jump in half-year profits to record $326 million, and says second-half figures may also outstrip last year's (S)

headline: Sprint to Offer Internet Service to Residential Customers
abstract: Sprint Corp to gradually begin offering low-cost Internet service to its residential customers later this year; will offer free service to some customers to test capacities (M)

headline: World News Briefs;Czech Premier Appoints A Coalition Government
abstract: Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus of the Czech Republic formally submitted a proposed new coalition Cabinet to President Vaclav Havel today, a step toward forming a minority Government after inconclusive elections.         After meeting with Mr. Havel, Mr. Klaus, a conservative economist, said he hoped to submit his new Government's program to Parliament for a confidence vote "around July 16 or 17."

headline: Erskine Childers, 68, Former U.N. Official
abstract: Erskine Childers, long-serving United Nations official who devoted last years of his life to promoting reform of organization, dies at age 68 (S)

abstract: CHARTER POWER SYSTEMS INC., Plymouth Meeting, Pa., which produces and markets integrated reserve power systems, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 500,000 shares, or 7.7 percent of the company's common stock outstanding.     GLENBOROUGH REALTY TRUST INC., San Mateo, Calif., a real estate investment trust, filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 4 million common shares. STEINWAY MUSICAL INSTRUMENTS INC., Elkhart, Ind., a maker of musicial instruments, known for its Steinway pianos, said it had sold about 3.57 million common shares for $19 a share, or $67.8 million, in an initial public offering yesterday.

abstract: The shares of the Iomega Corporation plunged 19 percent yesterday after the disk drive maker's second-quarter earnings disappointed some analysts and investors. In addition, Iomega told analysts yesterday on a conference call that third-quarter sales, especially in Europe, could be weak. European sales declined in the second quarter, Iomega said. Iomega's stock fell $5.50, to $22.50, in Nasdaq trading of almost 18.3 million shares yesterday. Iomega said late on Thursday that sales of its popular Zip and Jaz disk drives had pushed second-quarter profit to $14.1 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with a loss of $1.9 million, or 2 cents, in the period a year earlier.

headline: India Deadlocks Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty
abstract: Plans by Clinton Administration and dozen other governments to imminently finish work on nuclear test ban treaty collapse in Geneva as India, supported by Iran, blocks all efforts to close negotiations and open pact for signing (M)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bozell Worldwide Expands in Chicago
abstract: Bozell Worldwide, in its fifth acquisition in Chicago in two years, has agreed to buy the office there of Wells Rich Greene BDDP and merge it with the Bozell office in Chicago. Terms were not disclosed.         The Wells Rich office in Chicago has seven employees and billings estimated at $20 million from clients like the Citgo Petroleum Corporation and Cub Foods. The Bozell Chicago office has 220 employees and billings estimated at $125 million from clients like Harley-Davidson and Zenith Electronics.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Broker Links Sumitomo Officials to Trades
abstract: Sumitomo Corporation officials authorized accounts handled by the company's former chief copper trader, Yasuo Hamanaka, a brokerage firm for the Japanese trading company said today.         Credit Lyonnais Rouse, the commodity trading unit of France's state-owned Credit Lyonnais bank, made the statement after the owners of Winchester Commodities Group Ltd., which traded on Mr. Hamanaka's behalf through Rouse, said in newspaper interviews today that several Sumitomo directors had approved  his biggest trades.

headline: Thyssen's Chief Detained and Questioned
abstract: Dieter Vogel, Thyssen AG's chief executive, and several other current or former managers are detained and questioned in connection with possible fraud relating to company's involvement in liquidating East German metals trading company (S)

headline: How the Gold Group Is Keeping Its Luster
abstract: Magic touch of gold mutual funds in 1996 discussed; precious-metals group has gained 17.4% on average, compared with 9% for all equity funds; graph; basic reason is imbalance in supply and demand for gold that is prompting small exploration companies to accelerate operations (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bid From Hays For Christian Salvesen
abstract: Christian Salvesen P.L.C. said yesterday that it had received a bid from Hays P.L.C., a British office services company. Salvesen, a distributor of consumer goods and food, did not disclose the bid, which it said it was considering. As of yesterday, Salvesen's had a market capitalization of around L1 billion ($1.56 billion). The acquisition would catapult Hays into the ranks of Britain's 100 largest companies, at around 75th place.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Bosnian Officials Make First Visit to Serbia
abstract: For the first time since the start of the Bosnian war in 1992, high-ranking Bosnian officials and businessmen made an official visit to rival Serbia today.          The two-day visit represents a major breakthrough in the renewal of relations between Bosnia and Serbia, which supported the Bosnian Serb army against Bosnian Government forces.

headline: U.S. and Saudis Agree to Split Cost of Safeguarding G.I.'s
abstract: US and Saudi Arabia agree to split estimated $200 million cost of moving nearly 4,000 American soldiers stationed in Saudi Arabia to other bases to protect them from terrorist attacks; under agreement, approximately 4,000 of 5,000 American troops will be moved to isolated air base near Al Kharj, 50 miles southeast of Riyadh, including virtually all of 2,500 Americans living near complex in Dhahran, which was bombed on June 25 (M)

headline: West Plans to Correct Bosnia Vote Abuses
abstract: Western election monitors from Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe say they are likely to take action soon to correct what they call 'massive' manipulation of rules for next month's elections in Bosnia; note, in particular, evidence that Bosnian Serb refugees now living in Serbia have taken advantage of loopholes in voter registration rules to register in great numbers in few important towns that formerly had Muslim majorities; monitors remain undecided about how to counter this and other threats to integrity of Sept 14 elections; map (M)

headline: Market Place;Initial public offerings drift back to earth.
abstract: IN this month's market carnage, few areas have been hit harder than once-hot  initial public offerings. Stocks that soared on hopes of great future successes  have been among the most vulnerable to a change in market psychology, in which investors are interested in what can go wrong, as well as what can go right.         The accompanying table lists 15 stocks that had stunning debuts within the last year. All but one are technology companies, the exception being a microbrewery. All of them flew out of the box, ending the first day of trading with a gain of at least 50 percent from the offering price for those lucky enough -- or, more to the point, with the pull -- to get in on the initial offering.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;STARWOOD LODGING AGREES TO ACQUIRE 9 HOTELS
abstract: Continuing its buying spree, Starwood Lodging Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire nine hotels from Hotels of Distinction Ventures Inc. of Palm Beach, Fla., for $134 million. The hotels, with a total of 2,425 rooms, would be operated by Starwood Lodging Trust's affiliate, the Starwood Lodging Corporation, a hotel management and operating company. The hotels are in Atlanta; Needham, Mass.; Palm Desert, Calif.; St. Louis; Tucson, Ariz.; Minneapolis; Arlington Heights, Ill.; Allentown, Pa., and Winston-Salem, N.C. In the last 12 months, Starwood, which is based in Los Angeles, has bought properties that have about 11,300 rooms for $840 million. Its portfolio now includes stakes in 62 hotels with more than 16,400 rooms.

headline: The Perils of Consulting
abstract: Michael Yam letter comments on July 28 article by Leslie Bilodeau Placzek on consulting as an occupation (S)

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Kellogg Earnings Plunge 42.5% On Price Cuts and Competition
abstract: The Kellogg Company reported a 42.5 percent slide in second-quarter profits today, citing stiff competition and industry price cuts for ready-to-eat cereals.         Kellogg recently cut prices an average of 19 percent on two-thirds of its domestic cereal business, joining its major rivals in the $9 billion cereal industry.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Donna Karan Features Acting Couple
abstract: The designer Donna Karan is sending a valentine to Bruce Willis and Demi Moore in the form of a campaign featuring the acting couple for her fall Donna Karan New York Collection of women's and men's clothing.         The campaign was produced by an in-house creative team led by Trey Laird, senior vice president for creative services and advertising at Donna Karan International Inc. in New York; the budget is "a little over $5 million," he said. The campaign includes a 30-page "outsert," a polybagged ad supplement to accompany the September issue of W magazine.

headline: Rank Buying a Chain Of British Pubs
abstract: Rank Organization to acquire pub company Tom Cobleigh PLC for 95.6 million pounds ($148.8 million) (S)

headline: Apple and Hewlett In Printer Talks
abstract: Apple Computer Inc says it has entered discussions with Hewlett-Packard Co to collaborate on development of ink-jet printers; printers would be made by Hewlett-Packard to Apple specifications, and would be sold under Apple logo through Apple dealers (S)

headline: FUNDS WATCH;Whip Inflation Now? Lessons From the 70's
abstract: PRICES of commodities like oil, natural gas, wheat and corn have been rising  this year; the question is whether the pricing pressures are merely a blip or signs of a longer-term inflationary trend.         At CDA/Wiesenberger, a fund information and tracking firm in Rockville, Md.,  analysts say evidence is mounting that many of the increases are, in fact, driven by demand and are not simply results of a one-time phenomenon like the weather.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Gains 23.67 Points, As Bond Yields Drop   With traders heartened by economic signs that suggested the Federal Reserve would not raise short-term interest rates at next week's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the stock market forged ahead for the second time this week.    Financial stocks, being sensitive to interest rates, helped pace the market's advance, with PNC Bank, Comerica and Barnett Banks among the gainers. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 23.67 points, to 5,689.45, fueled by oil stocks. For the week, the Dow was up 8.14 points. But with many technology stocks off, the Nasdaq composite index slipped 1.04 points to close at 1,1133.65. $(Page 36.$)    Treasury bond prices gained for the first time in a week, as traders took the slide in housing starts as a sign of a slowing economy that should bode well for keeping interest rates down. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 16/32 , to 9928/32 , as its yield fell to 6.76 percent from 6.80 percent. But the yield was up 7 basis points for the week. $(39.$)    Western Resources Claims Victory   Western Resources claimed a victory in its $1.9 billion hostile takeover bid for Kansas City Power and Light, saying Kansas City Power shareholders rejected a plan to buy out Utilicorp United. The votes have yet to be counted, however, and Kansas City Power was not conceding defeat. A triumph, it is believed. would be the first successful hostile takeover of an American electric utility, and analysts predicted it would lead to more. $(37.$)    Directors of IES Industries, Cedar Rapids, Iowa, rejected a $1.17 billion buyout offer from MidAmerican Energy and approved a sweetened offer to merge with two other utilities, WPL Holdings of Madison, Wis., and Interstate Power of Dubuque, Iowa. $(35.$)    New Rules for Commuter Planes   Commuter aircraft, under rules taking effect today, will have to fly farther behind jet airliners when approaching or leaving airports to reduce the risk of crashes. Increased delays are expected to result. $(6.$)    A Costly Case of Writer's Block   Joe McGinniss had a front-row seat at the O. J. Simpson trial and a $1 million advance to write a book about the case. But Mr. McGinniss, best-selling author of ''Fatal Vision,'' quit the project, citing a lack of anything new to say about the case. The 53-year-old writer plans to focus on his true passion: European soccer. He thus loses a two-book deal with Crown Books, and must forfeit a total advance of $1.75 million. $(36.$)    Coke Aces Pepsi in Venezuela   Coca-Cola raided Pepsico's long-time partner in Venezuela, heating up the global cola war between the two American companies. In what analysts viewed as an embarrassment to Pepsi and a blow to the company's international expansion plans, Coca-Cola announced that it had formed a joint-venture company with the Cisneros Group, a Pepsi bottler for five decades. Pepsi, contending it had a contract with Cisneros until 2003, vowed to fight. $(35.$)    Crude Oil Price at 3-Month High   Crude oil rose to its highest price in almost three months -- $22.60 a barrel for September delivery, up 70 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange -- reflecting optimism that demand is robust enough and stockpiles lean enough to absorb the oil that Iraq is expected to start exporting next month. $(32.$)    Dollar Rises Against the Mark   The dollar rose to 1.4918 German marks, from 1.4854 marks on Thursday, bolstered by growing speculation that the Bundesbank will reduce interest rates when its policy council meets on Thursday. $(32.$)    Indians Raising Capital Abroad   Government institutions like the State Bank of India, under increasing pressure from India's leftist parties to halt sales of public-sector companies to foreign investors, are finding novel ways to raise capital abroad while sidestepping criticism. $(34.$)

headline: Correction
abstract: An article last Sunday about General Motors' lineup of new cars misstated the relative size of the G.M. work force and that of the United States Postal Service. G.M.'s work force of more than 700,000 employees is slightly smaller than that of the Postal Service, not twice as big.

headline: Jardine Fleming To Pay Fine
abstract: Jardine Fleming Group Ltd and its London parent say that they will pay $20.3 million in fines and restitution after Jardine's star manager, Colin Armstrong, was caught cheating clients by pocketing trading profits; firm, which is jointly owned by Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd and Robert Fleming & Co, says investigation by British and Hong Kong regulators has found that three clients were cheated by Armstrong, and total of 19 clients may have been misled about commissions (S)

headline: DANA TO ACQUIRE SPX'S PISTON RING UNIT FOR $235 MILLION
abstract: Dana Corp agrees to acquire piston ring and cylinder liner business of SPX Corp for $235 million in transaction that would eliminate Dana's biggest competitor in those businesses (S)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY

headline: U.S. to Tell Serbs They Face New Sanctions
abstract: Richard C. Holbrooke, the special American envoy to the Balkans, plans to tell President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia on Wednesday that economic sanctions will be reimposed on Serbia unless the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, is both removed from power and leaves Bosnia, two senior Western officials said.         Mr. Holbrooke made this stance clear today in meetings with top Bosnian Government officials and senior international civilian and military officials, said two officials familiar with the meetings.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: MONDAY

headline: Mortgage Rates Down
abstract: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.14 percent this week, down from 8.29 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the lowest since May 30, when rates averaged 8.03 percent. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.94 percent, down from 5.98 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 7.67 percent this week, down from 7.82 percent a week earlier.

headline: Two Cubans Wouldn't Toe Line for Olympic Glory
abstract: For both Ramon Garbey and Joel Casamayor, the years of training, success and  intense political pressure, their frustrations and hopes, sports and personal identity, all came together a week ago in Guadalajara, Mexico.         As highly rated members of the Cuban Olympic boxing team, training in Mexico, they recalled that their coaches effectively presented them with a choice of either standing on a podium later this month at the Atlanta Games accepting what almost certainly would have been silver or gold medals, or languishing in shame  back in Cuba, removed from the team, for their refusal to join or support the Communist Party.

headline: U.S. TO HELP FREE REFUGEES IN IRAQ
abstract: Clinton Administration says United States will help evacuate more than 2,000 Kurdish refugees who worked with US military and relief operations in northern Iraq and grant many of them asylum; US plans to coordinate convoy of trucks, buses and cars to transport refugees across border to Turkey, with the assent of Kurdistan Democratic Party, Kurdish faction now allied with Pres Saddam Hussein; refugees have been stranded in northern city of Zakho since Iraq sent its troops into Kurdish enclave on Aug 31; evacuation plan seen as further evidence that Washington's effort to provide protection and relief for Kurds in northern Iraq has collapsed, and that Hussein has now reasserted control over much of enclave; photo (M)

headline: Oil Soars as Report Says Group In Iran May Have Crash Role
abstract: Crude oil prices jump on New York Mercantile Exchange after report by Congressional group suggests terrorists in Iran might have been behind bombing of TWA jet, raising possibility of sanctions against one of world's largest producers; natural gas and corn prices rise on other markets (M)

headline: Multi-Ethnic Bosnians Share Lunch and Scorn for Politics
abstract: In a gravel parking lot in this serene mountain village, the license plates alone told a story today. On a red Opel, the plate bore the red-and-white checkerboard Croatian shield. A blue Yugo had the blue-and-yellow shield of Bosnia and Herzegovina. On a white Mercedes, the letters on the license plate were Cyrillic, evidence that the car was from Bosnian Serb territory.         The people in the cars were old friends and relatives by marriage -- Croats,  Muslims and Serbs -- who gathered here on the Serbian side of the border between the Bosnian Serbs' Republika Srpska and the rest of Bosnia.

headline: For a Struggling Sunbeam, Shock Therapy
abstract: Profile of Albert J Dunlap, 59-year-old takeover specialist who vows to do for Sunbeam Corp what he did for Scott Paper; interview; photos; graph of company finances; chronology of Dunlap's first days as chief executive, as he assembles key aides; skeptics question whether Dunlap knows small-appliance and houseware business, and speculate that he may be dressing up company for quick sale(M)

headline: An Increase in Wages May Hurt Some Teen-Agers
abstract: At one time, Sidewinder Pumps Inc., in Lafayette, La., would hire a dozen or  more young people to work each summer at minimum-wage jobs like weeding or expanding the parking lot -- tasks that were not really essential to the company but that let it give teen-agers a taste of what paid work is like.         When the Federal minimum wage went up in the early 1990's, the company cut back to three or four summer workers. And this year, the prospect of another increase led the company to end this quarter-century tradition. "We don't have any part-timers," said Ernie George, a co-owner of Sidewinder.

headline: Investor Gets Stake In Coca-Cola Amatil
abstract: Robert Kuok Hock Nien, Malaysian investor, acquires 9.3 percent stake in Coca-Cola Amatil Ltd, Australia, for $520 million (US) (S)

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Peace Talks Resume In Ulster, but in Anger
abstract: After a week of riots, Northern Ireland's politicians returned to peace talks today but spent the day denouncing one another.         As each side challenged the other's right to be at the negotiating table, the British said it was a sign of success that no one walked out.

headline: Air France Merger Wins Some Support
abstract: Representatives of workers at Air France today backed a plan by the airline's chairman, Christian Blanc, to merge the company with its domestic unit, Air France Europe, one day after a widespread strike.         The central works council, the highest representative body of employees of the Government-owned airline, said it had decided by 11 votes to 1, with 3 abstentions, to back the merger.

headline: Sale of BDDP Is Reported Close
abstract: BDDP Worldwide in Paris, world's 15th-largest agency company, is likely to be sold soon to investment group led by top managers (S)

headline: Magellan Fund Says Assets Fell $3.5 Billion in July
abstract: Fidelity reports assets of its Fidelity Magellan mutual fund fell $3.5 billion in July, to $51 billion on July 31, as result of stock market losses and shareholder redemptions; says new fund manager, Robert E Stansky, increased fund's equity holdings to 79 percent on June 30 from 72 percent on May 31 (M)

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;AMERICAN INT'L GROUP INC. (AIG,N)
abstract: The American International Group, the insurance company, said yesterday that  its second-quarter earnings rose 14 percent.         An $11.8 million gain from investment sales resulted in net income of $724.4  million, or $1.53 a share. A year earlier, a $9.4 million gain from investment sales resulted in net income of $633.8 million, or $1.34.

headline: OSHKOSH TRUCK TO BUY PIERCE MANUFACTURING
abstract: Oshkosh Truck Corp to buy Pierce Manufacturing Inc, privately owned maker of fire trucks, for $158 million (S)

headline: World News Briefs;Accused U.S. Sailor Turned Over to Japanese
abstract: The United States turned over a sailor alleged to have attacked a Japanese woman to the Japanese police today, opening a new legal era for American forces  in Japan.         It was the first time the American military has handed over a serviceman suspected of a crime before indictment. The action was taken under an agreement  made in October after the rape of a schoolgirl in Okinawa, for which three American servicemen were convicted by a Japanese court. The case brought protests against the American military presence, leading to the agreement.

headline: Despite increased security at airports, there have been surprisingly few long lines or delays.
abstract: Roundup of business travel news; increased airport security in wake of Trans World Airlines crash has led to few long lines or delays; Panama has reached accord to spend $50 million on infrastructure for $300 million resort complex United Enterprise Trust Group plans to build at Fort Amador, United States Army base that is being phased out (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Coastal Physician Group Inc hires Smith Barney Inc to advise it on sale of firm (S)

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Crude Oil Prices Soar on Signs Of Threat to U.N.-Iraqi Plan
abstract: Crude oil prices jumped on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday on signs that a United Nations plan allowing Iraq to sell a limited amount of oil was in danger.         On other markets, corn prices also rose.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BOEING IS PLANNING AN EMPLOYEE STOCK FUND
abstract: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it was establishing an unusual $1 billion stock fund for its 108,000 employees that could lead to big bonuses for  workers in the next decade. Under the plan, Boeing would establish an investment trust fund of 11.3 million shares of its stock, about 7.8 million of which would be purchased on the open market in the next few months. Returns over an average  3 percent a year, including appreciation and reinvested dividends, would be distributed to employees every two years beginning in 1998. An average annual total stock return of 15 percent would result in a pre-tax distribution of $1,150 in stock for each worker in 1998 and an additional $2,750 in 2000, according to figures provided by the company.

headline: Nanny's Dismissal Creates Uproar in Israel
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has created quite a splash as Israel's first "American style" leader, with his catchy sound-bites, the echoes of John F. Kennedy in his speeches, the First Lady ever at his side and the publicized strolls with his small sons. But his American models might have warned him that  the style has a price, which often comes with the suffix "-gate."         Mr. Netanyahu's present predicament, already dubbed "Nannygate" in the Israeli press, is not quite in the same league as Whitewater, and light years from Watergate. The story is simple: he dismissed his children's nanny after she burned the soup.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Marketers Choose Different Agencies
abstract: Two consumer marketers are changing agencies.         The First Union National Bank Corporation named Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco to handle its account, which had been at the William Cook Agency in Jacksonville, Fla., for nine years. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

headline: New Rebel Group Is Suspected in Ambush of Mexican Army Truck by Armed Gunmen
abstract: Attackers wielding AK-47 assault rifles ambushed a Mexican Army truck along a mountain road in Guerrero state on Tuesday evening, killing one civilian who drove into the gunfire and leaving one soldier and another civilian wounded.         No group took immediate responsibility for the attack here. But at about the  same time on Tuesday, east of the ambush site in this southwest state, men wearing military uniforms and carrying AK-47 rifles distributed a manifesto signed by a guerrilla group, the Popular Revolutionary Army, known by the Spanish acronym E.P.R. The group first appeared last month.

headline: U.S. Urges Israel to Yield And Close Tunnel Entrance
abstract: US urges Israel to close, at least temporarily, new entrance to archeological tunnel in Jerusalem to try to quell Palestinian violence; Clinton Administration calls on both sides to avoid raising new issues, like the tunnel; Sec Warren Christopher agrees with British Min Malcolm Rifkind that violence is symptom of deep deterioration in peace process (S)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 3/   They used to be called mere stationers. Now they're office-supply giants, and their multiples reflect that newly-earned respect. By Virginia Munger Kahn.    INVESTING IT /Page 3/   Higher interest rates are a real possibility after a Federal Reserve panel meets on Tuesday. That, or the markets are in for some bumps before November. By Jonathan Fuerbringer.    EARNING IT /Page 11/   More companies are offering employees the chance to take sabbaticals to do volunteer work. By Marcia Vickers.    VOICES /Page 13/   Bob Dole wants a smaller Internal Revenue Service, but should we? by Herbert Barchoff.

headline: As Israel Tilts To the Right, Envoy to U.S. Makes an Exit
abstract: Itamar Rabinovich resigns as Israel's Ambassador to United States, post he has held for four years, so that Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu can pick his own person to fill that important post; Rabinovich was ardent supporter of Israel's Labor Party Government in its attempts to find peace with Palestinians and Syria; Netanyahu chooses Eliahu Ben-Elissar to replace Rabinovich (M)

headline: Mercedes-Benz Reports 10% Rise in Car Sales
abstract: Mercedes-Benz AG says its car sales rose 10 percent in first eight months of 1996, as company introduced its new passenger mini-van; car sales reached 423,000 units in January through August (S)

headline: Ulster Protestants in Anti-Police Protests
abstract: Thousands of angry Protestants continued anti-police demonstrations today, some of them violent, across this predominantly Protestant British province for  the second straight day.         The protests and sporadic violence have weakened an already sputtering peace  effort. Formal talks in Belfast, the provincial capital, have been devoted mostly to procedural haggling in their first month.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Some Good News Is Seen For Cigarette Stocks   Wall Street analysts expect tobacco stocks to rise in response to a jury's ruling late Friday that the industry was not responsible for the cancer death of an Indianapolis lawyer.    Still, the verdict gives new attention to the wild card of the individual lawsuit in influencing the future value of tobacco shares. The stocks have been dropping since a similar suit in Florida went against the industry on Aug. 9. Market Place. $(Page D3.$)     Lloyd's Seeks a Reversal   Executives at Lloyd's of London worked through the weekend trying to overcome the latest obstacle to efforts to resolve the organization's financial crisis. A plan to split off billions of dollars in debt and liabilities was thrown into turmoil last week when a Federal judge extended the deadline for American investors to join in the plan. Lloyd's plans to argue for a quick reversal of the ruling. $(D2.$)    Tracking the Political Winds   ABC News used an electronic system to track, second by second, the responses of a group of uncommitted voters to speeches at the Republican National Convention. Though ABC will not use the system at the Democratic convention, which begins tonight, it will track opinions using focus groups. $(D5.$)    The Democrats have converged on Chicago, and so, it seems, have World Wide Web entrepreneurs. Sites provide everything from convention history to practical information about the city. Taking In the Sites. $(D4.$)    Making Machines, And Users, Smile   Macintosh owners may consider themselves to be iconoclasts, but they do rely on icons, those that give the computers a user-friendly face. Susan Kare, who designed the Mac icons, is busier than ever, but with other work. The growth of the World Wide Web has put a new premium on graphics like hers. $(D5.$)    How Best to Use the Web?   The rush to carve the Internet into multimedia fiefs by companies like Netscape and Microsoft is siphoning energy from what should be the goal: to help users and developers exploit the special interactive qualities of the World Wide Web.  Denise Caruso: Digital Commerce. $(D5.$)     Criticism of Programming Deals   As mergers have reshaped communications, companies are flexing their programming muscles by putting shows they produce on cable services they own. Critics at outside companies say they are sometimes being shut out of the bidding. Broadcasting. $(D7.$)    Tourism Rebounds in California   After several years of battering by earthquakes, riots and recession, California is in the midst of a tourist boom. Hotels, amusement parks and attractions are racking up record numbers of visitors. $(A7.$)    Labor Bounces Back   Only two years after a descent into near irrelevance, organized labor is experiencing a resurgence in Democratic politics -- driven by aggressive new leadership and fear of the Republican legislative agenda. $(A9.$)    Special Effects Bulk Up   Movie magicians have taught pigs to talk and roaches to sing. Now they are developing more efficient ways to model the bodies and movements of human beings. One new approach was used in the movie ''The Island of Dr. Moreau.'' $(D7.$)    Minute Maid Account Is Moved   The advertising account for Coca-Cola's Minute Maid line of juices has been shifted from Lowe & Partners/SMS to Leo Burnett. But, except for a slip-up in an unrelated news release, the move would not have been disclosed. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. $(D6.$)

headline: A Cry for Japan's Lost Isles: Is the Sea Listening?
abstract: Nearly 10,000 elderly Japanese in Nemuro and nearby towns want to return to Northern Territories, but islands remain one of unsolved legacies of World War II and main reason why Russia and Japan have still not been able to sign peace treaty; map; photo (M)

headline: Stratton Oakmont's drama with an initial public offering.
abstract: E-Net Inc discussed as example of Stratton Oakmont Inc's success in circumventing regulators, who charge it is boiler-room operation that rigs market for its offerings; E-Net, denied listing on Nasdaq's small-cap market, is instead being acquired by listed MVSI Inc, another Stratton client (M)

headline: Target Chain, Citing Costs, to Stop Selling Cigarettes
abstract: Target chain, nation's third-largest discount retailer, says it will stop selling cigarettes because it costs too much to keep them out of hands of minors; other retailers are also concerned about growing burden of new state and Federal regulations intended to curb teen-age smoking; two largest discount chains, Wal-Mart Stores and Kmart, say they will continue to sell cigarettes; drugstore chains are are most likely to follow Target's lead, so they can position themselves as health care providers (M)

headline: Boeing Receives Jet Order for $1.18 Billion
abstract: Boeing Co says that Philippine Airlines Inc ordered seven of its 747-400 jetliners valued at $1.18 billion (S)

headline: The Nanny Track: A Once-Simple World Grown Complicated
abstract: Problems of financial arrangements, trust and relationships between nannies and their employers, often two-income working couples, discussed; photo (M)

headline: Consumers Get the Credit for Expanding Economy
abstract: President Clinton claims the credit for himself, and analysts cite an array of other possible factors, but the most important source of the economy's remarkable resilience and vibrancy this year appears to be the consumer.         For most of this year, Americans have spent prodigiously on homes, cars, refrigerators and dinners out, carrying forward an aging economic expansion that as recently as January seemed in danger of expiring. In the process, they have largely ignored warning signs that they are becoming overextended.

headline: U.N. Asks Intervention Force As Burundi Nears a Collapse
abstract: Fearing that Burundi is on the verge of a political collapse, the United Nations is assembling an intervention force that could be used to prevent the country's ethnic Tutsi and Hutu from beginning a genocidal civil war, the head of peacekeeping operations said today.         But Kofi Annan, the Under Secretary General for peacekeeping missions, said that country after country has stalled at committing troops to the force, and there was a danger of repeating what happened when massacres began to consume neighboring Rwanda in 1994 and the Security Council, led by the United States, took weeks to react.

headline: Iraqi Troops Said to Round Up Kurd Leaders
abstract: International relief workers who fled Iraq say army, which captured city of Erbil in northern exclusion zone, conducted house-to-house searches for Kurdish leaders regarded as enemies and killed hundreds of people; military action comes amid rising tensions between two Kurdish factions, and was aimed at crushing Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, which is supported by Iran; reflects bitter conflict between Iraq and Iran since both countries fought war in 1980's (M)

headline: G.M. Sales Decline, but Chrysler's Surge
abstract: General Motors Corp sales fell by 2.3 percent in July from year earlier while Chrysler Corp's sales surged 18.8 percent, reflecting shift in demand toward mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks instead of cars; sales fell sharply for Honda, Nissan, Isuzu and Mitsubishi while rising for Volvo and Toyota and staying flat at Suzuki; Ford Motor Co is expected to announce overall sales down as much as 3 percent from year ago (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Latex Resources Inc agrees to acquire control of Alliance Resources PLC of London in $26 million stock swap; Latex would have 72 percent interest in the combined company; Medlogic Global Corp receives major investment from Travelers Insurance Co, unit of Travelers Group, in exchange for stake in the company; further details are not disclosed (S)

headline: Software Company Formed
abstract: Intel, Warner Music and Softbank, the Japanese publishing company, plan to announce on Monday the formation of the Palace, a company that will provide software for graphical, Internet-based "chat" systems.          The service will market and distribute the software originally developed by  Time Warner, the parent company of the Warner Music Group. The Intel Corporation has been cooperating to develop future versions of the technology, which now allows computer users to interact in "virtual" rooms while representing themselves with two-dimensional images.

headline: Bosnian Serbs Celebrate Srebrenica
abstract: Most of the world regards it as the date on which the worst war crime began in a war covered in crimes, but Bosnian Serb leaders have given it a new name: Liberation Day. And today, many of Srebrenica's new Serbian residents celebrated the anniversary of the capture of the town from Muslims one year ago.         There was no mention here of international investigators' estimates that after the town was taken as many as 8,000 men and boys were hunted down, captured and killed by Bosnian Serb soldiers. Most Serbs here appear to be convinced that such talk is nothing but lies.

headline: WOOLWORTH CORP. (Z,N)
abstract: Woolworth Corp earned $22 million in second quarter, compared with loss of $11 million in year-earlier quarter; sales fell 3.4 percent; chart (S)

headline: LEADERS OF ISRAEL AND PALESTINIANS DUE IN WASHINGTON
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, after intensive diplomatic efforts by US, agree to go to Washington to seek ways out of confrontation that has put entire Israeli-Palestinian peace in jeopardy; Pres Clinton will act as host to meetings, scheduled to begin on Oct 1 with US officials conferring separately with Israelis and Palestinians; Clinton says King Hussein of Jordan will attend; Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak has delayed announcing whether he will participate; photos (M)

headline: Another Sign Of Strength At Factories
abstract: National Association of Purchasing Management reports factory activity expanded in Aug, with its index rising 2.4 points to 52.6; rise, though smaller than feared, further undermines hopes that economic growth rate will moderate enough to persuade Federal Reserve not to raise interest rates; Conference Board reports index of leading indicators rose 0.2 percent, July; table; graph (M)

headline: Surprise Surge in Home Sales: Leap of 7.5%
abstract: Confounding analysts, builders sold new houses in May at the fastest pace in  more than 10 years as buyers appeared remarkably indifferent to rising interest  rates, Government figures showed today.         Word of the surprising 7.5 percent monthly advance came a few hours before the Federal Reserve Open Market Committee began a two-day policy meeting that analysts had already believed would involve a close call as to whether to raise  short-term interest rates.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daimler Announces Fewer Job Cuts at Airbus
abstract: Daimler-Benz Aerospace A.G. of Germany, a subsidiary of Daimler-Benz A.G., said yesterday that it would cut 3,300 jobs at its Airbus unit, a smaller total  than it had announced earlier.

headline: Infighting Hobbles Group Opposed to Iraqi
abstract: Even though Kurdish fighters controlled by Massoud Barzani battled alongside army of Saddam Hussein, dictator whom all opponents of Iraqi Government have vowed to topple, Barzani has not been formally removed from his seat on three-member presidential council of main opposition organization, Iraqi National Congress (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;STANLEY WORKS SELLING NONSTRATEGIC OPERATIONS
abstract: Stanley Works Inc., which has been reorganizing its operations in the last year, said yesterday that it had begun to sell certain nonstrategic segments. Among the segments being sold are the United States manufactured paint applicator, mail-order safety products and drywall-tape products businesses. The businesses had combined revenue of less than $200 million in 1995, a fraction of Stanley's $2.6 billion in annual revenue. The company, a tool maker based in New Britain, Conn., said additional costs to continue reorganizing its remaining businesses would lower earnings by an undetermined amount in the third quarter.  Shares of Stanley Works rose $1.75, to $28.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: A New Look For Chinese Capitalism
abstract: Artist's rendering of new skyscraper going up in Shanghai; it is second of three towers in emerging financial center in Shanghai, and will be tallest skyscraper in world when completed (S)

headline: How 1996 Is Like 1987, and How It Isn't
abstract: If investors were holding their breath yesterday, it was with good reason.         As the historically minded -- or superstitious -- might recall, in 1929 the stock market peaked and then, 55 days later, crashed. In 1987, the stock market  peaked and then, 55 days later, crashed. And in 1996, the stock market peaked and then, 55 days later . . .

headline: Debt and Executive Turmoil Keep Danskin Hobbling
abstract: Danskin Inc, 114-year-old company that once had women's athletic-apparel market virtually to itself, has fallen on hard times; sales have slumped 7 percent over three years to $125 million, and company is so hobbled by $40 million in long-term debt that it can barely afford to advertise; company's stock has been moved to Nasdaq's less prestigious Small Cap Market after three years in which company's losses exceeded its book value; some insiders wonder if company can survive; Danskin's desperate condition illustrates how excesses of 1980's takeover binge, combined with self-aggrandizing management, can sap strength of even strongest brand names; photos; charts; graphs (L)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Mercedes-Benz Reports Big Half-Year Demand
abstract: Mercedes-Benz A.G. said yesterday that its worldwide car deliveries climbed 7.2 percent in the first six months of the year, making the period the best half-year in the company's history. Mercedes, the auto-making arm of Daimler-Benz A.G., said it had shipped 315,000 cars and expected to deliver more than 600,000 cars for the year.          Delivery growth was strongest in Japan, climbing 52 percent, from 20,400. Deliveries in Germany, home market of Mercedes, climbed 15 percent, to 133,000. In the United States, the world's largest car market, deliveries climbed 14.6 percent, to 42,052. The company attributed the strong growth to demand for its new E-Class model.   (Reuters)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: Peter J. Quigley was named to the new position of marketing director at Parade Publications, New York, a unit of Advance Publications. He had been director for sales and marketing at 3M Media Networks, Stamford, Conn. a unit of Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co.

headline: Dire Details Plague a Grand Olympics
abstract: ATLANTA—  In one day the Centennial Olympics established a trend that will be difficult to undo. The Atlanta organizers were getting the big things right, wonderfully right, and the little things disastrously wrong.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Quarterly Profits Slip At British Telecom
abstract: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit slipped in the latest quarter as staff-cutting costs more than doubled and profits tightened in the cellular telephone business. Pretax profit in the quarter that ended on June 30 was L869 million ($1.34 billion), down from L874 million a year earlier. Sales were L3.64 billion, up from L3.5 billion.          The company said the cost of cutting its payroll was L52 million in the quarter, up from L22 million a year ago.   (AP)

headline: Bosnia's a Safe and Healthy Place, for the G.I.'s Anyway
abstract: Although a fear of American casualties has driven Washington's policy about military involvement in Bosnia, Army statistics show that the troops stationed in Bosnia have so far been safer, healthier and less likely to be killed than soldiers in the Army as a whole.         Among the 18,500 soldiers assigned to the Army task force in Bosnia, there have been only three deaths from the beginning of the year through late June, one-third the rate last year among soldiers throughout the Army. In Bosnia, one  soldier was killed by a mine, one by a kitchen fire and one when his truck ran off a narrow bridge.

headline: Bond Prices Little Changed Ahead of Fed Policy Session
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities are narrowly higher as dealers and traders adjust their positions ahead of Federal Reserve's upcoming meeting on interest rates; 30-year Treasury gains 1/32, to 96 13/32, to yield 7.04 percent, unchanged from Thursday (M)

headline: AT&T turns to its core agencies in awarding additional responsibilities.
abstract: AT&T Corp, after lengthy review of its corporate brand account, awards key added responsibilities to two of its four roster agencies, Young & Rubicam Inc and FCB/Leber Katz Partners (M)

headline: J. Michaels Sets A Distribution
abstract: J. Michaels Inc., a furniture retailer that plans to liquidate its assets and merge with Muriel Siebert Capital Markets Inc., a discount stock brokerage firm, expects to distribute at least $15.6 million, or $17 a share, in liquidation proceeds to shareholders.

headline: MATTEL SELECTS ITS NEXT CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: Mattel Inc says its president and chief operating officer Jill E Barad will succeed John W Amerman as chief executive, effective Jan 1; Amerman, who will be 65 next year, remains chairman (S)

headline: FACTION OF KURDS SUPPORTED BY IRAQ TAKES RIVAL'S CITY
abstract: Kurdish faction allied with Iraqi Government captures Sulaimaniya, city in northern Iraq, after it is virtually abandoned by defenders and residents; thousands of refugees flee, many to Iran; victory leaves forces of Kurdistan Democratic Party in control of all big cities in Iraq's Kurdish region; photo; map (M)

headline: Anger at Turkey Intensifies After 8 Die in Prison Fasts
abstract: Facing its first serious crisis only weeks after taking office, the Islamic-led Government came under growing pressure today to reform prison conditions after an eighth leftist hunger striker died in jail and radical Kurds said they were joining the 68-day-old "death fast."         Germany, Italy and the European Union urged Turkey to move quickly to ease the tensions in its overcrowded prisons.

headline: Another accepted truth under fire: electric cars = cleaner air.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column explores contention by Lester Lave, economist, that case for electric cars is deeply flawed; Lave contends that substituting 500,000 electric cars for same number of new gasoline-powered ones in Los Angeles or New York would not lower peak levels of ozone appreciably, and that electric cars are themselves environmentally suspect; says this ilustrates how attacking one pollution problem can worsen another; drawing (M)

headline: ADOBE SYSTEMS INC. (ADBE, NNM)
abstract: Adobe Systems Inc reports lower third-quarter earnings; net income fell to $29.8 million, and revenue fell 1 percent, to $180.9 million (S)

headline: Youth Isn't Eternal
abstract: Miriam Biddelman letter comments on July 21 article on problems that can beset menopausal and pre-menopausal women in workplaceú

headline: Pancho Villa's Wife, 100
abstract: Soledad Seanez Holguin, the widow of the Mexican revolutionary hero Pancho Villa, died here today. She was 100.         She died of respiratory failure after being hospitalized since Monday.

headline: More Movies for Turner
abstract: Turner Broadcasting System Inc says its Turner Classic Movies channel on cable television has acquired exclusive rights to show It Happened One Night and 35 other films owned by Columbia Pictures unit of Sony Corp (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Olivetti Picks Sole Successor To 2 Chiefs
abstract: Olivetti S.p.A. named a new chief executive today as Carlo De Benedetti, head of the company since 1978, stepped down, as expected.         Francesco Caio, the 38-year-old chief executive of Olivetti's telecommunications unit, Omnitel-Pronto Italia S.p.A., was named sole chief executive, replacing the two co-chief executives, Mr. De Benedetti and Corrado Passera, who resigned last week.

headline: OSI HOLDINGS TO ACQUIRE PAYCO AMERICAN
abstract: Payco American Corp agrees to be bought by closely held OSI Holdings Corp for about $150 million in cash and debt (S)

headline: Japan's Factory Output Dropped 4.3% in June
abstract: Japan's International Trade and Industry Ministry says Japan's industrial production fell 4.3 percent in June from previous month, in second-steepest decline this decade (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ROYAL AHOLD GROCERY CHAIN TO REALIGN SOME STORES
abstract: Royal Ahold N.V., the Dutch grocery chain that owns the Edwards and Giant chains in the United States and recently bought Stop and Shop, said yesterday that it would realign some of its stores from one chain to another to give them  more distinct geographical presences. Thirty-five Edwards stores will be turned  over to Stop and Shop to eliminate much of their overlap in the Northeast. Stop  and Shop will then have 192 stores, mostly in New England and the northern suburbs of New York City. Edwards and Giant will be merged into one company but  will keep their store names. Edwards will take over the 16 Mel's supermarkets owned by Stop and Shop on Long Island. The merged Edwards and Giant will have 135 stores on the East Coast.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Intel Earnings Surpass Expectations of Analysts
abstract: Offering jittery technology investors a dose of confidence, the Intel Corporation, which makes the microprocessor chips that power most of the world's personal computers, reported stronger-than-expected second-quarter results today, surpassing most analysts' expectations by a wide margin.         The results, which were released after the stock market's close, came on a day of heavy trading and dizzying gyrations for many technology stocks, which have been leading a steep decline in the overall stock market recently. But by the market's close, the technology-laden Nasdaq Composite Index had come most of the way back from yesterday's plunge, and Intel's strong numbers could help calm technology investors going into today's trading.

headline: Stocks Plunge as Dow Loses 161 And Technology Rout Continues
abstract: All news was bad news yesterday in the stock market, where there was a sharp  drop in the shares of every sort of company, big and small, high technology and  low, consumer and industrial.         The carnage continued to be worst in the stocks of companies in the computer  industry, which have been falling sharply for a week. The Nasdaq composite index, which includes many of these high-technology stocks, suffered its worst drop in five years, falling 3.9 percent. That, on top of the previous declines,  wiped out the double-digit gains the index scored in the first six months of the year and left it just eight-tenths of 1 percent higher than it was at the beginning of 1996.

headline: Atlanta Rates Only a Silver Medal for Its Games
abstract: ATLANTA—  There was a segment in the closing ceremony that symbolized the enormous strain Atlanta has been under for the past six years, since it was first awarded the Centennial Olympics. It was frantic and fragmented, there were fireworks, a woman in tinsel screaming operatically, bicyclists with sparklers coming out of their bicycles, skateboarders and rollerbladers and more cyclists riding up and down extreme ramps.

headline: Natural Gas Pipeline Planned Off Louisiana
abstract: The Marathon Oil Company, the Shell Oil Company and Leviathan Gas Pipeline Partners L.P. said today that they planned to build a $220 million natural gas pipeline system to serve growing production areas in the central Gulf of Mexico.         The system, in the gulf's Green Canyon area, consists of a new interstate gas pipeline and expansion of an existing natural gas gathering system linking numerous fields.

headline: James Gulliver, Chairman Of Food Group, Dies at 66
abstract: James Gerald Gulliver, son of grocer who rose to become chairman of Argyll Group, one of Britain's largest food retailing businesses, dies at age of 66; photo (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Germany's Telecom Law Approved by Parliament
abstract: Germany's Parliament gave final approval yesterday to a law that would open the nation's telecommunications industry to competition by 1998. The law would regulate Germany's telecommunications after competition begins and allow for the initial public stock offering of the state-owned Deutsche Telekom, which the company said would occur in November.          The law allows private companies to begin offering some services, like data  transmission, this year. The monopoly on basic telephone service will be lifted by the end of 1997 to meet the Jan. 1, 1998, deadline for the liberalization of European telecommunications markets.   (AP)

headline: Pennzoil Picks GGT Group Unit
abstract: Pennzoil Products Co says it has named GSD&M to handle its account; billings estimated at $40 million (S)

headline: A Ford Is Seen As Candidate For Chairman Of Auto Maker
abstract: Ford Motor Co's board of directors decides that Alexander J Trotman, chairman and chief executive. will remain for at least year after he turns 65 in July 1998; reportedly is discussing whether William Clay Ford Jr, great-grandson of Henry Ford, should become chairman or whether to tap Jacques A Nasser, group vice president for vehicle development, to become both chairman and chief executive (M)

headline: A WILD DAY ON WALL STREET: THE MARKET;Stocks on Roller Coaster, But Finish Little Changed
abstract: The stock market rode out the busiest day in its 204-year history yesterday,  and the wildest day since the 1987 market plunge, to end basically unchanged.         As the closing bell sounded at 4 P.M., the Dow Jones industrial average reported a gain of 9.25 points -- that is less than two-tenths of 1 percent -- to close at 5,358.76. This came after stocks dropped sharply on Monday, scaring  investors and causing the market to open uneasily yesterday on fears that the plunge would snowball.

headline: Who Keeps the Burmese in Step? Ask the Generals
abstract: Burmese military, which sees itself as historical backbone and only hope for future of nation, is displaying its all-pervasive power and influence over all aspects of country's economic life in new Defense Services Museum in Yangon, which was constructed three years ago at cost of $9 million; photo (M)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;U S West Unit In Media Deal
abstract: U S West Media Group Inc. has acquired a 10 percent equity interest in Preview Media Inc. for between $5 million and $10 million.         Preview Media derives about 85 percent of revenue producing and syndicating shows for the Travel Channel and the Weather Channel. It recently embarked on a  campaign to become a full-service on-line travel agency, booking airline tickets on the Internet.

headline: Taking In the Sites;Fourth of July Celebrations Go on the Net
abstract: By the time America turns 220 years old on Thursday, you may have had your fill of patriotism, politics and maybe even apple pie. The World Wide Web, however, is bursting out with flags, history and firecrackers.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
