abstract: Debt    * Aristar Inc., Tampa, Fla., is selling $100 million of notes due in 1999 through Merrill Lynch & Co. The notes are priced at 99.983 to yield 6.751 percent. The issue is rated A3 by Moody's Investors Service, A- by Standard & Poor's and A by Duff & Phelps.    * Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., or Freddie Mac, is selling $50 million of debentures due in 2001 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. Callable in a year, the debentures carry an interest rate of 7.310 percent and are priced at par.    * Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, is selling $200 million of medium-term notes due in 2001 through Merrill Lynch. The noncallable notes carry an interest rate of 6.690 percent and are priced at par.    * Southwest Gas Corp., Las Vegas, Nev., is selling $150 million of debt in two parts through Merrill Lynch. The first part is $75 million of notes priced at 99.176 to yield 7.619 percent. The second part is $75 million of debentures priced at 99.682 to yield 8.028 percent. The issue is rated Baa3 by Moody's and BBB- by both S.& P. and Duff & Phelps.    * Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, is selling $200 million of medium-term notes due in 1997 through Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. The notes, which are callable quarterly beginning Aug. 15, 1997,  carry an interest rate of 6.10 percent and are priced at par.

headline: Tax Amnesty Would Help Pay For Dole's Economic Plan
abstract: Article by Gene Gavin, Commissioner of Connecticut Department of Revenue Services, says Federal tax amnesty program could generate $125 billion to $150 billion for the Treasury, enough to pay for Bob Dole's 15 percent across-the-board tax cut; cartoon (M)

headline: Stock Offering Delayed
abstract: Stage Stores Inc. said yesterday that it had postponed its planned $144 million initial public offering, citing a weaker market for new stocks. The Houston-based operator of small-town clothing stores had planned to sell 9.6 million shares at $14 to $16 this month, but it said current market conditions caused it to postpone the sale. Stage Stores manages 301 stores in the central United States under the names Stage, Bealls and Palais Royal.

headline: U.N. Chief Approves a New Plan To Allow Iraq to Start Selling Oil
abstract: Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali approved an amended Iraqi plan today  for distributing food and other relief supplies bought with proceeds from oil to be sold under an exemption to international sanctions.         The Secretary General's approval of the reworked plan, which the United States had criticized in its original form as being full of loopholes and evasions, removes a major hurdle to the signing of Iraqi oil contracts.

headline: Toll of Pilgrims in Kashmir Storm Put at 160
abstract: Indian officials say as many as 160 Hindu pilgrims and mountain guides died of cold and hunger in storm in Himalayan mountains of Kashmir; toll is likely to rise as rescue teams gain fuller picture of disaster; maps (M)

headline: U.S. Warns U.N. on Campaigning for Post
abstract: The Clinton Administration threatened today to take action against the United Nations and any employees found to be campaigning for the re-election of Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali at the organization's expense.         Stepping up an increasingly sharp drive worldwide to prevent Mr. Boutros-Ghali from building support for a second five-year term when the first ends on Dec. 31, the spokesman of the United States Mission said today that the  Administration is "very concerned that U.N. officials have seen it to be their business to be promoting the re-election of a particular Secretary General."

headline: Turner Purchase Said to Hit Hurdle at F.T.C.
abstract: Staff members at the Federal Trade Commission have rejected a proposal from Time Warner Inc., Turner Broadcasting System Inc. and Tele-Communications Inc. in which the first two, when merged, would spin off the Time Warner stock owned  by Tele-Communications into a new company, people close to the talks said yesterday.         The F.T.C. has been concerned about the power that John C. Malone, who controls TCI, would have as a result of the planned merger of Time Warner and Turner. TCI is the largest cable television operator in the nation, and Time Warner is the second largest. As a result of the merger, Liberty Media, a subsidiary of TCI, would own 9 percent of Time Warner. Liberty now owns 22 percent of Turner.

headline: COMAPNY REPORTS;3M Earnings Climbed 7.9% in 2d Quarter
abstract: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 7.9 percent, bolstered by strong sales in the United States and lower raw material costs.         The company earned $381 million, or 91 cents a share, in the quarter, up from $353 million, or 84 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

headline: Backlash of Intolerance Stirring Fear in Iran
abstract: Vehement intolerance reigns in Iran; fundamentalist authorities are cracking down in backlash against incremental loosening of clerical control over last few years in arenas of politics, education, the arts and social activities; castigation comes not only through official channels, but also in form of attacks by Partisans of the Party of God, shock troops devoted to most puritanical Government factions; Iran's economy is in terrible condition, its capital choked by air pollution, its Government infested with embezzlement scandals; but most vociferous debate is whether women should be permitted to ride bicycles; this is not first time ideological war has cropped up in Iran as Government seeks to distract attention from deepening economic problems; photo (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;'Suspicious' Trading At Escom Under Review
abstract: Germany's Securities Trading Supervisory Office said yesterday that it was investigating possible insider trading in shares of Escom A.G., the computer retailer that filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday. The office said it noticed a surge in the number of Escom shares traded and a plunge in the share price in the weeks preceding the company's announcement.          "The turnover seen was very suspicious in comparison with previous levels,"  Anke Reeh-Schild, a spokeswoman for the office, said. She said that in the three weeks before Escom's announcement, trading volume in its shares was eight  or nine times its previous levels. Escom, Europe's second-largest computer retailer, filed for protection from creditors after a new estimate put its 1995  losses at 180 million marks ($118.3 million), up from a March forecast of a loss of 125 million marks ($82.2 million).   (Reuters)

headline: Offerings Scheduled This Week For Equity and Convertible Debt
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:         Adeza Biomedical Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif., an initial public offering of 2.5  million shares. Prudential Securities.

headline: Even With Mortgage Brokers, Let the Borrower Beware
abstract: Advice on negotiating best mortgage deal with banks and finance companies; warns of little-known practice of mortgage brokers and bank loan officers of bumping up interest rates or points and pocketing the difference; lawsuit filed by Richmond homeowners Mary and Earl Ransom against broker who overcharged them on refinancing discussed; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Job Outlook Is Little Changed
abstract: Manpower Inc survey of 16,000 businesses finds 25 percent plan to increase work forces in fourth quarter, while 9 percent plan staff cuts; in corresponding period year earlier, 25 percent planned hiring increases and 10 percent planned cuts (S)

headline: Orthodox Jews Protest to Close Roadway
abstract: Some 150,000 ultra-Orthodox Jews demonstrated on a main street in Jerusalem today demanding that it be closed to traffic on the Jewish sabbath.         Police closed Bar Ilan Street, for weeks the scene of skirmishes between police and religious and secular Jews, and parts of several other main roadways to permit the protest.

headline: U.S.-Bound Kurds Glad to Leave Iraq
abstract: Kurdish employees of American Government agencies begin heading toward resettlement in US; first of more than 2,000 begin arriving in Turkey from Dohuk; American diplomat says refugees, with Turkey's help, will be transported swiftly to new homes in US; map (M)

headline: FEDERAL-MOGUL CHIEF EXECUTIVE RESIGNS
abstract: Federal-Mogul Corp announces resignation of chairman and chief executive, Dennis J Gormley; says its 1996 earnings from operations would exceed last year's but would not match analysts' expectations; Roderick M Hills will succeed Gormley as chairman, and Robert S Miller Jr will serve as acting chief executive (S)

headline: Case Completes Purchase
abstract: Case Corp completes its acquisition of Steyr Landmaschinentechnik GmbH (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MOBIL CORP., Fairfax, Va., said it would buy a 26 percent interest in a production-sharing contract that included the Natuna gas field of Indonesia. The oil company will work in partnership with Pertamina, Indonesia's state-owned petroleum company that has a 24 percent interest in the contract, and Esso S.A.F., a unit of the Exxon Corporation, with a 50 percent stake. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Deal Is Set To Buy Casino From Griffin
abstract: Sun International Hotels Ltd says it has agreed to acquire Griffin Gaming and Entertainment Inc for about $210 million in stock and to assume $127 million in debt; acquisiton would give Sun ownership of Resorts Casino Hotel in Atlantic City, as well as 10 undeveloped acres in Atlantic City (M)

headline: Flextech and BBC Discuss TV Venture
abstract: Flextech PLC, British television programmer, is in talks with British Broadcasting Corp about creating as many as six cable and satellite television channels (S)

headline: Bodies of Russian 'Slaves' Found in Chechnya
abstract: Authorities found the bodies of 10 Russian prisoners of war today who military officials say were used as slave laborers, then tortured and executed by Chechen rebels.         The bodies of four officers and six soldiers were found near Khatuni, in southeastern Chechnya, where Russian forces are attacking separatists seeking independence for Chechnya, Russian officials said.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Gasoline Jumps as Supplies Are Drawn to the West Coast
abstract: Gasoline prices jumped on the New York Mercantile Exchange Yesterday on indications that surging prices on the West Coast were drawing supply away from  East Coast markets.         On other markets, coffee and corn prices fell.

headline: Borland's Chief Quits, Sending The Software Stock Down 15%
abstract: Shares of Borland International fell nearly 15 percent yesterday after its chief executive resigned and the company forecast a larger-than-expected loss in its fiscal first quarter as a result of disappointing sales.         Shares of Borland, which writes computer languages and other software for programmers, dropped $1.375, to end Nasdaq trading at $7.875.

headline: Real Estate;The market for family-size apartments on the Upper East Side is surging. Well, maybe.
abstract: A "HOT property" is not necessarily one that is soaring in market value.         For the last year, Manhattan real estate agents have said that the large family-size apartments on the Upper East Side and in a few other desirable locations are the hottest properties in town, complete with bidding wars and escalating prices.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Fruitopia Changes Its Campaign Slogan
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company has changed the slogan for its Fruitopia line of beverages after a complaint from Saab Cars USA Inc., which uses a similar slogan.         The Leo Burnett Company in Chicago introduced a campaign for Fruitopia in the spring that carried the theme "Find your own Fruitopia." Soon, Saab Cars pointed out that it had been using as a slogan the phrase "Find your own road,"  which was created by the Angotti, Thomas, Hedge unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York.

headline: Association Selects Young Achievers
abstract: American Advertising Federation elects seven new members to its Hall of Achievement for executives 40 or younger; they are Scott Bedbury, David Carey, Tony Dieste, James L Harrington, Timothy Mapes, Linda Srere and David Verklin (S)

headline: Market Place;To some newspaper publishers, TV has never looked better.
abstract: NEWSPAPER companies' earnings in the three months from April through June, lifted by advertisements for Easter sales and summer travel promotions, are normally second only to those in the last quarter, when papers are thick with ads for holiday shopping. But this year, without the strong earnings of their broadcast divisions, some newspaper companies would have reported profits that were flat, at best.         Because of rigorous cost-cutting and despite continuing high newsprint costs, profits from newspapers have begun to recover for many publishers. Yet for some, television revenue was the primary engine behind rises in overall earnings.

headline: Bitter Burden on Sarajevo: Invalids of War
abstract: Wounded and paralyzed residents of Sarajevo are struggling to restore tradition of solidarity and pluralism that existed before conflict; say they are being treated as outcasts, left in institutions, or at home without help, as city adjusts to peace; 21-year-old Faruk Sabanovic, who was shot by sniper in '95 and is left a paraplegic, comments; photo (M)

headline: Ethical Furor Erupts in Britain: Should Embryos Be Destroyed?
abstract: Britain will destroy more than 3,000 frozen, unclaimed human embryos from fertility clinics in keeping with 1991 law that mandates five-year limit on their storage; decision has stirred horror and outrage among many and raised ethical and practical questions as well; although embryos have been destroyed before, move represents first time procedure has been required by law and carried out on such large scale; embryos are part of total of between 6,000 and 10,000 that were fertilized and frozen since 1991 but whose donors have failed to respond to inquiries about what they wished done with them; photo (M)

headline: For Canada's brash young mining companies, that pot of gold may depend on acquisitions.
abstract: Market Place column on Canada's junior mining stocks; says $800 million takeover by Barrick Gold Corp, North America's biggest gold producer, of Arequipa Resources, a tiny, four-year-old Vancouver company with potentially rich deposits in Peru, is spurring renewed interest; to many analysts, acquisitions are key to growth for Barrick and other top producers (L)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: TODAY   The Reform Party announces whether Ross Perot or Richard D. Lamm will be its nominee for President.     MONDAY   Harnischfeger Industries, a maker of power cranes and other heavy machinery, is expected to report earnings for the latest quarter.      Jim Guy Tucker, former Governor of Arkansas, and James McDougal, a former business partner of President Clinton, are to be sentenced for their convictions on Whitewater charges.     TUESDAY   The Commerce Department will report the merchandise trade account for June. May's deficit was $10.8 billion, but it is expected to narrow for June, to about $9.3 billion. Exports likely grew faster while imports slowed.      The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee meets to discuss interest-rate policy, but few analysts expect the committee to make any changes.       Dayton Hudson, Ann Taylor, Limited and other big retailers are expected to report earnings.      WEDNESDAY    The Treasury will report the Federal budget deficit for July. It is expected to be wider than the $13.6 billion deficit in July 1995 because of special factors, but is still on track to end the year substantially smaller than last year.     THURSDAY    The Labor Department releases its report on initial claims for state unemployment benefits for the latest week.      FRIDAY   The Commerce Department reports on new orders for durable goods for July. A decline of five-tenths of a percentage point is expected, after June's decline of six-tenths of a point. The June decline was concentrated in the aircraft sector.

headline: PC Supplier To Be Sold for $1.5 Billion
abstract: Softbank Corp announces it is acquiring Kingston Technology Corp for $1.5 billion; Kingston is world's largest supplier of add-on memory boards for PC's; deal moves Softbank into hardware manufacturing for first time; Kingston, owned jointly by founders John Tu and David Sun, had revenue of $1.3 billion in 1995, up from $800 million year before; Softbank will acquire 80 percent of Kingston for $425 million in newly issued Softbank stock and remainder in cash; Tu and Sun will own combined 4.9 percent of Softbank, largest stake except for Masayoshi Son, head of Softbank, whose stake is greater than 50 percent (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: Summary of major stories on inside pages of business section

headline: IOMEGA SET TO CHARGE CUSTOMERS FOR ASSISTANCE
abstract: Iomega Corp says that it will begin charging customers $15 to $20 for assistance over the phone, in response to flood of calls from customers seeking help installing and servicing its disk drives; says it will bill customers per incident, meaning that repeated calls about same problem would be billed as one call (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ROLLS-ROYCE P.L.C., London, said it had received an order worth more than $:60 million ($92 million), to provide jet engines to United Parcel Service of America Inc.    RE-CON BUILDING PRODUCTS INC., Mission, British Columbia, a producer of roofing products, said it had formed a joint venture with Temple-Inland Forest Products Corp. to build and operate a cement fiberboard plant in Texas. The companies will invest about $73 million to build the plant.    GOODYEAR TIRE AND RUBBER CO., Akron, Ohio, said it would lay off about 100 hourly employees at its Topeka, Kan., tire manufacturing plant because of declining sales of tires for large trucks and off-road earthmoving equipment.    ELECTRONIC ARTS INC., San Mateo, Calif., an electonic software company, acquired a minority stake in Firaxis Software Inc. of Hunts Valley, Md., a video game software publisher, for undisclosed terms.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Retail Sales Fell in June; Producer Prices Edge Up Retail sales fell in June, while producer prices rose modestly. The two Government reports eased some concerns about inflation and interest rates. Retail sales fell two-tenths of 1 percent, to $205.2 billion last month, as demand for everything from new cars to clothing waned after several months of strength. The Producer Price Index edged up two-tenths of 1 percent in June, after falling one-tenth of 1 percent in May. Energy costs fell last month, but those declines were offset by a rise in food prices. [Page 34.] Treasury prices rose after reports on producer prices and retail sales eased worries that the Federal Reserve would quickly raise interest rates. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 9/32 , to 879/32 . The bond's yield fell to 7.03 percent from 7.05 percent on Thursday. [44.]

headline: Greek Premier Emerges From Predecessor's Shadow
abstract: For months after he resigned as Prime Minister in January, Andreas Papandreou continued to haunt Greek politics, even from his sickbed. It was not until his death last month that his successor, Costas Simitis, finally stepped from under  the shadow of the man he had alternately challenged and revered.         Within days of Mr. Papandreou's state funeral, Mr. Simitis won the last political prize Mr. Papandreou had kept for himself, the leadership of the Panhellenic Socialist Party.

headline: G.M. June Sales Fell 1.2% As Strike Reduced Inventory
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said today that its sales slipped 1.2 percent  in June from their levels a year earlier as consumer confidence weakened and auto dealers ran short of some models.         Wall Street analysts said it was unclear whether G.M.'s lackluster sales results pointed to a broad slowing of the industry, but added that the results were consistent with an economy that seems to have cooled slightly in June from  its torrid pace in April and May. A number of Japanese and European auto makers  reported mixed sales results today, while the Chrysler Corporation said on Monday that its sales rose 1 percent from a strong showing in June 1995.

headline: Lebed Suspends Chechen Talks; Blames Kremlin
abstract: Russian national security adviser Aleksandr Lebed abruptly cancels important peace negotiations with Chechen rebels, accusing political enemies in Moscow of trying to prevent him from making compromises necessary to end war in Chechnya; many in Moscow object to what they regard as Lebed's quick capitulation to rebels, his willingness to withdraw troops and his nearly overt admission that Russia has lost war; others fear he will become likely successor to Pres Boris Yeltsin if he is given credit for ending conflict; photo; maps (M)

headline: Exporters Scramble To Find Their Niches : The World Vies to Feed Asia's Rich
abstract: HONG KONG—  On Wednesday once a month in Picton, New Zealand, 100 kilograms (220 pounds) of salmon, pulled from their watery pens that morning, are gutted, scaled, carved up and packed in ice and put on the next day's morning flight to Hong Kong.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;WALDEN RESIDENTIAL PROPERTIES ACQUIRES 5 COMPLEXES
abstract: Walden Residential Properties Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired five Texas apartment complexes, with a total of 1,290 garden apartments, for about $39.5 million. The company, based in Dallas, said it financed the acquisition through a preferred stock offering and credit. Walden Residential Properties is  a real estate investment trust that owns garden apartment communities serving middle-income residents.

headline: Trelleborg of Sweden Seeks Rubber Company
abstract: Trelleborg AB seeks to buy Horda AB for 276 million Swedish kronor ($41.8 million) (S)

headline: MANUFACTURED HOME FILES LAWSUIT TO BLOCK MERGER
abstract: Manufactured Home Communities Inc says it will file lawsuit to block proposed merger of Chateau Properties Inc and ROC Communities Inc; Chateau had earlier rejected takeover bid by Manufactured Home; lawsuit accuses Chateau and ROC of acting to protect interests of insiders at expense of common shareholders (S)

headline: G.M.'S SATURN DIVISION TO BUILD A LARGER CAR
abstract: General Motors Corp says its Saturn division will build midsize car at its Wilmington, Del, plant (S)

headline: Market Place;Despite Stocks' Bounce, Profits Remain a Worry
abstract: Never mind.         That, at first glance, is what the stock market seems to be saying now about  the severe case of the jitters it suffered early this week over the outlook for  corporate earnings. The disappointing results reported last week by Hewlett-Packard and Motorola, which had helped prompt investors to dump stocks, were overwhelmed by reports of strong profits from investor favorites like Merck & Company and the McDonald's Corporation.

headline: China's Ambitious President Wants Mao's Title: Chairman
abstract: China's Communist Party leaders meet in Beidaihe to map out fundamental leadership and political changes for the future, and Pres Jiang Zemin is reportedly pressing them to declare him Chairman Jiang, giving him the ultimate honorific title--which no one now holds--of supreme chief of a Communist Party he already heads; Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader, is about to turn 92 and is reportedly too infirm to take part in any leadership discussions or functions; there is contentious debate within leadership over whether there will be another Deng- or Mao-like dynasty at the top, this one built around Jiang, or whether there should be a Cabinet-style Government with broader participation by Parliament and greater reliance on rule of law; photos (M)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Copycat Radio Station Challenges a St. Louis Institution
abstract: For decades, KMOX-AM, St. Louis, has been a dominant radio station in the Midwest. Its 50,000-watt, clear-channel signal allows it to be heard in at least eight states; its ownership by CBS Radio gives it the programming power and financial muscle to rank first in the local market, first among the CBS stations, and, at times, first nationally, as measured by market share. With a longstanding tradition of community involvement, the station was a St. Louis institution.         Now the giant is being annoyed by a gnat.

headline: Review Finds More Deception In Trading at Bankers Trust
abstract: Attempts to take advantage of customers, by employees of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation were far more widespread than the bank had indicated earlier, according to the conclusions of an investigation released yesterday by  two independent lawyers.         Bankers Trust's "derivatives business was not well managed or controlled in certain important respects and certain individuals at B.T. -- concentrated principally on the N.Y. interest-rate desk and N.Y. corporates desk -- exploited these weaknesses for their own purposes," the report said.

headline: From Microsoft To Venture Firm
abstract: Russell Siegelman, the former head of the Microsoft Corporation's on-line service, will join the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers on  Sept. 1.         Mr. Siegelman, who helped to develop and introduce the Microsoft Network last year, will help Kleiner Perkins find investments in new Internet and software companies.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Escom Computer Seeks Creditor Protection
abstract: Escom Computer A.G. of Germany, Europe's second-largest computer retailer, filed yesterday for protection from its creditors.          Hounded by losses that it now estimates at about 180 million marks ($117.8 million) last year, Escom held a crisis meeting with shareholders and potential  new investors on Tuesday. But once it became clear that talks would not be fruitful, Escom's board decided to seek protection from creditors -- similar to  filing for Chapter 11 in the United States. After announcing earlier this week that it would shut 65 of its 235 stores in Britain, Escom said yesterday that it would close stores in Europe, divest itself of noncore businesses and shed 1,900 of its 4,400 employees.   (Reuters)

headline: Novo Nordisk Profit Is Better Than Forecast
abstract: Noivo Nordisk AS says that its pretax profit was better than expected, surging 19 percent in first half on increases in operating income and profit from investments; pretax profit was 1.23 billion kroner, or $214 million, compared with 1.03 billion kroner in period a year ago (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;INVESTOR GROUP CUTS MICRON TECHNOLOGY STAKE
abstract: A group that includes the Idaho investor J. R. Simplot has cut its stake in Micron Technology Inc. to 6.6 percent, according to documents released yesterday. In a recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said it had sold 4.2 million common shares of Micron, a memory chip maker  based in Boise, Idaho, on July 11 at prices ranging from $20.38 to $24 a share.  The group now holds about 13.9 million shares. A company of Mr. Simplot, a billionaire potato tycoon, separately owned a 12.7 percent stake in Micron Technology at last filing.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Stone of Scone to Return To Scots After 700 Years
abstract: The Stone of Scone, the ancient coronation seat of the kings of Scotland, is  going home, 700 years after it was carried away to London by King Edward I, Prime Minister John Major announced today.         Mr. Major told the House of Commons that the stone, kept beneath the coronation chair at Westminster Abbey, will be returned once a new home is selected. The stone was captured in 1296 and has been used in every coronation since 1308.

headline: Jack Kemp: A Director With No Shares
abstract: Comment on problem of persons serving on company's board of directors, but who hold no shares in company; such a thing is less common than it used to be, because shareholder activists have persuaded many companies that directors, even if chosen by management, should have perspective of shareholders; many celebrity directors, people chosen for boards because of their fame or influence, never buy stock; example cited of Jack Kemp, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, who belongs to six corporate boards, but owns zero shares in companies (M)

headline: Consumers Continued Pace Of Borrowing During July
abstract: Federal Reserve figures show consumer borrowing, on the rise for three years, continued to grow in July as credit card use outpaced auto borrowing; level of consumer credit outstanding rose by $7.7 billion in July, to $1.164 trillion, greater rise than June's increase of revised $6.7 billion; previously, Fed said credit rose by $8.3 billion in June; graph (L)

headline: $46 MILLION STOCK-AND-DEBT BID FOR UTILITY SUPPLY
abstract: United States Filter Corp agrees to buy Utility Supply Group from CGW Southeast Partners for $22 million in stock and $24 million in assumed debt (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Chart on key United States interest rates

headline: Blue Cross Questions Purchase Of Ohio Plan by Columbia-HCA
abstract: National Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association suggests that Ohio Blue Cross and Blue Shield is not getting full value for main business lines it will sell to Columbia-HCA Healthcare Corp for $299.5 million; national association's board also questions $19 million that Columbia has agreed to pay Ohio Blue Cross executives; concerns have also been raised by Ohio Atorney General, Betty Montgomery; Ohio Attorney General and state insurance department have joined suit by Blue Cross policyholders calling for an independent board to set value of Ohio health plan (M)

headline: Japanese Trade Surplus Shrinks 46.4%
abstract: Japan's trade surplus shrank 46.4 percent to 361 billion yen, or $3.26 billion, in May, from 674 billion yen last year, the Ministry of Finance said today.         Many economists had expected, on average, that the May number would drop about 48 percent, to 337 billion yen.

headline: Dow Corning Selects Grey Advertising
abstract: Dow Corning Corp says it has selected Grey Advertising Inc to handle new worldwide corporate image account with billings that have not been determined (S)

headline: Cirrus Logic Is Set To Sell Picopower
abstract: The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire the Picopower unit of Cirrus Logic Inc. and that it would take a charge  of $10 million, or 5 cents a share, on completion of the acquisition.         Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. The transaction is expected to be  completed in August.

headline: Sam Zell Bids for a Rival Mobile-Home Maker
abstract: Manufactured Home Communities Inc, real estate investment trust controlled by Sam Zell, Chicago investor, offers to buy rival Chateau Properties Inc for $387.3 million in cash; offer is intended to derail Chateau's plans to buy ROC Communities Inc for $300 milion, move that would create competitor twice as big as Manufactured Home (M)

headline: Hughes Is Said To Be Nearing An Agreement For Panamsat
abstract: Hughes Electronics is in final stages of negotiations to acquire Panamsat in deal worth nearly $3 billion that would create world's second-largest satellite company; Hughes would merge Panamsat with its domestic satellite operations to create separate, publicly traded company; only Intelsat, giant Government-owned satellite consortium, would be larger (L)

headline: Sale of Italian Bank Stake
abstract: Banca Commerciale Italiana has signed a letter of intent to buy 55 percent of Biverbanca for 360 billion lire ($236 million) over three years. Biverbanca was  formed by the Cassa di Risparmio di Biella and Cassa di Risparmio di Vercelli merger.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: American Mobile Satellite Corp names Gary Parsons president and chief executive (S)

headline: A Spartan Trek To Hindu Shrine
abstract: Annual pilgrimage to Amarnath Cave in Himalayas is important rite for Hindus throughout India and has attracted pilgrims for at least 1,000 years; many visit shrine to see stalagmite sculpture that symbolizes phallus of Siva, one of three major gods of Hindu pantheon; at least 130 died in blizzard during trek into mountains; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: QUESTAR CORP., Salt Lake City, an energy company, will buy natural-gas and oil sites in Alberta from a privately held Canadian company for $51 million. The seller's name was not disclosed.    INTERNATIONAL TECHNOLOGY CORP., Torrance, Calif., which disposes of hazardous waste, agreed to a $45 million equity investment from Carlyle Group, giving the merchant bank a 38 percent stake in the company.

headline: U.S. Ready to Supply Muslim-Croat Army
abstract: President Clinton announced today that the American-led effort to train and equip the army of the Muslim-Croat Federation in Bosnia would begin immediately, now that the federation has adopted a law to merge the Muslim and Bosnian Croat  armies.         The adoption of the law, which also came today, was a condition that Washington set for delivering arms and developing a training program intended to bring the federation's forces up to the level of the better armed Bosnian Serbs.

headline: Big Insurer Promotes President To Chief
abstract: New York Life Insurance Co names its president, Seymour Sternberg, to succeed Harry G Hohn as chairman and chief executive officer when Hohn retires next April; Sternberg will retain his title as president; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HCIA IN DEAL TO ACQUIRE A UNIT OF HEALTHVISION
abstract: In a merger of companies that track health care costs and productivity, HCIA  Inc. agreed yesterday to buy a unit of Healthvision Inc., LBA Health Care Management Inc., for $130 million. HCIA, based in Baltimore, plans to use LBA's  clinical information from about 250 hospitals to expand its own data base. HCIA  expects to record a one-time charge of $41.2 million in the quarter ending Sept. 30 to cover the research and development projects already begun at LBA. Shares of HCIA fell $4.625, to $61.75, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HAMBRECHT & QUIST POSTPONES ITS INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING
abstract: Hambrecht & Quist Inc. rescheduled its $80 million initial public offering for the middle of August, according to people familiar with the situation. The San Francisco-based investment bank, which specializes in bringing technology companies public, is expected to sell a 15 percent to 20 percent stake to the public, analysts said when the offer was announced in June. Hambrecht & Quist put off its offering amid waning investor appetite for new stock. The sale would be priced the week of Aug. 12. The company has yet to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission the number of shares to be sold or the price  at which they will be sold.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HUNTSMAN OFFERS TO PURCHASE REXENE FOR $442 MILLION
abstract: The Huntsman Corporation offered yesterday to buy the Rexene Corporation for  $14 a share, or $442 million, including the assumption of $175 million in debt.  Rexene's shares rose $4.25, or 46 percent, to $13.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Jon Huntsman, chairman and chief executive of Huntsman, made the offer in a letter, the company said. Huntsman is the country's largest privately held  chemical company. Richard Durham, president and chief financial officer of Huntsman, said the offer would expire on Tuesday. A Rexene spokesman, Neil Devroy, said the company was evaluating the offer.

headline: Fragile Scrolls Cast New Light on Early Buddhism
abstract: For 18 months, scholars at the British Library have been poring over 13 scrolls of birch bark that were found rolled up inside clay pots, convinced they were looking at ancient manuscripts.         They carefully unrolled the fragile scrolls by moistening them overnight in a bell jar and then using tweezers to flatten them out and place them under glass. Then began the painstaking work of trying to figure out the language and script  and comparing fragments with known texts to unlock their mystery.

headline: Russians Continue to Pound Devastated Chechen Capital
abstract: Russian forces continue relentless aerial assault against rebels in Grozny, capital of breakaway province of Chechnya, despite urgent overnight visit to region by Russian national security adviser Aleksandr I Lebed and even though military commanders in Moscow vowed not to use air power to attack separatists; maps; photo (M)

headline: Armenia Chief Faces Protests Over Election
abstract: Armenian Pres Levon Ter-Petrossian says he won 'brilliant victory' in Sept 22 presidential election, but thousands of protesters demand that he step down because of voting irregularities (M)

headline: COKE SHARES FALL AFTER 3D-QUARTER FORECAST
abstract: Shares of Coca-Cola Co fall in heavy trading after company says third-quarter sales will fall short of expectations, mainly because of sluggish sales in Europe (S)

headline: Consumer Reports Forges a TV Identity
abstract: Magazine Consumer Reports forges new identity with Consumer Reports TV, which produces documentaries and shorter consumer news segments that are sold to commercial stations; executive director Joyce Newman comments; photo (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;VW Sales Up 28% In Asia-Pacific Region
abstract: Volkswagen A.G. said yesterday that sales to the Asia-Pacific region rose 28  percent in the first half of this year. During the same period, the company sold 8.4 percent more cars in Western Europe, according to preliminary figures from the European Automobile Manufacturers Association.          Volkswagen said sales to the Asia-Pacific region increased to 163,070 vehicles in the first six months of 1996 from 127,300 a year earlier. For the full year, the German car maker expects to sell more than 300,000 vehicles in the region. In the company's main market, Western Europe, car sales rose to 1,183,529 from 1,092,085.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Morgan Stanley Closes a Private Fund at $800 Million
abstract: Morgan Stanley Group closes to further investment its Princes Gate Investors II LP, private equity partnership with $800 million in capital; 16 partners, including Morgan Stanley, have contributed $50 million each; Morgan Stanley aide Hartley Rogers discusses plans, interview (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sema Group Buys Olivetti Unit
abstract: Sema Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it would pay L64.2 million, or $100 million, for Syntax Processing, an information technology unit of Olivetti S.p.A. Sema, a British-French technology services company, said it would pay L32.1 million for Syntax now, L22.6 million on Dec. 31, 1997, and a further L9.5 million to acquire the Syntax brand name.          Olivetti said the sale was part of its plan, outlined last September, to sell assets that fall outside its focus on three businesses: telecommunications, personal computers and office systems. Syntax, which has subsidiaries in Italy, Belgium, France and Britain, reported 1995 pretax profit  before one-time items of L6.3 million on sales of L88.8 million.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Targets Were Chosen to Punish and Weaken Hussein, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: US launched limited missile strikes at targets in southern Iraq hundreds of miles from Kurdish areas in north reportedly to avoid appearance of taking sides in factional fighting; by attacking air defenses in four areas in south, US hopes to pressure Iraq into withdrawing forces from north without entering into tit-for-tat exchange there; cruise missile raids served Administration's larger goals of punishing Pres Saddam Hussein and weakening his ability to lash out against oil-producing states to south (M)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Tambrands Puts Account in Review
abstract: Tambrands Inc., the marketer of Tampax tampons, said yesterday that it had placed in review its worldwide account, which the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group in New York has handled since 1993. Billings were estimated at $65 million.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ALLIED SIGNAL PREDICTS IT WILL MEET CASH TARGET
abstract: The industrial conglomerate Allied Signal Inc. said it would meet its 1996 target of $400 million in additional cash even though it had a cash deficit of $200 million in the first half of the year. In a memo to Allied Signal executives, Lawrence Bossidy, the company's chairman and chief executive, said that in order to reach its goal, the company would have to bring in about $650 million in the next six months. Allied Signal makes products for the aerospace, automotive and engineered-materials industries. Shares of Allied Signal fell $1, to $56.75.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A Shift in Standard For Environmental Rules  The Clinton Administration said that it would start basing all environmental protection standards on the particular risks that pollution poses to children's health.    The change could lead to tougher rules on everything from soot fouling the air to microbes contaminating water. $(Page A14.$)    Xerox Insurance Sale Is Canceled  Xerox and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said that they were calling off the planned $2.7 billion sale of Xerox's insurance units to Kohlberg. Neither company would say why the sale, for which Xerox had already taken a $1.5 billion charge, was canceled. $(D5.$)    Motorola Warns Of Weak Profit  Motorola's stock fell after the company warned Wall Street that disappointing sales of cellular phones and other products were taking a much bigger toll on its earnings than analysts had been projecting for the current quarter. $(D2.$)    Blow to Overseas Lending Agency  The House rejected a bill to renew the lending and insuring authority of the agency that provides insurance and loan guarantees to companies investing in poor nations. $(D2.$)    Nasdaq Is Said to Cost More  Two studies argue that institutional investors pay higher costs to trade on Nasdaq than they do on stock exchanges. $(D6.$)    New England Life in Software Deal  New England Life Insurance has bought a substantial stake in Meca Software, which produces personal-finance software. $(D3.$)    New Chief at Perot Systems  Morton Meyerson, Ross Perot's business lieutenant since the 1970's, stepped aside as chief executive of the Perot Systems Corporation and promoted the company president to take his place. $(D16.$)    Don't Raise Rates, Some Say  With unemployment falling to just 5.1 percent and economic growth robust, it appears that interest rates will be raised. Still, some economists are urging American monetary-policy makers to let the good times roll.   Peter Passell: Economic Scene. $(A1.$)    F.T.C. Approval for Time Warner  The F.T.C. plans to announce that it has officially approved Time Warner's $6.5 billion merger with Turner Broadcasting. $(D17.$)    New Tack in Mobile-Home Bid  Sun Communities, one of the three mobile-home park operators wooing shareholders of Chateau Properties, said it was willing to offer cash. Its original offer was in stock. $(D4.$)    Net Gatekeeper May Sell Stock  The private company that the Government put in charge of registering Internet names has been exploring the idea of cashing in on its gatekeeping role by selling stock. $(A1.$)    Brooklyn Union to Cut Some Rates  Brooklyn Union Gas said it would lower its gas rates next year for many customers and then freeze them over the next five years, the first time a large utility has committed itself to a cap on rates for such a long period. $(B3.$)

headline: Investment by Deutsche Bank Stirs Talk of Industry Mergers
abstract: Deutsche Bank A.G. said today that it had acquired a 5.21 percent stake in Bayerische Vereinsbank, a move that aroused speculation that German banking might be headed for a wave of mergers and consolidation.         Deutsche Bank, the nation's biggest, declined to comment on whether it intended to increase its stake, but analysts said that a takeover attempt of the large Bavarian institution was unlikely.

headline: Stocks Rebound in Japan
abstract: Stocks were rebounding somewhat here today, a day after they plunged to their sharpest one-day loss of the year. At the end of the morning session, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 59.28 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,690.31. On Wednesday the Nikkei fell 532.66 points, or 2.52 percent.

headline: Maple Creek Journal;A Prison Where the Great Spirit of Healing Dwells
abstract: Four years ago, Bridget Bruyere, 24, a Saulteaux Indian from Fort Alexander,  Manitoba, was a prostitute in Winnipeg. She picked up a customer, accompanied him to his apartment and knifed him to death.         Convicted of second-degree murder, she spent time in two other correctional institutions -- "where you open your windows and all you see is bars" -- before  her transfer in February to an unusual facility nestled in wooded hills near Maple Creek, a town of 2,500 in the cattle country of southwest Saskachewan. Now, she talks of her joy at being able to see trees and sky from her windows and go on walks amid the sage and prairie grass.

headline: Xerox and Kohlberg Kravis Call Off Planned Sale
abstract: Xerox Corp and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts say they have called off planned $2.7 billion sale of Xerox's insurance units to Kohlberg Kravis; both companies refuse to say why sale was canceled; Xerox says it will seek new buyers for insurance units (M)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: Goldwin Golf Inc., Carlsbad, Calif., to Foote, Cone & Belding, San Francisco, a  unit of True North Communications, as the first agency to handle advertising for the maker of golf clubs. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $8 million.

headline: MARKET WATCH;Stock Watchdogs Can't End Abuses
abstract: Bull markets come and go. But penny stock rip-offs are always with us.         The National Association of Securities Dealers, under its new regulatory chief, Mary L. Schapiro, has stepped up its campaign against penny stock firms that rip off customers. But even a major victory last week -- one that will give back more than $1 million to customers -- serves to emphasize just how hard the battle is to win.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;APPLIED MATERIALS SHARES DECLINE 9% ON REPORT
abstract: Shares of Applied Materials Inc. fell 9 percent yesterday after it said its third-quarter results would be lower than analysts expected as chipmakers slow orders for the company's equipment. Shares fell $2.625, to $25.375, on trading of almost five million shares. The company said sales would be about $1.1 billion and earnings about 90 cents a share for the three months ending July 28. Wall Street was expecting the Santa Clara, Calif., company to earn $1 a share, according to the average estimate of 17 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research Corp. A year earlier, net income was $139.2 million, or 79 cents a share, on sales of $897.7 million.

headline: Seoul Arrives At a Difficult Crossroads
abstract: SEOUL—  (Stella Kim, a freelance journalist based in Seoul, contributed to this and several other articlesin this report.)

headline: Kohl Finds Yeltsin 'Active' But 'Worried' About Surgery
abstract: Pres Boris Yeltsin of Russia gets visit from Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, who finds him 'cheerful and active' but also 'noticeably worried' about his coming heart bypass surgery; Kohl seeks to dispel talks of a power vacuum in the Kremlin caused by Yeltsin's illness; assures Yeltsin that NATO expansion into Eastern Europe will not take place this year and that negotiations over Russia's participation in an enlarged NATO will wait until after Yeltsin recovers; photo (M)

headline: Where Jobs Have No Collars
abstract: Tina Wright comment on her work as milker and cowperson on Holstein dairy farm in King Ferry, in upstate New York (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;UNITED DOMINION IS ALLOWED MEETING ON HOSTILE BID
abstract: United Dominion Industries Ltd. said yesterday that a Federal court had ruled it could call a special meeting of Commercial Intertech shareholders about Dominion's $465 million hostile bid. United Dominion said it sought to call the  meeting to remove the obstacles to its tender offer of $30 a share. United Dominion said the United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio had denied a motion by Commercial Intertech, which also sought to block United Dominion from soliciting proxies for the Aug. 30 meeting at which Commercial Intertech shareholders will consider United Dominion's bid.

headline: Operating Profit Rose In First Half at Wella
abstract: Wella AG reports first-half operating profit rose 25 percent, to 61 million marks (about $41 million) (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PHILIP MORRIS APPOINTS NEW CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
abstract: Louis C. Camilleri will become chief financial officer of the Philip Morris Companies on Nov. 1, the tobacco and food company said yesterday. Mr. Camilleri, who is president and chief executive of the Kraft Foods International Inc. unit  of Philip Morris, will replace Hans G. Storr, who is approaching retirement. John D. Bowlin, the current president and chief operating officer of Kraft Foods North America, will succeed Mr. Camilleri as president and chief executive of Kraft Foods International.

headline: Saskatchewan Company In Accord to Buy Arcadian
abstract: Potash Corp of Saskatchewan Inc says it will acquire Arcadian Corp in transaction valued at up to $1.23 billion in cash and stock; this ends agreement for Arcadian to be bought by Freeport-McMoran Inc (M)

headline: CRESCENT REAL ESTATE ACQUIRING CANYON RANCH RESORTS
abstract: Crescent Real Estate Equities Inc acquires two resorts for total of $84 million; Crescent buys Canyon Ranch-Tucson, health and fitness resort in Tucson, Ariz, for $27 million in partnership units and $30 million in assumed debt; also agrees to acquire Canyon Ranch-Lenox, resort in Lenox, Mass, for $19 million in cash and $8 million in assumed debt (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  American Intl Group  Kimco Realty  Omnicom Group  Stewart InfoSvcs    TUESDAY  Bankers TR N Y   Capitol Amern Finl   Citizens    CPC Intl   Essex Ppty Tr    Phillips-Van Huesen   Southwest Gas Corp   Toro      WEDNESDAY    Ameritech Corp   Bangor Hydro Elec   Clorox   Keystone Intl   Nat Re   National Svc Inds   Rchstr Gas & Eled   Spieker Pptys   St Joseph Lt & Pwr   Stone & Webster   Thrnbrg Mtg Asset     THURSDAY    Getty Pete   Marsh & Mclennan   State St Boston   Transamerica    Transatlantic Hldgs   Wiley (John) & Sons     FRIDAY    Intl Multifoods   Potlatch

headline: CULBRO IN TALKS TO BUY CIGAR MAKER VILLAZON
abstract: Culbro Corp discusses buying Villazon & Co, cigar maker (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 3/ A $285,000 award has forced Rebecca Goldstein, a novelist, to take a closer look at her family's finances and its debts. By Sana Siwolop.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 6/ Mark Holowesko manages several Templeton funds, but this summer he tried something different: the Olympics. By Juliette Fairley.    EARNING IT /Page 8/ Doctors have increasingly been finding it difficult to find a job in some highly paid specialties. By Leah Beth Ward.    FROM THE DESK OF /Page 8/ For the last four years, Trans World Airlines has been training its trauma unit, and the team responded in minutes after Flight 800 went down. By Jeffrey H. Erickson.

headline: In Paris, A Painful Wait And Grieving : Trauma Center Counseling (folo)
abstract: PARIS—  Max Berley of the International Herald Tribune reported:

headline: Hilton-Ladbroke Agreement Is Broader Than Expected
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp and Ladbroke Group PLC, which owns Hilton Hotels International, announces broader-than-expected alliance that allows each company to buy a fifth of the other; alliance unites ownership of Hilton name in US and abroad; Hilton sold its international operations in 1964, and Ladbroke, the British gambling and hotel company, bought the company in 1987; Hilton intends to acquire 5 percent stake in Ladbroke, currently valued at about $195 million, as soon as possible after signing the agreements (L)

headline: Arab Note Ends Office Dispute
abstract: Hatem Abdel Qader, who represents East Jerusalem in Palestinian legislative council, resolves dispute with Israel over office in his East Jerusalem home with written declaration that office does not belong to Palestinian Authority (S)

headline: As Insurers Cut Fees, Doctors Shift to Elective Procedures
abstract: Thousands of doctors, frustrated by price controls, red tape and sometimes intrusive oversight of managed care, have started building lucrative practices in fields like cosmetic surgery and infertility treatment, where patients will pay even when insurers will not; major reason specialists can find enough patients paying out of their own pockets is the stunning increase in family income of wealthiest Americans; photo of cosmetic surgeon; chart on surgeon's fees for common cosmetic procedures (L)

headline: Pro Bono Accounts
abstract: * Starlight Foundation of New York to Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, New York, as the first agency to handle its account.

headline: World News Briefs;Right-Winger Concedes Defeat in Ecuador
abstract: The rightist Christian Democratic candidate, Jaime Nebot, conceded defeat tonight in Ecuador's runoff presidential election to a populist, Abdala Bucaram.         Mr, Bucaram, of the center-left Roldosista Party, struck a sympathetic chord  with the nation's poor.

headline: Jefferson Smurfit Profit Off 37% in Paper Slump
abstract: Jefferson Smurfit Group reports first-half pretax profit fell 37 percent to 126 million Irish pounds ($204 million) from year-earlier 201 million pounds (S)

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Zimbabwe Lifts Ban On Gay Group at Fair
abstract: Zimbabwe said today that it would allow a homosexual organization to take part in an international book fair, reversing a ban last year that was condemned worldwide.          The Government will not interfere with the organizers of the state-backed Zimbabwe International Book Fair, said Information Minister Joyce Mujeru. The Organizers have given the Gays and Lesbians Society of Zimbabwe permission to exhibit literature, mostly on AIDS, at the weeklong fair starting July 29.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Several Large Banks Post Strong Results for 2d Quarter
abstract: Four of the biggest American banks reported strong second-quarter earnings yesterday, in several cases shrugging off increased loan losses.         The BankAmerica Corporation, the Bank of New York Corporation and the Wachovia Corporation relied on higher revenues from fees to offset the growth of bad loans. The Republic New York Corporation, with one of the biggest loan-loss reserves in relation to its current losses, had the strongest earnings report among large banks, as its income from lending and investments surged.

headline: Europe Seeks to Settle Pasta Rift With U.S.
abstract: The European Union called on the global trade watchdog, the World Trade Organization, today to settle its eight-year dispute with the United States over pasta exports.         The United States unilaterally imposed restrictions on imports of European pasta, tomato paste and citrus fruit back in 1988. It was a retaliatory measure  for a European Union ban on American hormone-treated beef.

headline: Japan's Lifetime Jobs: Foreigners Qualify, Too
abstract: Japanese companies, in a quiet change of culture, are extending to their foreign workers the special status of lifetime employment, which for the most part has been the exclusive right of Japanee-born employees for at least 30 years; photo (M)a

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;BANKERS TRUST N.Y. CORP. (BT,N)
abstract: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter net earnings climbed 65.9 percent, helped by increased revenues from its investment banking business, to $151 million, or $1.67 a share, from $91 million, or 98 cents, a year earlier.         Although the earnings were below the $1.75 a share estimated by analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research, the company's stock rose 75 cents, to $71.875, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

headline: Summers Without Vacations
abstract: Some workers comment on summer employment; drawing (L)L

headline: Politicians Take On Japan's Finance Ministry, With Caution
abstract: New program for Japan's vilified Finance Ministry is likely to disappoint proponents of greater change; Japan's governing coalition says it will leave most of Finance Ministry intact and create independent financial inspection and supervisory commission; program is first step politicians have dared to take to chip away at immensely influential ministry, which attracted worldwide criticism for its handling of string of financial crises during last few years (M)

headline: Containing Iraq Has Made Kuwait Duty Old Hat for G.I.'s
abstract: Hundreds of Army troops are on their way to new posts in Kuwaiti desert; seamlessness of movement was made possible by agreement that since Persian Gulf war has left enough heavy American weaponry in Kuwait to sustain at least an Army tank battalion with 40 tanks; photo (M) and American Army has maintinaed what has become more or less permanent presence; photo (M)

headline: The 10 major advertising makeovers done for 'Grease,' however painful, have paid off.
abstract: New advertising drive for improbably long-running Broadway revival of musical Grease discussed; seeks to institutionalize play as New York tourist destination; co-producer Barry Weissler comments (Advertising column) (M)

headline: World News Briefs;At Least 300 Are Killed In Severe China Flooding
abstract: Flooding brought on by heavy rains has killed more than 300 people, severed electrical lines and knocked down buildings, and the seasonal storms headed north today through China.         Hundreds of thousands of soldiers and reservists were called out to evacuate  more than half a million people and to repair damaged dikes in communities along the Yangtze River and its tributaries, official news reports said.

headline: A Maker of Generic Zantac Wins a Round From Glaxo
abstract: Novopharm Ltd. cleared a legal hurdle in its race to obtain the first United  States rights to make a generic version of Zantac, an ulcer medicine, when a Federal judge in North Carolina ruled Friday that it could produce the drug without infringing on one of two patents held by Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C.         At stake are the rights to make generic versions in the United States of a drug that generated $3.5 billion in worldwide sales in 1995 for Glaxo, which is  based in London. More than $2 billion of Glaxo's sales have been in the United States.

headline: Nationsbank Said to Be Set For Big Merger
abstract: Nationsbank, returning to aggressive acquisition strategy after sitting out last year's flurry of big bank mergers, has agreed to buy Boatmen's Bancshares Inc for $9.2 billion in stock and cash; deal, which would be industry's third largest ever, is indication of just how competitive banking industry has become, even for successful company like Boatmen's (L)

headline: Death Penalty Asked for Korean Ex-Leader
abstract: South Korean prosecutors demand death penalty for former Pres Chun Doo Hwan for his role in military coup in 1979 and massacre of pro-democracy protesters in city of Kwangju in 1980 (S)

headline: Ford Wants to Trim 1,000 Jobs in Britain
abstract: Ford Motor Co to eliminate 1,000 jobs at plants in Britain through voluntary reductions and early retirements; move is part of effort to make plants competitive globally (S)

headline: Lebed Lobbies in Moscow for Peace Plan
abstract: Russian national security adviser Aleksandr I Lebed meets with Prime Min Viktor Chernomyrdin to try to rally top-level support for plan to end war in breakaway Chechnya as plans for Russian troop withdrawal grind to halt; photo (M)

headline: Ford Offers White-Collar Early Retirement Plans
abstract: The Ford Motor Company will offer early retirement packages to white-collar workers in an effort to shed 2,000 employees from its auto operations around the world by the end of the year, helping the auto maker reduce costs and bring in employees with new skills.         The early retirement incentives being offered to 4,000 workers are Ford's first in five years for administrators and middle managers. Ford focused on well-paid senior managers and executives in its packages over the last two years.

headline: WORLD AIRWAYS TO DISCONTINUE MONEY-LOSING FLIGHTS
abstract: World Airways Inc to discontinue money-losing commercial flights and focus on military and international charter flights; reports second-quarter earnings rose 22 percent, to $14.5 million, from $11.9 million in 1995 period (S)

headline: Bombed Church Is Resurrected in Rome as Testament to Faith
abstract: Restoration work is completed on Church of San Giorgio, Rome, nearly destroyed by Mafia bomb in July 1993 (M)

headline: Lift the Ceiling
abstract: Letter by T P Thompson on June 23 Viewpoint article on Social Security

headline: McDonnell Wins Lufthansa Order for Cargo Jets
abstract: McDonnell Douglas Corp says it has won order worth $1.3 billion from Lufthansa for its MD-11 jet, to be used as cargo aircraft; firm orders are placed for five MD-11's, and there are options on seven more; General Electric will provide engines; order remains subject to approval of boards of Lufthansa Cargo and parent Lufthansa AG (M)

headline: Shanghai Journal;In 75 Years, a Party's Long March to Irrelevance
abstract: In a small brick home on a leafy side street in this city, a dozen idealistic young men gathered around a scuffed wooden table 75 years ago today to launch China's Communist Party, or so the history books say.         One of the participants, Mao Zedong, then just 27, later rose to lead the Communist Party through civil war to make it the ruling power of the land. For decades, Mao directed efforts to install the party's authority in every office,  factory and school, creating a juggernaut that could spread the party's word to  every household and monitor the daily activities of every worker or student.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SUN COMPANY SELLS LAST OF ITS OILFIELDS TO ENI
abstract: The Sun Company said yesterday that it had sold its North Sea oilfields off the British coast to ENI S.p.A. of Italy for $260 million. With the sale, Sun, based in Philadelphia, has shed its last remaining production business to focus  on refining and gasoline marketing. Sun said it would use the cash from the sale to either invest in its remaining businesses or buy back some of its stock. Shares of Sun were unchanged yesterday at $26.125. The stock has fallen 20 percent in two months.

headline: COMPUTER MAKER OFFERS SOME EMPLOYEES BUYOUTS
abstract: IBM has offered some of its US employees a buyout plan if they leave company by end of year; IBM will not disclose how many employees are affected (S)

headline: Fund Buys Stake In Mobile Systems
abstract: Mobile Systems International PLC says that General Atlantic Partners will buy 20 percent of company, valuing it at 180 million pounds, or $280 million (S)

headline: Deutsche Bank Backs 3 Equity Funds
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG discloses that it has pumped $270 million into three equity finds at its Morgan Grenfell Asset Management unit in London to buy certain unlisted securities in stock funds managed by Morgan Grenfell whose value had been questioned; Deutsche Bank also announces suspension of second trader, Stewart Armer (S)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;Should an extension of current copyright law, tweaked a bit, govern the Internet?
abstract: YET another new Internet law, this one governing copyright on the global computer network, has found its way into the legislative sausage grinder on Capitol Hill. But it looks as though this one might not make it into the frying  pan any time soon.         Bruce Lehman, the Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, whose agency drafted the bill, acknowledged in an interview last week that the bill, known as the National Information Infrastructure Copyright Act, was stalled in Congress.  But many people in the information industry and in public interest groups are hoping it never moves forward.

headline: Korea Order to Raytheon
abstract: The Raytheon Company has received a contract that could exceed $250 million to supply South Korea with an airborne reconnaissance system. The system will use reconnaissance equipment developed and integrated by Raytheon's E-Systems unit and will be installed on four of Raytheon's Hawker 800XP jet aircraft. South Korea will also buy another four Hawker 800XP jets for similar purposes. The military contractor, based in Lexington, Mass., did not disclose when it would deliver the system.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dole Plans to Announce $548 Billion Tax-Cut Plan  After weeks of debate within his campaign, Bob Dole has settled on the economic and political foundation of his Presidential run. In Chicago today, he is expected to announce a $548 billion tax-cut package highlighted by a 15 percent reduction in individual income tax rates and a halving of the capital gains tax.    Dole aides said that the plan was the single-most critical component to reviving Mr. Dole's fortunes against President Clinton. $(Page A1.$)    Mr. Dole is betting his campaign on convincing voters that tax cuts won't send the deficit sky-high and that smaller government won't hurt the economy or living standards. $(A1.$)    Bob Dole's campaign opened a Web site and accused President Clinton of being stodgy and behind the times. $(D5.$)    Revolution in Type Design  A new generation of designers of typefaces, or fonts, has emerged since the birth of the Apple Macintosh and desktop publishing. But the digital technology that makes type easier to design has made the profession more difficult and styles easier to steal -- and more designers mean more competition. $(D5.$)    Restrictions for Bond Lawyers?  Lawyers are raising the same ethical question that investment bankers have already answered: Should municipal bond attorneys be barred from donating to politicians with whom they do business? $(D2.$)    Global Village in Olympic Ads  In its coverage of the Olympics, NBC has been accused of chauvinism, featuring mainly home-grown athletes. But wait for the commercials. Some are so globally sophisticated, like ads from I.B.M. and Coca-Cola, that they are in French or Thai. Advertising. $(D6.$)    The Olympic Games in Atlanta began as a real estate lawyer's pipe dream, turned into unlikely reality and veered between triumph and nightmare. But at the end, by almost any accounting, a folly had paid off. $(A1.$)    Silicon Graphics Shares Lag  Silicon Graphics just can't seem to win. The company reported earnings last week that exceeded most expectations. Yet in the next two trading days, its shares fell and analysts lowered earnings estimates for fiscal 1997, citing slower growth. Market Place. $(D4.$)    Developing Antiterrorism Devices  As the White House moves to speed the development of antiterrorism devices by expediting patent applications, a survey of recent patents shows research is already under way. Teresa Riordan: Patents. $(D2.$)    'Green Mile' Crowds Rivals  Stephen King's successful serial thriller, ''The Green Mile,'' has been a killer for publishers angling to get their own authors on the paperback best-seller lists, which Mr. King now dominates like Carrie at the prom. $(D7.$)    Satellite TV in Latin America  Jose Antonio Rios of Galaxy Latin America and David Evans of Sky Entertainment Services Latin America will soon be archrivals, but they agree on at least one thing: Latin America is inhabited by millions of budding channel surfers. $(D7.$)    Children's Program Quota  Soon, television stations will be required to carry three hours of children's educational programs a week. Broadcasters say children won't watch them and advertisers aren't interested. But reasons for running them exist beyond the bottom line. Lawrie Mifflin: Broadcasting. $(D7.$)    Finding First Aid for PC's  Computer troubles? Here's how to avoid the technology support department: Almost every company now has a Web site offering support. Taking In the Sites. $(D6.$)

headline: The Young And the Exhausted
abstract: Lloyd M Krieger article on the physical and mental exhaustion that frequently afflicts young professionals like himself; says lack of relaxation and leisure restricts their creativity as well as social life; cartoon (M)

headline: Chief of McDonald's Defends Arch Deluxe to Franchisees
abstract: Edward H Rensi, president and chief executive of McDonald's Corp, sends memo to company's 2,700 United States franchisees defending introduction of Arch Deluxe, saying sandwich was never intended to be a miracle; memo is intended to counter outside criticism of introduction of product; McDonald's officials said at time of introduction in May that Arch Deluxe would generate $1 billion in sales in its first year; success of new product has been subject of intense speculation ever since; actual success of Arch Deluxe will not be known until company announces its same-store sales figures with third-quarter earnings in week of Oct 21 (M)
