The World Health Organization and the United Nations General Assembly had asked the court for an advisory opinion on whether international law permits the threat or use of nuclear weapons.

headline: Achtung! (Aktung?) Bonn Bans Some H's
abstract: It has been rushed through in mere decades, but finally German-speakers the world over are to have a new system of spelling.         And like the rules that dictate when and how Germans may use their lawn-mowers, cross the street or use a fishing-pole, the new orthography will join that canon of regulations that gives their society the reputation of being  Europe's most regimented.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bridgestone Reports 81% Gain in Profits
abstract: The Bridgestone Corporation, the Japanese tire maker, said yesterday that its net income in the first half of the year rose 81 percent on a 34 percent gain in exports, which were lifted by the drop in the value of the yen. Bridgestone raised its forecast for the year, citing stronger tire sales in Asia and the Middle East.          Bridgestone earnings rose to 18.82 billion yen, or $174 million, from 10.39  billion yen last year. Sales rose to 336.3 billion yen from 306.88 billion yen.   (AP)

headline: Strong Durable Goods Data Revive Fear of Higher Rates
abstract: Commerce Dept reports that orders for durable goods surged in July, jumping 1.6 percent; that is considerably more than analysts expected and casts new doubt on assumptions that economy is slowing from its unsustainable fast pace of spring; chart (M)

headline: Bond Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills and a 52-week bill being auctioned Thursday.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.18 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was 5.34 percent. In when-issued trading the 52-week bill was offered at a price to yield 5.56 percent.

headline: The Los Angeles Times tries to attract readers and advertisers by leaving them hanging.
abstract: Advertising column discusses drives to boost newspaper readership and attract advertisers; Los Angeles Times drive takes 'cliff-hanger' approach, giving first part of interesting news stories; approaches of some other newspapers noted (M)

headline: Saudi Rebels Are Main Suspects In June Bombing of a U.S. Base
abstract: Saudi Govt believes local Islamic militants, including many veterans of Afghan war, carried out June 25 bombing of US military base in Dhahran which killed 19 American servicemen; say there is evidence linking some of detainees under interrogation to four men executed in connection with bombing in Riyadh in Nov '95 that killed five Americans and two Indians; Saudi dissident group in London and Arabic-language newspaper say six suspects confessed to involvement in bombing; Saudi Govt denies reports (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Spain to Open Selloff With Gas Natural Stake
abstract: The Spanish Government will begin its sale of state assets with a share offering of its 3.8 percent stake in Gas Natural SDG as early as September, officials said yesterday.          Sepi, the Government holding company, said it had approved the sale of the Gas Natural stake.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Junk-bond funds had their best sales month ever in August.
abstract: Market Place column notes cash inflows into mutual funds that invest in stocks continue to surge, especially in high-yield mutual funds, meaning junk-bond funds; net inflows of $1.68 billion in August put junk-bond funds on track for their best year ever; analyst says strong inflows to junk bonds can be partly attributed to greater investment in all kinds of mutual funds; another factor is unusually low default rate for junk bonds (M)

headline: Netscape Product to Rely on I.B.M. System
abstract: Netscape Communications Corp will introduce new version of its Navigator software for browsing Internet's World Wide Web that will run on IBM's struggling OS/2; users will be able to call up sites on Internet by issuing voice commands (M)

headline: Islamic-Secular Coalition Cabinet Is Approved in Turkey
abstract: In a break with Turkey's 73-year record of zealous secularism, the Turkish Parliament gave narrow approval yesterday to a coalition government led by an Islamic party that has campaigned to restore the country's Muslim identity.         The coalition, a marriage between the Islamic Welfare Party and a center-right party headed by former Prime Minister Tansu Ciller, won a confidence vote in Parliament with the support of 278 deputies, just three more than the majority required.

headline: Applying Pay-Per-View Idea To the Compact Disk Business
abstract: Planet Graphics Ltd offers HyperCD, which can be loaded with material that contains any mix the producer wants of Web-controlled and free material; Web site operators can turn parts of CD off or on, opening door to such applications as pay-per-view shows; technology could be valuable for marketers who already distribute vast amounts of CD material (M)

headline: Fidelity Cut Its Stake in Chrysler Last Month
abstract: Fidelity Investments cut its holdings of Chrysler Corp's shares by more than a third last month, perhaps contributing to large selloff in Chrysler shares; Fidelity mutual funds owned cumulative 57.21 million shares of Chrysler stock at end of July, equal to 7.8 percent of company's total shares; at end of March, Fidelity owned 91.84 million Chrysler shares, or 12.2 percent of total (L)

headline: Media: PRESS;Financial pressures hammer at the wall between the business and the editorial sides.
abstract: THERE was a time not long ago when newspapers were so profitable that some small-town owners were said to lie about their family's vacation plans. "Just taking the kids to Miami," they would tell their friends -- and their advertisers at the Rotary or at the country club -- without adding that the next stop would be Rome or Hong Kong.         After all, if Disneyland was all the local Chevy dealer or the hardware store owner could afford, there was no point in making it harder for them to write that big advertising check to the newspaper every month.

headline: What's New at G.M.? Cars, for a Change
abstract: Article on General Motors program to rebuild core business of selling cars and vans to American public that has lost much of its loyalty to famous names; company has platoon of new recruits who know about marketing consumer products but little about cars in particular; chairman John F Smith Jr, considered affable finance man, gets high marks for resuscitating GM's balance sheet and turning impressive profits in satellite and other businesses, but North American president G Richard Wagoner Jr notes all-out effort this year will be to remake auto sales; photos; turning around world's biggest corporation, with $170 billion in sales last year and some 700,000 employees, is enormous task, complicated by plans to roll out new models over next six months, during contract talks with UAW; company needs to roughly double profit margins in good years to reach 5% average; auto reviewers are impressed with design of new minivans, but they are slow to arrive in dealerships; table profiling corporate finances (M)

headline: Correction: Women's Favorite Video Games
abstract: A chart in Business Day yesterday about results of a survey of people who play video games reversed the gender labels on bars showing women's favorite games. Here is a corrected chart.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Machine Tools Get New Report
abstract: Association for Manufacturing Technology and American Machine Tool Distributors' Association estimate United States orders for machine tools totaled $643.1 million, June; figure cannot be compared with previous months because it includes for first time imported tools distributed by American firms (S)

headline: Rebels Overrun Russian Troops In Chechen City
abstract: Chechen rebels overrun Russian troops in Grozny, capital of Chechnya, and take virtual control of city; scores of Russian soldiers are reported dead and hundreds wounded; many civilians are reportedly killed by Russian helicopter gunships, desperately trying to pick off rebels with rockets; assault is humiliation for Pres Boris Yeltsin on eve of his inaugural; his vow to end war in Chechnya during Presidential re-election campaign recalled; map (M)

headline: Lehman Brothers Settles Suit on Trading
abstract: Lehman Brothers Inc settles lawsuit over trading debts with China National United Petroleum and Chemical Co; terms of settlement are not disclosed; Lehman sued China National United Petroleum, known as Unipec, in 1994 for $44 million over debts related to foreign exchange trading (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BANKBOSTON IS THE NEW NAME FOR MERGED BANKS
abstract: The Bank of Boston Corporation said yesterday that the holding company for its bank and Baybanks Inc. would be known as the BankBoston Corporation after the closing of the $2 billion merger of the banks, which is expected later this  month. The new name would become the single brand for all branches, products and operations worldwide when the systems are converted in 1997. After the closing,  BankBoston would have assets of $60 billion.

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : Last 'Live' Jukebox Still Spins Its Disks
abstract: What is billed as the last "live" jukebox in the country is hanging on precariously in Pittsburgh, defying the fate of soda fountains and drive-in theaters. Live juke boxes, common until after World War II, work like this: Patrons in bars and restaurants make their choices in boxes that contain no records, but are connected by telephone to a studio, where an operator with a vast store to choose from plays the requested record.

headline: Paribas Earnings Jump Sixfold
abstract: Compagnie Financiere de Paribas SA says its earnings rose more than sixfold in first half, to $808 million, from year earlier (S)

headline: Bomb-Detection Stocks Ride Wave of Fear
abstract: Stocks of bomb-detection device makers and security services have soared since TWA airliner crash even though airlines and airports, main customers of these firms, are not rushing to place orders; analysts see airlines unlikely to spend heavily on systems not required by law (M)

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;African Nations Back 2d Term for U.N. Chief
abstract: African leaders, meeting today in Cameroon, appeared to give Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali qualified backing for a second term, diplomats said here.

headline: WPP Posts 40% Jump In Pretax Earnings
abstract: WPP Group PLC reports first half pretax profit rose 40 percent, to 68.1 million pounds ($105 million), up from 48.5 million pounds in 1995 period (S)

headline: INTERNTIONAL BUSINESS;Mexico Says It Will Repay $7 Billion To the U.S.
abstract: The Mexican Government helped the Clinton Administration neutralize a potentially difficult election-year problem today, announcing that early next month it would pay back $7 billion to the United States.         The early payment will leave only $3.5 billion in outstanding loans from the  bailout of Mexico last year, or slightly more than a quarter of the $12.5 billion that the Clinton Administration extended after Mexico came to the brink  of national bankruptcy in early 1995. The repayments make it possible for President Clinton to contend that his action, which encountered considerable political resistance, helped prevent a global meltdown of the world's most promising emerging markets -- while creating a profit for the United States Treasury of more than $500 million, because of high interest rates charged to the Mexican Government.

headline: Suburbia Can't Kick the Nozzle;As Gas Guzzling Becomes a Way of Life, Oil Imports Soar
abstract: Like most residents of this fast-growing bedroom community 20 miles north of  Albany, Janet Mulvey cannot do anything away from home without first hopping into one of the cars in her driveway.         To deliver her son to preschool, to buy new window shades or pick up the dry  cleaning -- not to mention doing her job as a roving children's speech therapist for adjacent Schenectady County -- Ms. Mulvey has to slide behind the wheel of her 1991 Toyota Landcruiser and negotiate the winding roads out of her housing development past all the other four- and five-bedroom homes. And her husband, Martin, who sells extended warranty programs to car dealers, burns up even more  miles in his 1994 Toyota Camry. Both carry cellular phones and laptop computers  wherever they go, turning their vehicles into instant mobile offices.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Southmark Corp says Glen Adams has resigned as its chairman and chief executive as company continues to liquidate under reorganization plan; Charles Brewer is named president and chief executive and director (S)

headline: Shadowy Rebels Pose New Problems for Mexico
abstract: A half-hour's drive from Acapulco into the backlands of Guerrero state, the pulsing beat of the resort's jet-set discos fades into the splash of mothers pounding the family wash on river stones and the cries of children with rotten teeth and dysentery.         Guerrero looks, smells and sounds like a banana republic, and for decades governors from Mexico's ruling party have relied on a corps of murderous state riflemen to keep order in villages like Tepetixtla, 30 miles northwest of Acapulco, where peons harvest coffee for a dollar and a half a day.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: * Ronnie Cooke Newhouse was named creative director at CRK Advertising, New York, the in-house agency of Calvin Klein Inc., succeeding Fabien Baron, who had handled those duties as a consultant and will continue as a consultant to Klein. Ms. Cooke Newhouse had most recently been vice president and creative director at the Barneys New York unit of Barney's Inc. * Peter M. Winter was named president of Cox Interactive Media, a new unit of Cox Enterprises Inc., Atlanta. He was vice president for market development at Cox Newspapers.

headline: Serbs Object as Bosnian Dead Are Retrieved
abstract: Finnish experts working under United Nations auspices ignored Bosnian Serb objections today and recovered at least nine bodies believed to be those of Muslims killed escaping Srebrenica last year, said Alexander Ivanko, a United Nations spokesman.         "They may recover more bodies before the end of the day," Mr. Ivanko added. A worker in the morgue at Tuzla, where the remains were taken, said that by late today, 30 bodies had been recovered.

headline: In Bosnia's Voter Registration, Portents of Trouble
abstract: Bosnian elections scheduled for Sept 14 is bringing into open the contradictions within American-brokered Dayton peace accord; little-noticed provision allows Bosnians to vote either in place they lived before war started or where they currently reside; voter registration patterns of different groups in Lusci Palanka appear to be bearing out critics' worst fears by reflecting starkly different aims of Muslims, Serbs and Croats and suggesting possibility of violence on election day or soon after; voting is almost certain to be dominated by Serbs currently packed into village, who plan to use election to solidify control; photo; map (M)

headline: Open Short-Sale Positions Increase by 7.7% on Nasdaq
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers reports open positions on short sales on Nasdaq stock market rose 7.7 percent in month ending Sept 10 to 1.26 billion shares, up from month-earlier 1.17 billion shares; tables (S)

headline: 2 New Convictions Cast More Shadows on Colombian President
abstract: Two former political associates of President Ernesto Samper have been convicted of charges that they knowingly funneled drug traffickers' money into the President's campaign, the very activities for which Mr. Samper was exonerated by the Colombian Congress last month.         The convictions have cast a new shadow over Mr. Samper, and raised troubling  questions about a system that could send two people to jail on the basis of evidence deemed insufficient to convict the President, the principal beneficiary of the crime.

headline: Binding Pact On Emissions To Be Sought
abstract: Encouraged by a United States policy shift, government ministers today urged  industrialized nations to make legally binding commitments to reduce so-called greenhouse gases.         A joint statement issued at a conference on climate changes said emissions of carbon dioxide, methane and other heat-trapping gases must be significantly reduced before the year 2020, and legal instruments are needed to enforce the measures.

headline: The Bosnian Minuet
abstract: The tussle during the past few days in Bosnia between the Bosnian Serb leadership and the West was all hauntingly familiar.         First came the demand from the international community: Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb political leader who has been charged with war crimes, must leave power. Then came the threat: if Dr. Karadzic does not quit, economic sanctions will be imposed. Then came a vague promise by the Bosnian Serbs to comply, followed by no compliance.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Apple Surprises Wall Street by Cutting Losses
abstract: Defying gloomy predictions from Wall Street that have sent its stock to its lowest point in 10 years, Apple Computer reported a surprisingly small quarterly loss yesterday and said that it had stemmed a slide in its revenues.         The results were helped by a one-time after-tax gain of $39 million from the  sale of stock in America Online Inc.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;North Korea Says U.S. Is Hampering Oil Supply
abstract: North Korea accused the United States Congress today of trying to cut back on fuel oil that is supposed to be supplied under an agreement to freeze North Korea's nuclear weapons program.

headline: Gasoline Prices Fall Again
abstract: Gasoline prices at the pump in the United States fell for the second consecutive month in the period that ended on July 15 after reaching 15-year highs for the spring in May, the American Automobile Association said yesterday. Average United States prices for self-serve regular unleaded gasoline fell 2.9 cents, to $1.274 a gallon, the association said.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Olivetti Expected To Name New Chief
abstract: Olivetti S.p.A., the unprofitable Italian information technology company, is  expected to name a new chief executive today, analysts say.  The chairman, Carlo De Benedetti, may step down as co-chief executive, they said. The changes are expected to accelerate the shift by the company toward its telecommunications business and away from personal computers and office products.          Francesco Caio, the 38-year-old chief executive of Olivetti's telecommunications unit, Omnitel-Pronto Italia S.p.A., is seen as the most likely replacement for the co-chief executives, Corrado Passera and Mr. De Benedetti. Mr. Passera, 41, is leaving the company to join Banco Ambrosiano Veneto S.p.A..   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;LG Group to Build Plants in Britain
abstract: LG Group of South Korea said yesterday that it would invest $2.6 billion to produce semiconductors and electronics in Britain. LG Group said the project in  Newport, Wales, would be the largest single investment in Europe by a non-European company and predicted it would create 6,100 jobs. LG, South Korea's third-largest conglomerate, already makes televisions and microwave ovens in Britain.          Under the first phase of construction, LG is to invest $350 million to build an electronics plant by the end of 1997. The plant will produce two million monitors a year, and LG will invest another $340 million to double its capacity  by 2002. The company will then invest $1.9 billion to build a semiconductor plant by 1999.   (AP)

headline: Liberia's Press, Floored, Bounces Back, Swinging
abstract: Liberia's fiesty press, put out of business by recent factional warfare, is printing again in what many residents of capital of Monrovia regard as hopeful sign of return to life in dispirited and ravaged city; photo (M)

headline: Pepsico Plans $500 Million In Charges
abstract: Pepsico Inc says it is moving to revamp its international operations and that it will take total of more than $500 million in charges in third and fourth quarters to cover costs; moves seen as signal that Pepsico is losing its global soft-drink struggle with Coca-Cola; this is second time Pepsico has scaled back its international operations in last 15 years; foreign beverage sales accounted for about third of soft drinks Pepsico sold last year, but less than fifth of group's operating profits; analysts expect announcement to push down price of Pepsico shares, although early reaction among investors is positive; chart (M)

headline: Magazines You Won't Find In Publishers Clearinghouse
abstract: What has four colors, lives for barely two weeks and makes a lot of money?         The temporary magazine.

headline: From Bears to Bulls and Back Again
abstract: WHEN David Shulman, the chief equity strategist for Salomon Brothers, announced last December that he had finally turned bullish on the stock market,  it seemed as if the last bear on Wall Street had gone into hibernation. Suddenly, though, the bears are foraging everywhere.         Elaine Garzarelli, the strategist known as a market guru for having predicted the October 1987 crash, abruptly metamorphosed from rip-snorting bull to bear last week, sending stocks into a temporary tailspin and generating plenty of publicity. It was a stunning about-face for someone who had predicted just days  before, in this newspaper, that the Dow Jones industrial average would hit 6,400.

headline: Fierce Microbe Is Rising Worldwide Problem
abstract: Outbreaks of food poisoning caused by a fierce strain of E. coli bacteria like the one now going on in Japan have been growing around the world.         The bacterial strain, known as O157:H7, was first identified as a problem in  1982, but was generally recognized as a hazard by doctors only after 4 people died and 700 became ill in 1993 in the northwestern United States. The outbreak  was caused by undercooked hamburgers at Jack-in-the-Box restaurants.

headline: REMEDY'S STOCK SURGES ON EXPECTATIONS FOR YEAR
abstract: Shares of Remedy Corp rise 19 percent after company predicted higher-than-expected 1997 revenue and wider operating margins; stock rises $9.50, to $58 (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;U.S. Investigates American-British Airways Link
abstract: The Justice Department has opened an antitrust investigation of the proposed  alliance of American Airlines and British Airways to determine whether the arrangement would unfairly dominate the main air avenues to England and Europe.          A Justice Department spokesman, Bill Brooks, said today that the agency's antitrust division was reviewing the proposal to coordinate various services, including flight schedules, air fares, and passenger and cargo service.

headline: Allied Agrees to Purchase Laidlaw's Waste Operation
abstract: Allied Waste Industries says it will buy solid waste management operations of Laidlaw Inc for $1.34 billion in cash and stock; acquisition will transform Allied Waste into fourth-largest waste management company in nation behind WMX Technologies, Browning-Ferris Industries and USA Waste Service; this furthers wave of consolidation in solid waste management business (M)

headline: Stock Funds Seeing Cash Pour In Again
abstract: Market Place column notes mutual fund investors have stepped up their purchases of equity mutual funds this month, shrugging off concerns that bull market might be finished; net inflows to equity funds totaled $6.2 billion in July, down 57 percent from June's net inflows, but sharply higher than preliminary estimate made by Investment Company Institute; much of July's unexpectedly strong net inflows represent new purchases; graph (M)

headline: GTE ANNOUNCES A SECOND BUYBACK OF ITS SHARES
abstract: GTE Corp says it will buy back as many as 25 million shares of its stock and use shares it buys back for employee benefit and investment programs (S)

headline: Baxter Purchasing Immuno, Swiss Blood-Products Maker
abstract: Baxter International says it will buy Immuno Intenrnational AG, Swiss blood-products company, for $715 million; Baxter says acquisition would help it catch up to world's biggest maker of blood products, Centeon, a joint venture recently formed by Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc and Hoechst AG (M)

headline: Karadzic Is Out of Sight, But Not Out of Voters' Minds
abstract: Sept 14 election of Federal Parliament and three-member presidency in Bosnia is haunted by presence of Serb leader Radovan Karadzic, who has been indicted for war crimes and is not permitted to run for office; while Karadzic no longer appears in public, posters bearing his image adorn buildings in Sokolac, Serb-held stronghold, in defiance of Dayton peace accords; map; photo (M)

headline: F.C.C. Continues Airwave Auction
abstract: Federal Communications Commission to begin auctioning almost 1,500 advanced wireless communications licenses; licenses give winners right to provide next-generation cellular phone service known as personal communications services (PCS); licenses will be fourth, fifth and sixth PCS licenses to be sold per market nationwide and the last (S)

headline: Clinton or Dole? You Might Check Your Portfolio
abstract: Study by Liberty Financial Companies suggests that small stocks may have better chance of shining if Pres Clinton is re-elected, while big stocks may do better if Bob Dole wins; graph showing average annual returns of small stocks under Democratic and Republican Presidents since 1937 (S)

headline: HIGH COURT FINDS DAMAGE TO S.& L.'S FROM RULE CHANGE
abstract: In a case that could cost the Federal Government billions of dollars in breach-of- contract damages to the savings and loan industry, the Supreme Court  ruled today that the Government knowingly went back on its word through accounting changes that plunged three savings and loans into insolvency.         The lending institutions were trapped during the savings and loan bailout of  the 1980's after regulators had induced them to assume huge liabilities to salvage other savings and loans.

headline: Coke Expands Ties With Cliff Freeman
abstract: Coca-Cola Co expands its relationship with Cliff Freeman & Partners, awarding it assignment to produce worldwide creative work for Fanta line of soft drinks; billings not disclosed (S)

headline: Appeals Panel Lifts a Bar to Lloyd's Plan
abstract: Federal appeals court clears way for Lloyd's of London insurance organization's financial recovery plan; dismisses suit by American investors, granted two-month extension by Federal court to weigh deal, holding they had agreed to sue only in British courts (M)

headline: Lower Copper Prices Hurt Chilean Concern
abstract: Codelco, Chile's state-owned copper company, reports profits declined 17 percent, to $684.7 million, compared with $826 million year earlier (S)

headline: Gannett to Sell Its Outdoor Advertising Unit
abstract: The Gannett Company said yesterday that it would sell its outdoor advertising division, the largest in North America, to Outdoor Systems Inc., a much smaller  competitor, for $690 million in cash.         The acquisition will quintuple the size of Outdoor Systems, making it the biggest outdoor advertising company on the continent. Outdoor Systems went public in April and has seen its share price more than double since then.

headline: The Week of Investing Dangerously
abstract: IS it the Big One? That's what Californians ask every time crystal trinkets start to tap-dance on the bookshelves. And that's what investors ask these days  every time this space-traveling stock market slips.         That can be a stomach-churning question indeed for investors old enough to recall a certain Monday in October 1987. They know what a market free fall can do to the gut or the nervous system, and now gladly play "Where were you that day?" No, last week won't join the disaster pantheon, even though for a time the crystal was audibly skittering on Wall Street.

headline: Investors Pull Money Out of Stock Funds
abstract: Investors were clearly rattled by wild swings in the stock market, withdrawing $4 billion from stock mutual funds -- the largest weekly withdrawal  in four years.         While the data, released yesterday, do not reflect investor activity on Thursday and yesterday, when the stock market was calmer, they continue a trend.

headline: Ad Council Work Focuses on Children
abstract: Advertising Council is introducing two public service advertising campaigns centering on children; one drive is sponsored by council and Benton Foundation on behalf of Coalition for America's Children; other drive is for Crime Prevention Coalition and Justice Department and seeks to teach children how to minimize violence (S)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Havas Unit Chosen By Oppenheimer Funds
abstract: Oppenheimer Funds Inc. said yesterday that it had named the Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG unit of Havas Advertising in New York to create advertising for its mutual funds. Billings on the account, which has been inactive for a decade, have not been determined.          Bruce Dunbar, brand marketing director at Oppenheimer Funds in New York, confirmed a report of the assignment this week in Adweek. The decision came, he  said, after a two-month review that began with 15 agencies and had been narrowed to Messner Vetere and one other finalist, the Angotti, Thomas, Hedge unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Pixar Plans End To Commercials
abstract: Pixar Animation Studios, best known for its work on the film "Toy Story," said today that it would stop making commercials after finishing its current slate of projects so it can concentrate on longer-format and interactive entertainment.         Pixar will move the 18 employees who are currently producing commercials to other projects. The company employs about 200 people in all.

headline: Pentagon Sees A New Threat By Iraq Forces
abstract: Clinton Administration officials say that United States has stepped up its military activity in Persian Gulf region after detecting threatening movements by Iraqi troops against Kurdish districts in north, ordering forces to 'be prepared to deploy' if necessary; officials say Iraq has amassed 30,000 to 40,000 troops this week a few miles south of Erbil, village inside Kurdish zone in northern Iraq, which is under United Nations protection; map (M)

headline: Sumitomo Trust Plans to Buy 52 Planes
abstract: Sumitomo Trust and Banking Co announces plans to buy 52 passenger aircraft through two related companies from Boeing Co and Airbus Industrie for $4.2 billion; companies, Boullioun Aviation Service Inc and Singapore Aircraft Leasing Enterprises of Singapore, will use aircraft to expand their leasing operations; Singapore Aircraft Leasing is jointly owned by Boullioun and Singapore Airlines Ltd; Boullioun is wholly owned by Sumitomo Trust (S)

headline: Some Bosnia Voting Delayed Over Abuses
abstract: The Western official in charge of the September elections in Bosnia postponed municipal voting, citing abuses. The delay raised fears about whether the timetable for pulling out peacekeepers could be maintained.     Article, page A6.

headline: Korea's Romeos and Juliets, Cursed by Their Name
abstract: Centuries-old South Korean law, which bars couples with same name and same ancestral clan from marrying discussed; although practice may originally have been conceived as way of preventing incest, it has developed into strong ostracism of same-clan marriages; nearly 40 percent of population comes from three major clans, namely, Kim, Lee and Park; 22 percent of country's 44 million people are named Kim; photo; map (M)

headline: Agency's Report Supports Treasury's Debt Maneuvers
abstract: General Accounting Office, months after Republican leaders accused Clinton Administration of 'raiding' Government funds while trying to outmaneuver Congress during budget showdown, concludes that Treasury Secretary Robert E Rubin acted legally; report about Rubin's efforts to sidestep Congressionally set limit on nation's borrowing was commissioned by two Republicans, William V Roth, chairman of Senate Finance Committee, and Bill Archer, chairman of House Ways and Means Committee; but its conclusions are likely to disappoint Republican Presidential candidate Bob Dole, because it undercuts Republican argument that Clinton put billions in Federal funds at risk as he tried to sidestep that limit (L)

headline: Why a $120 Million Contract Makes Sense for Lakers
abstract: Article on why Los Angeles Lakers' signing of Shaquille O'Neal to record 7-year, $120 million contract makes business sense; says O'Neal's commanding presence is sure to sell more tickets, adding to Lakers' bottom line, but tickets are only part of the calculation; holds O'Neal should also increase sales of Lakers merchandise, raise team's take on local broadcasting contracts, attract more corporate sponsors--and make it more likely the Lakers advance to the playoffs, gathering added revenue; chart; photo (L)

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Arms-Control Program Backed by 30 Countries
abstract: Negotiators from more than 30 countries agreed today on a pact to control the arms trade.         The agreement covers conventional weapons and "dual-use technology," like computers that can be used to develop weapons. It is intended to keep arms from  reaching countries like Libya and Iran, where they could lead to destabilization.

headline: VALUJET INC. (VJET, NNM)
abstract: Valujet Inc posts $9.6 million second-quarter loss, compared with earnings of $16.9 million in 1995 period; table (S)

headline: DIARY: AEROSPACE;Space Travel Inc.
abstract: One short generation ago, space travel was a wondrous novelty, one that only  Washington's wondrously deep pockets could bankroll. Now it's just another business. Last week NASA picked Lockheed Martin to build a possible replacement  for the space shuttle; it would be this nation's first major new spacecraft in 25 years. NASA, you see, no longer wants to be in the business of owning and launching rockets -- it wants to stick to research. The goal is to have a fleet of rockets owned and operated by industry, hauling stuff aloft that's both public and private. And Lockheed says that with the X-33, it can do it at one-tenth the cost -- and one-tenth the risk. For one thing, all those things that drop off the current shuttle -- like booster rockets and fuel tanks -- will be gone. The X-33 stays in one piece.

headline: U.N. Plans to Hold Spending And Cut Staff by 30 Percent
abstract: United Nations, under pressure from Washington to cut costs and streamline itself, releases outline of its 1998-99 budget that projects no overall growth in expenditures for rest of century while staff reductions continue; by 2,000, UN will have reduced size of its permanent secretariat staff by 30% since 1985 (S)/

headline: AIDS Meeting: Signs of Hope, And Obstacles
abstract: The 11th international AIDS meeting opens here on Sunday with leading researchers' hopes as high as the sun-drenched mountains surrounding this Canadian seaport.         Remarkable gains in using combinations of costly new and old drugs promise to slow the progression of AIDS, if not stop it in its tracks, and to allow many people infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, to live longer and healthier lives, the researchers said in interviews.

headline: For Motorola, Computer Lead
abstract: Motorola Inc says it expects to ship computers based on the Power PC platform in the first quarter of 1997, beating Apple Computer Inc in offering machines that run Macintosh software as well and Microsoft's Windows NT (S)

headline: Corsica's Tourism, Stunted by Strife, Puts Hope in French Aid
abstract: Ongoing violence between Corsican groups that want independence from France has strangled island's summer tourist season most Corsicans depend on for living; officials say question is whether French Govt package of tax breaks and aid measures that would make island into special; economic zone in '97 can help end 20 years of violence (M)

headline: Philip Morris Sticks to Form and Raises Quarterly Dividend
abstract: Board of Philip Morris Companies votes to increase regular quarterly dividend by 20 percent, continuing string of increases that began almost three decades ago (M)

headline: Berlusconi Faces Trial With Craxi
abstract: PARIS—  Silvio Berlusconi and Bettino Craxi, two former prime ministers who have dominated Italian politics in recent years but who now face multiple corruption investigations, were indicted Friday and ordered to stand trial together on fraud and illegal party financing charges.

headline: Burmese Dissident Urges Western Sanctions to Oust Military
abstract: In a videotape smuggled out of Myanmar and made public today, the campaigner  for democracy and winner of the Nobel prize, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, issued a call for international sanctions to be imposed on her country to force political change on the military rulers.         "What we want are the kind of sanctions that will make it quite clear that economic change in Burma is not possible without political change," Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi said in the videotape, which was shown by members of the European Parliament.

headline: U.N. Assembly to Consider A-Test Ban Tomorrow
abstract: Australia and more than 115 other countries will present a resolution to United Nations General Assembly on Sept 9 seeking approval of a pact banning all nuclear explosions worldwide; unusual procedure is made necessary by India's decision to block accord's adoption through the normal process--consensus in the 61-member standing Conference on Disarmament in Geneva (M)

headline: Saudi Exile Warns More Attacks Are Planned
abstract: A militant Saudi dissident has warned that the terrorists who carried out bombing attacks against American soldiers in Saudi Arabia will also strike at British and French military personnel, adding that those responsible for the bombings in Riyadh and Dhahran that killed 26 "have a deep understanding in choosing their targets."         Speaking in an interview that was held in Afghanistan with The Independent, a British daily, Osama Bin Laden, a scion of a wealthy trading family who was stripped of his Saudi citizenship by King Fahd, said the bombers "hit their main enemy, which is the Americans."

headline: Stocks Lower in Japan
abstract: Stocks were lower here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues stood at 20,815.31, down 152.23 points, or 0.73 percent. On Monday, the index fell 157.36 points.

headline: N.A.S.D. Fines Rochester Brokerage Firm
abstract: The National Association of Securities Dealers said this week that H. J. Meyers & Company and 22 of its current and former brokers had been ordered to pay fines and refunds to investors totaling $1.5 million for overcharging 3,000  customers.         The firm was known as Thomas James Associates at the time of the violations.  The owner and chief executive of the Rochester-based firm, James A. Villa, was fined $25,000, censured and suspended for 20 business days. The fine was the fifth paid by the firm in the last decade and the third by Mr. Villa.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Victor in Russian Election Today Faces Economic Crisis Tomorrow
abstract: Russian voters will make a distinct and fateful choice in Wednesday's presidential election, but the economic and social problems that will surface after they cast their ballots will bedevil the Government no matter who wins.         Even if President Boris N. Yeltsin wins re-election, his Government will have little time for rejoicing. Tax revenues are dangerously low, while Government spending throughout the campaign was feverish and unaccounted for.

headline: Natural History at Unnatural Prices
abstract: Sales market for fossils and other natural-history objects, from ancient shark's teeth to Mars meteorites, noted; graph of some sales prices (S)

headline: Rebels Kill 80 in Strongest Attacks in Colombia in Decades
abstract: Left-wing rebels in Colombia mount one of deadliest offensives in decades, killing at least 80 soldiers and policemen in separate attacks across country; 54 soldiers are killed as rebels overrun army base in southwest; map; authorities blame FARC guerrilla movement, one of oldest in Latin America; unrest now is attributed to Pres Ernesto Samper's weakness in face of accusations of drug-related corruption (S)

headline: From Regional Brokers, Bets on Local Businesses
abstract: Regional stock brokerage firms in various areas of country note some of their favorite locally-based companies; map; advice on investing in such companies through regional brokers (S)

headline: Cups, Pots and Rituals:Hong Kong Museum Traces All the Tea in China
abstract: HONG KONG—  Whatever differences exist between the British and the Chinese, one belief has never been challenged by either: a cup of tea is more than just a cup of tea.

headline: AMERISTAR CASINOS STOCK TUMBLES BY 22%
abstract: Stock of Ameristar Casinos Inc falls 22% after company says it expects earnings for third and fourth quarters to be below Wall Street's expectations (S)

headline: SFX BROADCASTING AGREES TO BUY 4 STATIONS IN RICHMOND
abstract: SFX Broadcasting Inc to buy ABS Communications LLC for $37.5 million; deal will give it four Richmond radio stations (S)

headline: Yale International Rejects Acquisition Bid
abstract: Yale International Inc, formerly known as Spreckels Industries, says its board has rejected American Enterprises LLC's unsolicited acquisition offer of $16.50 a share, terming it inadequate (S)

headline: Two Attacks On Foreigners Raise Tension In Bosnia
abstract: Two attacks on foreigners, including the shooting of an American working for  the United States Embassy, have heightened tensions in Bosnia and may also increase concerns that any attempt by NATO forces to arrest Bosnian Serb leaders for war crimes could result in retaliation against foreigners.         The American, a woman whose name was not released, was shot in the back late  Friday night while she and her husband were driving between Kiseljak and Sarajevo. She was reported in stable condition after undergoing surgery at a NATO military hospital.

headline: Brute Strength! Africans Harness the Elephant
abstract: Owners of Imire Game Park in Marondera, Zimbabwe, launch unusual experiment to train elephants to perform work; even though animals are used in Asia for variety of chores, Africans have traditionally steered clear of their elephants, more skittish breed that kills people every year and is widely believed to be untrainable; zoo keepers and circus trainers say Southern African elephants are acutally more intelligent than Indian counterparts, and, with patience, quite trainable; photo; maps (M)

headline: Treasury Will Offer Both Bills and Notes at This Week's Auction
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two- and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday.         According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.13 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was 5.26 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was  offered at a price to yield 6.20 percent and the five-year note at 6.56 percent.

headline: William C. Trimble, Ex-Foreign Service Officer, 89
abstract: William Cattell Trimble, a retired Foreign Service officer, died last Monday  in his home in Brooklandville, Md. He was 89.         Mr. Trimble began his career as a vice consul in Seville, Spain, in 1931 and  finished it in 1968 as Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs.  In 1958, he became United States Ambassador to Cambodia, where he remained until 1962.

headline: In Los Angeles, War of Weeklies Erupts
abstract: Alternative papers are growing in circulation and revenue even as some dailies struggle; In Los Angeles, city's two largest alternative weeklies, New Times Inc and LA Weekly, are engaged in backbiting war to lure readers; photo (M)

headline: Caterpillar Acquisition
abstract: Caterpillar Inc. said today that it would acquire Fried. Krupp A.G.'s diesel  engine subsidiary, MaK Maschinenbau G.m.b.H. Officials at Caterpillar declined to disclose terms of the agreement. Caterpillar said the unit would retain the MaK brand name and operate as a distinct unit in association with Caterpillar's  engine businesses.  Based in Kiel, Germany, MaK had 1995 revenue of 541 million marks ($354 million). The company employs about 14,000 workers.

headline: Internet Sales Offer an Insurance Alternative
abstract: Advent of cybersales may force insurance companies to rethink traditional role of salesmen; so far, number of Internet shoppers is small, but relatively young people, who are already comfortable with Internet as resource for information or retail sales, are starting to turn to it for insurance needs as well; ranks of such shoppers are expected to swell; Internet insurance is now spreading beyond relatively simple term life policies; some companies have begun offering auto and individual health insurance, as well as specialized policies; many industry executives are resisting, citing possible breaches in security if networks were widely used for policy sales; those selling on Internet say they use complex encoding systems to protect buyers and that chances of losing material in cyberspace are remote; photo; drawings (M)

headline: WARNER-LAMBERT SHARES JUMP AFTER INVESTOR MEETING
abstract: Warner-Lambert Co shares hit record high amid speculation that Roche Holdings AG plans bid (S)

headline: Wall Street Questions Cost Of Bank Deal
abstract: Nationsbank makes expected $9.46-billion bid for Boatmen's Bancshares; Nationsbank stock falls 8 percent on analysts' view that price is too high; deal will bring Nationsbank colossus into seven new Midwestern and Southwest states; tables showing biggest US bank deals, ten largest US banks and comparing financial status of Nationsbank and Boatmen's Bancshares (M)

headline: Calls Home From Bosnia Can Shell a G.I.'s Wallet
abstract: Sole threat facing many American troops stationed in Vlasencia, Bosnia, is high cost of long-distance telephone service, coupled with constant temptation to call home; many report telephone bills of $500 or more each month; long-distance service is provided exclusively by AT&T; map; photo (M)

headline: Kazakstan Oil Deal
abstract: Hurricane Hydrocarbons Ltd of Alberta will buy 89.5 percent stake in Yuzhneftegaz, state-owned oil and natural-gas company in Kazakhstan (S)

headline: Canal Plus Is in a Deal For Nethold
abstract: Canal Plus SA of France says it will acquire Nethold BV of the Netherlands in $1.6 billion deal that would cement its position as Europe's biggest pay-television operator (M)

headline: Amoco Ends India Project
abstract: Amoco Corp drops plan to invest up to $1 billion in methane project in eastern India because it cannot reach accord with Indian Government (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ANN TAYLOR SHARES FALL ON LOWER SALES EXPECTATIONS
abstract: The shares of the Ann Taylor Stores Corporation fell yesterday as analysts said they expect the retailer's June same-store sales to drop for the 13th straight month. The stock fell $2.125, or 10 percent, to $18.125 on the New York Stock Exchange. The monthly same-store sales for the women's clothing chain based in New York have declined during the last year as merchandising miscues caused stores to display a mishmash of different styles instead of its traditional classic wares. Analysts said, however, that the retailer is now selling more clothing at full price, which lifts margins. Jeff Edelman, an analyst at Deutsche Morgan Greenfell, said that he expected Ann Taylor's June same-store sales to fall about 5 percent. He said the retailer could begin to report increases in September or October.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TAURUS EXPLORATION TO BUY METHANE PRODUCER
abstract: The Energen Corporation said yesterday that its Taurus Exploration unit had agreed to acquire methane-producing properties from Burlington Resources Inc. for $61 million. Energen said that along with the $26 million it has invested in conventional oil and gas reserves already this fiscal year, sole ownership of these properties would place it on track toward significantly improved financial performance in its 1997 fiscal year.

headline: Everybody Wants Rights To the King Of the Blues
abstract: B B King, legendary blues singer, is engaged in legal battle with operators of jazz clubs that bear his name in Memphis and elsewhere; Sidney Seidenberg, King's agent and manager, claims Beale Street Blues Co failed to meet contract agreements to pay King's licensing company minimum of $550,000 over five years from Memphis club and another $210,000 from Los Angeles club; suit contends operators have no further right to use of King's name; Beale Street Blues Co countersues, claiming King did not live up to his agreeement to appear at least four times at two clubs each year; photo (M)

headline: Bozell Worldwide joins in a venture to reach black consumers with nontraditional marketing.
abstract: Bozell Worldwide, nation's 11th-largest ad agency, joined with two partners to start Graham Gregory Bozell, which develops sponsored projects aimed at nation's black consumers; impetus was research showing that spending by black households outpaced spending in white households last year in categories such as children's apparel, foods and personal-care services (M)

headline: Serbs Evicted From Apartments in Sarajevo
abstract: The Bosnian police have evicted dozens of people, mainly Serbs, from apartments that once belonged to the Yugoslav Army, United Nations officials said today. Most of the apartments are in parts of Sarajevo that reverted to Bosnian Government control under the 1995 Dayton peace treaty.         Kris Janowski, a spokesman in Bosnia for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said people were being evicted even though they had valid papers from the Yugoslav army in the late 1980's. The army built the apartments when Bosnia was a member of the Yugoslav federation; it seceded in 1992.

headline: Chase Forms Venture Fund With Softbank
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp and Softbank Corp of Japan have agreed to invest $25 million each in new venture-capital fund focused on the Internet companies that are based in New York; so far Chase's venture arm, Chase Capital Partners, and Softbank, which has been spending billions of dollars lately on information technology investments, are only investors in the fund, called Flatiron Partners (L)

headline: Multi-Market Radio Deal
abstract: Multi-Market Radio Inc acquires radio station WKSS-FM in Hartford, Conn, from Precision Media Corp for $18 million (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BANK OF BOSTON CORP., Boston, said it had completed the acquisition of Baybanks  Inc., creating the nation's 15th-largest bank, with more than $60 billion in assets. The merged companies will be called BankBoston Corp.

headline: Rich Nations May Forgive Debt of Poor Nations
abstract: World's major industrial powers agree to forgive up to 80 percent of the debt owed to them by the poorest nations, primarily in Africa, if those countries agree to extraordinary economic reforms, including lower trade barriers, privatization of state industries and more openness toward foreign investment; agreement opens door to formal endorsement of the plan by World Bank and International Monetary Fund, which have issued most of the loans (M)

headline: ARCO EXPANDS PARTNERSHIP WITH RUSSIA'S LUKOIL
abstract: Atlantic Richfield Co expands partnership with AO Lukoil Holding, Russia's largest oil company, by signing $5 billion venture to jointly develop projects in former Soviet Union; agreement replaces earlier plan that called for US oil company to team up with Lukoil for $3 billion in projects over 10 years (S)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Scientology Suit Is Thrown Out
abstract: A Federal judge in Manhattan dismissed the last element yesterday of a $416 million libel suit brought by the Church of Scientology International against Time Warner Inc. and Time magazine, involving a 1991 article that described the  Scientology movement as "global racket."

headline: Fed Report Finds Growth Still Modest
abstract: Federal Reserve Board reports wages are rising as economy across most of nation continues to grow at moderate pace; sees little evidence yet of inflation taking root; report, based on survey of businesses by 12 regional Federal Reserve Banks, is latest to suggest that economy remains finely balanced between sustainable expansion and onset of inflation; economists who think economy will keep growing at strong pace see substantial risk of inflation; those who see economy slowing view inflation as less of threat despite low unemployment rate and upward pressure on wages; map (M)

headline: Stocks Higher, With Dow Gaining 17.38
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 17.38 points, to 5,711.27, on New York Stock Exchange trading volume of 310.5 million shares; table (M)

headline: Kidder to Pay $15 Million in Fraud Claim
abstract: Kidder, Peabody & Co agrees to pay $15 million to settle suit by Bonneville Pacific Corp bankruptcy trustee Roger G Segal charging it took part in reported securities fraud by firm (S)

headline: Independent Investigation Of Mattel Data Is Questioned
abstract: Earlier this year, Gary Lynch, a former top enforcement official at the Securities and Exchange Commission, was hired by Mattel Inc. to conduct an independent inquiry into allegations of questionable accounting practices at the toy maker. But now, a misdialed fax machine may raise questions about the independence of that investigation.         At issue: why did Mr. Lynch quickly forward to Mattel officials a letter he received from a lawyer suing the company that suggested areas in which he should concentrate his inquiry?

headline: Earnings at Deere Climbed By 13.3% in Third Quarter
abstract: Deere & Co says earnings rose 13.3 percent in third quarter; company earned $204.4 million, up from $180.1 million in the quarter a year earlier; revenue rose 9 percent, to $2.91 billion, from $2.67 billiion in quarter a year ago; agricultural equipment sales rose 18 percent, to $1.61 billion from $1.36 billion; table (M)

headline: Left and Right Turn Up Heat On Netanyahu About Hebron
abstract: Conflicting pressures on Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu to decide whether to honor Israeli pledge to withdraw its troops from most of West Bank town of Hebron are turned up a notch when his predecessor, Shimon Peres, meets with Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, and urges withdrawal, while leaders of his conservative Likud Party meet to resist; Netanyahu says he is still not ready to decide (M)

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Strength in U.S. Business Lifts Federal Express Earnings 32%
abstract: The Federal Express Corporation reported yesterday that earnings rose 32 percent in its fourth quarter ended May 31. The results well exceeded Wall Street's forecasts, as the company's American operations were strong.         Federal Express said net income in the quarter rose to $115.4 million, or $2.01 a share, from $87.2 million, or $1.54, in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue for the express package-delivery service rose 11 percent, to $2.74 billion from $2.47 billion.

headline: The Speed of Arbitration
abstract: Paul McDonough letter comments on advantage of arbitration and mediation to employees caught up in dispute with employerï

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Two Developments In Ads on Taxicabs
abstract: Two developments involving taxicab advertising were announced yesterday.         The Medallion Financial Corporation in New York acquired See Level Advertising in New York, which owns 453 taxi rooftop advertising signs. Terms were not disclosed. As a result of the acquisition, Medallion's ownership of such signs on New York City cabs increased to 1,861. Medallion also has taxi rooftop ad operations in Atlanta, Boston, Miami and Philadelphia.

headline: Where's Rose Mary Woods When You Need Her?
abstract: Nixon: The CD-ROM" could have used a Rose Mary Woods.         Ms. Woods, you may recall, was the White House secretary blamed for cutting 18 minutes from one of Richard Nixon's potentially damaging Watergate tapes. An  equally forceful editor might have been in order for this new CD-ROM account of  Nixon and Watergate, which contains a potentially damaging number of spelling and proofreading errors.

headline: That Cold Caller Might Have Been Me
abstract: Murray Bromberg comment on his experiences 'cold-calling' potential stock investors (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;UNIT OF BAIN CAPITAL IN DEAL FOR A RIVAL
abstract: Wesley-Jessen, a contact lens maker, signed an agreement yesterday to acquire a rival, Pilkington Barnes Hind, for about $79 million. Pilkington, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., a seller of contact lenses, reported sales of $125 million in its latest fiscal year. Wesley-Jessen, which is based in Chicago and expects 1996 revenue of $125 million, is owned by Bain CapitalInc., an investment firm in Boston with holdings in more than 80 companies.

headline: BRADLEES PLANNING TO CLOSE 14 UNPROFITABLE STORES
abstract: Bradlees Inc, bankrupt discount retailer, says it will close 14 unprofitable stores in Northeast within next few months in move to shore up its losses and complete its Chapter 11 reorganization (S)

headline: Clinton Likely to Visit China in 1997 if He Is Re-elected
abstract: Celebrating an apparent warming in relations, Chinese and American officials  said today that they expect President Clinton to visit China sometime next year  if he is re-elected. In return, President Jiang Zemin would visit Washington.         As President Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, concluded two days of meetings with China's top leaders, officials from both countries stressed the positive side of their relationship.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.25   5.30   5.75        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.18   5.13   5.14        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.30   5.26   5.27        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.81   6.83   6.24        30-YR. TREAS. headline: Drunken Driving Is No Joke
abstract: To the Editor:

headline: Discovery and BBC Plan Joint Programming Venture
abstract: Discovery Communications Inc and British Broadcasting Corp announce joint venture under which Discovery will spend more than $500 million to produce new programs and start cable and satellite television channels in United States and around the world with BBC Worldwide Ltd, commercial arm of BBC (M)

headline: U.N. Panel Says Qaddafi Violated Air Curbs
abstract: A United Nations sanctions committee said today that flights by Libyan aircraft taking Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, to and from an Arab  summit meeting in Cairo last month violated sanctions imposed in 1992. The committee said it would consider seeking tougher curbs if the violation was repeated.         Libya has been the target of United Nations sanctions -- including an air flight ban -- for failing to surrender for trial two men indicted in Britain and the United States on charges of bombing a Pan Am airliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988, killing 270 people.

headline: Perry Accepts The Blame In Saudi Blast, But Not All
abstract: Defense Sec William J Perry tells House National Security Committee that he is to blame for any 'failure of leadership' that may have resulted in terrorist bombing in Saudi Arabia in June that killed 19 US airmen; acknowledges that Gen Binford Peay 3d, head of US Central Command, deserves criticism for lax security measures at Khobar Towers (M)

headline: Treasury Securities Prices Mixed
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities are mixed in thin trading; day's statistics, July business inventories, have little impact on market, as traders look ahead to Fed's monetary policy meeting next week; graph (M)

headline: Liggett's Tobacco Settlement In Danger of Coming Undone
abstract: Liggett Group, which stunned and infuriated its larger rivals in tobacco industry in March by agreeing to settle lawsuits, is negotiating to avoid being dragged back into the litigation; Liggett's initial settlement agreements have already resulted in first damage payments ever by a tobacco company--$1 million to five of the states that sued the industry seeking compensation for smoking-related health care expenditures (L)

headline: Trade groups square off against tobacco restrictions, but not all agencies agree.
abstract: Madison Avenue advertising agencies are officially a fierce and aggressive opponent of regulations to restrict selling and marketing tobacco products that Pres Clinton is expected to announce on Aug 23; yet many agency executives support the curbs, particularly if they are aimed primarily at minors--and some seek even more severe sanctions (L)

headline: Tobacco Shares Lead Drop As Dow Falls 31.44 Points
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 31.44 points, to 5,689.82; table (M)

headline: French Insurer Plans Sale of Bank Subsidiary
abstract: Groupe des Assurances Nationales to sell majority of its stake in CIC, network of banks, in a private placement; sale is part of preparation for parent company's sale to private investors (S)

headline: Johnson & Johnson Fights to Retain Its H.I.V. Test Unit
abstract: Johnson & Johnson filed suit today, seeking to overturn an arbitrator's ruling that it must hand control of its H.I.V. home-testing business back to an  executive whom the arbitrator said the company had wrongfully dismissed.         On Friday, John J. Gibbons, the arbitrator, ordered Johnson & Johnson to give the former executive, Elliott Millenson, "all assets necessary" to put him in operating control of the business he founded for home-testing of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. The order was reported in The Wall Street Journal today.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;LOCKHEED SELLING MARTIN MARIETTA MATERIALS
abstract: The Lockheed Martin Corporation, the world's largest aerospace and military contractor, said yesterday that it would divest itself of its 81 percent stake in Martin Marietta Materials Inc. of Raleigh, N.C., a supplier of sand, stone and gravel aggregates used to build roads and other projects. The holding is worth an estimated $840 million. Lockheed Martin said it would offer its own shareholders the chance to swap stock for a total of 37.35 million shares in the materials company. Lockheed has not disclosed how many material shares will  be given to holders for each Lockheed share turned in.

headline: Castro Scornful of Clinton
abstract: President Fidel Castro today derided President Clinton's decision to approve  new sanctions against some companies investing in Cuba but to suspend action for six months.         Mr. Castro said Mr. Clinton was "pulling the world's leg."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL TO ACQUIRE BROOKTREE
abstract: The Rockwell International Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the Brooktree Corporation for $15 a share in cash, or about $275 million. Rockwell plans to take a one-time charge estimated at $120 million, when it completes the acquisition, for research and development that is in progress. Brooktree, based in San Diego, manufactures high-performance digital and mixed-signal integrated circuits for computer graphics, multimedia, imaging and communications applications. It had sales of $138 million in the 1995 fiscal year and has about 575 employees. Rockwell has operations in automation, avionics, aerospace, military electronics, semiconductor systems and automotive  component systems. Rockwell's stock fell 75 cents, to $56.625.

headline: 5 Nations Agree on a Strategy To Monitor Lebanon Cease-Fire
abstract: The United States and four other countries have given final approval to long-stalled arrangements to monitor a cease-fire in Lebanon, the State Department said today.         The monitoring group, expected to be based in the Lebanese border town of Naqura, would observe compliance with the April 27 cease-fire, which ended a 17-day Israeli attackagainst Party of God guerrillas in southern Lebanon.

headline: Jaguar Considers A Small Model
abstract: Jaguar, the British luxury auto maker owned by the Ford Motor Company, is considering a small car to compete with some of the best-selling models of BMW and Mercedes-Benz of Germany.         But a spokeswoman said a decision was still a long way off. The car would compete with BMW's 3-series and the C-class sedans of Mercedes, a unit of Daimler-Benz. Both lines attract younger, less affluent customers.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Wheat Prices Fall Second Day After China Cancels Big Order
abstract: Wheat prices fell for the second day after China announced that it had canceled a purchase of more than 725,000 tons of United States hard red winter wheat.         In other markets, gasoline fell while copper rose to its highest price in more than a month.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Sumitomo Estimate of Loss Grows in Copper Scandal  Sumitomo said the losses incurred by Yasuo Hamanaka, its former chief copper trader, had increased to $2.6 billion, $800 million higher than earlier, and that it would request that criminal charges be filed against him.    Much uncertainty remained, but Sumitomo seemed to be trying to put the scandal behind it, giving few details of how the trader could have hidden such losses or whether others might have cooperated with him. $(Page D3.$)    Showdown Over Wireless Taps   The wireless communications industry voted to reject Government-backed technology that would make it possible for law enforcement agencies to keep closer tabs on cellular telephone users. $(A1.$)    Fraud Charges Against Merrill Seen   Merrill Lynch has been told by regulators that they intend to charge it with disclosure fraud in connection with the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., lawyers said. $(D2.$)     A Big Gain In Construction   Builders broke ground on new homes and apartments at the fastest rate in nearly two and a half years during August. Housing starts, which were predicted to decline modestly, instead increased 4.5 percent. $(D2.$)    After the housing report, bond yields rose because of fears of rising inflation and an increase in interest rates by the Fed. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond was 7.04 percent, up from 7.01 percent on Wednesday. $(D13.$)     2 Big Ad-Agency Companies to Join   The stampede of acquisitions involving advertising-agency companies continued, but with a twist: the buyer is smaller than the seller. BDDP in Paris, the 15th-largest agency company in the world, agreed to be acquired by GGT in London, the 22d largest. $(D5.$)    Settlement in Comparator Case   The S.E.C. settled cases against Comparator Systems, a company that had no successful products but that somehow became valued at a billion dollars, and two officials who had been accused of issuing financial reports that overstated the company's assets.  Floyd Norris: Market Place.$(D6.$)     Group to Buy Ryder Rental Unit   Questor Partners Fund and a group of other investors plan to buy Ryder System's rental truck division for about $575 million. $(D16.$)    Olivetti's New Chief  Carlo de Benedetti may no longer be the chairman of Olivetti, the computer maker, but he remains a powerful shareholder. With this leverage, his representatives on the board ousted the company's chief executive and installed Roberto Colaninno, above, who headed an auto parts company controlled by Mr. de Benedetti. $(D3.$)    Insurance Accord In Congress   House and Senate leaders agreed on two major health insurance proposals, directing insurance companies to offer comparable coverage for mental and physical illnesses and to guarantee mothers coverage for at least 48 hours of hospital care after childbirth. $(A20.$)    I.B.M. said it would provide benefits to the partners of lesbian and gay employees. It is the largest employer yet to extend health care coverage to couples of the same sex. $(A18.$)    Barneys Parent Seeks to End Deal   The parent company of Barneys New York, which filed for bankruptcy protection last January, said it was seeking to end a licensing agreement with its partner, Isetan. $(D6.$)

headline: Belgrade Journal;In Yugoslavia, Traditional Gypsy Bands Play On
abstract: Brass instruments and snare drums dangling from black leather straps stretched across their chests, the musicians of the Unity Orchestra crept on tiptoe down a small, dimly lighted street in the Belgrade suburb of Zemun.         When they reached a wooden gate, directed by a young man, the musicians briefly assembled, before beginning a cacophonous rendition of a traditional Gypsy dance tune.

headline: Rebels' New Cause: A Book for Yankee Bashing
abstract: Interview with Zhang Xiaobo, former Chinese pro-democracy rebel who has written The China That Can Say No, best-selling book that gives voice to anti-Americanism and has won praise from Communist party officials, all way up to Pres Jiang Zemin; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent

headline: There Oughta Be a Law
abstract: Laws -- the theoretical variety, not those made by governments -- have been part of science since before Sir Isaac Newton, his apple and what became known as Newton's Law of Gravitation. But the practice among physicists of observing a phenomenon, creating a testable hypothesis, then sometimes elevating that hypothesis to a named law has become a popular hobby in other fields. For example, the laws of motion in physics have been joined by the laws of markets in economics.         And as information technology and computer science have risen to prominence  in the economy, they have given rise to a few laws of their own. These lie somewhere between the laws of physics, which are not all exactly true, and the laws of economics, which are not all exactly false. Einstein showed that Newton's laws were false, except for practical purposes. As for the various laws of economics, we can expect one to prove true any day now, but don't hold your breath.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Microsoft Plans to Blend Windows and the Web Microsoft, in its push to control the Internet market the way it dominates personal computing, is preparing to release software that could bring a fundamental change in the way people use PC's.

headline: Profits Jump at SGS-Thomson Microelectronics
abstract: SGS-Thomson Microelectronics N.V., Europe's biggest independent chip maker, reported a sharp gain in second-quarter profits today despite a slowdown in the  chip market.         The company said earnings for the quarter rose 44 percent, to $176.1 million, or $1.27 a share, from $122.6 million, or 95 cents, in the second quarter a year earlier. The results surpassed Wall Street expectations of $1.13 a share, according to a survey of four analysts by the Zacks Investment Research Corporation. Revenue rose 19.2 percent in the quarter to $1.05 billion.

headline: Hal Riney Gets Cox Unit Account
abstract: Cox California PCS, Cox Communications Inc unit, selects Hal Riney & Partners as first agency to handle advertising for its new wireless phone service (S)

headline: Hard Times for Millions As Argentina Slims Down
abstract: When Francisco Pena, a 48-year-old mechanic, hears talk of the "economic miracle" that Domingo Cavallo performed in Argentina as Finance Minister, he shakes his head and wonders if he is living in the same country.         Mr. Pena, who has not found steady work since he was laid off four years ago, says he barely makes enough money to feed his family of five and cannot even afford the beef for which this country is famous.

headline: Heirs and Elders Out in the Cold
abstract: Survey by Roper/Starch Worldwide for Massachusetts Financial Services finds that affluent Americans in the so-called 'sandwich generation' are lagging in the estate planning and other steps necessary to provide for aging parents and adult children (S)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Campbell-Ewald Promotes 3 Executives
abstract: Three executives at Campbell-Ewald Advertising, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in Warren, Mich., have been promoted as part of a long-planned reorganization as Richard D. O'Connor, chairman and chief executive, plans for his retirement on Jan. 1.          Effective immediately, Anthony J. Hopp, 51, vice chairman and chief operating officer, becomes chief executive; Mr. O'Connor, 64, continues as chairman. Frank E. Hoag, 53, president, assumes the post of chief operating officer. Also, Mr. Hoag relinquishes his duties as chief executive of C-E Communications, a Campbell-Ewald affiliate, to Louis M. Schultz, 51, president of C-E Communications.

headline: Lloyd's to Proceed With a Revamping
abstract: Lloyd's of London says it received enough support from money-losing investors to proceed with revamping that will keep it solvent (S)

headline: Profit Motive Clouding Effort To Buy Up A-Bomb Material
abstract: United States Enrichment Corp, US Government-owned corporation charged with acquiring much of Russia's military stockpile of uranium for resale as civilian reactor fuel, has turned down repeated Russian offers to sell material sufficient to build 400 bombs, raising question of whether it is putting profits ahead of national security; Russian fuel is competing with fuel corporation itself makes from American uranium, and handling of Russian uranium makes considerably less money for corporation than it can make from its own operations (M)

headline: W. R. Grace-Fresenius Deal Is Cleared
abstract: Shareholders of W R Grace & Co and Fresenius USA Inc approve $4.4 billion merger of their dialysis businesses to create Fresenius Medical Care AG (S)

headline: Alcoa Cuts 2,900 Jobs, As Expected
abstract: Aluminum Company of America says it will reduce its work force by about 4%, cutting 2,900 jobs (S)

headline: World News Briefs;In New Attack, Russians Hit Chechen Rebel Base
abstract: Russian troops carried out a new attack in Chechnya over the weekend, on what they described as a well-fortified rebel base in southern Chechnya.         The assault, which began on Saturday, was a new stage of an offensive against Chechen separatist fighters that began after President Boris N. Yeltsin was re-elected on July 3. The attack broke a cease-fire negotiated during the election campaign.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MELLON BANK CORP., Pittsburgh, expanded its commercial equipment-leasing business with a definitive agreement to acquire FUL Inc., a privately held company that operates as First United Leasing. Financial terms were not disclosed.     TERADYNE INC., Boston, a maker of automatic test equipment for the electronics and telecommunications industries, plans to buy back 5 million common shares of its stock. The company has about 85 million common shares outstanding.

headline: CS Holding Sets Job Reductions
abstract: CS Holding says it reached agreement with employee organizations on how to eliminate 3,500 Swiss jobs that are to be cut as part of bank's reorganization 'almost entirely' without dismissals; banks says early-retirement program would account for about 1,500 jobs, while rest would be cut by increasing the share of part-time jobs to 20 percent from 16 percent (S)m

headline: New Life Insurance Isn't Always the Best Policy
abstract: Insurance regulators are taking steps to halt the practice called churning or twisting, in which an agent persuades a customer to trade in his old whole-life or universal life policy for a new one on the basis of unrealistic yield projections; graph (M)

headline: It's Not a Pretty Movie (It Wasn't a Pretty War)
abstract: Belgrade Journal: It's Not a Pretty Movie (It Wasn't a Pretty War)*Pretty Villages, Pretty Flames, searing film about Balkan conflict by Serbian director Srdjan Dragojevic, paints unflattering picture of men who fought for Greater Serbia; portrays Bosnian Serb fighters as petty criminals, thugs and drug addicts and offers many moviegoers first view of war outside prism of Serbian nationalism; photo (M)

headline: Patents;A 'fish' with a mission: hang out in shallow waters and listen for anything, say, fishy.
abstract: IT sounds like the makings for a scene from a Tom Clancy novel: a surveillance device disguised as a fish detects the presence of an enemy frogman laying a mine in a busy harbor.         James L. Pickens, an engineer in Vicksburg, Miss., said he had helped invent  a fish that might do just that.

headline: STOCK UP AT ARGYLE AS IT STUDIES SALE
abstract: Shares of Argyle Television Inc rise 23 perent after company says it is exploring possibility of selling the company or taking other strategic steps; Argyle Television owns stations in markets that include Grand Rapids, Mich, Buffalo, NY, Providence, RI, and Fort Smith, Ark (S)

headline: The Real North Korea: The Bustle of a Mausoleum
abstract: Three-day Government-sponsored conference aimed at attracting investors to new free-trade zone in North Korea gives foreigners rare glimpse into North Korean life; two towns in new zone, Rajin and Sonbong, had been spruced up for visitors, but people there cannot speak freely, and any foreigner leaving conference site is followed by security agents; foreigners are struck by the silence--the lack of hustle and bustle found in other Asian countries; photo; map (M)

headline: With Little Fanfare and Facing Crisis, U.N. Starts a New Year
abstract: UN General Assembly begins 51st session without ceremony, in financial crisis and with uncertainty over who Secertary General will be when session ends on Dec 23 (M)

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: LOCKHEED MARTIN CORP., Bethesda, Md., the aircraft maker, agreed to buy $90 million of spare parts from Taiwan.

headline: A Fervent Traditionalist in Japan (an American?)
abstract: Article profiles Alex Kerr, 44-year-old American devotee of kabuki and calligraphy who resides in Japan, and who has emerged as prominent spokesman for country's environment and traditions; photo; map (M)

headline: Credit Offerings During the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.89 percent and on a six-month bill, 5.02 percent.

headline: Apple Computer Shifts Course on Its New Operating System
