But in the last two weeks of the month, many fund managers were scrambling just to hide the carnage caused by a swift downturn in those same stocks.

headline: Advertising;The Olympics start to look more and more like the Super Bowl.
abstract: HIS just in from the BBDOlympics: Visa Gold, Centrum Silver, Clinique Bronze  Gel.         So far, anyway, the 1996 Summer Games seem like the BBDOlympics because in between lachrymose tales of athletes overcoming asthma, Communism or logistical  foul-ups -- or all three -- to compete for medals, the marketing aspects of the Centennial Olympiad are looming as large as, well, that fiery red clay cauldron resembling a Presidential-sized portion of McDonald's french fries.

headline: Empire Is Emerging from a Cloud
abstract: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New York, which is converting to for-profit insurer, has been plagued by scandals in the past; in 1993, while company was enduring huge losses, investigation found that it was offering lucrative contracts to insiders and lavished perquisites on its executives; company's president, Albert E Cardone, and two other top executives, were forced to resign, and state created oversight panel to monitor Empire's operation (M)

headline: Market Place;Municipal bond investors could wind up in an I.R.S. crackdown.
abstract: BUYERS of municipal bonds beware: The Federal Government is cracking down on  an illegal price-gouging practice in which bond underwriters overcharge municipal issuers for securities used to set up bond escrow funds. In the process, the I.R.S. may wind up hurting investors who bought the bonds.         This week, the Treasury outlined rule changes aimed at increasing bond issuers' reliance on a special type of Treasury security specifically intended for escrow accounts. By making the securities more attractive, Treasury officials say, they hope to encourage their use and eliminate the opportunities  for underwriters to sell issuers Treasury securities at illegally high prices -- a practice known in the municipal bond market as yield burning.

headline: Bruno's Picks D.M.B.& B. for Account
abstract: Bruno's Inc unit of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co names D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York to handle its account; billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million (S)

headline: Hoping for Green in the Pink Sheets, but Seeing Red
abstract: Unlisted issues, called penny stocks or pink-sheet stocks, have allure during bull market, but are highly risky; these stocks, not listed on major exchanges, are traded by dealers over the telephone and priced on the OTC Bulletin Board or the 'pink sheets'; Bulletin Board trade has grown from 57 million shares in December 1995 to 78 million shares in June 1996 and new investments aids have appeared, including Walker's Manual of Unlisted Stocks; chart of selected stocks (M)

headline: Olivetti Talks With France Telecom
abstract: PARIS—  France Telecom and Italy's Olivetti group are in talks aimed at forging a new strategic alliance that could lead to the French state telephone monopoly's eventually buying an equity stake in the troubled Italian company, according to executives close to the discussions.

headline: British Business For Devon Direct
abstract: British Telecommunications names Devon Direct Marketing and Advertising to handle its consumer direct-marketing account; Deutsch Inc opens a direct-marketing unit, named Direct Deutsch (S)

headline: Poland Is Resisting U.S. Call That It Sell Tanks to Bosnia
abstract: Polish Government, in bow to European Union but rebuff to US, is resisting selling battle tanks to Bosnian Army; special Clinton Administration envoy to Balkans, James W Pardew Jr, will visit Warsaw within days in effort to persuade Warsaw to aid controversial program to train and equip army of Muslim and Croatian federation, which controls about half of Bosnia, while Serbs control rest (M)

headline: After 50 Years, German Court Exonerates Anti-Hitler Pastor
abstract: Berlin court formally exonerates Dietrich Bonhoeffer, Lutheran theologian who joined resistance against Hitler and was executed for activities during closing days of World War II; ruling is seen by most Germans as righting one of great wrongs of postwar history (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;J. C. PENNEY IN TALKS TO BUY FAY'S DRUGSTORES
abstract: The J. C. Penney Company is in talks to buy Fay's Inc., a move that would expand J. C. Penney's Thrift Drug chain. Fay's, the 12th-biggest drugstore chain in the United States, has 272 stores, less than half the number owned by Thrift  Drug, the 9th-biggest chain, with 645 stores. Fay's stock rose $1.375, or almost 16 percent, to $10. At that price its market capitalization is about $209 million. Sales at Fay's, based in Liverpool, N.Y., rose 5.5 percent in the first quarter, to $248.6 million, with same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least a year, rising 4.4 percent. Thrift Drug's sales in its latest fiscal year rose to $1.85 billion from $1.54 billion in the period a year earlier.

headline: More Information On Olivetti Is Sought
abstract: Consob, Italian stock market regulatory agency, says it is asking Olivetti SpA to provide further information about its financial situation; market uncertainty about Olivetti's financial situation has been heightened since Renzo Francesconi, company's director general, resigned last week, questioning validity of half-year results (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PAINE WEBBER CLASS ACTION SETTLEMENT APPROVED
abstract: A Federal judge has approved a settlement estimated to be worth $200 million  in a class-action lawsuit against Paine Webber Inc. related to its sale of limited partnerships. Paine Webber Group Inc., the parent company of the brokerage, said the settlement would not cost it anything more than the reserves it had already set aside. The settlement provides $125 million in cash and additional guarantees valued at $75 million, according to Nicholas Chimicles, the lawyer who headed a committee of law firms that represented 150,000 disgruntled investors. The value of the guarantees could change as the value of  the partnerships fluctuate. Paine Webber guaranteed that some of the plaintiffs  would get their original investments back by the year 2000. It guaranteed for others, depending on which partnership they had invested in, minimum payments by the same year. Paine Webber will pay the $125 million in cash to those who had invested in partnerships without guarantees, Mr. Chimicles said. Paine Webber brokers sold about $2.5 billion in real estate, energy and other limited partnerships between 1980 and 1992. Investors contended the brokers misrepresented the risks involved, used fraudulent marketing materials and collected inflated fees. In January, Paine Webber said it had agreed to pay $292.5 million to settle client claims.

headline: Ex-Policeman's Jail Term Hailed by Women in India
abstract: Conviction of India's best-known police officer, K P S Gill, for slapping woman's backside at party eight years ago, and his sentencing to three months in jail and $20 fine have been hailed by women's groups as landmark in struggle for women's rights; Gill retired at end of 1995 as director general of police in Punjab State (M)

headline: U.S. Presses Effort to Remove Indicted Bosnian Serb Leader
abstract: Negotiations here that the Clinton Administration hopes will succeed in ousting Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb political leader, and thus pave the way for smooth elections in Bosnia and Herzegovina dragged on inconclusively into the early hours of thise morning.         At midnight Richard C. Holbrooke, the special United States envoy to the Balkans, who has shuttled to Belgrade, Sarajevo and Zagreb in the last few days, was uncharacteristically silent, saying through a spokesman that he would have no statement overnight.

headline: Thugwane Wins Closest-Ever Marathon : South African Triumphs As Games Come to Close
abstract: ATLANTA—  Josia Thugwane was anonymous within the large crowd of marathoners shuffling early Sunday morning, eyes down, past the birthplace of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Two hours later, he returned to the Olympic Stadium as the first black South African to win an Olympic gold medal, a scar shining on his chin where he had been shot five months before.

headline: Corrections
abstract: A table last Sunday with an article about the growing popularity of home exercise equipment misstated the industry's annual sales in the United States. The amounts were in billions of dollars, not millions.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TELECOMMUNICATIONS CONCERN HIRES FINANCIAL ADVISER
abstract: The Diana Corporation said yesterday that it had retained the investment banking firm Hambrecht & Quist as a financial adviser to evaluate the company's  alternatives, including separating the company's units. The company, a Milwaukee-based maker of telecommunications equipment, has been struggling of late and has said its board is looking into a major reorganization. The company's stock price, which was above $100 a share in May, has been buffeted by speculation about the prospects for its Internet-switching technology, which  it has touted as allowing Internet-service providers cheaper access to the Net.

headline: World News Briefs;Canadian Company Invests in Cuban Tourism
abstract: A Canadian company has signed a deal with the Cuban state hotel company to build 11 hotels and other tourist attractions, Cuban news organizations reported today.         The agreement appeared to be the largest single investment Cuba has secured for its tourism industry. It represented a significant boost for Cuba in the face of recent United States legislation aimed at discouraging foreign investment in Cuba.

headline: THE NEW YORK TIMES BUSINESS BEST SELLERS
abstract: HARD COVER  THIS MONTH  LAST MONTH  1      1  THE DILBERT PRINCIPLE by Scott Adams (Harperbusiness, $20). The creator of the Dilbert comic strip satirizes management manuals.    +2      2  THE SEVEN SPIRITUAL LAWS OF SUCCESS By Deepak Chopra (Amber-Allen/New World Library, $14). How to ''generate wealth in all its forms.''  3      4  WALL STREET MONEY MACHINE by Wade Cook (United Support Association, $24.95). Strategies for enhancing cash flow and wealth.    4      3  HIT AND RUN by Nancy Griffin and Kim Masters (Simon & Schuster, $25). How the movie industry producers Jon Peters and Peter Guber came to tbe chosen by Sony to run Columbia Pictures.    +5      -  RAVING FANS by Kenneth Blanchard and Sheldon M. Bowles (Morrow, $20). How to make customer service more than lip service.    +6      -  INSIDE THE TORNADO by geoffrey A. Moore (Harperbusiness, $25). Marketing strategies gleaned from ''hyper growth'' high technology companies.    +7      -  HOW TO THINK LIKE A C.E.O. by D.A. Benton (Warner Books, $23.95). Free to be the top brass, in 22 attitude-changing steps.    +8      -  BEYOND RE-ENGINEERING by Michael Hammer (Harperbusiness, $25). Processes replace tasks in the workplace of the 21st century.    9      -  WHERE WIZARDS STAY UP LATE by Katie Hafner and Matt Lyon (Simon & Schuster, $24). The originas of the Internet.    +10     7  LEADERSHIP SECRETS OF THE ROGUE WARRIOR by Richard Marcinko (Pocket, $20). A former Navy officer applies combat principles to business.      PAPERBACK    THIS MONTH  LAST MONTH  +1      1  THE SEVEN HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE by Stepehn R. Covey (Fireside/S&S, $12). Principles for success.    2      4  GET A FINANCIAL LIFE by Beth Kobliner (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $11). Financial planning for people in their 20's and 30's.    3      3  STILL PUMPED FROM USING THE MOUSE by Scott Adams (Andrews & mcMeel, $9.95). Dilbert, the comic-strip engineer, presents workplace farce.    +4      5 BEING DIGITAL by Nicholas Negroponte (Vintage, $12). Computers and our future.    5      -  THE 1996 WHAT COLOR IS YOUR PARACHUTE? by Richard Nelson Bolles (Ten Speed Press, $14.95). Advice about careers.    *5     -  DIVIDED LIVES by Elsa Walsh (Anchor/Doubleday, $14). Professional women balance work and family.      Rankings are based on august sales figures of 3,985 bookstores and of wholesalers serving 50,000 hard-cover retailers and 60,000 paperback retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets). The numbers ares statistically weighted to represent sales in all such outlets nationwide. An asterick indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.    +Some bookstores report receiving bulk orders of these titles.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Italy Treats a Top Mafia Leader's Repentance With Caution
abstract: Giovanni Brusca, top Mafia boss who was arrested last May after six years as fugitive, is cooperating with Italian prosecutors; Italian officials say they are treating his collaboration with caution, taking into account that his 'repentance' could be ruse to escape harsh prison terms given ranking Mafia bosses; photo of Brasca under arrest in Palermo, Sicily (M)

headline: Pavel Sudoplatov, 89, Dies; Top Soviet Spy Who Accused Oppenheimer
abstract: Lt Gen Pavel A Sudoplatov, legendary Soviet spymaster, dies at age 89; exploits, including death of Leon Trotsky, recounted; photo (S)

headline: Expanding the Boundaries of E-Mail
abstract: JFAX Personal Telecom, a company headed by Jaye Muller, a musician from former East Germany now based in Manhattan, provides an E-mail-based service that allows a computer user to set up a 'virtual office,' getting faxes, voice messages and E-mail from anywhere in the world for the price of a local telephone call; JFAX plans improvements that will allow users, who pay $15 setup fee and $12.50 a month, to send voice messages back via E-mail and to get access to E-mail through a phone call; photo; map (M)

headline: Green Cross of Japan Settles AIDS Lawsuits
abstract: Green Cross Corp of Japan to pay 1.3 billion yen ($11 million) in 109 recently settled suits over blood products tainted with AIDS virus; hopes to settle 52 more suits by paying total of 700 million yen (S)

headline: Hambrecht Halts Stock Offering
abstract: Hambrecht & Quist Inc., an investment bank in San Francisco that specializes  in bringing technology companies public, has delayed its own plans for an initial public stock offering, four people at the firm said today.         Hambrecht & Quist delayed its expected offering as the rally in United States stocks has stalled and demand for shares of newly public companies has faltered.

headline: American Express Names Financial Chief
abstract: American Express Co names Richard K Goeltz vice chairman and chief financial officer, succeeding Michael P Monaco, who resigned in Apr (S)

headline: World News Briefs;Serbian Protesters Ask Delay in Croatia Rule
abstract: Several thousand Serbs demonstrated today in the last Serbian-held enclave in Croatia, demanding a delay in a scheduled transition to Croatian rule.         The enclave, Eastern Slavonia, is to come under Croatian authority by January 1997, but the Serbian protesters appealed for the United Nations Security Council to extend the transition for another year.

headline: Maya Renaissance in Guatemala Turns Political
abstract: Guatemala's Maya majority is beginning to flex its muscles after five centuries of bitter repression; Maya leaders are taking advantage of political opening that has accompanied winding down of country's 35-year civil war; they are demanding new relationship with democratic Government that promises to end racial discrimination and that sees Mayas not as subversive force but as voting bloc to be courted; photo; map (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.00   5.17   5.68        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.01   5.06   5.44        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.09   5.13   5.43        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.56   6.57   6.55        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.79   6.79   6.89        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.85   7.85   7.78        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   5.86   5.86   6.28          *Estimated daily average, source Telerate  **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Vineyards Planned In China and India : Italian Firm Puts Wager On Wine
abstract: VICENZA, Italy—  Nestling unobtrusively among neat terraces of vines in the foothills just west of this attractive town in northeastern Italy, Gambellara has a deceptively sleepy air. From outside, the central winery buildings look much like many others in this part of the world.

headline: Yeltsin Security Aide Denounces Russian War Effort in Chechnya
abstract: Yeltsin Security Aide Denounces Russian War Effort in Chechnya** Russian national security adviser Aleksandr I Lebed returns to Moscow from secret talks with rebel commanders in Chechnya and expresses horror and outrage at condition of Russian troops and disgust over conduct of bureaucrats leading war effort in breakaway province; describes troops as hungry, lice-infested and underclothed; says they should be removed from combat for purely humanitarian reasons; says they have been stationed in Chechnya as 'cannon fodder;' derides Russian security officials as inept and corrupt and Moscow-installed Chechen government as liars, while praising courage of rebels; says state commission for settling crisis in Chechnya, which is headed by Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin, has failed; says cease-fire is possible within 24 hours and that truce is necessary to prevent further useless slaughter of Russian troops; photo (M)

headline: The Fed Will Act, But Does It Matter?
abstract: Floyd Norris column on Wall Street's likely response to a rise in the discount rate in light of report that 8 of the 12 regional banks in the Federal Reserve want a higher rate; graph (M)

headline: Italy Reopens Old Inquiry Into 2 Ex-Nazis in Killing of Prisoners
abstract: Italian Defense Min Beniamino Andreatta says military prosecutors resume long-abandoned probe of former Nazi soldiers Karl Titho and Hans Haage, who are suspected of killing civilian and military prisoners during mass deportations of Italians to Germany prison camps during World War II; two are thought to be living in Germany; move may be bid by Italy to defelect criticism of military court's decision that former Nazi officer Erich Priebke cannot be punished for role in massacre of 335 civilians outside Rome in 1944 (M)

headline: The cover is peeled off of Minute Maid's quiet switch to the Leo Burnett Company in June.
abstract: Coca-Cola Co has quietly moved advertising account of its Minute Maid line of refrigerated and frozen juices to Leo Burnett Co from Lowe & Partners/SMS; switch is inadvertently disclosed in announcement that former Burnett aide Robert H Welke joins Euro RSCG Tatham as chairman and chief creative officer (M)

headline: Bosnia G.I.'s See Themselves as Lucky After Bomb Mishap
abstract: While the Navy investigated why one of its aircraft accidentally dropped a 500-pound bomb on the edge of a United States military base near here, soldiers  at the base were asking similar questions today and counting themselves lucky that there were no injuries.         Aside, that is, from damage to the nerves of the some 800 people, most attached to an Army cavalry squadron, who were at the base on Saturday afternoon when the bomb struck.

headline: Cuba Sentences Fugitive Businessman Vesco to 13 Years for Fraud
abstract: Cuban sentences Robert L Vesco to 13 years in jail for defrauding country's Health Ministry and other investors while seeking to market unproven drug; sentences his wife, Lidia Alfonso Llauger, to nine years (M)

headline: Moves Against Iraq Send Oil Prices Surging
abstract: Oil prices soar in wake of United States retaliatory attack on Iraq and United Nations suspension of accord to allow some Iraqi oil exports; crude oil for Oct delivery jumps $1.15 a barrel to $23.40; most analysts say price surge will not last; graphs (M)

headline: A Downgrade Hurts Shares Of Harrah's
abstract: Shares of Harrah's Entertainment Inc fall as much as 14 percent to 52-week low after analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc cuts his rating on the stock two notches to 'hold' from 'strong buy' in anticipation of slower earnings (S)

headline: Farm Woes Curb British Growth
abstract: Britain's economy grew four-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, less than economists were expecting, as the "mad cow disease" scare brought a sharp drop in farm production.         The Office for National Statistics said today that the lost beef sales from mad cow disease took a tenth of a percentage point off the quarterly gross domestic product growth.

headline: 2 Agencies Expand In New Media
abstract: Neil Faber Media opens Nexgen Media Worldwide, and Marketing 1:1 to combine with Human Endeavors (S)

headline: About Real Estate;Alcoa Vacating Its Downtown Pittsburgh Landmark
abstract: A corporate restructuring at the Aluminum Company of America has brought with it a decision to relinquish the company's 31-story aluminum headquarters building in downtown Pittsburgh, a landmark on the city's skyline since its construction in 1952.         To replace it as the corporate headquarters, Alcoa is putting up a $40 million building on the riverfront on the city's North Side, about a 15-minute walk from downtown. But the new building is designed for only 450 employees; the existing building has been home to about 1,500 of Alcoa's 1,700 employees in the Pittsburgh area. At one time 2,000 Alcoa employees worked there. The company has 10,000 salaried workers in the United States.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: SPENDING IT;More Than One Way to Pay Off That Student Loan
abstract: WHEN Jane Penn graduated last year from New York University with a master's in fine arts, she planned to repay her $23,000 in student loans over the usual period: 10 years. But the $300 monthly payment was more than she could afford.         So Ms. Penn renegotiated her loans to pay only interest for three years. This slashed her bill to $175 a month but stretched out her payments to 13 years. If her finances improve, she can pay more at any time. If they worsen, she can extend her repayment period to 15 or 20 years. Or if she is really strapped, she can link the amount she pays to a part of her income for a few years under a 30-year plan.

headline: BATON BROADCASTING IS ADDING BUSINESS OF ELECTROHOME
abstract: Baton Broadcasting Inc to acquire television broadcasting business of Electrohome Ltd in stock-and-cash deal valued at almost $79 milllion (S)

headline: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp.
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp posts $364 million second-quarter profit, up from $18 million loss in 1995 period; table (S)

headline: KASH N' KARRY IN TAKEOVER TALKS WITH FOOD LION
abstract: Kash n'Karry Food Stores Inc says it held talks with Food Lion Inc about acquisition of Kash n'Karry by Food Lion (S)

headline: Charles and Diana Agree on Divorce Terms
abstract: It began as an old-fashioned fairy tale but soon became just another failed modern marriage, brought down by anger, tears and adultery. And today, almost 15 years after the wedding between Lady Diana Spencer and Charles, the Prince of Wales, the consummately incompatible couple announced that they had finally reached an agreement on the terms for their divorce.         Under the agreement, announced in a joint statement by Buckingham Palace, representing Charles, and Anthony Julius, Diana's lawyer, the Princess will receive a big lump-sum payment instead of regular alimony checks. Neither side would release details of the financial settlement, but London newspapers have reported that Diana is getting about $22.5 million in cash, as well as about $600,000 a year earmarked to maintain her private office.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;MONSANTO CO. (MTC,N)
abstract: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 26  percent, which was stronger than expected, on increased sales of its agricultural products and drugs.         Monsanto, the St.Louis-based maker of drugs, chemicals and agricultural products, said that net income rose to a record $365 million, or 62 cents a share, from $290 million, or 51 cents, a year earlier.

headline: Prudential Unit To Kirshenbaum
abstract: Prudential Health Care names Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners to handle its consolidated national account; billings estimated at $20 million (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Harrah's Entertainment, Memphis, and Players International, Atlantic City, to TBWA Chiat/Day, St. Louis, a unit of the Omnicom Group, as the first agency to handle advertising for a joint venture, the Riverport Casino Center. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.    Rabasca & Co., Melville, L.I., was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $3 million: the New York Islanders, to handle advertising for the National Hockey League team, which had been handled by Hanft Byrne Raboy Abrams Partners, New York, and Great Earth Cos., Hicksville, L.I., to handle advertising for Great Earth Vitamin Stores, which had been handled in-house.

headline: Incentive Has Earnings Decline
abstract: Incentive AB says its first-half pretax profit fell to 1.989 billion kronor ($300 million) or 9 percent, from 2.190 billion in last year's half; total first-half sales dropped 16 percent, to 12.632 billion kronor (S)

headline: Europe Moves to Halt Protection for Brewers
abstract: European Commission begins legal proceedings against Britain and Belgium, holding they use illegal means to protect their domestic brewers (S)

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Earnings Climb by 35% For Computer Associates
abstract: Perhaps belying some recent worries that corporate spending on information technology might be slowing, Computer Associates International Inc., which supplies software to medium-sized and large businesses, reported strong results  yesterday for its fiscal first quarter.         The announcement yesterday morning, after a surprisingly robust earnings report from the Intel Corporation late in the day on Tuesday, was good news for  beleaguered technology investors. And it helped set the tone for the broad rebound yesterday in technology stocks, which had been plummeting for several days on concerns about a possible slowdown in business for these companies.

headline: War Tribunal Paints an Ugly Picture of 2 Wanted Serbs
abstract: The international war crimes tribunal shuddered today at the details of mass  murders as the court for the first time presented its evidence of the role that  the Bosnian Serb commander played in the widespread killing of civilians in Srebrenica, once a city of refuge.         Today was the fifth day in a week of special hearings held to increase pressure on NATO powers to capture both the commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic, and the Bosnian Serb political leader, Radovan Karadzic. They have been charged in connection with war crimes they are said to have either ordered directly or failed to prevent.

headline: Taking In the Sites;Free Maps for Travelers on the Web
abstract: Free customized maps are becoming one of the handier features of the World Wide Web. They might soon take the place of that tattered road atlas in the trunk.         Suppose you are planning a restful drive this summer with the family, from your home in Buffalo to Ithaca, N.Y., and the serene Cayuga Lake. A quick click or two and you could have itemized directions. Click to a map of Ithaca and you could even find the automated teller machine nearest to your bed and breakfast.

headline: Japan Premier Visits Shrine to War Dead
abstract: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto visited a shrine for Japan's war dead today, the first by a serving Japanese leader in nearly 11 years.         Visits by Japanese officials to the Yasukuni Shrine are highly sensitive because World War II war criminals also are enshrined there. Paying homage to them is seen by critics as a defense of Japan's wartime aggression.

headline: An Assassin For Apartheid Recalls Trade, And Trauma
abstract: Eugene de Kock, who headed South Africa's notorious Vakplaas police unit for more than eight years and has been convicted on 89 charges, including murder, describes under oath at trial in Pretoria his long career as one of apartheid era's most successful assassins (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Siemens Posts 17% Rise In Profits for 9 Months
abstract: Siemens A.G., the German electronics company, said yesterday that its profits rose about 17 percent in the nine months that ended on June 30, helped by strong international sales that offset lower sales in Germany. Siemens said it earned 1.65 billion marks ($1.08 billion) on sales of 64.5 billion marks, up from a profit of 1.41 billion marks on sales of 60.2 billion marks in the corresponding period last year. Siemens said its foreign sales rose by 15 percent, while German sales fell 2.7 percent. The Siemens communications and automotive businesses led the growth.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Microsoft in Joint Venture
abstract: British Telecommunications P.L.C. and the Microsoft Corporation announced today a joint-marketing venture aimed at small businesses in Britain.         "Computer ownership among U.K. small businesses is high, but not many customers have networks to link them together," Kathleen Flaherty, marketing director of BT Business Communications, said in a statement.

headline: Be Only Burundian, Coup's Leader Urges Ethnic Rivals
abstract: The new President of Burundi took his message of reconciliation to the people today, explaining his reasons for the coup he led this week and asking them to "calm all the ethnicities, to let everyone know that there is no Hutu, no Tutsi, but only one Burundian people."         Burundi, like neighboring Rwanda, has been torn by fighting between the majority Hutu and the Tutsi ethnic groups that has claimed 150,000 lives in the  last three years. The coup, led by the Tutsi-dominated army, overthrew the Hutu  President.

headline: Burmese Junta Seems Headed for Showdown
abstract: Heightening of tensions seen between Burmese Government junta and democracy movement led by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi; she has been permitted to hold weekend rallies at her front gate, even as regime continues to arrest supporters, but that window of freedom may be closing as hopes for dialogue fade; photo (S)

headline: Graft Inquiry in Mexico Ties Zedillo to Disputed Payment
abstract: A commission investigating Government corruption in Mexico has implicated President Ernesto Zedillo in a questionable Government payment to a company controlled by a leading supporter of his political party.         Documents obtained by the multi-party congressional commmision and made available to The New York Times show that Mr. Zedillo acquiesced in the $7 million payment in 1989, when he was the senior budget official in the Cabinet of his predecessor, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. Mr. Zedillo permitted the payment despite repeated warnings by lower-ranking officials that it was unjustified and probably illegal.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Alitalia Holders Approve $1 Billion Aid Package
abstract: Shareholders of Alitalia S.p.A. approved a capital increase of 1.5 trillion lire ($1 billion) yesterday to help the Italian national airline stay afloat. The company's main shareholder is the Government holding company Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale S.p.A., or I.R.I.          On June 19, Alitalia's unions and management reached an agreement that would pave the way for a cost-cutting program and a capital injection to keep the money-losing airline from going bankrupt. The agreement will enable employees to take a 20 percent stake in the company. I.R.I., which controls 89.3 percent of Alitalia, plans to inject up to 3.5 trillion lire ($2.3 billion) into Alitalia in the next five years, along with other investors.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Zenith's U.S. Unit Says Chief Has Gone
abstract: William J Grimes leaves as president and chief executive of Zenith Media Worldwide's United States operations with expiration of his two-year contract; Steve King will assume his duties in new post as Zenith North America chief operating officer (S)

headline: Choate on the Cheap: Prep Schools Woo the Middle Class
abstract: Number of prestigious private boarding schools, dismayed by paucity of middle-income students, are offering financial aid to students; officials of Phillips Academy, Philips Exeter and Choate Rosemary Hall comment; photos of students (M)

headline: Stealing G.O.P.'s Thunder, He Reduces Stress on U.N. Role
abstract: Alison Mitchell analysis contends that Pres Clinton came into office talking about standing United Nations rapid deployment force and with aides preaching policy in which US shared costs and burdens of collective world leadership; maintains that after nearly four years of facing crises in Somalia, Haiti, and Iraq, Clinton has shifted away from his emphasis on relying on UN for collective security and is increasingly comfortable with acting alone (M)

headline: Behind North Korea's Barbed Wire: Capitalism
abstract: Capitalism is seen bursting out in parts of North Korea, last and most rigid bastion of Stalinism on earth; this weekend, North Korea is host to conference aimed at luring foreign companies to invest in free trade and economic zone it is setting up in Sonbong region; North Koreans wearing their Kim Il Sung buttons on business suits are wheeling and dealing with foreign entrepreneurs and investment bankers about potential joint ventures and marketing tie-ins; map (M)

headline: Getting Down and Dirty in the Garden Is Big Business
abstract: Baby boomers' interest in gardening fuels growth of both specialty catalogues and big home garden and nursery centers; retailers add teak furniture and goatskin gloves to their basic inventory of plants and tools; lawn-and-garden spending has nearly doubled from $12.0 billion in 1985 to $22.2 billion in 1995; photo of scene at Smith & Hawken store; company is known for its upscale catalogues; other photos; charts (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;QUESTOR INVESTMENT GROUP TO BUY BUMBLE BEE
abstract: Questor Public Fund L.P. agreed yesterday to buy Bumble Bee tuna from the Unicord Company of Thailand in a deal that would represent a major shift in the  global tuna industry. Terms were not disclosed, but people knowledgeable about the deal said Questor, an investment group in Southfield, Mich., would pay more  than $200 million. As part of the deal, Questor would sell three Bumble Bee tuna production plants to the H. J. Heinz Company, based in Pittsburgh, whose Star-Kist Foods Inc. unit would pack Bumble Bee tuna for Questor. The move would allow Heinz to consolidate its Star-Kist plants with Bumble Bee's.

headline: The Great Olympic-Sponsor Challenge: Games Fail to Make Stocks Jump
abstract: The sponsors of the Olympic Games spent large sums and went to great lengths to get the world's attention. But they didn't impress Wall Street.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Docks de France Seeks Alternatives to Bid
abstract: Docks de France S.A., the supermarket operator sought by a rival, Auchan S.A., in a hostile $3.1 billion bid, said key shareholders had unanimously rejected the bid. It added that it was studying other solutions that "might better suit the company and its shareholders." A spokeswoman said Docks de France had until July 25 to present alternatives. The Financial Times reported yesterday that Tesco P.L.C., Europe's largest supermarket chain, was considering a bid.          The rejection of the bid by the Toulouse, Deroy and Dian families, who effectively control 41 percent of the voting rights in Docks de France, will probably not prevent Auchan from winning control, analysts said.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: North Carolina Rail Plan
abstract: State of North Carolina has hired Nationsbank to evaluate purchase of 25 percent of North Carolina Railroad Co that it does not already own (S)

headline: Concerns Persist About Wage Inflation
abstract: Growing number of companies are facing tight labor market in which many workers can be much more choosy about their jobs; wide range of employers in many parts of the country are grappling with an inability to fill their ranks with qualified workers; these areas of virtually full employment hold important implications for household incomes, financial markets and political campaigns as well as business profitability itself; tightening labor market has generated only scattered--and in most cases --pay increases; most companies, unable to pass on higher costs by raising prices because of intense competition from foreign and domestic rivals, are working even harder to keep a lid on labor costs, in part by adopting novel ways of coupling pay to profits; labor situation at Trinity Packaging Corp in Remington, Va, discussed; map shows unemployment rates across country; photo (L)

headline: Armenia Opposition Urges Resistance to 'Unelected' President
abstract: Armenia opposition leader Vazgen Manukian urges his followers to put up quiet resistance, calling Government of Pres Levon Ter-Petrossian 'illegal power' that stole recent Presidential election (M)

headline: Sharon Joins Netanyahu's Cabinet at Last
abstract: After weeks of political haggling and last-minute crises, Ariel Sharon was sworn in as a Cabinet minister today, strengthening the hard line in Israel's new Government as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu flew to Washington to meet President Clinton.         The Israeli Parliament voted 58 to 33 with 1 abstention to approve Mr. Netanyahu's appointment of Mr. Sharon, 68, a hawkish former general and Defense  Minister who bitterly opposes the Israeli-Palestinian accords and is a forceful  advocate of Jewish settlement in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

headline: Political Savvy Tempers European Furor Over U.S. Bill Aimed at Libya and Iran
abstract: European officials depict Pres Clinton's threat of sanctions against foreign companies that invest heavily in Iran or Libya as election-year ploy that will have little real effect on either trade or terrorism; officials in Germany, Italy and France say new policy will not deter them from dealing with two nations, which Washington has cast as principal sponsors of terrorism (M)

headline: Past Is Prologue for Vote in Nicaragua
abstract: Arnoldo Aleman, Nicaraguan presidential candidate for rightist Liberal Alliance, holds 10-point lead in polls; he constantly reminds voters of hardships during country's civil war; his opponent, former Pres Daniel Oretega Saavedra, who led Sandinista revolution, is now positioning himself as a moderate and embracing market economics; photos; map (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;GT INTERACTIVE ACQUIRES HUMONGOUS ENTERTAINMENT
abstract: The GT Interactive Software Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired Humongous Entertainment Inc., a developer and publisher of children's software based in Woodinville, Wash., for four million shares, or about $76 million. It was GT Interactive's third acquisition in two weeks. Last week, it acquired Formgen, publisher of the Duke Nukem 3D computer game, and the Wizard Works Group. GT Interactive's shares fell 50 cents, to $19, in Nasdaq trading. GT Interactive, based in New York, produces interactive software. Its best-selling  titles include Doom II and Mortal Kombat 3.

headline: A Union Gives an Old Refinery a New Lease on Life
abstract: Members of Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers approve contract under which about one-third of workers will lose their jobs when Tosco Corp reopens refinery in Marcus Hook, Pa; workers voted down earlier offer and have been out of work since Tosco shut down refinery last January; 93 percent vote for new contract is grudging acceptance of need to get back to work; Tosco will invest about $110 million to upgrade facility, which was acquired from British Petroleum; graph showing decline in refinery employment (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan Reports a Surplus Following Earnings Rise
abstract: The Japanese Finance Ministry announced yesterday that it had a national budget surplus of 616.4 billion yen ($5.5 billion), for the fiscal year ended March 31, caused in part by a rise in corporate earnings.          A ministry official said the excess revenues would be used to repay previous Government deficits, which, as of March 31, exceeded 241 trillion yen. But Japanese publications reported that some members of the ruling coalition wanted  the money to go toward a supplementary budget.   (Dow Jones)

headline: And in This Corner
abstract: On-line comments solicited regarding violence in the workplace

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;To hook more marketing executives, Newsweek casts another line and dangles a new Web site.
abstract: NEWSWEEK is stepping up efforts to woo media decision makers by casting a wider net on the Internet.         The Newsweek site on the World Wide Web, called Mediaspot, is aimed at media  planners and buyers at agencies as well as the marketing executives who oversee  advertising spending. In addition to features like a media kit, the site (http:// www.mediaspot.com) offers biographies of the editorial and sales staffs along with information about restaurants and night life in cities where Newsweek has sales offices.

headline: Correction
abstract: A report in the Business Diary column on Aug. 18 about the market performance of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment vehicle of Warren E. Buffett, misstated the estimated daily increase in his net worth in the last year. It was $12.5 million a day, not $125,000.

headline: Union Pension Funds Give Land a Try
abstract: Construction begins on office park in North Reading, Mass, which will be financed by Massachussets Laborers' Pension Fund, Massachusetts State Carpenters Pension Fund and Massachusetts State Carpenters Guaranteed Annuity Fund (About Real Estate) (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: The Cleveland Clinic to BBDO Chicago, a unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle its account, which had been handled by Wyse Advertising, Cleveland. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $3 million to $5 million.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;UNION CARBIDE CORP. (UK,N)
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation reported a 24 percent drop in second-quarter profits yesterday, citing falling prices for one of its key chemical products, ethylene glycol.         Net income was $173 million, or $1.23 a share, which was in line with analysts' expectations. It compared with $228 million, or $1.59 a share, a year  earlier. Sales increased 1 percent, to $1.56 billion, compared with $1.54 billion a year earlier.

headline: Ryder Selling Truck Unit To Questor
abstract: Questor Partners Fund LP agrees to buy consumer truck rental division of Ryder System Inc for about $575 million in cash, allowing Ryder to focus on its other businesses (M)

headline: Storm in St. Kitts, as a Cocaine Case Churns Politics
abstract: Drug trafficking scandal on Caribbean island of St Kitts has brought down one government and threatens another, which is under attack for supposedly doing too much; several people, including sons of former Deputy Prime Min Sidney Morris, have been arrested and accused of working with Colombian cartels to ship cocaine to US; map (M)

headline: Europe Court Backs Ban on British Beef
abstract: The European Union's high court ruled today that the 12-nation organization was within its rights to halt worldwide sales of British beef in response to concern over so-called mad cow disease.         The action dashed Britain's hopes for an immediate end to the ban on its beef exports. Last month the European Union agreed to lift the embargo on a gradual basis as Britain enforces new health safeguards.

headline: Sir Anthony Parsons, British Diplomat, Is Dead at 73
abstract: Sir Anthony Parsons, who capped distinguished diplomatic career in Middle East with tough job of representing Britain at United Nations during Falkland war with Argentina in 1982, dies at age 73; photo (M)

headline: The Toll of Ethnic Revenge: Dead Women and Children
abstract: The dead are laid out on the ground in front of the still-smoldering tea factory. Someone has covered a few of the bodies with old shawls and rags. People who have come in search of their relatives tiptoe down the line of the dead, gingerly picking up the rags with shaking hands.         One woman lifts the corner of a bloody cloth, catches her breath and begins to cry.

headline: Russian-Chechen Battles Rage On Across Grozny
abstract: Fighting rages in Grozy, Chechnya, as Russian troops, backed by airstrikes and helicopter fire, battle rebels in bid to recapture positions where soldiers and civilians have been trapped for days; Russian Parliament confirms reappointment of Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin, who demands probe of why Russian troops failed to avert rebel incursion; Pres Boris N Yeltsin names his national security adviser, Aleksandr I Lebed as presidential envoy in Chechnya, move that fails to mollify Parliament; Defense Min Igor Rodionov holds Russian troops have regained upper hand in fighting; map; photo (M)

headline: Ex-Communists Lose In Mongolia Election
abstract: The opposition Democratic Union Coalition swept 48 out of 76 seats in parliamentary elections on Sunday, the General Election Committee said today.         The ruling party, the formerly Communist Mongolian Revolutionary People's Party, won 23 seats, the head of the committee, Lhagrasuren, said. Vote counting for five seats is not yet complete, he added.

headline: Canada Auto Pact Talks
abstract: Canadian Auto Workers says Chrysler Canada Ltd's latest contract offer does not adequately address outsourcing, most contentious issue in union bargaining; union has set strike deadline for Sept 17 (S)

headline: Steelmakers plan to polish their product's image to compete with aluminum and plastics makers.
abstract: Alliance of American steelmakers will underwrite advertising campaign to dispel idea that steel is heavy and polluting; campaign will be created by unit of GGT Group, with cost of $100 million to $125 million over five years (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Advance Strongly On Producer-Prices Report  Stocks rose as the Producer Price Index showed scant signs of inflation amid surprisingly strong economic growth and corporate profits. The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 17.02 points, at 5,771.94, within 7 points of its closing high set on May 22.    Broader indexes remained short of their records. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 3.85 points, to 671.13, or 1.1 percent short of its closing high. The Nasdaq index climbed 11.86 points, to 1,165.81, roughly 6.7 percent below its acme. $(Page D6.$)    Hefty increases for food and energy drove up producer prices three-tenths of 1 percent in August, but a slip in the rest of the Producer Price Index for finished goods was said to show that inflation was not a threat. $(D4.$)    S.E.C. Settles With Tudor   Tudor Investment, headed by the trader Paul Tudor Jones 2d, agreed to pay $800,000 in fines after the S.E.C. uncovered trades that could be construed as attempts to manipulate the market. Tudor settled the case without admitting or denying the charges. $(D5.$)    Revamping Ahead for Prudential? Analysts said Prudential Insurance could restructure its health care business following the loss of a $4 billion A.A.R.P. contract. $(D6.$)      A Vote of Confidence in Salomon   Berkshire Hathaway, the company controlled by Warren Buffett, said it planned to convert 140,000 preferred shares into common stock of Salomon Inc. this year. The move shows Mr. Buffett is warming to Salomon, which has seen its fortunes improve after a hard 1995. $(D2.$)    Doubletree to Buy Red Lion Hotels   Doubletree said it would acquire Red Lion Hotels for about $1 billion. Two-thirds of Red Lion's shares are held by a limited partnership involving Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. $(D4.$)    A Deal Undone Shakes Wall Street   Xerox has long sought to be judged only as a document-processing company and finally found a buyer this year for its poorly performing insurance units. And that goes a long way to explain Wall Street's initial panic after an announcement Wednesday that the deal had fallen apart. Market Place. $(D6.$)     ABC to Broadcast 'The Lion King'   The ABC television network, which is owned by Walt Disney, said it would broadcast Disney's wildly successful movie ''The Lion King'' in November, the first such broadcast of a modern-era Disney animated feature film. ABC also said that Spike Lee would develop a new comedy for the network, in association with Brandon Tartikoff, a former head of entertainment programming for NBC. $(D2.$)    A New Marketing Course for G.M.   General Motors' new marketing strategy starts with its 1997 models. First up is Buick, where campaigns attach slogans to certain models, rather than use an overarching tag line for the division. Advertising. $(D2.$)

headline: Denial and Taboo Blinding India To the Horror of Its AIDS Scourge
abstract: Special Report on AIDS scourge in India; United Nations agencies dealing with AIDS conclude that India will become world center of the disease by end of decade; by then, United Nations estimates indicate, a million Indians will be sick with AIDS, and as many as 10 million will be infected with HIV; a quarter of all projected infections worldwide will be in India; India's five million truck drivers are at center of expected explosion of disease amogn its 970 million people; at places such as Petrapole, vast and chaotic truck stop, where drivers have little to do, it is common for a man to buy sex every day, sometimes several times a day, from local women and teen-age girls for as little as 10 rupees, about 28 cents; social attitudes and taboos that make it difficult to confront AIDS discussed; photos; map (L)

headline: G.M. Makes Offer to Union as Ford and Chrysler Continue Talks
abstract: General Motors Corp makes comprehensive contract offer to United Automobile Workers, as national labor contract talks continue at GM, Ford Motor Co and Chrysler Corp (S)

headline: APPLE COMPUTER TO LOWER ITS SPENDING ON RESEARCH
abstract: Apple Computer Inc vice president Ellen Hancock says Apple plans to cut percentage of revenue its spends on research; cost control measures include freezing research staffing and possibly charging customers for software that is now given away free (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   4.75   5.02   5.72        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.11   5.16   5.17        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.24   5.26   5.19        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.81   6.82   6.10        30-YR. TREAS. headline: Paging Network Taps J. Walter Thompson
abstract: Paging Network Inc selects Chicago ofice of J Walter Thompson to handle its advertising account, which had been handled by Larkin, Meeder & Schweidel since June 1994; billings are estimated at more than $10 million (S)

headline: Mexican Whistle-Blower Held on Drug Charge
abstract: Ricardo Cordero Ontiveros, former official of Mexican anti-drug unit who accused former colleagues of narcotics trafficking and bribery, is himself arrested on same charges; spokesman for Mexico's Attorney General denies that timing of Cordero's arrest was related to his public accusations against others; Cordero's wife maintains that Government trumped up charges against her husband in reprisal for his whistle-blowing crusade (M)

headline: Miller Brewing to Cut Jobs
abstract: The Miller Brewing Company plans to eliminate 200 production jobs at its Milwaukee brewery in October, as part of a program to cut costs at the plant. Miller, a unit of the Philip Morris Companies, also plans to make about $20 million worth of improvements in equipment and procedures at the plant in the next year, Dianne Markut, a spokeswoman for Miller Brewing, said. The job cuts affect about a fifth of the plant's hourly employees.

headline: Markets Closing Early
abstract: Most financial and commodities markets in the United States are reopening today after being closed in observance of the Fourth of July holiday. But the trading sessions will be abbreviated. The stock market will close at 1 P.M. Eastern daylight time, while bond trading is to end at 2 P.M. The commodities exchanges in Chicago are open, but those in New York are closed. Most foreign markets were open yesterday.

headline: Earnings Are Off 67% At Steelmaker Usinor
abstract: Usinor Sacilor SA reports net income fell 67 percent in first half to 800 million francs ($160 million), down from 2.4 billion francs in 1995 period; forecasts significant gains in 1997 first half (S)

headline: JAMES RIVER ACQUIRES REMAINING INTEREST IN JAMONT
abstract: James River Corp says it acquired full ownership of Jamont NV by paying $201.4 million for remaining 13.6 percent stake from Europaper Inc (S)

headline: Seabourn Cruise Line's revived campaign appears to be producing results.
abstract: Seabourn Cruise Line, luxury cruise operator, has returned to advertising market after spending advertising funds for several years training travel agents; writes its own copy, does its own research and decides on own media placement (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Mexico Builds a Picture of a Fanatic Rebel Group
abstract: Mexican Government says Popular Revolutionary Army, which carried out recent attacks against police officers and soldiers across Mexico, is fusion of dozen leftist factions around dominant one with 20-year history of clandestine recruitment, murders and kidnapping; identify imprisoned university dean Felipe Martinez Soriano as its ideological pioneer; experts on Mexican left, including former guerrillas and Communists, describe him as embittered leader long ostracized by other revolutionaries for his violent sectarianism; say Government appears to have underestimated new force; photos; map (M)

headline: SUDBURY REJECTS BID BY PARK-OHIO INDUSTRIES
abstract: Sudbury Inc says its board rejected unsolicited offer of $170 million by Park-Ohio Industries Inc for the company, calling the bid inadequate (S)

headline: Arafat Seeks Saudis' Help
abstract: Yasir Arafat arrived in Saudi Arabia today to seek political and financial support for the Palestinians in their peace effort with Israel.         Mr. Arafat's planned meeting with King Fahd, the first since May 1995, was expected to focus on persuading Saudi Arabia to use its influence with Washington to pressure the new Israeli Government to abide by accords signed with the Palestinians.

headline: U.S. Embassy in Berlin to Be Part of a Historic Plaza's Revival
abstract: United States plan to build new embassy in Berlin advances revival of city's historic Pariser Platz; design for building, by firm of Moore Ruble Yudell, described; map (M)

headline: Tiff on TV Takes Israel Cabinet Spat Public
abstract: In a blunt public confrontation with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Foreign Minister David Levy threatened today to resign if his political ally, Ariel Sharon, is not appointed to the Cabinet by the time Mr. Netanyahu leaves for Washington on Monday for a meeting with President Clinton.         The rare spat before television cameras at a meeting of Mr. Netanyahu's governing coalition exposed the simmering political tensions that have plagued the early days of his new administration.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;FUNDS WATCH
abstract: Some Different Paths In the Search for Yield

headline: Mannesmann Reports 28% Gain in Profits
abstract: Mannesmann AG says its profits rose 28 percent in first half of 1996, to $120.8 million, compared with year earlier half (S)

headline: On State Street, that great street, a couple of old pillars and a prospering wave of discounters.
abstract: Old Navy chain is set to open store on State Street, move expected to further revival of retailing in Chicago's downtown shopping district (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * McDonald's Operators Association, San Jose, Calif., to Hoffman/ Lewis, San Francisco, to handle advertising for the San Francisco and Monterey Bay markets. Those duties, with billings estimated at $9 million, had been handled by Davis, Ball & Colombatto, San Francisco. Also to Hoffman/Lewis, Golden Gate University, San Francisco, to handle its account, which had been in-house; billings were estimated at $1 million.  * Fit America Inc., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Bleecker & Sullivan, New York, to handle marketing communications for the health and weight-loss centers. Billings were estimated at more than $2 million.  * Schieffelin & Somerset Co., New York, a unit of Guinness P.L.C., to Frierson & Mee, New York, to handle advertising for Ruffino wines, which had been at Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, New York. Billings were estimated at $1.2 million.  * Microcom, Norwood, Mass., to Partners & Simons, Boston, to handle advertising for its Carbon Copy software, which had been at Houston Herstek Favat, Boston, an affiliate of Houston Effler Inc. Billings were estimated at $1 million to $2 million.

headline: Netscape Program to Get Tighter Security
abstract: The Netscape Communications Corporation said today that the Government had granted the company permission to distribute within this country a version of its popular Navigator browser software containing substantially stronger encryption technology.         Coding software is used by Internet browser programs to provide secure channels to transmit information like credit-card and banking data.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: Table of United States petroleum data

headline: 'Resting Room' in Tokyo:Rent-a-Nap in Private
abstract: TOKYO—  A Japanese television crew has brought its own "salaryman," a weary-looking fellow who appears to be in his 40s.They position him between rows of men's suits and have him act as if he is doing a little shopping.

headline: Russell H. Dorr, 89, International Banker
abstract: Russell Higginson Dorr, a retired international banker and Government official involved with postwar Europe and the Far East, died last Saturday during a visit to the Galapagos Islands. He was 89 and lived in Point O'Woods, N.Y., and Fort Myers, Fla.         He suffered a heart attack while hiking, his family said.

headline: Caradon Is Selling 15 of Its European Units
abstract: Caradon PLC agrees to sell most of its European engineering and distribution businesses to British venture capital firm for at least 190 million pounds ($296.4 million) (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;RAYTHEON AND MCDONNELL RISE ON NEWS
abstract: The stock prices of the Raytheon Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation rose yesterday after reports that the companies were talking about combining some of their operations. Neither company would comment on the reports, which appeared in The Wall Street Journal and The Boston Herald. Raytheon stock rose $1.875, to $47.125, and McDonnell Douglas gained 37.5 cents, to $44.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. McDonnell Douglas, based in St. Louis, is the largest maker of military aircraft in the country. Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., produces military electronics.

headline: Netanyahu Airs Differences With Clinton on Peace Issues
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, after his first meeting with President Clinton, made it clear today that his new Government had important differences with the Americans on the approach to peace in the Middle East.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;J. Walter Thompson Gets Schick Account
abstract: The Warner-Lambert Company has named the J. Walter Thompson Company in New York to handle the consolidated worldwide account of its Schick shaving products group, which is based in Milford, Conn. Billings on the consolidated account, which includes advertising for the Schick and Wilkinson brands, were estimated at $65 million to $75 million.          The bulk of the account had been divided between Thompson and the London office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide; both those agencies are owned by the WPP Group. Thompson was selected after a three-month review that also included Ogilvy and two other agencies on the Schick group roster: Bates Worldwide in New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., and Dai-Ichi Kikaku in Tokyo, which will continue handling media buying in Japan. Media buying in other countries will still be handled by the agencies now performing those duties, including Thompson.

headline: S.E.C. Argues Against Prudential Claimants
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission asks Federal District judge to reject accusations that Prudential Securities Inc miscalculated settlement payments to thousands of people who had been fraudulently sold investments; group of plaintiffs claims systematic Prudential miscalculations might have cost claimants hundreds of milions of dollars (M)

headline: Airbus Says New Orders Have Helped Triple Its Business in a Year
abstract: Airbus Industrie wins $3 billion in new jetliner orders, bringing its plane orders for year to $17 billion, triple figure for all of 1995 billion; jousts with Boeing Co at Farnborough International Air Show about each other's plans for jumbo jet (S)

headline: Bond Prices Up Modestly On Price Data
abstract: Bond prices rise modestly, following release of data that show decline in last month's core wholesale prices; 30-year bond rises 15/32, to price of 96 2/32; yield slips to 7.07 percent, from 7.11 perent on Sept 11; graph (L)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;KMART PLANS TO REORGANIZE ITS MERCHANDISING UNIT
abstract: The Kmart Corporation, the struggling retailer, said yesterday that it was reorganizing the way its merchandisers buy goods, in an effort to cut costs. The company, based in Troy, Mich., said that its general merchandise managers would  be provided with a team of experts in planning, sales, advertising, finance and  product development. Under the new structure, rather than each buyer making decisions for each order placed, experts in apparel product development and international sourcing would determine where best to make the garments, Warren Flick, president of merchandising for Kmart, said.

headline: The Ante Rises In East Asia
abstract: IT looks like a private club. Guarded door. Tea served in plush green chairs. Marble fountain. Chandelier.         Actually, it's the exclusive reserve of Citibank customers here with more than $120,000 on deposit, part of a program called Citigold that treats customers like first-class airline passengers. And it's a far cry from what such people were accustomed to at competing banks. No standing in line with the riffraff here; each customer has a personal banker, just as the super-rich do.

headline: AMRESCO AGREES TO ACQUIRE A MORTGAGE BUSINESS
abstract: Financial-services concern Amresco Inc will acquire Quality Mortgage USA Inc and Calmac Funding Inc for $95.2 million (S)

headline: A Family's Bonanza in Yukon: The Contented Life
abstract: At least 125 small-time gold operators still scrabble for gold in Dawson City in Canada's Yukon Territory more than 100 years after discovery of nuggets touched off greatest gold rush in history; map; photo (M)

headline: A Pepsi Challenge To Coke Agreement
abstract: Pepsico Inc formally petitions Government of Venezuela to block Coca-Cola Co from forming joint venture with Cisneros Group, which had been Pepsi's bottling company in Venezuela for last 47 years; Pepsi claims it has contractual agreement with Cisneros Group until year 2003, and accuses Coca-Cola Co of seeking to create soft drink monopoly in Venezuela (M)

headline: Saudi Islamic Council Condemns Bombing
abstract: In a hint of the debate raging beneath the surface of Saudi society, Saudi Arabia's highest religious authority has issued a formal opinion concluding that the bombing attack that killed 19 Americans last Tuesday was a sin against Islam.         The ruling was described by a Saudi official as part of an attempt by the senior clerics to counter more militant religious figures here and abroad who have described the presence of Americans in Saudi Arabia as a violation of Islamic law and suggested that Americans may be legitimate targets of violence.

headline: Sigh of Relief Greets New Telephone Rules
abstract: Federal Communications Commission issues 700-page book of rules and analysis on local telephone competition, encoding Telecommunications Act of 1996 that Pres Clinton signed last February; rules stipulate in elaborate detail how Baby Bells and other local providers must open their networks to competition; it also establishes range of discounts that local companies must offer to long-distance companies who want to offer local service by leasing capacity on Bells' networks, rather than constructing their own systems; FCC defers issue of access charges--an estimated $25 billion a year that Bell companies charge AT&T and other carriers to complete their long-distance calls; decision to defer issue is seen as windfall for local phone companies; graph; chart (M)

headline: Grief Stirred By a Sex Case Grips Belgium At 2 Burials
abstract: Belgium is stirred by self-doubt, anger and fear as it buries two women, the 17- and 19-year-old victims of a sex crime case surrounding Marc Dutroux of Charleroi (M)

headline: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;Let's Make Phone Tag a Medal Event
abstract: THE Olympics are back, but I'm not watching. It's not that I'm boycotting them; that would sound too political. The Games are about something purer and more important than politics: endorsements and sponsorships. I'm sitting out the Olympics because most of the 270 events are not relevant to contemporary life.        Some sports, like rhythmic gymnastics, table tennis and badminton, are so obscure that they are not even the subject of beer commercials. (With good reason; it is hard to imagine a pitch like this one: "You've just hit the shuttlecock nearly 200 miles per hour to win the best-of-three-game match. Now it's Miller time.")

headline: Chief Who Preserved Mill Jobs Is Now Cutting 450 Positions
abstract: Aaron Feuerstein, the chairman of Malden Mills Industries who became a national folk hero for his loyalty to his workers, is backing away from a promise to preserve the jobs of all 3,200 employees at the family-owned textile  company in Lawrence, Mass.         Starting on Friday, he and his executives have been notifying 450 employees that they must look elsewhere for jobs because the company cannot rebuild quickly enough to need them before late next year, at the earliest.

headline: Sara Lee Unit Shifts Agencies
abstract: Champion sportswear division of Sara Lee Corp is moving its account to TBWA Chiat/Day after year at Merkly Newman Harty; billings estimated at $10 million (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN ONCOLOGY STOCK FALLS AFTER REPORT
abstract: The stock of American Oncology Resources Inc. skidded nearly 44 percent yesterday after the physician-management company gave a disappointing earnings forecast for the quarter that ended on June 30. The company, which is based in Houston, said it expected to earn 9 cents or 10 cents a share, compared with 6 cents a share a year earlier adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split. Analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation had predicted earnings of 11 cents a share. The company also predicted revenues of $47 million, up from $24.7 million in the period a year ago. The company cited rapid expansion for the disappointing forecast. American Oncology shares sank $6.25, to $8.

headline: An Upstart Mexican Network Gets a Bit Personal
abstract: A prominent politician is gunned down on a city street. The police commander  in charge of the investigation is up to his badge in the international cocaine trade. The bumbling young journalist who tries to get to the bottom of it all is deceived and disdained by the authorities.         It is all fiction, but it sounds very much like real life to many Mexican television viewers. This is the plot of a new nighttime soap opera called "Nothing Personal," the first foray into serial melodramas by an upstart Mexican network, TV Azteca.

headline: Gillette and Duracell In $7 Billion Deal
abstract: In a deal that joins two household names, Gillette agreed to acquire Duracell, the world's leading producer of alkaline batteries, for about $7 billion in stock. The agreement, which the companies announced jointly, ends a five-year search by Gillette for what Alfred M. Zeien, its chairman and chief executive, has called a ''new leg'' acquisition, one that would take the company that makes everything from razors to toothbrushes to pens into a new product category.

headline: Voters in a Japanese Town Oppose Nuclear Power Plant
abstract: Japan's ambitious plans to increase use of atomic energy suffer blow when voters in town of Maki, participating in first official local referendum in country's history, soundly reject proposal to build power plant in area (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GST TELECOMMUNICATION INC., Vancouver, British Columbia, a telecommunications network operator, reached a preliminary agreement to acquire Call America Business Communications Corp. of San Luis Obispo, Calif., a reseller of long-distance services, for $16 million in stock.

headline: Suits Accord By America Online Set
abstract: America Online Inc. will give away millions of hours of on-line time to some  subscribers to settle a series of lawsuits, lawyers involved in the litigation said yesterday.         The agreement is intended to settle 11 class-action suits against America Online on allegations of improper billing practices.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Lloyds TSB Group Profit Rose 12% in First Half
abstract: Lloyds TSB Group, Britain's largest provider of retail financial services, reported a 12 percent rise yesterday in its pretax profits in the first half of  the year, to L1.14 billion ($1.77 billion). The company was formed last year through the merger of Lloyds Bank with TSB and the Cheltenham and Gloucester Building Society.          The company's chief executive, Sir Brian Pitman, said that the efforts to merge Lloyds and TSB were progressing satisfactorily, adding that cost savings from consolidation would be seen in the second half.   (Reuters)

headline: Bonn Accuses Paris of 'Window Dressing' : Germany Assails France Over Budget Maneuvers
abstract: BONN—  Senior government officials in Germany on Thursday sharply criticized what they called "window dressing" used by France this week when it presented a 1997 budget that Paris asserted would meet the conditions for Europe's single currency.

headline: COLEMAN STOCK DROPS ON REPORT OF DEFICIT
abstract: Stock of Coleman Co drops more than 16%, day after company, maker of outdoors equipment, says it will report small third-quarter loss (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PATRIOT AMERICAN HOSPITALITY INC.,  Dallas, completed the purchase of the Valley River Inn in Eugene, Ore., for $18.8 million from Valley River Inn L.P., a private investment group.    CRAIN INDUSTRIES, Fort Smith, Ark., a maker of flexible polyurethane foam used in furniture and bedding, agreed to buy Comfort Clinic Inc. of Atlanta, a unit of Sunrise Medical Inc., for $14 million.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES TO BUY NORA BEVERAGES
abstract: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. signed a letter of intent yesterday to acquire Nora Beverages Inc., producer of Naya brand Canadian spring water, for about $117 million. The payment would be made in cash and stock at the discretion of the seller, the investor Ahmed Hbouss, who holds 60 percent of Nora's stock and  would remain on the management team. Coca-Cola Enterprises, based in Atlanta, is the largest distributor of Naya, handling about half of the worldwide volume. In 1995, Nora, based in Mirabel, Quebec, had operating revenues of $46 million.  Coca-Cola Enterprises is the world's largest bottler of soft drinks, distributing about 57 percent of the Coca-Cola Company's bottle and can volume in the United States.

headline: Metallgesellschaft Set To Merge 2 Units
abstract: Metallgesellschaft AG says it will merge its two plant construction units, folding Lentjes AG into Lurgi AG (S)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Lancome's ubiquitous rose grows into a full-blown icon to compete with higher-priced rivals.
abstract: AMONG better-known roses, there are Gypsy Rose and Lida Rose, Rose Marie and  Red Rose tea, Rose of Washington Square and the Yellow Rose of Texas, not to mention the roses in the garden you were never promised in that song by Lynn Anderson. Now Lancome, the international marketer of beauty products, hopes to transform its own rose into a similarly familiar flower.         As part of an extensive overhaul of the Lancome image, the rose that has served as the brand's symbol since 1935 will grow in prominence. The flower, which has appeared on product packages as well as in ads, is the central focus of a campaign -- with a significantly increased budget -- that will begin appearing in September issues of magazines.

headline: In its first brand-identity campaign in a decade, Novell will try to take the 'No' out of its name.
abstract: Advertising column on assertive advertising blitz that will begin brand-identity campaign by Novell Inc, embattled network-software company; Novell will spend $20 million through Oct 31 on campaign, which was created by San Francisco office of Young & Rubicam Inc; goal of ads is to paint more positive portrait of Novell, whose recent problems led to resignation of its top executive, Robert J Frankenberg; photo (M)

headline: Official Embrace of Khmer Rouge Leader Roils Cambodia
abstract: Offer by Hun Sen, one of Cambodia's tandem Prime Ministers, welcoming Khmer Rouge rebel leader Ieng Sary back into society and personally guaranteeing his safety, reopens painful question of how Cambodia is to deal with unhealed wounds of past; points up widening divisions within Govt, and severe split within guerrilla movement, in which Ieng Sary's faction has talked openly about truce with Government; he has been implicated in mass murders of millions during Khmer rule from 1975 to 1979; photo; map (M)

headline: Intel Introduces Phone Software
abstract: In its quest to make the personal computer an indispensable tool, the Intel Corporation introduced software today that it said would make it easy to place long-distance phone calls over the Internet.         The company said the Intel Internet Phone software was the first to allow users of different types of computers and software to connect. The software works on PC's running the Microsoft Corporation's Windows 95 operating system. Intel has also signed 120 companies that have agreed to use the standard in new  products.

headline: 2 H.M.O. Shifts Are Further Indications of Consolidation
abstract: Humana Inc, one of nation's largest health maintenance orgns, announces that it is pulling out of its health care plans in Washington area; another HMO, Pacificare Health Systems Inc, says that it is considering sale of its Florida operations (M)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Magnacom the Top Bidder in Wireless Auction
abstract: Magnacom Wireless L.L.C. offered the highest bids today on six licenses in the second round of a Federal Communications Commission re-auction of 18 wireless licenses.         In the first round today, Next Wave Telecom Inc. pledged the highest bids on  all but 1 of 18 licenses up for bid. Next Wave bid a total of $311.7 million.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Rout in Stocks Continues, With Every Sector Hit Few investors or companies avoided the carnage on Wall Street as shares of every sort of company, big and small, high technology and low, fell sharply. Technology stocks suffered the most, with the Nasdaq composite index falling 3.92 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 161.05 points, or 2.9 percent, to 5,349.51. [Page A1.]

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BEACON GROUP INVESTMENT FUND TO ACQUIRE AMBAR
abstract: Ambar Inc., a provider of fluids and chemical and environmental services to the oil and natural gas industries, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Beacon Group Energy Investment Fund L.P. for $18 a share, or about $67 million. The fund, which is affiliated with the Beacon Group, an investment  fund in New York, has investments primarily in the energy industry. As part of the transaction, it has agreed to buy the 51 percent of Ambar's shares that are owned by Randolph M. Moity, the company's chairman, and the 6 percent owned  by Kenneth Boutte, an Ambar director. The stock of Ambar, which is based in Lafayette, La., jumped $3.1875, to $17.6875, on Nasdaq.

headline: About Real Estate;Westchester Development Is On Again
abstract: At Rosecliff, a development of single-family houses overlooking the Hudson River in the Westchester County community of Briarcliff Manor, construction has  been stop and go since it began in the building boom of the mid-1980's.         Eleven years and three owners later, the project, which will eventually include 116 single-family homes, is two-thirds complete. And now the project is to begin its latest chapter. Earlier this month, Toll Brothers Inc., among the region's larger developers, bought one model home and 36 building lots for $4.6 million at the 152-acre site.

headline: U.N. Council Votes Air Embargo on Sudan
abstract: UN Security Council, punishing Sudanese leaders for failing to extradite three men accused in plot to assassinate Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak last year, votes to impose air embargo on Sudan, but delays it for at least three months (S)

headline: Fidelity to End Sale of Funds By 3d Parties Like Schwab
abstract: Fidelity Investments, in a major shift in how it markets its mutual funds to  individual investors, will stop selling its most popular funds through third-party retail channels, including Charles Schwab & Company's Mutual Fund Marketplace and similar programs at other discount brokerage firms, Fidelity said yesterday.         Fidelity, which has been working on its new product-distribution policy for close to a year, plans to outline the new strategy next week.

headline: Pan Am and Carnival Air Call Off Merger Plan
abstract: Carnival Air Lines and Pan American World Airways call off plans to merge; Carnival's chairman, Reuven Wertheim, says two parties could not come to terms; tentative merger agreement announced two weeks ago essentially amounted to a Pan Am purchase of Carnival for about $100 million, half of it in Pan Am stock (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: A table last Sunday with an article about the dual roles of Linda J. Wachner as chief executive of the Warnaco Group and the Authentic Fitness Corporation misstated the Cabinet position in the Carter Administration held by Joseph A. Califano Jr., who is a director of both of Mrs. Wachner's companies. He was Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, not Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY    Labor Day -- Just about everything financial is closed.    TUESDAY    Chrysler and General Motors report August car sales.
