The National Association of Purchasing Management releases its August purchasing managers' report.    WEDNESDAY    Congress returns to work.    THURSDAY    Ford reports August car sales.    The Labor Department issues its weekly report on initial unemployment claims.

headline: Arafat's Call for Prayer Protest Gets Modest Response
abstract: Rigid Israeli police cordon and apparent shortage of enthusiasm among Palestinians makes for modest and peaceful turnout at Al Aksa Mosque, where Yasir Arafat had called on Palestinians to converge for protest prayers; photo; maps (M)

headline: After Crisis, Czechs Look For Waysto RepairImage
abstract: PRAGUE—  By the time Kreditni Banka, a small Czech bank, was shut by regulators last month, it had lost an estimated 12 billion koruny ($455 million). Ten other Czech banks had already collapsed with hardly a ripple.

headline: ITT Hartford Puts Account in Review
abstract: ITT Hartford Insurance seeks new advertising agency after parting company with Hampel/Stefanides (S)

headline: Checkmate In Chechnya
abstract: Analysis: Russian Government and its Muslim adversaries in Chechnya have taken giant step toward ending war; deciding factor for Russia was when rebels seized Grozny from distressed and demoralized Russian Army, and then surrounded as many as 3,000 Russian soldiers in their barracks; there was little left for Kremlin to do but back away or bomb Grozny--and its own soldiers--to dust (M)

headline: NASA PICKS MODEL FOR A NEW FLEET OF SPACE VEHICLES
abstract: NASA selected the Lockheed Martin Corporation today to build a futuristic experimental rocket that could lead to drastic cuts in the cost of putting payloads into space.         The wedge-shaped re-usable vehicle, the X-33, will be the first major new spacecraft built by the United States in 25 years. It is a step toward replacing the space shuttle, and will be built under a program intended to move much of the initiative for developing high-risk technologies out of NASA's hands and into those of private industry.

headline: Treasury Securities Drop in Price
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities give ground; 30-year bond falls 17/32, to price of 96 30/32, to yield of 7.00 percent, up from 6.95 percent on Aug 23; graph (L)

headline: New York City starts moving on Federal rules for notification about lead-based paint.
abstract: Real Estate Board of New York, with first phase of new Federal regulations on disclosure of lead-based paint in residences scheduled to take effect on Sept 6, has sent to its members sample disclosure forms intended to help them comply with new regulations; similar forms will eventually be given to every person who buys or rents a home built before 1978 (L)

headline: Economy Grew 7.2% in Mexico Last Quarter, a Sign of Revival
abstract: Mexico announces that its economy grew by 7.2 percent in second quarter; figure exceeds analysts' expectations and is latest and strongest indication that long-awaited recovery is solidly under way; it is first economic growth country reported since beginning of devastating crisis that followed peso's devaluation in December 1994; economic surge is vindication of harsh financial-stabilization program pursued by Pres Ernesto Zedillo, whose policies have had strong backing, as well as $12.5 billion emergency loan, from Clinton Administration; graph (M)

headline: Digital Faces Tough Market For Altavista
abstract: Market Place column discusses Digital Equipment Corp's decision to spin off Altavista Internet Software division; says it will not be easy for Altavista to command a premium, given performance so far of four other Internet search companies that have gone public this year; some analysts say Digital's principal aim is not to raise capital, but to receive more recognition for developing cutting-edge Internet technology, which could boost sales of Digital computers (M)

headline: After Chemical Merger, Chase Promotes Itself as a Nimble Bank Giant
abstract: New signs with Chase label are affixed to Chemical Bank branches, implementing merger of Chase Manhattan and Chemical Bank that was announced year ago; goal in merger is to close 100 branches out of 612 in region, and save $1.7 billion a year in overlapping costs; Chase Manhattan's stockholders may rejoice, but many customers are skeptical that merger will benefit them; as merger becomes reality, bank's first challenge is to reconcile its parents' disparate images; the new Chase wants to combine mass market draw of Chemical with more solid image of Chase; photos (M)

headline: BEN & JERRY'S PREDICTS LOWER QUARTERLY EARNINGS
abstract: Shares of Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc fall 7 percent after ice cream company says its third-quarter earnings will be lower than anticipated; stock falls $1, to close at $13.375 (S)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;TV Rights Are Set For the World Cup
abstract: Kirch Group, a German television company, and Sporis Holding of Switzerland have been awarded the television rights for the 2002 and 2006 soccer World Cups, the sport's international governing body said today.         Kirch, a privately owned German company, and Sporis will pay at least 2.8 billion Swiss francs, or about $2.24 billion, for the worldwide TV rights to the events, according to FIFA, soccer's governing body.

headline: A Wave of Casinos Hits Mississippi's Gulf Coast;Las Vegas Operators Hope to Build Biloxi Into a Top-Tier Gambling Port
abstract: Here in the South's Monte Carlo among the magnolias, casino companies are transforming the Mississippi coast from a strip of decaying motels and dilapidated mansions into the nation's hottest new gambling hub.         Industry executives come to check out their rivals' projects, bump into each  other and then waste no time in augmenting their already ambitious plans. Four 1,000-room hotels are now being built, and a fifth is planned. Mirage Resorts, vowing to outdo all comers, announced a $200 million, 1,000-room hotel and casino last fall, raised the stakes in April to $325 million and 1,200 rooms and then upped them again in May to $475 million and 1,800 rooms -- more than any hotel in Atlantic City can boast.

headline: Pete's Brewing Names Gotham
abstract: Pete's Brewing Co names Gotham Inc as agency of record; billings not disclosed (S)

headline: Nextel Seeks Wireless Network Financing
abstract: Nextel Communications Inc. said today that it was negotiating with banks for  $1.25 billion in financing to build its nationwide wireless network.         The agreements, outlined in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, are the latest steps in Nextel's plan to build a nationwide wireless voice and data communications network aimed at businesses and competing against the cellular industry.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Publisher Resigns At USA Weekend
abstract: Brette Popper, president and publisher of USA Weekend, a supplement that the  Gannett Company distributes through Sunday newspapers, said yesterday that she would resign at the end of the month. Two executives at USA Weekend were promoted to succeed Ms. Popper, 38, who joined Gannett 11 years ago. Marcia Bullard, 43, editor, becomes president and takes a new post, chief executive. And Charles M. Gabrielson, 46, executive vice president, becomes publisher.

headline: Brazil Plant Seen For Chrysler
abstract: Chrysler Corp says it will build Dakota pickup truck factory in Brazil; analysts estimate such an assembly plant, which will use parts made elsewhere, would cost $100 million to $400 million; trucks will be sold mainly in Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay (S)

headline: His Doctors Give Yeltsin an Unexpected Tonic: He Is Fit for Surgery
abstract: Boris N Yeltsin's doctors, calming mounting concern that Russian leader may be too sick to rule Russia, say that he will go ahead with bypass operation and is expected to make full recovery; optimistic prognosis, endorsed by renowned American specialist Dr Michael E DeBakey, gives badly needed lift to Yeltsin Government, which has been shaken by assertions that he might be too sick to risk surgery; photo (M)

headline: F.D.A. APPROVES MARKETING OF NEW GENZYME MEMBRANE
abstract: Genzyme Corp receives approval from Food and Drug Administration to market Seprafilm, bioengineered membrane that surgeons can use to prevent internal scar tissue from forming after abdominal or pelvic surgery (S)

headline: Dubrovnik Is Seeking A New Path For Tourism
abstract: Normality is returning to Dubrovnik, Croatia, after war; city, which once earned 85 percent of its revenue from tourism, seeks to upgrade tourist facilities but switch stress to becoming boutique version of antiquity and beach; also seeks to develop other economic alternatives (M)

headline: American Express Scrambles to Remake Its Credit Unit
abstract: American Express Co, scrambling to regain market share, has shifted focus from charge-card business to more popular credit cards, introducing variety of new cards in last 18 months; has signed up hundreds of thousands of new merchants and reversed decline in number of card holders, sharply increased loan balances and raised overall profitability of its cards; gains have not kept pace with those of leading card issuer; vice chairman Kenneth I Chenault cites plans to speed growth; will let banks issue own American Express cards; table; drawing; photos (M)

headline: Muslim and Croatian Leaders Approve Federation for Bosnia
abstract: US Sec of State Warren Christopher, trying to save Dayton peace accord, announces that Bosnian Muslim and Croatian leaders have agreed to create federation to jointly govern Muslims and Croats in half of Bosnia (M)(

headline: A Publisher's Trademark: Low Advances and High Prestige
abstract: Profile of Roger W Straus Jr, who is about to turn 80 but has no intention of relinquishing reins of Farrar, Straus & Giroux, the prestigious publishing house he founded; he continues to resist transformation of publishing into a business of brand-name authors and big advances, a stance that has not prevented him from attracting and keeping the most acclaimed authors; Verlagsgruppe Georg von Holtzbrinck, the German publisher to whom he sold a controlling interest in Farrar, Strauss in 1994, is well content with Straus's continued leadership; Jonathan Galassi is heir apparent; list of Farrar, Straus's Nobel and Publizer winners; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Business Digest of major business news in today's newspaper

headline: U.S. Bomb Drops in Mishap
abstract: An American plane accidentally dropped a 500-pound bomb that exploded near a  United States military base in northern Bosnia today, NATO officials said.         The bomb fell from an FA-18 plane during a routine training exercise. No one  was wounded in the blast, southwest of Brcko, 100 miles north of Sarajevo, said a NATO spokesman, Lieut. Col. Max Marriner.

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: Epic Design Technology Inc, Sunnyvale, Calif, to acquire Cida Technology, also based in Sunnyvale, for $3.75 million in cash and 810,000 Epic Design shares; Textron Inc, Providence, RI, acquires Bunton Co for undisclosed terms; Rhone-Poulenc Inc, Princeton, NJ, to close down manufacturing activities at its factory in Dayton, NJ, in April 1997, affecting 42 jobs; Urban Shopping Centers Inc, Chicago, says its retail division lost nine property management contracts that accounts for about 4 percent of company's total annual revenue (S)

headline: Software Error Returns Patent Office Mail
abstract: Postal Service official says software problem caused nearly two weeks worth of mail to Patent and Trademark Office's Washington branch, an estimated 50,000 pieces, to be returned to senders; says patent applications and other time-sensitive documents may well have been among pieces affected (S)

headline: Netanyahu, Home, Finds Honeymoon Is Waning
abstract: Fresh from an American tour and boasting that Washington did not try to "twist my arm," Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has returned to new pressures  at home, and is bracing for some arm-twisting by his Arab neighbors.         Upon his return, Mr. Netanyahu was greeted by withering criticism from his predecessor, Shimon Peres, and a call by Israel's umbrella labor federation for  a general strike on Wednesday. And as Mr. Netanyahu heads to Cairo on Thursday for his first face-to-face encounter with an Arab head of state since he became  Prime Minister, even his supporters have warned that he has a difficult mission  ahead.

headline: India to Block Completion Of Pact to Ban Nuclear Tests
abstract: India has decided to block an international nuclear test ban treaty now in the final stages of negotiations, saying it is coercive, the country's chief negotiator said today.         India had long objected to certain aspects of the treaty and was not likely to sign it, but its most recent decision raises a new hurdle in the struggle to  complete the agreement, which is being debated at a conference in Geneva. India's decision also clouds chances that the treaty will be ready for signing in September, as the United States had hoped.

headline: Motorola Warns Quarterly Profits Will Shrink
abstract: Motorola Inc warns Wall Street that disappointing sales of semiconductors, cellular phones and paging products are taking much bigger toll on its earnings than analysts had been projecting for third quarter; Motorola says earnings for quarter ending Sept 28 could be down 'significantly,' word company has used in past only to refer to changes of 25 percent or more (M)

headline: The Path of Capitalism
abstract: To the Editor:         "Beneficial Capitalism, R.I.P." sustained a balanced tone in delineating serious and controversial subject matter.

headline: 300 Slain in Attack on Camp For Refugees in Burundi Strife
abstract: An attack by rebels on a refugee camp in Burundi has left more than 300 people dead and 100 wounded, local journalists said today.         The journalists who visited the attack site in central Burundi said they counted 304 bodies and 100 wounded people from the attack on Saturday. The attack was by Hutu rebels on Tutsi who had been displaced from elsewhere in Burundi during the intensifying ethnic warfare in that country.

headline: Dominican Republic Holds Runoff, Capping Fierce Race
abstract: Both presidential candidates are men of the left who have scrambled back toward the center. As a result, the runoff vote here today has been transformed  into a brutal struggle for power in which ideology means virtually nothing and personalities, feuds, grudges, innuendo and deal-making have determined almost everything.         After months of campaigning and a preliminary round of balloting six weeks ago, voters in this Caribbean nation of 7.5 million turned out in large numbers  to choose between Leonel Fernandez Reyna of the Dominican Liberation Party and Jose Francisco Pena Gomez of the Dominican Revolutionary Party. Final results are not expected until late Monday.

headline: Finding Faith the Hard Way: The Pluck of the Irish
abstract: Article on Station Island in Lough Derg, northwestern Ireland, which has been shrine for Christian pilgrims from Ireland and European continent for centuries; approximately 15,000 Irish men and women come each summer during 10-week pilgrimage season to walk about stony islet and pray in their bare feet; photo; map (M)

headline: Chechen Rebels Trying to Act As a De Facto Government
abstract: Chechen rebels who fought Russian Army to standstill have begun to assert themselves as budding government in disputed republic six days after signing of peace agreement; under accord, which defers decision on Chechen independence, Russians remain in Chechnya as formal partners in administering breakaway region; map; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Supreme Court Finds Shift By U.S. Unfair to S.& L.'s The Supreme Court ruled that the Government knowingly went back on its word through accounting changes that plunged three savings and loans into insolvency. The case could cost taxpayers billions in breach-of- contract damages.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Bertelsmann Affirms It Wants Digital TV System in Germany
abstract: Bertelsmann A.G., which has planned to start a digital television system in Germany, said today that it was talking with a rival, the Kirch Group, about how best to do so. But Bertelsmann denied that it wanted to take a stake in Kirch's  digital channel and said it still wanted its own.         Early today, Ulrike Grunrock-Kern, a Bertelsmann spokeswoman, said the company might seek an alliance with Kirch, whose digital channel, DF1, is to start this weekend. But later Bertelsmann said that its talks with Kirch covered only technical matters and marketing.

headline: Media
abstract: IT just seems so right for the 90's.         KYPA-AM, Your Personal Achievement Radio, went on the air in February with a  slogan reminiscent of all-news radio -- "Give us 21 minutes, and we'll change your life" -- and the personal-growth equivalent of a Top 40 station's play list.

headline: CENTURY COMMUNICATIONS TO ACQUIRE 3 CABLE SYSTEMS
abstract: Jones Intercable Inc to sell two Southern California cable television systems to Century Communications Corp for $140 million; Jones Growth Partners II LP to sell third system to Century for $36 million (S)

headline: Heated Bonn-Moscow Debate About Art: Prize or Plunder?
abstract: More than half a century has passed since the Soviet occupiers of a defeated  Germany perpetrated what Germans regard as the art theft of all time: By German  accounts, more than 200,000 works of art and countless books and documents were  carried off to the Soviet Union at the end of World War II.         And today, with Germany reunified and the cold war behind them, Russia and Germany remain in history's grasp over one last campaign from that era, the fight for control of Renoirs and Rembrandts.

headline: Venezuela Gets Big I.M.F. Credit, Backing Market Reforms
abstract: Venezuela was awarded a $1.4 billion credit from the International Monetary Fund yesterday, a distinction that also serves as a seal of approval on the country's economic reform package.         Venezuela's plans to create an open, market-oriented economy, free of the stifling controls and regulations that once characterized virtually all the countries of Latin America, were introduced there in April by the Government of President Rafael Caldera.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HAMBURGER HAMLET FILES PLAN WITH BANKRUPTCY COURT
abstract: Hamburger Hamlet Restaurants Inc. of Sherman Oaks, Calif., said yesterday that it had filed a reorganization plan with the United States Bankruptcy Court  that would cancel its shareholders' rights to company property. The company said the filing was in response to an offer on Tuesday from Grill Concepts Inc. of San Vicente, Calif., to buy some assets, including as many as 19 restaurants, from Hamburger Hamlet for about $10 million in cash, notes and warrants. Under the reorganization plan, the amount paid by Grill Concepts and any remaining assets would be distributed to pay Hamburger Hamlet's creditors and the costs of its bankruptcy case. Shareholders would not receive anything for their stock.

headline: Acapulco's Smut Ring: The Children Remember
abstract: United States Postal Service, with series of arrests that began in May, reports closing down major child pornography ring based in Acapulco, Mex, that was run by Americans; has arrested 56 people across US so far who received by mail order videotapes showing sex involving young Mexican boys; identifies Clair Anthony Frank, whose Aug 1995 death Acapulco police called suicide, as ringleader; his alleged partner, John William Willets, is fugitive, and another alleged partner, James Leroy Kemmish, is serving 5-year jail term for distributing child pornography through mail; case, involving some 300 street boys, has spurred call for tighter Mexican laws; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Technology Stocks Rise, Leading Markets Higher  Stocks recouped some of their losses as the strong earnings reported by Dell Computer sparked a rally in personal computer makers and other technology issues.    The Dow Jones industrial average rose 19.60 points, to 5,666.88, after falling 57.70 points on Tuesday. The Nasdaq composite index, heavy with shares of technology companies, rose 7.36 points. $(Page D8.$)    Prices of Treasury bonds were mixed, as fresh economic data somewhat reassured investors. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond was 6.78 percent, unchanged from Tuesday. $(D18.$)    Fidelity Pares Chrysler Stake  Fidelity Investments cut its Chrysler holdings by more than a third last month, perhaps contributing to a large selloff in Chrysler. S.E.C. filings by Fidelity's parent showed Fidelity mutual funds owned 57.21 million Chrysler shares at the end of July, or 7.8 percent of the total, down from 81.84 million, or 12.2 percent, at the end of March. $(D8.$)    Morgan Stanley Settles Lawsuit  Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $20 million to settle a lawsuit brought against it by West Virginia over a failed investment strategy that ultimately cost the state $280 million and forced it to raise taxes. $(D2.$)    Productivity Slipped Last Quarter  Workplace productivity slipped at an annual rate of one-tenth of 1 percent in the second quarter, the Labor Department reported. Separately, the Commerce Department said business inventories rose one-tenth of 1 percent in June, while sales slipped five-tenths of 1 percent. $(D4.$)    National Steel Chief Demoted  National Steel said that it would strip V. John Goodwin of the post of chief executive, but ask him to stay as president and chief operating officer. $(D4.$)    Earnings Fall at Berkshire Hathaway  Berkshire Hathaway said earnings dropped slightly in the second quarter after recording an investment loss of $2.5 million. $(D4.$)    F.D.A. Delivers Smoking Proposal  The F.D.A. has given the White House its proposed rule to ban the marketing of cigarettes to young people. The White House has 90 days to negotiate any changes. $(D20.$)    Valujet Seeks to Renegotiate Debt  Valujet is trying to renegotiate its debt in an effort to avoid default, the company said. $(D2.$)    A Clinton Book on the Future  President Clinton has written a book about his vision for the future. The President has waived royalties and an advance, so the book, published by Random House and with a first printing of 400,000, will sell for $16.95. $(D20.$)    Managed-Care Plan Moves Ahead  New York State's plan to move its 3.5 million Medicaid recipients into managed care plans took a major step forward. $(B1.$)    Genta Inc. Sees Difficulties  Genta, a biotechnology company, said it would close unless it raised more money and said it no longer met Nasdaq listing criteria. $(D2.$)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Elida Faberge, London, a unit of Unilever P.L.C., to Bartle Bogle Hegarty, London, to handle three brands -- Pears soap, Salon Selectives hair-care products and Lynx skin systems -- with combined billings estimated at $9.4 million.    National Potato Board, Denver, to McClain Finlon Advertising, Denver, as first international agency of record. Billings were estimated at $3 million. Ketchum Advertising San Francisco, a unit of the Omnicom Group, continues as domestic agency of record.    Baby Publishing Group, New York, to Lunt Sausville Burek, New York, as its first agency. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: New Acquisition For Medpartners
abstract: Medpartners/Mulliken Inc., the largest manager of doctors groups in the United States, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Summit Medical Group for an undisclosed amount of stock.

headline: Tele-Communications Says 2d-Quarter Loss Jumped
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc reports loss of $184 million in second quarter compared with loss of $95 million in corresponding quarter; revenue rose nearly 23 percent, to $2.02 billion from $1.65 billion; table (L)

headline: Is the U.N. Inefficient? U.S. Critics Draw Retort
abstract: Stung by charges of waste and mismanagement from Congress and the Clinton Administration, United Nations officials are fighting back against criticisms that they say are politically motivated and based on misinformation or no information at all.         Joseph E. Connor, who was recruited in 1994 by Secretary of State Warren Christopher to join the United Nations as an Under Secretary General for administration, took exception last week to Washington's assertion that Boutros  Boutros-Ghali, the Secretary General, was holding up reform. The Administration, which vows to block a second term for Mr. Boutros-Ghali, has said that is one reason to oppose him.

headline: Q & A / Kim Jong U : North Korea's Bid for Investment
abstract: HONG KONG—  Buffeted by food shortages and serious flooding, political isolation and poverty, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea hopes to convince foreign investors that it is open for business despite being perhaps the world's most rigid remaining Communist regime. The establishment of the Rajin-Sonbong Free Economic and Trade zone in the Tumen River area along the country's northeast border with China and Russia is Pyongyang's strategy for attracting investment without opening much of country to other influences.

headline: Holt & Ross Merges With DKB
abstract: DKB & Partners and Holt & Ross Inc merge to form agency, using DKB & Partners name; terms not disclosed; Gary J Davis, president and chief executive of DKB, will contininue in those roles in merged firm (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CLEAR CHANNEL TO PROPOSE MERGER WITH TICHENOR MEDIA
abstract: Clear Channel Communications Inc., which is buying the Heftel Broadcasting Corporation, said yesterday that it would propose a $184 million merger between  Heftel and Tichenor Media System Inc. The merger would expand Heftel's presence  in Spanish-language broadcasting. Clear Channel is acquiring the remaining 79 percent of Heftel it does not own for $183.6 million. Under Clear Channel's plans, Tichenor Media holders would exchange their stock for about 5.7 million Heftel class A common shares and about $3.2 million in cash. Heftel's shares rose 75 cents, to $32.50, in Nasdaq trading. Tichenor Media, based in Dallas, operates 20 Spanish-language radio stations in six markets. Heftel, based in Las Vegas, Nev., operates 17 radio stations.

headline: A Swarm of Cabs, All Making a Beeline for Fares
abstract: Driving a taxi has become fastest-growing profession in Lima, Peru, in country with widespread unemployment and virtually no regulation of public transportation; recent arrival of low-cost imports from Asia allows many Peruvians not only to buy car for first time but to use it as taxi; photos (M)

headline: Sales Sputter And Retailers Cite Weather
abstract: Goldman Sachs retail composite index, which tracks sales data from about 60 retailers, reports results were worst performance for month of July in eight years, with index gaining 1.9 percent, compared with 3,6 percent in July 1995; several large retailers cite cooler temperatures and interest in Summer Olympic Games as factors that kept consumers out of stores; overall results for July are latest indication of an economy moderating from stronger levels of growth in spring; graph on retail sales; chart on sales for some large retailers (L)

headline: Can Unemployment Fall Further Without Setting Off Inflation?
abstract: Decline in unemployment to its lowest level in seven years has focused added attention on issue that increasingly dominates policy debates and financial markets: whether economy has changed so fundamentally in recent years that it can accommodate lower rate of unemployment, and resulting wage increases, without reigniting inflation; over the last two years, as unemployment rate edged below 6 percent and slid gradually down to its current level of 5.1 percent, economists have had to reassess one of their most widely accepted assumptions: that the natural rate of unemployment is a little more than 6 percent; assumption held that below that rate, labor markets would become so tight that wages would surge, sending prices upward; graphs (L)

headline: Canal Plus Says It Joins TV Talks
abstract: The French pay television company Canal Plus said today that along with Rupert Murdoch it was participating in talks involving Bertelsmann and Kirch, two German media companies, about digital television in Germany.         The talks, if successful, would combine the efforts of a number of Europe's biggest media concerns to create digital satellite television in the Continent's biggest market.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Loss at Groupe Bull Widened in First Half
abstract: Groupe Bull, the biggest computer company in France, said yesterday that its  net loss more than quadrupled in the first half, mainly because of losses at Zenith Data Systems, a former Groupe Bull subsidiary.          Bull posted a net loss of 612 million French francs ($122 million), compared with a net loss of 125 million francs a year earlier. Zenith Data Systems had 661 million francs in mainly one-time losses, as computer sales fell 17.5 percent, Bull said. Zenith Data Systems was merged into Packard Bell Electronics in April 1996; Groupe Bull has retained a stake in Packard Bell. Groupe Bull's sales fell 3.6 percent, to 11.4 billion francs ($2.3 billion), in  the period.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;UNITED DOMINION RAISES OFFER FOR COMMERCIAL INTERTECH
abstract: United Dominion Industries raised its offer yesterday to buy the stock of the Commercial Intertech Corporation to $30 a share from $27 a share. Including the  assumption of debt, United Dominion, a building products maker based in Charlotte, N.C., put the value of its new offer at $550 million. On Friday, Commercial Intertech advised its stockholders to reject United Dominion's offer  to acquire their shares and reaffirmed two moves designed to raise the price of its stock: a buyback of 2.5 million shares and the spinoff of its Cuno filtration unit. Commercial Intertech, based in Youngstown, Ohio, makes hydraulic components, building systems and fluid purification systems.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;RYKA GETS MERGER PROPOSAL FROM KPR SPORTS
abstract: Ryka Inc., a maker of women's athletic shoes, said yesterday that companies owned by its chairman and chief executive, Michael Rubin, had proposed that Ryka acquire them in a stock deal valued at $61.6 million. Mr. Rubin owns KPR Sports  International Inc. and its affiliates. KPR markets the Apex One and Yukon shoe brands. Last year, KPR had sales of $43 million. Under the proposal, Ryka would  issue about 140 million shares to KPR shareholders. Ryka's stock rose 1 cent, to 39 cents. Ryka, based in King of Prussia, Pa., would be the surviving company in the merger. It makes shoes for aerobics, aqua conditioning, walking and running. The merger proposal also provides that Ryka would effect a 1-for-20 reverse stock split.

headline: Hicks, Muse and Travelers in Mexico Deal
abstract: Group led by Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc and Travelers Group Inc to buy $153 million of the stock of Mexican insurer Seguros Comercial America; investment will be first in Mexico by Hicks, Muse (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.25   5.10   5.96        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.15   5.13   5.29        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.28   5.31   5.29        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.91   6.91   6.18        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   7.11   7.11   6.52        TELEPHONE BONDS   8.17   8.16   7.50        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   6.03   6.03   5.99          *Estimated daily average, source Telerate  **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Earle Palmer Loses Two Big Clients
abstract: A large client of Earle Palmer Brown and an account handled in partnership with a second shop are both leaving the agency.         USAir Inc. shifted the retail portion of its account from Earle Palmer to the McCann-Erickson New York unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, which has handled smaller assignments like corporate advertising. Combined billings were estimated at $60 million to $65 million. David Castelveter, a spokesman for USAir in Arlington, Va., confirmed reports of the consolidation this week in trade publications.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;United Airlines Is Put Up for Review
abstract: The United Airlines unit of the UAL Corporation unexpectedly placed its account in review yesterday after 31 years at the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago. Billings were estimated at $60 million to $70 million.         Connie Huff, a spokeswoman for UAL in Elk Grove Village, Ill., said the review was part of a process by which "every division of the company is currently reviewing its business practices." Burnett and five agencies that she  declined to identify have been invited to participate, she said, adding that a decision is expected by mid-October.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: * Thomas Groves was named to the new post of chief planning officer at Warwick Baker O'Neill, New York. He had been a senior partner and deputy director for account planning at the J. Walter Thompson New York unit of the WPP Group. Also  at Warwick Baker, Margaret Lewis, associate media director, was promoted to media director, succeeding Mike Haggerty, who left to join Wells Rich Greene BDDP, New York, a unit of BDDP Worldwide, in a similar capacity.

headline: U.S. Starts Trial of Reputed Mexico Drug Boss
abstract: Trial of Juan Garcia Abrego, reputed drug trafficker accused of transforming Mexico's drug trade from backwoods marijuana operation into $4 billion cocaine industry, begins in Federal court in Houston eight months after he was arrested in Mexico and expelled to US; most important issue in trial is not conviction, but whether proceedings give him opportunity or incentive to clarify what he knows about how narcotics have corrupted Mexican politics (M)

headline: Buzz Enterprises Promotes Four
abstract: Eden Collinsworth, president and chief executive of Buzz magazine, is promoted to added new post of president of Buzz Enterprises; Mark Smelzer, associate publisher of Buzz magazine, is promoted to publisher, succeeding Allan Mayer, magazine's editor in chief, who had held that position temporarily after Susan Gates left; Jocelyn McCormick, publishing director of Buzz magazine, is promoted to new post of vice president for publishing at Buzz Enterprises; Scott Kramer, vice president for marketing and development at Buzz Enterprises, is named to new post of senior vice president for business development (S)

headline: Plan to Cut TV Channel Angers Women's Groups
abstract: Plans by Tele-Communications Inc to drop Lifetime Channel, service aimed at women, from cable systems in several areas of the country have prompted unusually angry, well-organized protest from women's groups and many prominent political figures, who call decision blow to interests of women; TCI has announced it intends to drop number of cable channels, including Lifetime, by Oct 7, to make room for all-news channel being created by Rupert Murdoch's Fox Inc, a channel in which TCI has a deal to become a partner; among those criticizing cable company are Sen Bill Bradley, Repr Patricia Schroeder, Libby Pataki, wife of New York State Gov George E Pataki, Repr Peter A DeFazio of Oregon, who represents the district, including city of Eugene, which has most viewers of any region affected by TCI decision (L)

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article on June 30 about the corporate deal makers of the 1980's misstated a holding of the family of Jay A. Pritzker, the Chicago financier. The family has a partial interest in Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd.; it does not own Regency  Cruises Inc.

headline: From Italy, a Model T for the 90's;Fiat Joins Race to Build a Car With Worldwide Appeal
abstract: When Fiat, with Latin frenzy, brought out its "world car" in Brazil in April, the big Italian auto maker called it the Palio, after the breakneck horse race that the Tuscan city of Siena has staged in its cobbled lanes since the Middle Ages.         It is an aptly named effort because the goal of designing a car that can be built and sold in pretty much the same form worldwide is fast becoming something of a steeplechase on wheels. And for Fiat, which has had trouble reaching out beyond Europe, the Palio represents its most ambitious marketing attempt to compete with its Japanese and American rivals.

headline: Coffee Prices Rise as Colombia Increases Payments to Farmers
abstract: Coffee futures prices rise after Colombia raises amount it pays farmers by 17 percent in response to heavy rains that cut crop; coffee for Dec delivery rises 1.95 cents, to $1.17 a pound (S)

headline: Business Travel;The cost of doing business on the road is expected to increase by 4.7% next year.
abstract: THE cost of traveling for business will rise 4.7 percent next year, led by an 8.5 percent increase in car rentals and a 7.5 percent advance in lodging costs.  Air travel, which amounts to about 41 percent of total travel spending, and ground transportation will each increase 4 percent.         Those estimates, by Runzheimer International, the management consulting firm  that tracks such matters, are exactly that -- estimates. But Runzheimer said businesses could offset expected increases with policies like trading down to compact cars or economy hotels.

headline: 2 Spirits Marketers Alter Accounts
abstract: Paddington Corp assigns ads account for Di Saronno Amaretto to Grace & Rothschild; names Gyro Worldwide to handle 'special brand-building projects'; Remy Cointreau names Bartle Bogle Hegarty to handle international creative portion of the Cointreau account (S)

headline: Stocks Gain in Japan
abstract: Stocks trade higher in Tokyo on Sept 9; at midday break, Nikkei index of 225 issues is up 94.25 points to 20,246.78 (S)

headline: SPENDING IT;Nasty Calls at 6 A.M.: Dunners Who Go Too Far
abstract: LORETTA BROADWAY of Meriden, Conn., owed $373 to a catalogue merchandiser in  1993 when she received a letter from what she assumed was a law firm. The letter threatened to have her car and bank account seized if she did not pay up. On the letterhead were the scales of justice and the name of the firm, Goldman & Levine.          The letter was from G & L Financial Services, a debt collection agency in Secaucus, N.J., according to Ms. Broadway's lawyer, Joanne Faulkner of New Haven. When Ms. Faulkner spoke with the company, she said she received the "most obscene phone call I had ever gotten." Eventually, she helped Ms. Broadway win a $22,000 judgment against the company for violating the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. In June, the Federal Trade Commission obtained a consent order against G & L Financial Services, doing business as Goldman & Levine, for violating at least half a dozen provisions of the act. The company did not respond to a request for comment.

headline: Durable Goods Orders Fell More Than Forecast in June
abstract: Orders for durable goods declined in June, weighed down by weaker demand for  aircraft, cars and business equipment, the Commerce Department reported today.         New orders for durable goods fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in June to a seasonally adjusted $169.07 billion -- slightly weaker than the drop of six-tenths of 1 percent Wall Street economists had anticipated.

headline: MARINE MIDLAND TO BUY S.& L. IN ROCHESTER
abstract: Marine Midland Bank agrees to buy First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Rochester from CT Financial Services Inc of Toronto for $620 million (S)

headline: For Bank's Boy Wonder, Gray Hairs and Lessons
abstract: I'VE made every mistake that anybody in the business has made," John S. Reed says, twirling his half-glasses in his hotel-room armchair.         He has too much gray in his black hair to be banking's boy wonder anymore. He is still an eclectic thinker, with more interest in the future than in the stodgy ways of banking. But Mr. Reed now blends his enthusiasm with a new sobriety forged in 12 painful years as chairman and chief executive of Citicorp.

headline: Richards Group Opening New Office
abstract: Richards Group to open its first office outside Dallas; it has hired Virgil Shutze to head joint venture based in Atlanta (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PERFUMANIA GROUP DROPS PLAN TO TAKE COMPANY PRIVATE
abstract: Perfumania Inc. said yesterday that the management group that proposed taking the discount perfume retailer private by buying the shares it doesn't already control for $6 each has withdrawn its offer. On June 28, a group controlled by Simon Falic, the chairman and chief executive, and other executives had said it  would buy out other holders. The main reason for the withdrawal "is that the largest shareholder wouldn't come on board with me," Mr. Falic said. The largest shareholder, with about 1.5 million shares, is the former chairman and chief executive of the company, Ilia Lekatch. The company had 6.69 million shares outstanding as of May 4. The stock of Perfumania rose 9.4 cents, to $3.531.

headline: Europe Slaps Turkey, but Some Say the Slap Was Too Hard
abstract: Turkey's human rights record has come under new criticism in recent days, but several leading American and European officials warn against judging record too harshly (M)

headline: Senior Bosnian Serbs Face New Warrants
abstract: The United Nations war crimes tribunal issued international arrest warrants for the Bosnian Serbs' political leader, Radovan Karadzic, and their military chief, Gen. Ratko Mladic, both charged with genocide in the four-year Bosnian war.         The warrants oblige United Nations members to arrest the men if they enter their countries. But so far Western countries have not been willing to have their peacekeepers in Bosnia seek out the two leaders.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Judges Rule Against Law To Ban Internet Smut Three Federal judges in New York ruled that the Government's attempts to halt indecent material on the Internet were unconstitutionally broad and voted to grant a temporary injunction against enforcing the Communications Decency Act, which President Clinton signed on Feb. 8.

headline: U.S. and Bosnia Sign Pact on Investment
abstract: The United States and Bosnia signed an agreement today to provide incentives  to American businesses to help Bosnia recover from the war.         The agreement between Bosnia and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation  enables American businesses to receive the corporation's support for long-term investments.

headline: Rules Approved To Let Trading Resume Faster
abstract: Federal regulators yesterday approved rules to allow the stock market and the stock index futures market to resume trading more rapidly in the event either is forced to halt trading by plunging prices.         The current rules for the New York Stock Exchange, which have never been used, call for trading to halt for one hour if the Dow Jones industrial average  has fallen 250 points, and for two hours if it reopens and then falls to a 400-point loss. The new rules, effective Monday, would halve those periods, to 30 minutes and one hour.

headline: BMW turns to fashion, and media and retail partners, to promote its stylish Z3 Roadster.
abstract: Advertising column describes how BMW of North America is turning to fashion, and media and retail partners, to promote its stylish Z3 Roadster; BMW pitch, known in Madison Avenue parlance as an integrated marketing campaign, will cost more than $2 million; elements of campaign range from distributing free program for VH1 awards show with copies of Vogue, to BMW and Vogue serving as hosts of awards-show 'viewing parties' in 10 cities, to displaying Z3's at Nordstrom stores (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Botswana Is Pressing Bushmen to Leave Reserve
abstract: The 1,000 Bushmen on this vast reserve are often described as the last Bushmen on earth living their traditional hunter-gatherer life. But this is a romantic view.         In the settlement here called Xade, five hours from the nearest town, there are plenty of signs of Western civilization, from the tin cans that litter the desert floor to the plastic milk crates that are used as chairs and the prefabricated schoolrooms brought in on trailer beds.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MUZAK POSTPONES ITS INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING OF STOCK
abstract: Muzak Inc. of Seattle postponed yesterday its planned $69 million initial public offering amid a weaker market for new stocks. The company, a provider of  background music to fast-food and department stores, had planned to sell 4.6 million shares at $14 to $16 this month. The lead underwriter, Paine Webber Inc., said current market conditions caused it to postpone the sale. The market  for new issues has faltered in recent weeks as a stumbling broader market keeps investors from buying shares in unproven companies.

headline: Oil Companies Join Forces
abstract: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, or Adnoc, said today that it was forming a joint venture with Borealis, owned by Neste Oy of Finland and Statoil of Norway, to market products from their planned petrochemical plant. The proposed plant, to be owned 60 percent by Adnoc and 40 percent by Borealis, is expected to begin producing 450,000 tons of polyethylene a year when it goes on line in 2000.

headline: Consumer Price Index Barely Rises, Easing Inflation Fears
abstract: Labor Department reports consumer prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent in August, a better performance than expected and one that economists regard as solid confirmation that inflation remains in check; Commerce Department reports retail sales gained modest two-tenths of 1 percent in August; Dow Jones industrial average gains 66.58 points, or 1.15 percent, to record 5,838.52, surpassing high of 5,778 set on May 22; table; chart; graph (L)

headline: Moscow Move Casts Doubt On Accord In Chechnya
abstract: Kremlin, challenging a key provision of peace accord for Chechnya, warns that southern republic must remain part of Russia; statement is issued after top-level meeting on Chechen crisis led by Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin (M)

headline: Perry Says 'Backing Off' By Iraq Eases Need for Ships
abstract: Defense Sec William J Perry says Iraq is 'backing off' from its recent military threats and that as a result, United States could decide as early as next week to remove one of two aircraft carriers now in Persian Gulf; but says additional 3,500 American ground troops being sent to Kuwait would remain there for several months, since Iraq could resume its threats to neighbors in gulf at moment's notice (M)

headline: Moves by Campbell Soup Send Shares Surging to Reach a High
abstract: Management of Campbell Soup Co announces $160 million restructuring plan, the $210 million purchase of German soup business, a $2.5 billion stock repurchase plan and large increase in its advertising budget; shares of Campbell shoot to record high following presentation by David W Johnson, president and chief executive; revamping would entail dismissal of 650 workers, or 1.5 percent of company's work force; it will close plants in Atlanta, Ga, and Lakeland, Fla, sell poultry processing operations in three states and close poultry research operation; advertising expenditures will be increased 30 percent to $250 million; Campbell will buy Erasco Group, German market-share leader in soups, from Grand Metropolitan PLC for $210 million in cash; Johnson says goal is for Campbell to create stronger international presence; graphs (L)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF SCIENTIFIC GAMES HOLDINGS DROP 32 PERCENT
abstract: The stock of the Scientific Games Holdings Corporation skidded more than 32 percent yesterday, after the company, a lottery-ticket maker, warned of a slowdown over the coming months. The company, based in Alpharetta, Ga., cited lower prices because of competition in the lottery industry and sluggish international sales for its prediction of "moderate growth" in the next few quarters. On Monday, after the market closed, the company reported earnings for the period ended June 30 that were in line with Wall Street's expectations.  Scientific Games' stock slipped $9.625 yesterday, to $19.625, in Nasdaq trading  of almost 1.7 million shares.

headline: Wall Street Is Calmer As Stocks Rise Again
abstract: Shoulders dropped a little on Wall Street yesterday, as a reassuring day ended with all the major market benchmarks higher in extremely heavy trading. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 18.12 points, and the badly battered  Nasdaq composite index, rose 33.18 points, or 3.15 percent -- the index's largest single-day jump ever.          The tension-easing session suggested that investors had not fled the market  in disgust after a two-week downturn. Corporate earnings that were better than expected helped spur the market.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Donors Increase Fund To Rebuild Cambodia
abstract: International donors and lending agencies pledged today to give an additional $500 million to help Cambodia rebuild its economy after years of war. Japan is the largest contributor, promising up to $90 million in development aid and $2.5 million to clear land mines.         The $500 million pledged for 1996 was "an exceptionally high level of aid on  a per-capita basis," said Javad K. Shirazi, co-chairman of the donors' meeting and director of the World Bank's East Asia and Pacific region.

headline: Lebed Gains Victory in Defense Ministry
abstract: The Russian Army general chosen today by President Boris N. Yeltsin to head the Defense Ministry represents a bureaucratic victory for the administration's  new security adviser, Aleksandr I. Lebed.         The new Defense Minister, Col. Gen. Igor N. Rodionov, is a contentious figure among reformers because of his role in a brutal crackdown on peaceful demonstrations in Georgia during the waning years of the Soviet Union.

headline: CURRENCY MARKINGS;Dollar Tops 110 Yen on Signs Japanese Won't Raise Rates
abstract: The dollar rose above 110 yen for the first time in 29 months yesterday, as concern faded that the Bank of Japan would soon raise interest rates.         "The overriding thing that's really driving the currency is the consistent insistence from the Japanese that any further rate hikes are further down the road," said Ricardo Gomes, foreign exchange chief at the Republic National Bank of New York.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;EMERSON RADIO INCREASES ITS OFFER FOR JENSEN SHARES
abstract: The Emerson Radio Corporation said yesterday that it was willing to increase  to $10 a share from $8.90 its offer for William Blair Leveraged Capital Fund's shares in International Jensen Inc. Emerson, based in Parsippany, N.J., also said it was willing to buy all of Blair's stock immediately. Jensen has already  agreed to be acquired by the Recoton Corporation, based in Lake Mary, Fla., for  $101.7 million, in the form of $11 a share to holders other than Jensen's president, Robert Shaw, and Blair, and $8.90 a share for Mr. Shaw and Blair. Mr. Shaw and Blair together control 63 percent of Jensen. Emerson's new offer is its latest for Jensen, based in Lincolnshire, Ill., a loudspeaker manufacturer and distributor.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;IDEX TO BUY MAKER OF COLOR FORMULATION EQUIPMENT
abstract: The IDEX Corporation, which makes fluid handling and industrial products, said yesterday that it would acquire Fluid Management L.P. for about $135 million. Fluid Management, an affiliate of the Saranow Company of Wheeling, Ill., makes color formulation equipment for paints, coatings, inks, colorants and dyes. It has manufacturing operations in Wheeling and other operations in the Netherlands, Germany and Australia. Fluid Management has annual sales of about $90 million. The shares of IDEX, which is based in Northbrook, Ill., rose  75 cents, to $38.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Mexico to Dismiss 737 From National Police
abstract: Mexico Atty Gen Antonio Lozano, responding to criticism of persistent corruption in one of Mexico's national law enforcement agencies, says he is dismissing more than 700 commanders and agents--about one in every six officers (S)

headline: MAGNA TO BUY HOMELAND BANKSHARES FOR $216 MILLION
abstract: Magna Group Inc to buy Homeland Bankshares Corp for $216 million in stock and cash (S)

headline: Double Trouble at Linda Wachner's Twin Companies
abstract: Linda J Wachner, chief executive of Warnaco Group, is under fire for her role as chief executive of Authentic Fitness Corp, Warnaco's sportswear division that was spun off in 1990; Wachner's efforts to reunite two companies has Wachner tripping over herself; while $502 million stock deal for Authentic Fitness has some logic to it, it would add some $40 million to Wachner's own net worth and has angered a partner that Authentic does business with; investors and analysts are miffed enough with her indelicate handling of the matter that for now, she has had to back off, scrapping the bid on July 25; photo (L)

headline: SCHERING-PLOUGH BUYING BACK COMMON STOCK
abstract: Schering-Plough Corp says it will buy back as much as $500 million worth of its common stock (S)

headline: Rabin Killer and 2 Others Guilty of Related Plots Against Leader
abstract: Israeli court today convicts Yigal Amir, assassin of Prime Min Yitzhak Rabin, brother Hagai Amir and third Jewish nationalist, Dror Adani, of conspiring to kill Prime Minister and to attack Palestinian Arabs (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bass Seeks Stake In Beer Venture
abstract: Bass P.L.C. said yesterday that it was in talks to buy a 50 percent stake in  the Carlsberg-Tetley brewing venture, a move that would reinstate Bass as Britain's largest brewer. The announcement followed reports in the British press that Bass wanted to buy all or part of Carlsberg-Tetley, a joint venture between Allied Domecq of Britain and Carlsberg A.S. of Denmark.          Analysts said the bid by Bass was for Allied Domecq's 50 percent stake. Such a move would clear the way for Bass to combine its brewing operations with those of Carlsberg-Tetley, while Allied would be free to focus on its spirits and retail operations. The companies would not provide details of their talks, but reports over the weekend in The Sunday Times and The Observer put the price  of a 50 percent stake at about L200 million ($311.2 million).   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: People
abstract: * Mel Hioki was named senior vice president and associate creative director at Citigate Albert Frank, New York, a unit of the Citigate Group Ltd. Mr. Hioki was vice president and senior art director at the New York office of Young & Rubicam Inc.

headline: Mexicans Send Dollars Home and U.S. Companies Profit
abstract: Migration of Mexicans across border with US is producing what some experts estimate is annual transfer of some $4 billion to $6 billion back to family and friends who are shuttling to Mexican banks and wire transfer agencies to pick up money that helps them make ends meet; experts say transfer of money reflects evolution of single labor market between the two countries that is generating reliable source of dollars for Mexico; flow of money has become so steady that last month, in second deal of its type, SBC Warburg Inc, Europe-based investment bank, sold $100 million in securities tied to money moving to Banco Internacional, Mexico's fourth-largest bank, from US; last year, J P Morgan Securities Inc and Merrill Lynch & Co completed $206.5 million sale with Banco Nacional de Mexico, or Banamex, country's largest bank; tables; photos (L)

headline: Japanese Stocks Lower
abstract: Stocks were trading sharply lower here today in early trading. At the midday  break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 361.64 points, or 1.63  percent, at 21,870.78. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 60.49 points, bringing the total loss for the week to 298.33 points. The decline was blamed, in part, on the surge in United States jobs reported last week.

headline: Palestinian Police: The Breakdown and the Gunfights
abstract: Gun battles between Israeli soldiers and Palestinian police signal breakdown in system of cooperation that was carefully laid out in 1995 agreement on self rule; Palestinian officers have taken only sporadic action to restrain stone-throwing mobs; both sides say they fire in self-defense; 40,000 Palestinian officers include PLO fighters from abroad and local recruits, and are backbone of Yasir Arafat's rule in West Bank zones and Gaza (S)

headline: Lloyd's Says Most States Support Settlement
abstract: Lloyd's of London said yesterday that regulators in states representing 84 percent of its American investors had agreed to a proposal under which they would drop lawsuits in which they contended that the insurance market had deceived them about the risk of their investments.         In exchange, the investors would have their debts to Lloyd's cut by as much as 23 percent. The proposal is part of a broad settlement under which Lloyd's is seeking to reorganize after losing almost $12 billion in the late 1980's and  early 1990's.

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : As Late Summer Rolls Around, So Do Bikers in a Quiet Town
abstract: The people of little Sturgis, South Dakota, find themselves bracing each year as late summer rolls around; some leave town. What began years ago as a week of motorcycle races and rallies has evolved into perhaps the world's largest annual collection of motorcycles, and their leather-wearing, tattoo-sporting, whisky-swigging riders.

headline: U.N. Endorses a Treaty to Halt All Nuclear Testing
abstract: UN General Assembly, in 153-3 vote, approves Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty to end nuclear weapons testing; action revives hopes that voluntary test ban currently observed by world's nuclear nations may become international obligation; all five declared nuclear weapons powers pledge to sign treaty, but of three nations believed to have clandestine nuclear weapons, namely, Israel, India and Pakistan, only Israel has pledged to sign; chronology; photo (M)

headline: CELLULAR INDUSTRY REJECTS U.S. PLAN FOR SURVEILLANCE
abstract: Wireless communications industry rejects Government-backed technology that would make it possible for law enforcement agencies to keep closer tabs on cellular phone users; many industry executives and privacy-rights advocates disagree with Government's interpretation of 1994 law intended to bring law-enforcement techniques into modern era with powerful new surveillance technology; industry says new cellular abilities would be burdensomely expensive to administer, while privacy groups argue that measures Government seeks will give FBI and other law-enforcement agencies worrisome new powers over citizens (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;European Commission Clears Air France Aid
abstract: The European Commission cleared a final installment of state aid worth 5 billion French francs ($1 billion) for Air France yesterday, overriding objections from rival airlines. Other carriers said they wanted the commission to block the last round of aid amid complaints that Air France used subsidies to reduce fares on European routes.          The final subsidy payment is part of a capital increase of 20 billion francs for Air France approved by the commission in July 1994. KLM and Lufthansa said they were considering legal action against the commission, the executive agency  of the European Union.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Anabolic Steroid Use Grows, Legal or Not
abstract: Anabolic steroid use among athletes is growing; black market is huge: an estimated 500,000 Americans, mostly young, white and male, spend total of $400 million a year on the synthetic steroid hormones; quiet revolution is under way in much smaller but booming legal market for the drug; IMS America, company that compiles data for health care industry, estimates that $36.7 million worth of anabolic steroids were sold through prescriptions or administered in hospitals last year; IMS America calculates that in first five months of 1996, sales have swelled by 38.5 percent compared with corresponding period last year (L)

headline: U.A.W.'s Pact At Ford Aims At Downsizing
abstract: Ford Motor Co's new three-year contract with United Automobile Workers addresses two issues that have haunted organized labor for more than decade, namely, layoffs and moves by companies to rely more on outside suppliers; requires Ford to guarantee minimum number of union jobs, while adding incentives for company to produce more automobile parts itself; union, in exchange, will allow Ford to pay permanently lower wages in any new automobile business it enters; agreement comes at time when many large companies, including automobile makers, are downsizing work forces in effort to cut costs and deliver more value to shareholders; photos (M)

headline: People
abstract: Duncan Pollock, chairman and chief executive of the New York office of Ammirati Puris Lintas, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was promoted to the additional position of zone chairman for North America, a new post, and will join the agency's worldwide executive board.    Gary Wolfson was named to the new position of senior vice president and creative director at W. B. Doner  & Co., Southfield, Mich. He had been executive vice president and chief creative officer at Ross Roy Communications, Bloomfield Hills, Mich., a unit of the Omnicom Group.

headline: Advertising;People
abstract: Lorraine Ketch and Steve Le Neveu, group planning directors at TBWA Chiat/Day, Venice, Calif., a unit of Omnicom Group, were named co-planning directors at the New York office. They assume responsibilities held by Cathy Clift, who resigned. Also in New York, Eric McClellan, group creative director, was promoted to creative director, working with Marty Cooke, who was named to a new post, executive creative director.

headline: Bombardier of Canada Introduces a Long-Range Business Jet
abstract: Bombardier Inc, world's fourth-largest manufacturer of civil aircraft, introduces new long-range business jet that can circle world in a day; jet, called Global Express, is latest entry in increasingly competitive $2-billion-a-year executive aircraft market, which grew by 23 percent last year and is forecast to rise 10 percent more in 1996; price tag for new jet is $35 million, one-quarter of the cost of a Boeing 747 jumbo jet (L)

headline: SANDOZ TO SELL UNIT IN THE U.S. TO BASF
abstract: Sandoz AG of Switzerland says it plans to sell its North American corn herbicide business to German chemical maker BASF AG for $778 million (S)ï

headline: People
abstract: Recent appointments in advertising industry noted (S)

abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.13   4.96   5.71        3-MO. headline: KIDS MART TO CLOSE 97 STORES AND REDUCE WORKERS
abstract: Kids Mart Inc to close 97 stores and cut unspecified number of jobs in bid to reverse losses; weighs closing another 10 stores; seeks interim financing to buy inventory (S)

headline: Bosnia Election Results Certified by West Despite Fraud Charges
abstract: Organization of Security and Cooperation in Europe certifies Bosnia's election, which was intended to foster unity but was stained by accusations of intimidation and fraud; certification is viewed by many as landmark in country's move toward stability (M)

headline: British Airways In French Deal
abstract: British Airways P.L.C. announced today that it would exercise its option to buy the remaining 50.1 percent of its French partner TAT European Airlines.          British Airways will pay L21 million, or $32 million, for the stake. British Airways acquired 49.9 percent of TAT in January 1993 with an agreement to buy the balance by April 1, 1997. Bob Ayling, chief executive of British Airways, said, "We intend now to take further steps to improve TAT's profitability."

headline: Municipal Elections in Bosnia Postponed, Raising Doubts About Troop Pullout
abstract: September 14 vote for municipal officers in Bosnia is postponed because of widespread abuse of rules and regulations; vote will proceed for three-member shared national presidency, national legislature and separate Muslim-Croat and Bosnian Serb regional legislatures; action follows documentation of pattern of abuses, especially by Bosnian Serb officials, in which refugees were directed to register in strategically important towns in effort to consolidate Serbs' control of Bosnian towns that were once ethnically mixed; raises fears in Western capitals and among NATO commanders, who were to begin pullout of 53,000-member peacekeeping force by end of 1996; map (M)

headline: GGT to Pay $163 Million For BDDP
abstract: BDDP Group in Paris agrees to be acquired by GGT Group PLC of London; terms call for GGT to pay about $163 million in cash and stock (M)

headline: U.S. Finds Mexico Is Adamant on Cuba Trade
abstract: Special US envoy Stuart E Eizenstadt visits Mexico in mission for Clinton Administration to defend Helms-Burton Act, which punishes foreign companies for doing business with Cuba; Mexico, dead set against legislation which it regards as violation of international law, says it will not compromise (M)

headline: HUNTSMAN CHEMICAL SWEETENS ITS OFFER FOR REXENE
abstract: Huntsman Chemical Corp increases to $15 a share its offer to buy rival petrochemical manufacturer, Rexene Corp; latest offer increases to $281.6 million the cash portion of offier; including assumption of $175 million in Rexene debt, total offer is worth $456.6 million (S)

headline: C.F.T.C. Halts Illegal Advice
abstract: Commodity Futures Trading Commission orders Steven Jay Marks of Ocala, Fla, and J Spencer Brown of Fort Worth, Tex, to stop offering illegal trading advice over the Internet in agency's first enforcement crackdown in cyberspace (S)

headline: How a Radio Station Turned the Beat Around
abstract: Successful shift of WKTU-FM from country to disco format discussed; station, formerly WYNY, has moved from 21st to top of New York City market; turnaround has helped owner, Evergreen Media Corp, strengthen its role as major player in big-league broadcasting; table; photos (M)

headline: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC. (FD,N)
abstract: Federated Department Stores Inc lost $27.2 million in fiscal second quarter ended Aug 3, compared with loss of $66.9 million in same year-ago period; sales were $3.28 billion, up 7.8 percent from $3.05 billion a year earlier; table (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: McDonald's Corp., Oak Brook, Ill., and the Walt Disney Co. are joining for a promotion commemorating the 25th anniversary of the opening of Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla. The promotion features Disney glassware, sold with purchases of menu items, and a contest giving away vacations.

headline: Colin Mitchell Is Dead at 70; British Hero in Aden Battles
abstract: Colin Mitchell, a British officer who sacrificed his military career for one  moment of glory in 1967, died last Saturday at his home in London. He was 70.         After a brief tenure in Parliament and a later career as an itinerant military consultant, he won renewed public recognition as a founding director of a charity that clears land mines from former war zones.

headline: Jordan, McGrath And Nestle End Bond
abstract: Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor and chocolate and confections division of Nestle Food Co to end their relationship (S)

headline: U.S. Objects to Details of Plan To Let Iraq Sell Oil for Food
abstract: A plan allowing Iraq to sell limited amounts of oil to meet urgent civilian needs was thrown into jeopardy today when the Clinton Administration said Baghdad was trying to twist the exemption to import high-technology goods in violation of economic sanctions.         Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States representative here, said the  Iraqis were also hoping to get control of goods intended for Kurdish areas in the north, which they could skim off in a subversion of procedures established by a Security Council resolution.

headline: Moscow Journal;Secrets of the K.G.B.: A Very Discreet Disrobing
abstract: When the secret police came for Osip Mandelstam in 1938, the one book that this century's greatest Russian poet managed to take with him on his lonely road to Siberian exile and death was Dante's "Inferno."         With the Soviet secret police, Mandelstam knew where he was headed. Who wouldn't? Few organizations in modern history have inspired as much fear, caused more pain or managed to remain shrouded more completely in mystery. Until now.

headline: Hillary Clinton Encourages Polish Women to Press for Wider Rights
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton came to talk with women in Poland today and found, six years after the end of Communism, much what she finds at home: issues that range from sexual harassment to credit access, from family violence to politics.         She heard about the low number of women in public office, discrimination in employment and weak laws protecting the rights of women.

headline: Echoes of Franco as Spain Fires Senior TV Reporters
abstract: When José Antonio Martínez-Soler was chosen by all of Spain's political parties to conduct interviews with candidates before the general election last March, he took it as a tribute to his journalistic impartiality.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;EUROGAS PURCHASES DANUBE INTERNATIONAL PETROLEUM
abstract: Eurogas Inc. said yesterday that it had bought the closely held Danube International Petroleum Ltd. for $38 million in cash and stock. Eurogas will pay $3 million in cash, 2.5 million restricted common shares of Eurogas, 1.25 million nonvoting preferred common shares (convertible in one year to 2.5 million restricted common shares), and five-year warrants to buy up to 5 million more common shares at $3 a share. The Dallas-based Danube has majority stakes in oil and gas reserve ventures in Slovakia and the Czech Republic. Eurogas's stock was down 78.1 cents, to $4.844, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: Oil Fire Raging In South Russia
abstract: A huge fire has been raging at a southern Russian oil refinery, and local authorities said it would not be brought under control for two to three more days, Itar-Tass news agency reported.         The fire, which began five days ago because of what Tass said was a breach of security regulations, was centered on one of the oil storage areas of the refinery in Volgograd. The plant is a subsidiary of LUKoil, Russia's biggest oil company.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: N.A.S.D. and Government  Are Seen in Deal on Abuses   The Securities and Exchange Commission and the National Association of Securities Dealers are expected to announce a $100 million agreement today to end abuses on the Nasdaq stock market, people with knowledge of the deal said. The agreement came after marathon talks that included the chief executives of top Wall Street firms. $(Page D2.$)    Growth Slackens Slightly   A Federal Reserve survey found that economic growth slackened a bit in early summer as consumers spent cautiously for most big-ticket items. Wage pressures remained in check despite what appeared to be a further tightening of the job market.    This combination of less exuberant business activity and continued subdued inflation is just what policy makers and financial markets have been hoping for. $(D4.$)     New Approach to U.S. Auto Market   Daewoo, the South Korean manufacturer, plans to enter the United States auto market by opening 200 to 500 company-owned sales outlets. The plans by Daewoo, South Korea's fourth-largest conglomerate, go against current practice. First, most car makers sell their cars and trucks to independent dealers. And second, Daewoo plans to focus on students, professors and their families -- a novel approach. $(D4.$)     Dow Average Closes Above 5,700   The Dow Jones industrial average ended above 5,700 for the first time in a month, gaining 22.56 points, to 5,718.67, as vigorous buying in semiconductor stocks, inspired by Merrill Lynch's upgrading of Micron Technology, spilled over to the broader market. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 12.24 points, to 1,141.11. $(D8.$)    Disappointing demand at the Treasury's auction of new 10-year notes depressed prices in the credit markets and sent the yield on the 30-year bond up slightly to 6.77 percent. $(D18.$)    Apple Drops Plans for Upgrade   Apple Computer has scrapped plans for a major upgrade of its flagship Macintosh operating system software next year, jeopardizing what remains of its technological lead over Microsoft's Windows system. $(D2.$)     Roadblock Removed to Iraqi Oil Sale   The United States removed the last major roadblock to the sale of Iraqi oil to pay for civilian needs, but the oil was not expected to reach the market for another month. $(A9.$)    Freeport and Arcadian to Merge   Freeport-McMoran, the mining and mineral giant, announced plans for a complicated merger with Arcadian, a fertilizer producer, exchanging stock worth $1 billion. If the public owners of Freeport-McMoran's 51.6 percent owned fertilizer partnership decide to exchange their stakes, the new company would have a market value of $3 billion. $(D4.$)    401(k) Rules Are Tightened   The Labor Department, seeking to halt abuse of workers' retirement funds, required companies to invest employees' money in 401(k) plans promptly. $(D8.$)    F.D.A. Gets Tough With Pfizer   The Food and Drug Administration ordered Pfizer to stop making unauthorized claims for Zoloft, its widely used antidepressant. $(D19.$)    Profits Fall at Turner Broadcasting   Turner Broadcasting System said second-quarter earnings fell 47.9 percent because of weak results at its film unit. $(D7.$)     When They Call, People Tremble   When Fran and Barry Weissler, the producers of ''Grease'' on Broadway, call their ad agencies, the members of the creative teams tremble. The producers demand a lot from their agencies, and the success of ''Grease'' shows why. Advertising. $(D7.$)

headline: The C.I.A. Seeks Out Informers On Terrorism, and Finds Them
abstract: CIA Dir John M Deutch says agency is recruiting informers on terrorism at unprecedented pace, speech at Georgetown University; says counter-terrorist operations have helped foreign governments arrest suspects and prevented number of terrorist acts (S)

headline: Playing 'Beat the Index'? This Time, You Might Win
abstract: Carole Gould (Funds Watch) column on investing in funds that track the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index; chart (M)

headline: Computer Program Clears the Static
abstract: Bose Corp's Auditioner system combines information about materials and measurements of room to replicate existing sound, and then forecast how sound might be altered by changing certain acoustical feature; diagrams explaining computer mapping of size and sound of structure; system has been used to improve acoustics in Nassau Coliseum, Sistine Chapel, European Parliament building and other public spaces; latest high-profile job is revamping of sound system at Louisiana Super Dome (M)

headline: British Call Halt to Cow Slaughter Demanded by European Union
abstract: British Government says it is calling halt to slaughter of cattle that it had agreed to this summer as condition for gradual lifting of ban on British beef exports by European Union; British Agriculture Min Douglas Hogg mets with his European counterparts and urges them to revise agreement in light of new evidence that bovine spongiform encephyalopathy would run its course by year 2001 without huge culling called for in earlier accords (M)

headline: MARINER HEALTH PLANS TO ACQUIRE ALLIED HEALTH
abstract: Mariner Health Group Inc says it will buy Allegis Health Services Inc for about $95 million in cash and assumption of $15 million in debt (S)

headline: U.S. Strips Colombian President of His Visa
abstract: Invoking a clause in the Immigration and Naturalization Act that makes anyone who has "assisted or abetted" drug trafficking ineligible to visit the United States, the State Department said today that it had canceled the visa of President Ernesto Samper of Colombia.         "People who knowingly assist narco trafficking are no longer welcome in this  country," said the State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, who announced the decision at a press conference in Washington.

headline: German Economy Shows A Gradual Strengthening
abstract: German economy is continuing to improve gradually, with reports showing business confidence climbing to nine-month high and money supply growing faster than expected; Economics Ministry says there is evidence that recovery that started in second quarter is on track; Bundesbank leaves its full slate of rates unchanged, as had been expected (S)

headline: Pentagon Gives Contract to Raytheon Unit
abstract: Defense Department awards $169 million contract to E-Systems Inc as part of $2 billion program to modernize its computing capability; under five-year contract, computing center will be established at Army research laboratory at Aberdeen Proving Ground, Maryland (S)

headline: NATO Team Visits Bunker Used as HQ By the Serbs
abstract: NATO military inspectors tour sprawling mountainside compound in Han Pijesak, Bosnia, that served as central command post for Bosnian Serb military leader Gen Ratko Mladic and army during four years of war; declare visit success; visit ends tense standoff between peacekeeping forces and Bosnian Serbs; photo; map (M)

headline: Casting Big Nets for Latin American Channel Surfers
abstract: Galaxy Latin America and Sky Entertainment Services seek to tap into Latin American market for satellite television service; face daunting obstacles that stem from region's patchwork of countries and vastly unequal income distribution; direct broadcasting from satellite to home may be too expensive for most consumers; photos (M)

headline: SUMMIT BANCORP TO BUY B.M.J. FINANCIAL
abstract: Summit Bancorporation will buy BMJ Financial Corp for $164.5 million in stock (S)

headline: AMR TO SELL 20% OF SABRE IN A PUBLIC OFFERING
abstract: AMR Corp to sell about 20 percent of its Sabre travel reservation system to the public this year, ending months of speculation about the future of Sabre (S)

headline: STUNG BY ATTACKS, MEXICO INTENSIFIES SEARCH FOR REBELS
abstract: Mexican Govt, stung by widespread attacks this week by new leftist guerrilla orgn, condemns rebels as terrorists and steps up hunt for them in seven states; Govt of Pres Ernest Zedillo is caught off guard by coordinated assaults on military and police posts across southern Mexico by shadowy new rebel orgn, Popular Revolutionary Army; photos (M)

headline: On-Line Access to G.O.P. Convention
abstract: Guide to World Wide Web sites featuring Republican National Convention; table; drawing (M)
