headline: Enron Can Resume Big Indian Power Project
abstract: The Enron Development Corporation received approval today from the Indian Government to proceed with a controversial $2 billion power project in a western state of India.         Clearance by the national Government was the final hurdle for the stalled project 250 miles south of Bombay. Enron Development, a unit of the Enron Corporation of Houston, revised the project after the Maharashtra state government had canceled it last August.

headline: Australian Deal by Dana
abstract: The Dana Corporation has acquired the Australian filter maker James N. Kirby  for undisclosed terms. Kirby, which is closely held, makes air filters for cars  and trucks. Dana, based in Toledo, makes automotive components and industrial products.

headline: Would the Belly Wiggle or Shake?
abstract: Digital Domain artist Kevin Mack is working on digital special effects software that will enable motion picture director to create sustained shots of slow-moving digital human at lower cost and to model movements of variety of physical types; photos (S)

headline: Russian Plane Hits Mountain On Arctic Isle, Killing 140
abstract: Russian jetliner carrying more than 140 people crashes into mountain on remote Arctic island of Spitsbergen, in Norwegian territory; map; no survivors reported; passengers were mostly coal miners and their families (S)

headline: Pro-Beijing Lawyer Running For Hong Kong's Top Post
abstract: If eagerness, self-promotion, campaign speeches and tub-thumping professions  of loyalty were any measure, Lo Tak-shing would be well on his way to succeeding Hong Kong's last colonial Governor, Chris Patten, as the first chief executive under Chinese sovereignty, which begins on July 1 next year.         Once a member of the colonial administration, and a decorated British citizen, Mr. Lo now brandishes a Chinese passport and insists that he is the best man to run Hong Kong under Chinese rule. So far, he is the only announced candidate.

headline: Investors Pull Money Out of Stock Funds
abstract: Mutual fund investors, shocked by a turnaround in stock prices so sharp and so sudden that in some cases it erased a year's worth of gains in a few weeks, have pulled money out of stock funds at several of the country's biggest mutual  fund companies the last two days.         For now, most of the investors appear to be headed for the safer haven of money market funds, rather than cashing out of mutual funds entirely and stashing their money back in the bank or the mattress. While that will make it easier for fund investors to move back into stock funds once a roily market calms down, some investors clearly have been spooked by the raging volatility.

headline: Cast-off U.S. Jeans Are Prized Items
abstract: OMAHA, Nebraska—  Cheryl Sellhorst sat in her car in the gas station parking lot,waiting for Nebraskans to bring their cast-off Levi's jeans.

headline: Stocks Lower in Japan
abstract: Stock prices were trading lower here today. At the midday break, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 41.90 points, or almost two-tenths of 1 percent, at 22,488.85. On Friday, the Nikkei gained 29.14 points.

headline: Bribesville's Solitary Prisoner: He's Crying Scandal
abstract: Walter Armanini, former Milan councilman and business consultant, is only one of 2,187 people charged in Italian corruption scandal to actually serve jail sentence; Armanini returned from Brazil in January 1995 to serve five-year sentence for extorting about $200,000 in campaign contributions; he is now model prisoner in Orvieto's small jail, working in home-decorating shop during day; photo (Orvieto Journal) (S)

headline: HBO & COMPANY TO ACQUIRE GMIS IN STOCK SWAP
abstract: HBO & Co to acquire GMIS Inc for about $212 million in stock (S)

headline: After July's Shock: Foreign Stocks?
abstract: Article on investing in foreign stocks after dramatic downturn in US stocks in July; graph (L)v

headline: Mexico's New Press Boldness Stops at Leader's Desk
abstract: Even though Mexican reporters are enjoying outspoken new brand of journalism, often investigative and frequently irreverent, Govt and President can still wield heavy hand at times to influence news coverage; many journalists say, despite new freedoms, system still remains authoritarian (M)

headline: The Smoke Thickens But Managers Don't Run
abstract: Recent political and legal setbacks for the tobacco industry do not appear to have scared off mutual fund managers, some of whom are even buying more shares as values emerge; graph (M)

headline: Do Analysts Favor Firms' Customers?
abstract: New study confirms that there are real pressures on analysts to give good ratings to securities of companies with with their employers do business; study, conducted by Warren Boeker and Matthew Hayward of Columbia University Business School, shows that investment banks generally give higher ratings in offerings and deals when involved companies are banks' clients than when they are not (M)

headline: New Era of Phone Competition in Mexico
abstract: Pres Ernesto Zedillo makes call on Avantel SA's newly completed digital fiber optic network, opening new era of competition in long-distance telecommunications in Mexico; call is first long-distance call not carried by Telefonos de Mexico SA (Telmex), which held 48-year monopoly; Avantel, owned by MCI Communications Corp and Grupo Financiero Banamex-Accival, and other competitors will begin providing long-distance service to homes by interconnecting with Telmex's network in Jan (M)

headline: Inflation Bonds May Prove Hard To Sell
abstract: Market Watch column speculates about appeal of inflation-linked savings bonds (S)

headline: Odd Allies in Song Royalties Battle
abstract: On Capitol Hill, curious alliances between interest groups are common, but none is more curious than that of religious broadcasters and owners of bars and  restaurants, who are fighting together to reduce the royalties they pay to songwriters.         The battle not only features an unusual joining of forces between the vendors of spirits and the proponents of spirituality but also has frayed relationships  between normal allies, like the Republican Senators Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, who  supports the songwriters, and Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, who supports the broadcasters and bar owners.

headline: World News Briefs;Battles in Somalia Focus on Large Airport
abstract: A Somali faction leader, Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, has regained tenuous control of his main airport, a top aide said today. The official also denied reports that General Aidid had been wounded in recent fighting.         The general's militia recaptured Bale Dogle airport, 55 miles west of Mogadishu, on Friday night, witnesses said. He had lost control of the vast Soviet-built base 24 hours earlier to a coalition led by Mohammed Ali Mahdi. Both men claim to be president of Somalia.

headline: U.N. Is Urged To Combat Sex Abuse Of Children
abstract: Belgian Foreign Min Erik Derycke, in speech to United Nations General Assembly, proposes treaty that would make sexual abuse of minors and trafficking in children an internationally recognized criminal offense (M)

headline: Bosnian Serb Offers Riddle: Is He Out Or Is He In?
abstract: The senior civilian administrator for the Bosnia peace accord announced today that the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, had resigned.         But the statement was denied by Bosnian Serbs, leaving open the possibility of renewed international sanctions against Serbia.

headline: Advertising;A Saatchi & Saatchi survey indicates women are still unhappy with how they are depicted in ads.
abstract: DESPITE some progress, women are still quite unhappy with the way they are depicted in advertising, according to a new survey by Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising. They believe it frequently treats them as sex objects, and often does not realistically portray their changing roles as wives and mothers.         The ads that did appeal to the women whom Saatchi polled reflect values they  consider important, such as the ability to be competent and caring, to be flexible about the many demands on their time and to define their lives on their own terms.

headline: Coca-Cola Expands An Agency's Role
abstract: Coca-Cola Co expands relationship with Fallon McElligott Berlin by awarding creative duties for Georgia Coffee (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Deutsche Bahn to Name A Partner Next Week
abstract: Deutsche Bahn A.G. said yesterday that it would announce the winner of a 49.9 percent stake in its telecommunications subsidiary DBkom next week.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;NatWest's Drop in Net Is Less Than Expected
abstract: The National Westminster Bank P.L.C. said yesterday that its profits fell 65  percent, less than expected, in the first half as strong growth in interest and  fee-related income part ly offset one-time charges. The bank company, Britain's  fourth largest in market capitalization, also said it had bought back as many as L450 million worth of its shares.          Profit before taxes, but after special items, fell to L302 million, or $471  million, from L872 million in the first half of 1995. That exceeded an average estimate of L262 million in a survey of five analysts. Among one-time items, NatWest lost L690 million on the sale of its United States banking unit, NatWest Bancorp.    (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: World News Briefs;Tamils Continue Battle With Sri Lanka Troops
abstract: A Tamil rebel suicide squad blew up a naval gunboat today and pinned down a squad of elite commandos, killing its commander, in one of the fiercest battles  of their 13-year war for independence.         The rebels rammed a speedboat packed with explosives into the gunboat, setting it on fire, military officials said. More than 40 sailors were aboard; their fate is unknown. It is also known how many rebels were in the speedboat.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Inspec Group to Buy A Royal Dutch Unit
abstract: Inspec Group P.L.C., a former unit of the British Petroleum Company, said yesterday that it would buy the specialty chemical unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group for L200.5 million ($311 million) in a bid to expand its product mix. The  acquisition of Shell Fine Chemicals is the biggest ever for Inspec, which was created in a 1992 management buyout and has grown by acquiring specialty chemical units of big companies.          Shell Fine Chemicals makes ingredients for starch used in paper and antioxidants for animal feed and sunscreen lotion. Inspec's main chemicals are used in automobile lacquers and antifreeze and a product that makes plastic bottles clear.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Ammirati Puris Lintas And Citrus Group Part
abstract: Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York yesterday unexpectedly resigned the Florida Department of Citrus advertising account, with billings estimated at $25 million to $27 million, after only five months.

headline: Contests Tighten For 2 Accounts
abstract: USA Network cable channel narrows review of its account to three agencies; account had been handled by Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG; Genrad Inc, systems software firm, narrows review of its account to three agencies; account had been handled by several agencies on project basis (S)

headline: British Airways to Cut 10% of Its Work Force
abstract: British Airways PLC to cut 5,000 jobs in Britain as part of $1.55 billion reorganization; cuts represent about 10 percent of airline's work force (S)

headline: TRON STOCK PLUNGES ON PROJECTION OF LOSS
abstract: Itron Inc says it expects to post loss for its third quarter; stock slides nearly 28 percent on news (S)

headline: German Business Index Jumped in July
abstract: Germany's Ifo institute says its business-climate index for July jumped to 94.1 from 90.4 in June, far exceeding economists' expectations (S)

headline: Lebed Assails Yeltsin Decree On Chechnya
abstract: Aleksandr I Lebed, Russian Pres Boris N Yelsin's chief security adviser, scores Yeltsin's newly disclosed decree to bar all social payments for redevelopment in Chechnya and elsewhere in Russia; holds decree would make it almost impossible to stop Chechen war; is set to hold new talks with Chechen rebels (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FOXMEYER HEALTH AGREES TO SELL A BUSINESS TO SHOPKO
abstract: The Foxmeyer Health Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its Carestream Scrip Card operation to Shopko Stores Inc. for $30.5 million in cash. Scrip Card is Carestream's pharmacy benefit management business, which offers drug benefits consulting and claims processing services to more than 1,900 health groups. If the deal closes by Aug. 1, Shopko expects additional revenue of $100 million to  $115 million from the Scrip Card operations for the current fiscal year. Foxmeyer, based in Carrollton, Tex., said that it was selling Scrip Card at a substantial gain. Shopko, based in Green Bay, Wis., owns 129 stores in 15 states. Shares of Foxmeyer rose $1.50, or 25 percent, to $7.50, and Shopko rose  $1.125, to $14.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Sprint and Ameritech Post A Rise in Their Earnings
abstract: Two of the nation's largest telephone companies posted higher second-quarter  earnings yesterday, reflecting increases in phone traffic and in demand for more phone lines.         The Sprint Corporation, the nation's No. 3 long-distance company after the AT&T Corporation and MCI Communications, reported a 30 percent profit rise on its highest long-distance volume and revenue growth in six years; it also posted a 5.3 percent increase in local phone lines.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SUNBEAM SHARES RISE ON NEWS OF CHIEF'S APPOINTMENT
abstract: The stock of the Sunbeam Corporation soared yesterday on news that the former chief of the Scott Paper Company, Albert Dunlap, an aggressive cost-cutter, had  been hired to recharge the consumer products and appliance maker. The stock rose $6.125, to $18.625, a 49 percent increase, on the New York Stock Exchange. Sunbeam announced on Thursday that Mr. Dunlap had been named chairman and chief  executive, replacing Roger Schipke, who left the company in May. Analysts predicted that Mr. Dunlap, who was known as the Chainsaw when he ran timber companies and has engineered eight corporate turnarounds, will take an ax to Sunbeam.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Wall Street Is Startled By Strong Economic Data  Stocks tumbled to their worst losses in six weeks after a surprisingly strong report on new home sales and a sharp revision upward of the second-quarter gross domestic product renewed concern that in a buoyant economy, borrowing costs could rise and thus cut corporate profits.    The Dow industrials fell 64.73 points, to 5,647.65. The S.& P. 500 dropped 7.41 points to 657.40, and the Nasdaq composite index slipped 8.85 points, to 1,145.03. $(Page D7.$)     The prices of Treasury securities tumbled on the signs of stronger strength. The yield on the benchmark 30-year bond rose to 7.03 percent, from 6.98 percent on Wednesday. $(D13.$)    New Snags for a European Currency   Nervousness over the prospects for European monetary union has spread, as Governments in France and Italy feel pressed to avoid a slowing of their economies and the accompanying job losses by extending the timetable for introducing a single currency, and some German officials seemed to soften their opposition to such a prospect. $(D3.$)    I.M.F. May Sell Gold to Help Poor   The International Monetary Fund has indicated it may sell some of its gold supply and use the proceeds as a gift to cut the debts of the poorest developing countries, letting them improve economic growth and attract more foreign investment. $(D3.$)     Deal for Blood-Products Maker   Baxter International said it would buy Immuno, a Swiss blood-products company, for $715 million. The deal would help Baxter catch up to the world's biggest maker of blood products, Centeon. $(D2.$)    Daimler-Benz Is Back in the Black   Daimler-Benz posted a first-half net profit of 782 million German marks, or $530 million, bouncing back after a reorganization that brought a record loss last year. $(D3.$)     Iran Accused of Breaking Embargo   The United States has accused Iran's Revolutionary Guards of helping smuggle oil and gasoline out of Iraq in violation of the United Nations embargo. If Iran's Government is implicated in violating the embargo, it could face sanctions. $(A4.$)    Valujet Gets Flight Approval   The F.A.A. gave Valujet permission to resume flying under greater scrutiny. The agency grounded the discount carrier 10 weeks ago after a fatal crash in the Everglades. Flights could resume as early as Thursday. $(A12.$)    A Broad Hilton-Ladbroke Deal   Hilton Hotels and the Ladbroke Group, which owns Hilton Hotels International, agreed to a broader-than-expected alliance that lets each company buy a fifth of the other. The deal reunites ownership of the Hilton name in the United States and overseas. $(D2.$)     Editor of New York Is Dismissed   Kurt Andersen, the editor of New York magazine since 1994, who supervised a costly redesign of the magazine, was dismissed. The redesign and a shift in editorial focus have been resisted by important segments of New York's subscriber base. Mr. Andersen's interim replacement is  Richard Babcock, editor of Chicago magazine, also owned by K-III Magazines. $(D4.$)

headline: Tamil Rebels Report Overrunning Sri Lankan Base and Killing 500
abstract: Separatist Tamil Tiger rebels overran a key army camp in northeastern Sri Lanka on Thursday and said today that they had killed more than 500 Government troops in the attack.         But a Government military officer said the rebels' radio reports had put the  toll at 150 soldiers.

headline: Longtime General Partner Plans To Retire at Goldman, Sachs
abstract: David M Silfen, co-head of Goldman, Sachs & Co's equities business, says he will retire as general partner on Nov 30, end of company's fiscal year, after 28 years with the firm; Silfen will remain a limited partner and continue as an adviser to his former colleagues (M)

headline: Berkshire Gives a Vote of Confidence to Salomon
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway Inc, investment firm controlled by Warren E Buffett, says it expects to convert 140,000 preferred shares into common stock of Salomon Inc this year, raising its holding to almost 10 percent of big Wall Street firm (S)

headline: Barney's Acts to End Isetan Licensing Pact
abstract: Barney's Inc, parent company of Barneys New York, which filed for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy protection last January, says it is seeking to terminate licensing agreement with its Asian partner, Isetan Co (S)

headline: Samsung Declares Intent To Buy Fokker Unit
abstract: Samsung Aerospace Industries of South Korea says it intends to buy bankrupt aircraft production arm of Fokker NV but deal has not been finalized (S)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The Democratic National Convention opens in Chicago.    The National Association of Realtors reports on existing-home sales for July. In June they fell 2.3 percent.    TUESDAY  The Conference Board reports on consumer confidence for August. In July its index stood at 107.2.    Earnings reports are expected from Albertson's and Toro.    THURSDAY  The Labor Department reports on the week's initial claims for unemployment benefits.    The Commerce Department makes a preliminary estimate of economic growth in the second quarter.    The Commerce Department reports on new-home sales for July. In June they fell 5.3 percent.    An earnings report is expected from Regis.    FRIDAY  The Commerce Department reports on personal income and spending for July. In June, income rose nine-tenths of 1 percent while spending fell two-tenths of 1 percent.    The Commerce Department reports on factory orders for July. In June they fell nine-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;UAL Reports 42.8% Climb In Its Earnings
abstract: The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines and the Shuttle by United, reported a 42.8 percent increase in quarterly earnings today on strong bookings  by business travelers, who typically buy the most expensive seats.          For the three months ended June 30, the company earned $307 million, or $2.17 a share, up from $215 million, or $1.63 a share, in the comparable period  a year ago. This year's net was after a $30 million charge for early debt retirement. Before the charge the per share income was $2.52.

headline: Moving Beyond the Wires
abstract: Technology that breathes life into many computer creatures may soon be made easier; Advanced Telecommunications Research Institute has spent two years developing system that captures motion using camera that can measure warmth of human body; simplicity of system broadens its possible commercial application; for example, it could be used to free virtual reality from its current constraints, which require person to wear headgear and work a keyboard, mouse or data glove; photos (M)

headline: CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER AT XYLAN RESIGNS
abstract: C Stephen Cordial resigns as Xylan Corp chief financial officer; Xylan stock continues to fall (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: Summary of major news stories on inside pages

headline: Corrections
abstract: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the quality of new jobs in the economy misstated the previous job of Jeffrey Pelkey, systems administrator at Viatech Laboratories. He had been a systems administrator for a hospital, not a hospital administrator.         A chart with the article, showing the pay breakdowns for new jobs, mislabeled the reference to jobs paying up to 30 percent above average. A corrected version appears today on page 9. Another table with the article, showing job growth from 1991 to 1996, omitted two industry sectors from the list of those with the least growth. They are nonmetallic minerals, with an annual growth rate of one-tenth of 1 percent, and  water transportation, with an annual rate of decline of 1.2 percent. Nonmetallic minerals had 107,000 workers in the first quarter this year, and average earnings in the industry were $39,474 in 1993. Water transportation had 171,000  workers, with average 1993 earnings of $38,121.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Norsk Talks in Trinidad On Big Smelter Project
abstract: A subsidiary of the Norwegian industrial giant Norsk Hydro A.S. is holding talks with the Government of Trinidad and Tobago on the construction of a $750 million aluminum smelter, Trinidad's Energy Minister, Finbar Gangar, said. Hydro Aluminum, a subsidiary of Norsk Hydro's metal producing companies, is conducting feasibility studies for a smelter with a capacity of 200,000 metric tons a year.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: For Investors, an Initial Public Offering of English
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission launches effort to aid businesses in drafting initial public offerings, mutual fund prospectuses and other disclosure documents in clear and concise English instead of the almost indecipherable language currently in use; later this year, the commission plans to adopt new clear-language rules for all disclosure filings; examples of tortured writing from current prospectuses and samples of improved versions; photo (M)

headline: Accordion Trills of Old For Bosnia
abstract: Nationalist passions are kept in check in Orasje, Bosnia, where Croats make up 90 percent of the population but treat the Muslim minority fairly; friendships, business and love of folk traditions like accordion music help to reduce ethnic fear and distrust; photo; map (M)

headline: Kurds Wary of the Hidden Price of Turning On the Lights in Dohuk
abstract: Rush of events that has seen Massoud Barzani take control of entire Kurdish region of Iraq has set off widespread suspicions; Barzani controlled only one of three major cities in Iraq's Kurdish region until Aug 31; he insists his alliance with Iraqi Government is both temporary and limited; he vows to pursue pluralism, democracy and unity; Kurds say they do not know whether to cheer end of Iraqi embargo, or worry that it is ploy to allow Iraqi agents to circulate more freely; maps (M)

headline: STERLING SOFTWARE SAYS BOARD APPROVES SPINOFF
abstract: Sterling Software Inc board approves spinoff of Sterling Commerce unit (S)

headline: About Real Estate;On the Rise: Instant Selling Success
abstract: The New York City real estate market is full of tales of sellers who put their houses or apartments on the market, clean them every morning just in case  an agent comes by with some eager buyers, only to wait and wait for an offer that seems to never come.         Although the last few years have been grim for many sellers -- average selling times have dragged out to over a year in some parts of the region -- there are now an increasing number of tales of instant selling success that give heart to the anxious seller.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FOUNDATION HEALTH SHARES FALL AS EARNINGS RISE
abstract: The stock of the Foundation Health Corporation fell yesterday, even though the company released earnings in line with Wall Street estimates. The company said that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 12 percent, citing one-time gains from the sale of two independent practice associations and lower taxes. The company, based in Rancho Cordova, Calif., operates managed-health-care plans. It said its net income rose to $43.6 million, or 74 cents a share, from $38.8 million, or 68 cents, a year ago. Wall Street had been expecting earnings of 74  cents. Shares of Foundation fell $1.875, to $25.875.

headline: Human Error And Software Created Data Network Glitch
abstract: America Online says software bugs and human error combined to create huge system failure that blacked out its on-line service for nearly 19 hours on Wednesday; calls failure 'coincidental series of sequential events that will most likely never occur again'; details events that led to problem (M)

headline: The Risks of Keeping a Promise;In Becoming an Icon, a Mill Owner Bets His Company
abstract: In his 60's, Aaron M. Feuerstein, awakening at 5:30 A.M., began to devote the first hour of his day to memorizing passages from Scripture and Shakespeare. He  worried that age would erode his memory and this early- morning ritual became his daily antidote. Perhaps prophetically, he gravitated to Lear and Hamlet, each with his tragic flaw.         Mr. Feuerstein -- now 70, gaunt, white-haired, patriarchal -- is strikingly theatrical himself as he paces restlessly in his office during an interview, grasping a thin silver-and-mahogany walking stick as if it were a sage's staff.  Six months after a fire nearly destroyed his textile company, Malden Mills Industries, he has set himself up as a hero of corporate responsibility, insisting that his loyalty to his workers should be the model for all chief executives.

headline: People
abstract: Beth Sullivan was named to the new position of senior vice president and marketing research director at Arnold Communications, Boston. She previously held similar posts at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston.    Loreen Babcock was named to the new position of senior vice president and group account director at Lowe Direct, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. She was previously a partner and account director at Ogilvy & Mather Direct, New York, a unit of the WPP Group.

headline: Warily, Hong Kong Greets a General From Beijing
abstract: As the wail of "Highland Cathedral" wheezed from bagpipes played by Ghurkas in crisp green and white uniforms, the British Army welcomed the first Chinese Communist general to visit Hong Kong.         The three-day visit last week was intended to familiarize the Chinese military with the activities and installations of British forces here before the handover to Chinese rule next year. But even though Hong Kong residents have had years to prepare for Chinese rule, and many reminders of the impending change, the military visit was one of the more jarring.

headline: A Former Army Leader Is Arrested in Haiti
abstract: Claude Raymond, a feared army chief during the Duvalier dictatorship who is suspected of carrying out a massacre of voters in 1987, was arrested on Tuesday  on charges of subversion, police officials said.         Mr. Raymond, who was Jean-Claude Duvalier's army chief of staff for 16 years, was arrested with three associates while attending a voodoo festival at Saut d'Eau in the Central Plateau area.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Red Cross, Under Threat, Delays Burundi Convoy
abstract: The United Nations refugee agency said today that it had suspended plans to send an aid convoy to the Cibitoke region in Burundi after a threat of attack.         The convoy, which was to have been escorted by the Burundi Army, would have been the first to enter the area since three Swiss staff members of the Red Cross were killed there last month.

headline: Market Place;The S.E.C. says it happened: a corner in the Treasury market.
abstract: CORNER the Treasury market?         It sounds impossible, but Federal regulators said yesterday that it was done  three years ago by Fenchurch Capital Management, a Chicago company that runs two commodity funds.

headline: Fallon Resigning Prudential Account
abstract: Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis says it will resign account of Prudential Insurance Co of America and withdraw from review for account of Prudential subsidiary, Prudential Health Care (S)

headline: Consumer Prices Show a Bit of an Upturn
abstract: Labor Department reports Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of 1 percent in July, lifting inflation for last 12 months to 3 percent; department calculates that real average weekly earnings dropped 1.5 percent last month after hefty 2.2 percent June surge; average weekly hours fell sharply while hourly earnings were down modestly; table; graph (L)

headline: QUINTILES TRANSNATIONAL PLANS TO BUY BRI INTERNATIONAL
abstract: Quintiles Transnational Corp to buy BRI International Inc for $133.5 million in stock (S)

headline: Bond Prices Are Higher On Thin Day
abstract: Treasury securities prices rise in lackluster trading; 30-year bond rises 8/32, to 96 5/32, to yield 7.02 percent; graph (M)

headline: Science and scientists are facing some rough going as the millennium approaches.
abstract: Technology column discusses two new books that take sober view of technological promise and scientific exploration; The End of Science, by John Horgan, contends that science is fast approaching its conclusion, that the great era of scientific discovery is over; Edward Tenner's book, Why Things Bite Back: Technology and the Revenge of Unintended Consequences, speaks of the limits of technology, and states that technology designed to solve one problem invariably ends up creating another or undoing its own solution; drawing (M)

headline: Where Lenin Ruled, Stocks Gain
abstract: WHERE are the world's hottest stock markets? Not in the economic powerhouses  of Asia, but in a region that largely spurned capitalism until recently: Russia  and its former satellites in Eastern Europe.         The stock markets there carry substantial risks, and even willing investors find it hard to gain access to them. But the performances have been mouthwatering.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MOTOROLA SHARES CLIMB ON EARNINGS EXPECTATIONS
abstract: The shares of Motorola Inc. rose yesterday on optimism that its earnings would exceed expectations because of stronger-than-expected sales of its lightweight cellular phone. Motorola shares rose $1.875, to $67.75, on trading of 6.5 million. In a report yesterday, Albert Lin, an analyst at Cowen & Company, projected that Motorola could earn as much as 85 cents a share in the second quarter. The maker of computer chips and electronic equipment based in Schaumburg, Ill., had been expected to report per-share earnings of 69 cents, according to the average estimate of 20 analysts surveyed by IBES International  Inc.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Cement Acquisition Planned in Brazil
abstract: The Swiss cement company Holderbank Financiere Glarus A.G. said yesterday that it would buy Companhia de Cimento Portland Paraiso of Brazil for $200 million. The acquisition of family-owned Paraiso will make Holderbank the No. 2  cement company in southern Brazil, Holderbank said. In adding Paraiso's 2.2 million tons of annual capacity, Holderbank's capacity in Brazil will total 5.2  million tons a year.          Holderbank will merge Paraiso into its Brazilian unit, Ciminas S.A. Ciminas  has annual sales of around $221 million, while Paraiso's cement sales total $172 million.   (Dow Jones)

headline: Life on the Bottom Rung: Top Executives Remember
abstract: Memories of chief executives of their first jobs noted (S)

headline: Depressed Office Market Sees Little Room for Hope
abstract: LONDON—  Office space in those gleaming glass-and-steel structures that dominate the world's cityscapes has fallen in price over the last few years. To the dismay of developers from Los Angeles to London, this time, prices seem likely to stay low for some time to come.

headline: ICAHN GROUP RAISES STAKE IN RJR AND AGAIN URGES SPINOFF
abstract: Investment group that includes Carl C Icahn raises its stake in RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp to 5.8 percent from 4.8 percent and repeats call for immediate spinoff of company's Nabisco food unit (S)

headline: Clinton Acts and Tobacco Profits
abstract: Floyd Norris (Market Watch) column holds that new Clinton Administration rules to curb cigarette marketing aimed at teen-agers will actually be boon to tobacco industry; says restrictions will cause cigarette companies to spend less on advertising, raising profits, and the likeliest losers will be billboard companies like Outdoor Advertising Inc; chart (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;2 Brazilian Banks In Talks to Merge
abstract: Banco de Credito Nacional S.A., one of Brazil's largest nonstate banks, and Banco Itamarati S.A. are holding talks to merge, the two banks said yesterday. Control of the newly formed bank, which would rank among Brazil's five largest,  was not immediately clear. Further details will be supplied when talks are concluded, the banks said.          Banco Credito is the larger of the two banks, with 108 full branches in Brazil, while Itamarati is essentially an investment bank.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Autostock Inc says it agreed to buy 24 Autostock warehouses and 125 Apple Auto Glass stores from TCG International for $35.8 million (US) (S)

headline: Taiwan Cuts Forecast For 1996 Growth
abstract: Taiwan cuts its forecast of economic growth in 1996 to its lowest in six years amid slower gains in export sales and decline in private investment; gross domestic product is now expected to expand only 5.89% this year, down from forecast of 6.17% made three months ago (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;WARNACO PLANS TO BUY BODYSLIMMERS
abstract: Warnaco Group of New York said yesterday that it would buy Bodyslimmers Inc.  by Nancy Ganz for an undisclosed price in cash, tapping into Bodyslimmers' popularity with baby boomers. Bodyslimmers, also based in New York, makes and sells body slimming undergarments. The company said that it had 1995 revenues of $30 million to $34 million. Nancy Ganz, founder and president, would run the operation for Warnaco as president of the new Nancy Ganz/Bodyslimmers division.

headline: EVERGREEN TO BUY 4 STATIONS IN 2 CITIES
abstract: Evergreen Media Corp to buy three Detroit radio stations and one Philadelphia station from Secret Communications LP for $237.8 million; will swap one of Detroit stations, WQRS-FM, for Greater Media Inc's WWRC-AM in Washington plus $9.5 million in cash; swap modifies June accord under which Evergreen was to buy Washington station (S)

headline: S.E.C. Is Set Back on 'Viatical Settlements'
abstract: An investment plan that sells shares in a terminally ill patient's life-insurance policy is not subject to Federal rules that regulate the sale of  securities, a Federal appeals court said today.         On a 2-to-1 vote, a panel at the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, ruled that "viatical settlements" are not legally  securities. The decision, a setback for the Securities and Exhange Commission, threw out lower-court orders that barred Life Partners Inc. of Waco, Tex., from  selling partial interests in life-insurance policies unless they were registered as securities.

headline: Drug Companies Turn Aggressive In Promoting New Drugs for AIDS
abstract: A few years ago, medicine's weaponry against H.I.V. consisted of a single drug, AZT, that did not work very well and had awful side effects. Today, at least a dozen new drugs for the treatment of the virus that causes AIDS have just reached the market, are awaiting Government approval or are in the late stages of clinical trials.         The hope is that these drugs will help H.I.V.-infected patients "manage" their disease so they can live much longer and relatively symptom-free, much as  diabetics can.

headline: CLARCOR AGREES TO STOCK SWAP FOR UNITED AIR
abstract: Clarcor Inc to acquire United Air Specialists Inc in stock swap valued at $26.3 million (S)

headline: No Tailspin From AT&T
abstract: AT&T's announcement of drop in profits has little effect on telecommunications mutual funds, because many of funds do not carry shares in giant company; list (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ITALIAN OVEN'S CHIEF RELINQUISHES RESPONSIBILITIES
abstract: Italian Oven's chairman and chief executive, James A. Frye, relinquished his  responsibilities but will remain on the board, the company said in a statement yesterday. As reported last month, Mr. Frye, who founded the restaurant chain in 1989 and is its largest shareholder, turned over control to Cornerstone Capital  Advisors Ltd., the company's temporary manager. In a cost-cutting effort, Italian Oven also suspended or laid off 10 employees, more than 25 percent of the corporate staff, at its Latrobe, Pa., headquarters. The company also said that Wheat First Butcher Singer Inc. has agreed to help it explore financing options and potential partnerships.

headline: The Internet's Gatekeeper May Cash In on Its Role
abstract: Network Solutions, private company designated by Federal Government to register addresses on Internet computer network, weighs cashing in on its gatekeeper role; company, buoyed by phenomenal growth of Internet and demand for new Internet domain names or addresses, is exploring public offering of stock; charges $100 to register new domain for two years and $50 per year thereafter to maintain it; was acquired in 1995 by Science Applications International Corp, $2 billion privately held research company with close ties to Defense Dept; critics say public stock offering would create furor since company should not be allowed to profit excessively from virtual monopoly granted by Government (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A Fed Governor Sees Risk Of Inflation in Job Gains   A governor of the Federal Reserve warned that the drop in the unemployment rate to 5.1 percent in August raises the risks of unacceptable wage inflation.

headline: Archer Settles Pricing Suits for $65 Million
abstract: Archer Daniels Midland Co, in flurry of settlements across country, agrees to pay more than $65 million to resolve three separate lawsuits stemming largely from price-fixing scandal at company; under separate agreements, Archer Daniels would pay $35 million to settle price-fixing lawsuit brought on behalf of purchasers of citric acid and $30 million to shareholders whose stock lost value after scandal became public; graph shows fluctuations in Archer Daniels Midland shares in recent months (M)

headline: NCR Reports a Small Profit After Reducing Expenses
abstract: The NCR Corporation, the troubled computer division that the AT&T Corporation plans to spin off at the end of the year, said yesterday that it had a small operating profit in the quarter ended in June for the unit's first time in the black since 1994.         AT&T, which still includes NCR's results along with its own, said that the computer unit's various businesses recorded a profit of $11 million for the quarter, in contrast to a loss of $219 million in the corresponding period last  year. Revenues were down 18 percent, to $1.7 billion, but excluding sales of personal computers, a business the company quit earlier this year, revenues were essentially flat.

headline: Another Trolley Bombing In Moscow Leaves 30 Hurt
abstract: Fear and anger swept across the Russian capital today after a second bomb in  less than 24 hours tore through a trolley bus in Moscow at the height of the morning rush hour.         The blast, which sent 30 passengers to the hospital, blew a hole in the top of the bus and sent glass shards and twisted metal flying across the crowded roadway. Somehow, no one was killed.

headline: Sri Lanka Rebels Said to Seize Army Camp
abstract: The Sri Lankan armed forces sent in reinforcements today to try to regain control of a strategic military base that has been under assault by Tamil rebels in one of the fiercest battles of the 13-year separatist war.         The rebels appeared to have gained control of the camp, 175 miles from Colombo, army officials said, although the Defense Ministry said Government troops had established a beachhead south of the camp.

headline: Acquisition by Eye Care
abstract: Eye Care Centers of America Inc agrees to acquire Vision-works Inc, optical retailer with 49 stores in southeastern United States (S)

headline: A Twist in the Metallgesellschaft Saga
abstract: PARIS—  In a remarkable about-face in one of Europe's longest-running corporate disputes, Metallgesellschaft, the German industrial conglomerate, is preparing to make a cash payment and withdraw all charges of wrongdoing against the former chief executive it fired two years ago after a $1 billion oil trading scandal.

headline: Anglo American Deal With a Black Group
abstract: Anglo American Corp of South Africa Ltd to sell 20 percent stake in Johnnies Industrial Corp to National Empowerment Consortium, group representing black business people and trade unions, for more than $335 million (S)

headline: BASF to Sell Its Tape Division
abstract: BASF to sell its entire tape and computer disk production division to RAKS Holding AS for undisclosed price (S)

headline: Conflicting Signals On Nintendo Results
abstract: Trading in Nintendo Co is suspended in Tokyo, after Nihon Keizai Shimbun, an economic newspaper, says pretax profit would tumble 70 percent for fiscal year; Nintendo denies report and says its pretax profit might exceed its forecast of 27 billion yen, or $250 million; Kyodo News Service further reports that Gumpei Yokoi, head of Nintendo's development team, is leaving (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;RYDER STUDIES SALE OF CONSUMER TRUCK RENTAL UNIT
abstract: Ryder System Inc. said yesterday that it was considering selling its consumer truck rental division and was in serious talks with possible buyers. The company said it had hired the investment firm Goldman, Sachs & Company to explore the sale of the unit, which accounts for about 10 percent of the company's revenue.  On the New York Stock Exchange, Ryder's stock closed up 62.5 cents a share at $26.875. The division for sale has 35,000 trucks, from 10 feet long to 24-footers. The commercial truck rental division is not for sale. The consumer truck rental unit, which operates in the 48 contiguous states and in Canada, had revenue of $500 million in 1995.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;United International To Sell Brazil Stake
abstract: United International Holdings Inc.  agreed yesterday to sell its stake in the Brazilian cable TV operator Net Sao Paulo for about $78.1 million. The Denver-based company said it would sell its 25.5 percent interest in Net Sao Paulo to Globo, a Brazilian television broadcaster, for $70 million. The company said it had an unrelated prior contractual obligation to sell an 8.5 percent interest in Net Sao Paulo for about $8.1 million.   (Dow Jones)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sony's Chairman Is Hospitalized
abstract: The Sony Corporation said yesterday that its chairman, Norio Ohga, had been hospitalized for sunstroke and would probably miss a meeting of United States and Japanese officials trying to resolve differences over semiconductor trade. Mr. Ohga, who is 66, began to feel ill while playing golf in Hawaii on Friday and checked into a hospital on Monday for tests after his return to Tokyo, the company said.          Mr. Ohga, who is also chairman of the Electronic Industries Association of Japan, will probably be hospitalized for about 10 days. He will not be able to attend a meeting on Saturday of United States and Japanese semiconductor industry officials, the company said. Last month, Mr. Ohga was hospitalized briefly after complaining of feeling ill, though the company said then that tests did not turn up anything unusual.   (AP)

headline: AAR Buys Aircraft Parts
abstract: The AAR Corporation, a supplier of new and used aircraft parts, bought 22,000 components today from a unit of the United Technologies Corporation for substantially less than the catalogue price of more than $200 million. The parts were made and sold by Hamilton Standard, a division of the Hartford-based United Technologies.

headline: Christopher in Sarajevo, Pressing the Flesh
abstract: US Sec of State Warren Christopher returns to Saravejo, ravaged capital of Bosnia, stumping to encourage citizens and candidates to participate in elections he concedes will be far from perfect but are vital first step toward creating unified nation (M)

headline: ABC Lines Up 'Lion King' and Spike Lee
abstract: Walt Disney-owned ABC television network says ABC will show Disney movie The Lion King in November, the first time one of Disney's modern-era animated feature films has been shown on broadcast television; ABC announces that film director Spike Lee will develop a new comedy for the network, in association with Brandon Tartikoff, former head of entertainment programming for NBC (L)

headline: Kemp Says Clinton's Policy On Iraq Emboldens Hussein
abstract: Republican Vice Presidential candidate Jack Kemp accuses Pres Clinton of vacillating on policy on Iraq, and says Administration's vague and uncertain foreign policy goals have contributed to current state of unrest there; remarks represent latest attempt by Republicans to turn Iraq into campaign issueagainst Pres Clinton; also signals that Republican campaign intends to use others, apart from Presidentiual candidate Bob Dole, to lead attack (M)

headline: Alcatel Would Hold All Units of Thomson
abstract: Alcatel Alsthom SA says it will hold onto all units of Thomson SA, including its unprofitable Thomson Multimedia unit, if its bid to acquire company succeeds; company declines to say exactly how much it would pay for Thomson or how it would finance the purchase (S)

headline: Croatia and Yugoslavia Reach Accord to End 5-Year Struggle
abstract: Croatia and Yugoslavia, in move that formally ends five years of hostilities, sign mutual recognition accord that is seen by many in region as key step to heading off resumption of war; agreement calls for restoring full diplomatic relations within 15 days and resumption of trade and transportation links; also recognizes Croatia's international boundaries but does not solve all outstanding issues between two neighbors (M)

headline: The Senate Clears $1 Billion In Subsidies to Shipping Lines
abstract: Senate, 88-10, approves $1 billion in subsidies over 10 years for nation's private merchant-marine fleet; critics score bill, already passed by House and backed by Pres Clinton, as example of 'corporate welfare' and pork-barrel politics; program replaces much larger Depression-era subsidies set to expire in 1997 (M)

headline: Oil Prices Fall as Iraqi Sales Seem Close to Being Cleared
abstract: Crude oil futures prices fall after United States says it will approve United Nations procedures governing Iraq's $2 billion oil sale; crude oil for Sept delivery falls 10 cents, to $21.13 a barrel (S)

headline: How the Chechen Guerrillas Shocked Their Russian Foes
abstract: Special report, Rout of the Russians, on how 1,500 Chechen guerrillas led by Shamil Basayev surprised numerically far superior Russian force and retook Grozny; Chechens sought drastic action to show Russians futility of war; Basayev comments, interview; Russian force is weakened by corruption and poorly trained, rarely paid soldiers who lack will to fight; maps; photos (L)

headline: Mayor Thrives on Political Theater
abstract: Almost every Saturday after his regular soccer match, Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov leaps into his black Volga limousine and speeds in a police convoy to construction sites across the metropolitan region to give local administrators a taste of his inimitable style of hands-on governance.         "This is absurd!" he shouted at room filled with cringing construction engineers and administrators who explained they had budgeted $9 million to erect a telephone station in a huge, partly unfinished apartment complex in this suburb south of Moscow. "Are you people out of your minds?"

headline: For U.S-Japan Trade Pact, Less at Stake
abstract: Analysis: United States-Japanese talks on extending computer chip trade pact seen having lost past aura of epic struggle; raft of new countries have become major chip producers, US chip industry self-confidence has soared and protectionism is no longer huge problem in semiconductor business (M)

headline: New York Magazine Editor Who Led Redesign Is Ousted
abstract: Kurt Andersen, co-founder of Spy magazine who has been editor of New York magazine since February 1994, is ousted; Andersen will be replaced on interim basis by Richard Babcock, who is editor of K-III's Chicago magazine (M)

headline: A Director Quits Egghead Board
abstract: Egghead Inc., the software retailer, said today that Paul G. Allen, a co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation, would step down from its board after serving as a director for more than nine years.         Egghead, based in Spokane, Wash., said Mr. Allen, who is also an investor in  the company, would be succeeded as a director by Eric Robison, who works for Mr. Allen's Vulcan Ventures Inc., an investment firm.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Business Digest column

headline: Bosnia Election Results Are Delayed for a Day
abstract: Preliminary results of Bosnian national elections are withheld for day as returns trickle in at slower pace than expected (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the expected release dates for major economic indicators this week.      MONDAY

headline: 7 Bosnia Candidates Ousted After Attack
abstract: The Western group supervising this fall's elections in Bosnia has disqualified seven candidates from the Government's ruling Muslim party as punishment for a violent attack on a rival Muslim politician.         Officials of the group, the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, said it was sending a warning to all Bosnian parties and candidates that the international community would deal forcefully with breaches of the peace and other actions that undermined the election.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;In a market where names seem to blur together, Luxottica sees a chance to become the next Nike.
abstract: IN ambitious attempt to bring the principles of branding to a so-called commodity category of consumer goods is asserting -- with apologies to the Communist Manifesto -- that eyeglass wearers ought to unite because they have nothing to lose but those funny little indentations on the sides of their noses.         The Luxottica Group S.p.A., the eyewear marketer and retailer based in Milan, Italy, is for the first time promoting its flagship Luxottica brand of frames in the United States. In a broadcast and print campaign with a budget of $25 million, Luxottica and its agency, the feisty New York shop Deutsch Inc., seek to accomplish a difficult task: convincing shoppers to insist on the benefits ostensibly brought by a brand to what seem to be parity products.

headline: Less Torrid Initial Offerings: An Opportunity for the Savvy
abstract: Market Place column on less torrid initial public offerings; says decidedly tepid temperature of current market offers buyers greater opportunity to snatch up stock in solid companies at reasonable prices; holds change in climate comes after Wall Street spent last several months plying investors with countless Internet or technology outfits; Securities Data Company says average initial offering in May gained 25 percent in its first day of trading; graph; chart (L)

headline: New ways of sending radio over the Net promise more sound and less static.
abstract: New software technology and faster modems are improving sound quality of radio received over computers via Internet; efforts of software firms Progressive Networks and Xing Technology Corp cited; drawing (M)

headline: Stocks Climb, With Dow Up 73.98 Points
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average climbs 73.98 points, or 1.31 percent, to close at 5,733.84; broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index jumps 8.08 points, to 663.76; Nasdaq composite index rises 9.32 points, to 1,148.71; table (L)

headline: PATRIOT AMERICAN DEAL WITH DOUBLETREE HOTELS
abstract: Patriot American Hospitality Inc agrees to buy up to $200 million worth of hotels from Doubletree Corp in next two years; Doubletree will continue managing and retain 10 percent stake in each of hotels (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TRAVELERS/AETNA PROPERTY TO BUY BACK SHARES
abstract: The board of the Travelers/Aetna Property Casualty Corporation has approved the repurchase of as much as $100 million in stock, or about 1 percent of total  outstanding shares. Travelers/Aetna also declared its first dividend, 7.5 cents  a share on its class A and class B common stock, which will be payable Aug. 23 to shareholders of record Aug. 5. In April, Travelers Group Inc., which is based in New York, merged its insurance subsidiary with the Aetna Life and Casualty Company's property and casualty unit, which it bought for $4 billion. Based on today's closing stock price of $25, down 25 cents, the $100 million would buy four million shares. The Hartford-based insurer has 400 million shares outstanding.

headline: Tapie Is Declared Bankrupt and Faces Prison
abstract: PARIS—  Bernard Tapie, a symbol of France's easy-money culture in the 1980s, was confirmed as being bankrupt on Tuesday by the highest appeals court in France, making it more likely that he will serve time in prison.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Busines Digest column of major news stories

headline: Agency Search Begun By GO-JO Division
abstract: Purell Brand consumer products division of Go-Jo Industries Inc says it is in preliminary stages of search for agency to introduce Purell Brand Instant Hand Sanitizer to consumer market (S)

headline: United Technologies Deal
abstract: United Technologies's Carrier Transicold unit acquires Sutrak Transportkalte GmbH; deal does not include Sutrak's United States operations, which will operate independently (S)

headline: World News Briefs;Islamic Militant Leader In Algeria Is Killed
abstract: The fundamentalist Armed Islamic Group of Algeria said today that its leader, Djamel Zitouni, also known as Abu Abderrahman Amin, was killed on July 16 near Medea, 70 miles south of Algiers.         "Our brother Abu Abderrahman was killed after he fell in a trap near Medea on July 16 before sunset," the statement said. "Two other brothers who accompanied  him were also killed."

headline: Half-Year Profit Leaps At Big French Insurer
abstract: Axa SA says its profits jumped 52 percent in first half of 1996, to $388 million (S)

headline: 500,000 Strike in Israel to Protest Netanyahu's Economic Plans
abstract: Opponents of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's plans for Israel's economy today closed factories, banks and Government offices across the country with a general strike, which also crippled hospitals, public utilities and the national airport.         The strike was called by the umbrella labor federation, the Histadrut, which  accuses the Government of approving budget cuts that will hurt middle-class wage-earners and the poor. About half a million workers took part.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Laidlaw Waste Units To Be Sold for $1.34 Billion  Allied Waste Industries said it had agreed to buy the solid waste management operations of Laidlaw for $1.34 billion, as the consolidation in that business continues.    The acquisition will transform Allied Waste into the fourth-largest waste collection company in the nation, with revenues of roughly $1 billion. $(Page D2.$)    Tracking Electronic Money  Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin plans to announce initiatives intended to grapple with the development of electronic money, which has raised fears about new types of money laundering, counterfeiting and runs on banks. An international group of regulators will examine a similar issue, studying the cooperation needed as currency moves through the borderless Internet. $(D5.$)    I.M.F. Likely to Sell Gold  The International Monetary Fund is likely to sell some gold to finance two new initiatives to help the world's poorest countries, officials said. Agreement was reached to finance a joint debt-relief plan with the World Bank and a special credit service for poor nations. $(D2.$)    Swiss Bank Plans Big Cuts  Swiss Bank said it would cut 1,700 jobs, close a quarter of its Swiss branches and take a $2.65 billion charge in an attempt to raise earnings at its domestic operation. $(D15.$)    Olivetti Chief Out After 2 Weeks  The chief executive of Olivetti resigned, only two weeks after he won a battle with the longtime chairman, Carlo de Benedetti, for leadership of the troubled Italian computer and telecommunications company. $(D19.$)    Mobile-Home Company Rejects Bids  Chateau Properties, an operator of mobile-home parks in an intense takeover fight, rejected two bids and said that it had altered the merger agreement it already had. $(D4.$)    Ruling Sought on Insider Trading  An appeals court is being asked to decide whether it is legal to buy the stock of a takeover target with inside knowledge of a secret takeover offer, as long as that information did not come from the target itself. Floyd Norris: Market Place. $(D8.$)    F.T.C. Seeks to Speed Up Rulings  The Federal Trade Commission has approved new procedures designed to speed up decisions in challenges to corporate mergers, in antitrust complaints and in consumer protection disputes. $(D4.$)    Memo Talked of Burying Study  A Philip Morris researcher wrote in a 1977 memo that if a study showed that nicotine produced the same withdrawal symptoms as drugs like morphine, ''we will want to bury it,'' papers filed in a Minnesota lawsuit say. $(A21.$)    A Golden Arch, Or Gold-Plated?  In an unusual move, McDonald's has sent a memo to franchisees defending the Arch Deluxe, a new hamburger it is marketing to older customers. The memo was intended to counter criticism of the introduction of the Arch Deluxe, and the company tried to marshal market-research data in defense of the sandwich. $(D4.$)   Times Books Publisher to Depart  Peter Osnos, the head of Times Books and the publisher of presidents from Clinton to Yeltsin, resigned to help create a new publishing line with the Twentieth Century Fund. $(D7.$)

headline: Alcatel Alsthom Cuts First-Half Loss
abstract: Alcatel Alsthom says it has narrowed its losses in first half to $77.7 million, and expects profit for 1996; company had posted biggest loss in French corporate history in 1995, $5.2 billion, after heavy charges (S)

headline: Warnaco to Buy Maker of Speedo
abstract: The Authentic Fitness Corporation, the maker of Speedo swimwear and fitness apparel, said today that it had agreed to be reacquired by Warnaco Group Inc. in a deal valued at $438.6 million.         Both companies are headed by Linda J. Wachner, who was part of the investment group that bought Authentic Fitness from Warnaco in 1990. Authentic Fitness, based in Los Angeles, had been Warnaco's activewear unit before the sale.

headline: Islamic Bomb Is Jolt for Church and French : Bishop Is Slain in Algeria After Seeing Paris Official
abstract: PARIS—  Terrorists have murdered the Roman Catholic bishop of Oran, in eastern Algeria, in another shock for the French government as well as for the Algerian church, beset by tragedy.

headline: Market Place;Score one for S.& L. investors, who won a bet against the U.S.
abstract: JACKPOT!         That was the reaction among investors yesterday after the Supreme Court cleared the way for some of the nation's savings and loans to pursue billions of dollars in damage claims against the Government. After years of on-again, off-again rulings in the case, savings and loan investors finally saw their most profitable day of the decade.

headline: A New Executive At Merkley Newman
abstract: Marty Cooke joins Merkley Newman Harty as partner and executive creative director, a new position (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CCB FINANCIAL CORP., Durham, N.C., reached an agreement to buy Salem Trust Bank of Winston-Salem, N.C., for about $39 million in stock.

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 3/ Single-state municipal bond funds aren't as low in risk as they used to be. By Sharon R. King.

headline: Profits at Hoechst Triple in Quarter
abstract: Hoechst AG says its pretax profit in second quarter rose nearly threefold to 3.08 billion marks, or $2.08 billion, compared with second-quarter pretax profit of 1.14 billion marks last year (S)

headline: Key Kurd Calls Deal With Iraq A Stopgap
abstract: Interview with Tayib Ahmad, leader of Kurdish faction backed by Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein, who insists alliance with Iraq is tactical and temporary partnership of kind that has sustained beleaguered Kurds for centuries; says short-term necessity had driven his group into military alliance with Hussein; photo (M)

headline: Coldwell Banker Moves to Sawtooth
abstract: Coldwell Banker Corp says it has named Sawtooth Group to handle its national account; billings are $17 million (S)

headline: Palestinians Voice Dismay At Comments By Netanyahu
abstract: As Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu uses an American tour to vow steadfastness on Jerusalem, Palestinian officials are expressing new dismay at what they describe as a deliberate effort to inflame tensions between peace partners.         A day after Mr. Netanyahu told a joint meeting of Congress that he would never allow Jerusalem to be divided again between Arabs and Jews, Yasir Arafat,  the Palestinian leader, shot back today that "holy Jerusalem is the capital of Palestine forever."

headline: Returnees Ante Up Venture Capital: Their Ideas
abstract: Hundreds of young Vietnamese-born Americans have returned to Vietnam in the last few years to do business and to seek their roots; many express uncertainty over their cultural identities, and Vietnamese Government seems equally divided between wanting the money and expertise they bring back and fearing Western cultural influences; photo (M)

headline: World News Briefs;Bosnian Serbs Press Case To Indict Muslim Leader
abstract: A Bosnian Serb delegation seeking war crimes charges against the President of Bosnia met today with officials at the Yugoslav war crimes tribunal.         It was the first time Bosnian Serbs have sent a high-level delegation to the  tribunal at The Hague, and the gesture was seen as an indication that they may be ready to recognize the United Nations court.

headline: Asking Questions At Towers Financial
abstract: Letter from Thomas B Evans Jr, former Congressman from Delaware, says he seriously acquitted his responsibilities as a director of Towers Financial Corp, a company that turned out to be a Ponzi scheme; he was mentioned in Aug 18 article on service of former members of Congress on corporate boards

headline: On-Line Guide to TV Viewing Offered by Upstart Company
abstract: The Gist, first personalized on-line television viewing guide, makes its debut; users enter their choices of channels, subject matter and viewing times, and instantly receive lineup for following week; The Gist uses software called TV1, which was acquired by Gist Communications Inc in June; Gist will use demographic information from users of its free service to attract advertisers (M)

headline: Zell Company in Hostile Bid Of $387 Million for a Rival
abstract: Manufactured Home Communities Inc, which is controlled by Chicago investor Sam Zell, says it started hostile $387 million bid for rival Chateau Properties Inc after Chateau ignored its earlier offer; bid by Manufactured Home is intended to derail Chateau's plans to buy ROC Communities for $300 million (M)

headline: CHINA HAS BECOME CHIEF CONTRIBUTOR TO U.S. TRADE GAP
abstract: China has for first time surpassed Japan as largest source of US trade deficit, which could exacerbate strains over US charge of unfair Chinese limits on US-made products; deficit with China rose in June to $3.3 billion, 40 percent of total American imbalance, driven mainly by imports of toys, apparel, footwear and household goods; graphs; China has become major Asian exporter, while Japan is increasing imports and shifting some industrial operations to other countries; Commerce Department also reports surprisingly large shrinkage in overall trade gap in June, down to $8.1 billion from $10.5 billion in May; Clinton Administration claims credit for opening up foreign markets and enhancing American competitiveness; deficit with Japan declined in June to $3.2 billion, from $5.3 billion in June 1995; deficit with Mexico narrowed about $100 million, to about $1.5 billion, but still 27 percent higher than in 1993, year before Nafta (S)

headline: FUNDS WATCH;Checkbooks Ready? Go!
abstract: Too much money can be a liability for mutual funds, especially those that buy small stocks. As a result, many such funds close to new investors when their coffers reach a predetermined level. But in one day?         In what must be a record, PBHG Limited, a new fund that scours around among the tiniest of stocks, opened and closed for business last Monday. It gathered the $100 million it had sought by soliciting shareholders of its other funds. "It was easier than we thought," said Mike Carrington, the director of mutual funds for Pilgrim Baxter & Associates.

headline: Foster's Expects Delay In China Profits
abstract: Foster's Brewing Group Ltd of Australia has pushed back its expectations for turning a profit in China, saying its operations there will not be out the red until at least 1999; chief executive Ted Kunkel says that China effort is about 18 months behind its target; Foster's also says its total profits climbed 2 percent, to $293 million (Australian), or $232 million (US) in year ended June 30, up from $287.3 million (Australian) a year earlier; sales dropped 46 percent, to $2.35 billion ($1.86 billion), from $4.37 billion (S)

headline: Deutsche Telekom Says Profits Sagged
abstract: Deutsche Telekom reports first half profit fell 96 percent to 129 million marks ($89 million), down from 3.5 billion marks in 1995 period (S)

headline: Orders for Machine Tools Rise by 18.7%
abstract: Orders for American industrial tools rose 18.7 percent in June from the previous month as demand from domestic customers soared, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said today.         Total orders for machine tools advanced to $447.75 million in June from $377.10 million in May. Compared with June 1995, last month's orders were up 19.30 percent.

headline: Delta Air Lines Introduces New Budget Carrier
abstract: Delta Air Lines, in move aimed at bringing back business from discount rivals like Southwest Airlines, introduces budget carrier named Delta Express; new service will link 10 cities in Midwest and Northeast with five Florida cities starting Oct 1; one-way fares will run $19 to $159 (M)

headline: First-Half Profits Disappoint At Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz
abstract: Ciba-Geigy AG and Sandoz AG report earnings gains for first half of their fiscal year that disappointed analysts; Ciba's net income rose to $1.3 billion, but operating profits grew only 3 percent; Sandoz's net income rose 12 percent, and sales rose 7 percent; two companies are merging to form Novartis AG, one of world's largest drug manufacturers (M)

headline: ARAFAT SAYS PLAN FOR SETTLEMENTS VIOLATES ACCORDS
abstract: Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, in bitter speech showing growing disillusionment with policies of Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, calls decision by Israeli Govt to permit expansion of Jewish settlements in West Bank and Gaza flagrant violation of Palestinian-Israeli accords that should be resisted 'on the ground'; says decision is most dangerous threat facing Palestinians and is tantamount to destruction of peace process; says Palestinians should use all means at their disposal to resist settlements; call to action raises prospect of renewed confrontations between Palestinians and Israeli settlers, and is harshest response by Palestinian leader to positions of new Israeli Govt since Netanyahu took office; remarks reflect mounting frustration among Palestinian officials over what is perceived as Netanyahu's deliberate attempt to back out of signed agreements and put of talks on final peace settlement; photo (M)

headline: British Drug Maker Expects Strong Half
abstract: Zeneca Group PLC is expected to post 19 percent rise in first-half pretax profit to about 600 million pounds ($930 million), up from 506 million pounds in 1995 period (S)

headline: Car and Truck Sales Mostly Off in August
abstract: Sales of cars and trucks sagged by 2.3 percent in August from year ago, signaling that auto sales in the last half of the year will be significantly off unexpectedly brisk pace set in spring and early summer; graphs (M)

headline: AT&T to Market Satellite Dishes
abstract: The AT&T Corporation plans to market the DirecTV satellite broadcast system through the Sharper Image Corporation and Tower Records retail stores. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Genetic Systems To Get New Owner
abstract: German chemical company Hoechst AG says that Agrevo GmbH, its crop-protection-chemical joint venture with Schering AG, has agreed to take control of Dutch-Belgian company Plant Genetic Systems International NV; Agrevo will initially buy a stake of at least 75 percent for $550 million (S)

headline: U.S. Flying Out Refugees
abstract: More than 2,000 Kurdish refugees, who worked with American military and relief operation in northern Iraq, cross safely into Turkey; first group is flown to Guam en route to US (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ERNST & YOUNG L.L.P., New York, the accounting and consulting firm, announced the acquisition of closely held Wright Killen and Co. of Houston, consultants for the energy and chemical industries. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Developments of rental apartments are being planned at an old factory site in Hoboken.
abstract: Huddle of manufacturing buildings is being torn down to make way for what its to become first new rental complex in a decade in Hoboken, NJ; $40 million complex, to be built over next 15 months, will have 240 apartments of one to three bedrooms; complex will be built by Bellemead Development Corp (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: McLEOD INC., Cedar Rapids, Iowa, a provider of local and long-distance telecommunications services, said it would acquire Ruffalo, Cody & Associates Inc., also of Cedar Rapids, for $21 million in cash and stock.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;J. & J. Results Cheer Investors; Eli Lilly Profits Stir Concerns
abstract: Johnson & Johnson and Eli Lilly & Company both reported earnings gains yesterday for the second quarter. But after looking hard at the results, investors showed their approval of Johnson & Johnson and displayed concerns about Lilly.         Johnson & Johnson, the big diversified pharmaceutical and health products company, said its net income rose 19.7 percent, slightly exceeding Wall Street's forecasts.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Disney Has 27.7% Rise In Earnings
abstract: The Walt Disney Company reported a 27.7 percent rise in third-quarter profits today, with improvements in all three of its major businesses.         The company, the world's largest in the entertainment business, earned $406 million, or 59 cents a share, in the three months ended June 30, up from $318 million, or 60 cents a share, a year earlier. The results were in line with Wall Street's expectations.

headline: Building Starts on Homes Took Strong Jump in June
abstract: Construction starts on new homes rose unexpectedly in June, the Commerce Department said today, in the latest evidence of the resiliency of the housing market.         "So far, the strong job market and strong consumer confidence have been winning the tug-of-war against higher interest rates," said Eileen Neely, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae.

headline: Japan Inc., so resilient in the past, can't find its footing.
abstract: Peter Passell (Economic Scene) column explores why Japan has been unable to shrug off its current economic problems (M)

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Amnesty Critical of Rate Of Executions in China
abstract: China has executed at least 1,000 people since it began a campaign against crime two months ago, Amnesty International said today. Most were executed immediately after unfair trials, the rights organization said.         Chinese officials were not available to comment on the report.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Anheuser-Busch Companies, St. Louis, is selling $200 million of notes due in 2003 through Dillon, Read & Co. The noncallable notes carry an interest rate of 6.75 percent and are priced at par. The issue is rated A1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's.     Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $100 million of global medium-term notes due in 1998 through Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. The notes, which are callable quarterly beginning Nov. 20, 1996, pay an interest rate of 6 percent twice a year annually and are priced at par.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;BMW Says New Models Helped Increase Profits
abstract: Bayerische Motorenwerke A.G., the German luxury car maker known as BMW, said  yesterday that its first-half net income rose 9.8 percent, crediting the success of the new 5-Series, the sold-out Z3 roadster and new models of its Rover subsidiary in Britain. Profits grew to 335 million marks, or $226 million, in the first half, from 305 million marks last year, within analysts' expectations.         First-half revenue rose 7.9 percent, to 25.167 billion marks, from 23.32 billion marks last year, and auto sales increased 5.7 percent, to 556,800 BMW and Rover models.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Equity Offerings Planned During the Week Ahead
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      Adeza Biomedical Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif., an initial public offering of 2.5 million shares. Prudential Securities.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;GOLDEN POULTRY RISES AFTER COURT ORDERS PURCHASE
abstract: The shares of the Golden Poultry Company rose 23 percent yesterday after an Alabama judge ordered Gold Kist Inc. to purchase the 27 percent stake in the company owned by minority shareholders. Stock in Golden Poultry, a poultry and dairy products company based in Atlanta, rose $2.25, to $12, in Nasdaq trading.  Gold Kist, a closely held farmers' cooperative that controls 73 percent of Golden Poultry's shares, said that a Jefferson County Circuit Court judge in Birmingham, Ala., had ordered it to pay "fair value" for the 3.92 million Golden Poultry shares held by minority investors. The order, while not final, would resolve a suit filed in 1993 by two farmers who accused Gold Kist officers of breaching their fiduciary duties.

headline: Pentagon Sees Slim Chance of U.S. War Role in Northern Iraq
abstract: Defense Dept officials say US is unlikely to be drawn into fighting between two Kurdish factions in northern Iraq, despite reports that Iraqi troops are continuing to fight alongside one of groups; US warns Iraq it faces new military attacks if it tries to repair air-defense sites in south, recently destroyed by American cruise missiles (S)

headline: A British agency gets the Sebastiani account, while a French one expands in Mexico and Brazil.
abstract: Advertising agencies in Britain and France are picking up accounts in North and South America; San Francisco office of British agency Leagas Delaney is named to handle account of Sebastiani Vineyards, with billings at $5 million; Publicis SA in Paris has acquired controlling interests in agencies in Mexico and Brazil; Maurice Levy, chairman of Publicis, says company's route to globalization is now open (M)

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices End Up Slightly
abstract: Treasury prices ended slightly higher yesterday on relief that Federal Reserve policy makers had left interest rates unchanged.         While the decision by the Fed was expected, recent strong economic reports had raised doubts among some market participants. Investors have now turned their attention to tomorrow's June employment data, which are expected to help determine the Fed's next move on interest rates.

headline: World News Briefs;18 Remain Critically Ill After Protest in Turkey
abstract: Eighteen Turkish prisoners remained critically ill today following a two-month hunger strike that ended over the weekend, human rights workers said.          Eleven hunger strikers died before the protest was called off after the new Islamist-led Government accepted some of the inmates' demands for better prison  conditions. Another protester died after the agreement was made.

headline: Kirshenbaum Gets Apparel Account
abstract: Emanuel/Emanuel Ungaro, the apparel company, selects Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York to handle its national account; billings estimated at $12 million to $15 million; Popeyes Chicken and Biscuits names Hill, Holliday/Altschiller to handle its account, with billings at $11 million (S)

headline: GOLDMAN SACHS TRUST BUYS BOSTON GLOBAL ADVISORS
abstract: Goldman Sachs Trust Co, Goldman Sachs Group LP unit, acquires Boston Global Advisors Inc from Paloma Partners LLC for over $10 million (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Merck & Co., Whitehouse Station, N.J., to Lowe Direct, New York, a unit of the Lowe Group, owned by the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle consumer direct marketing for Fosamax, a treatment for osteoporosis. Those duties had been handled by FCB Direct, New York, a unit of True North Communications. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: * Holiday Inn Worldwide, Atlanta, a unit of Bass P.L.C., to Draft Direct Worldwide, Chicago, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle direct marketing in North America, previously handled by various agencies. Draft handles direct marketing assignments throughout Asia. Billings were not disclosed. * Gaylord Entertainment Co., Nashville, to ABP Interactive, New York, a unit of  Adler Boschetto Peebles & Partners, as the first agency to handle interactive marketing.
