Billings were not disclosed. * Hannaford Brothers Co., Scarborough, Me., to Pedone & Partners, New York, to handle advertising for the operator of Shop 'n Save supermarkets and the Hannaford Food and Drug stores, which had been handled by Houston Herstek Favat, Boston. Billings were not disclosed. * Primeco Personal Communications L.P., Westlake, Tex., an alliance of Air Touch Communications, Bell Atlantic, Nynex and U S West, to Fox Pavlika & Partners, New York, as its first direct marketing agency. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Sears Expands Role With Young & Rubicam
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co has further expanded its ties with Young & Rubicam Inc, naming advertising agency first to handle its Home Services group (S)

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Weak Reports On Economy Bolster Bonds
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday on renewed optimism that the economy would slow enough to keep inflation from accelerating, an outlook that was bolstered by reports of weaker orders for durable goods and lower sales of existing homes.         The reports gave investors some relief from the fear that the Fed would raise interest rates before its next monetary policy meeting on Aug. 20.

headline: Two Directors of Archer Not Running for Re-election
abstract: Archer Daniels Midland Co says two former officers of company will step down as directors; planned resignations of John Daniels and Ralph Bruce are latest response to criticism of insider domination of board; company says majority of board will now be independent directors; some critics contend many members of board have close family, personal or business ties to Dwayne O Andreas, chairman and chief executive (M)

headline: Newspaper Takes a $1.3 Million Charge
abstract: The Providence Journal Company said today that it had taken a $1.3 million charge in the second quarter because more employees than expected accepted voluntary severance packages. The charge follows one of $1.1 million taken in the first quarter, also because of the severance program, and $6.8 million in restructuring costs taken in the fourth quarter of 1995 in anticipation of the job cuts in the publishing division.         The company received 175 responses to the offer, more than the 160 it planned on, said Thomas Matlack, chief financial officer.

headline: AVANT IN $153 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR META-SOFTWARE
abstract: Avant Corp, maker of computer design software, agrees to buy Meta-Software Inc for about $153 million in stock (S)

headline: Ex-Mayor on Trial, a Rwanda Town Remembers
abstract: Jean-Paul Akayesu goes before UN tribunal in Tanzania on charges of genocide and murder in massacre of at least 2,000 people in Taba, Rwanda, where he was Hutu mayor; photo; survivors recall him exhorting Hutus to hack thousands of Tutsi to death and torture Hutus who tried hide people from killers; recall Akayesu seeking out educated people and promising to reward killers with Tutsi land (S)

headline: Oil Rises as Storm Threat in Gulf Shuts 3 Big Mexican Installations
abstract: Crude oil prices climb after tropical storm Dolly forces ports to close on Gulf of Mexico, temporarily delaying Mexican oil imports; Petroleos Mexicanos shuts down three main harbor installations because of the storm (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Consolidated Stores Corp receives $29.7 million from Melville Corp as price adjustment on Consolidated's purchase of Kay-Bee Toys; final purchase price is $285.3 million (S)

headline: Growth in Jobs Slowed in July, Breaking Trend
abstract: New Government figures indicate that after several months in overdrive, the economy is showing signs of slowing to a more moderate pace that is generating no increases in inflation; Labor Department reports that the economy created jobs in July at a somewhat slower rate than during the spring and the upward pressure on wages ebbed; Commerce Department reports consumer spending fell in July for the first time since winter and factory orders fell in June for the first time in four months; charts (M)

headline: Serb Stands Firm in Face of U.S. Effort to Oust Karadzic
abstract: A round of high-profile American talks to persuade President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia to remove the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, from power in Bosnia ended without progress today, the special United States envoy to the Balkans, Richard C. Holbrooke, said.         After four hours of talks with Mr. Milosevic, the man whom Mr. Holbrooke persuaded to sign the Dayton peace accords last fall, the envoy left for Zagreb  to meet with the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, and said he would return here on Thursday.

headline: Takeover of Snapple Is the Prime Suspect in the Food Giant's Weak Showing
abstract: Negative impact on Quaker Oats Co stock, income and management of Nov 1994 acquisition of beverage firm Snapple discussed; Snapple has obscured firm's strengths, preoccupied management and created financial strains that have limited firm's strategic flexibility; graphs; photos (M)

headline: In Australia, Signs of Artists Who Predate Homo Sapiens
abstract: Archeologists say they have found in remote tropics of northwestern Australia the rock face and many surrounding boulders engraved with thousands of circles, the work of people some 75,000 years ago; it is by far earliest known sign of artistic behavior, more than twice the age of any European cave painting and at least 15,000 years older than any previous Australian rock art; digging deeper at base of stone monolith, archeologists made what may be even more stunning discovery: red ochre and stone artifacts of an age that could triple the time people have occupied Australia, from about 60,000 years to 116,000 years and perhaps as much as 176,000 years; new dates suggest that modern human beings might not have been able to migrate to Australia early enough to be these artists; could it be that in some rare cases, artistic expression began before modern Homo sapiens? maps; diagrams (L)

headline: The World Wide Wait: Don't Get Mad, Get Off
abstract: Mark Pincus and Sunil Paul of Freeloader Inc think they have discovered solution to the excruciating delay that many home computer users experience when they try to download graphics and photos from multimedia Web sites; user with Internet access can direct Freeloader's software to retrieve pages from specific sites and automatically download those pages onto user's hard drive; once on hard drive, pages come up quicker, without having to be transferred over slow telephone modem; Freeloader is just one of several companies trying to persuade on-line world to go off line; diagram (M)

headline: IRAQ PULLING OUT, BUT LEAVING SPIES BEHIND, U.S. SAYS
abstract: US officials say Saddam Hussein is withdrawing most but not all of his forces from Kurdish enclaves in northern Iraq, but is leaving behind 'massive security presence' of spies and agents to reclaim his power in region; photos; map; CIA Dir John M Deutch offers generally optimistic assessment following US missile strikes, but State Department concedes that idea of two warring Kurdish leaders settling differences is now but a distant hope; Massoud Barzani has allied with old enemy Hussein and his rival, Jalal Talabani, vows to make no peace (M)

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn Prices Soar to Records And Soybeans Join in Rally
abstract: Corn and soybean prices surged a second day on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, following forecasts for scorching, dry weather in the Midwest that threatens to ravage late-planted crops.         On other markets, coffee prices fell and natural gas prices rose.

headline: Bertelsmann Reports Mixed Picture for Year
abstract: Bertelsmann AG says lower tax bill helped raise profits by 11 percent in its latest fiscal year, but its operating profits fell 8.1 percent, to 1.53 billion marks, largely because of higher paper costs (S)

headline: Congress Is Faulted on North Korea
abstract: The Clinton Administration accused Congress today of jeopardizing an international agreement under which North Korea consented to freeze its nuclear  program.         The House and Senate have agreed to provide only $13 million of the $25 million requested by the Administration as the American share for the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization, an international consortium set up to provide alternate fuel sources for North Korea.

headline: Acquisition by Grace
abstract: W R Grace & Co buys Mexican maker of can coatings and sealants from Grupo Zapata of Mexico to increase its access to rapidly growing soft drink market in Latin America (S)

headline: Central Bankers' Group Adding to Ranks
abstract: Bank for International Settlements will admit nine new members, including China and Russia, as it expands beyond industrial West to include central banks in world's fastest-growing economies; others admitted are India, Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea, Brazil, Mexico and Saudi Arabia (M)

headline: Intermedia Acquires Unit From Newhouse
abstract: Intermedia Communications Inc. said Friday that it had acquired the telecommunications division of the EMI Communications Corporation, a unit of the Newhouse Broadcasting Corporation, in a stock deal valued at about $30.5 million.         The agreement calls for Intermedia to offer 937,500 shares of its stock, which rose $2 Friday, to $32.25, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Group to Re-edit TV Commercials
abstract: The Partnership for a Drug-Free America has agreed to re-edit television commercials that had been labeled "patently homophobic" by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation.         The commercials are part of a public-service campaign against heroin use that was introduced last month. They featured a young addict describing how after losing his job, he had to "have sex with men for money to support my habit." In  a letter to the Partnership, the gay and lesbian organization, known as Glaad, urged the spots be withdrawn for suggesting that "if there is one thing worse than being an addict, it's being a homosexual."

headline: SIERRA SEMICONDUCTOR EXPECTS TO CUT 150 EMPLOYEES
abstract: Sierra Semiconductor Corp says that it expects to dismiss 150 employees, or 30% of its work force, in next few months as it stops selling chips for computer modems (S)ï

headline: A Great Name Like Eskimo Pie Can't Lose. Or Can It?
abstract: Profile of Eskimo Pie Corp, 75-year-old maker of famous chocolate-covered ice cream bar; chairman-chief executive David V Clark has resigned amid disappointment over earnings and plummeting stock price; photos; map; critics point to unprofitable new ventures, such as new line of low-fat, artificially-sweetened Eskimo Pies (S)

headline: People
abstract: Janet L. Klineman was named to the new post of senior vice president and senior account planner at Wells Rich Greene BDDP, New York, a unit of BDDP Worldwide. She had been senior account planner at Fallon McElligott Berlin, New York, an affiliate of Fallon McElligott, Minneapolis.    Robert Reina was named regional marketing director at Customer Marketing Associates, New York, a newly created unit of Robert A. Becker Inc. Euro RSCG, which is owned by Havas Advertising. He had been vice president and account director at the Comtact Corp., New York, a division of the Klemptner Advertising unit of Cordiant P.L.C.

headline: A pharmacist offers an alternative to progesterone injections for treating infertility.
abstract: William J Bologna, chairman of Columbia Laboratories, patents alternative to twice-a-day injections of progesterone that many women being treated for infertility must undergo; his invention is progesterone gel that is inserted with applicator into vagina; American Home Products ahs worldwide license to the patent; Craig L Monroe gets patents for eyeglass frames made of wood, which will be sold through his company. Woody's Originals Inc; David Levy gets patent for volume thumbwheel that alerts player of portable tape or CD player of how loud volume is set at (M)

headline: 'American' Arrowhead Found in Siberia
abstract: Archeologists discover stone arrowhead, believed unique only to Paleo-Indians of North America, in Magadan, Siberia; discovery could provide important evidence relating to thorny questions about early colonizations of Americas; site of discovery is 1,200 miles from Bering Strait; photo; map (M)

headline: Mercedes Buses in China
abstract: Mercedes-Benz AG of Germany says it has completed agreement to form joint venture to manufacture touring buses in China; venture will turn out 7,000 coaches annually and 5,000 bus chassis for Mercedes' partner, Yangzhou Motor Coach General (S)

headline: PHARMACIA & UPJOHN IN MARKETING PACT WITH GILEAD
abstract: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc says it will pay Gilead Sciences Inc $60 million for overseas rights to drug, to be sold under name Vistide, that helps AIDS patients fight blindness (S)

headline: Murdoch Places Bets On a Global Vision
abstract: Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation, is willing to act quickly and spend heavily to enhance his strategy of having a finger in every major form of programming, in every corner of the world.          A shopping spree this summer has helped position his company for an era of rapidly changing technologies and business alliances.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;IMPERIAL HOLLY AGREES TO SELL 27% STAKE TO GREENCORE
abstract: The Imperial Holly Corporation, a sugar refiner, agreed yesterday to sell a 27 percent stake to the Dublin-based Greencore Group P.L.C. for $50.4 million. Imperial Holly said its directors yesterday approved the sale of 3.8 million newly issued common shares to Greencore -- the only sugar processor in Ireland -- for $13.25 a share. Greencore, which is also a leading marketer of malt and flour in Britain, will name two directors to Imperial Holly's board, the company said. Imperial Holly, based in Sugar Land, Tex., said proceeds from the  sale would initially be used to partly repay indebtedness.

headline: When a Magazine Isn't Afraid to Look in the Mirror
abstract: Comment on crowded field of magazines devoted to personal finance; Smart Money is cited as magazine that is willing to admit mistakes, and analyze its own track record; other magazines mentioned are Money, Worth and Kiplinger's Personal Finance; photo (M)

headline: Inflation Is Coming! Inflation Isn't Coming! Bond Shoppers Can Decide
abstract: Question-and-answer column about new US Savings Bonds pegged to inflation rates (S)

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Hewlett Earnings to Drop; Omen for Computer Stocks?
abstract: In news that could roil technology stocks again today, the Hewlett-Packard Company said late yesterday that orders for its products were slowing and that its profitability for the current fiscal quarter would probably be hurt as a result.         The company said it planned to close its two computer disk-drive plants and take a pretax charge of $150 million for the moves.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Leo Burnett Promotes Executives
abstract: The Leo Burnett Company in Chicago has expanded top management by promoting several executives as a leading creative executive leaves.         James M. Jenness, 50, group president for the Americas, was promoted to the new post of vice chairman and chief operating officer, reporting to William T. Lynch, president and chief executive. When Mr. Lynch, 53, was asked whether that made Mr. Jenness his heir apparent, he replied, laughing, "I'm going to be  around for a long time."

headline: Bond Yields At Highest In 3 Weeks
abstract: Treasury bond prices fall, sending up yields; 30-year bond drops 14/32 to 99 to yield 6.83 percent; Treasury says it plans to sell $31.5 billion in two- and five-year notes next week; graph (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Serbs in Pragmatic Pullout from Albanian Region
abstract: In 1989 the Serbian strongman, Slobodan Milosevic, swooped down in a helicopter onto the field where 600 years earlier the Turks had defeated the Serbs at the Battle of Kosovo. In a fervent speech before a million Serbs, he galvanized the nationalist passions that two years later fueled the Balkan conflict.         Now, in this bedraggled southern province of Kosovo, a predominantly Albanian Muslim region where President Milosevic promised a glorious future for the minority Serbs, the Balkan conflict appears to be playing out a subdued denouement.

headline: More Than Just Numbers
abstract: Sears Roebuck chief executive Arthur C Martinez recalls first job as stock boy at Bohack's supermarket in Brooklyn; photos (S)

headline: Karadzic Says He Won't Run
abstract: The Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, said today that he would not run in the September elections in Bosnia. Under the peace accord Dr. Karadzic, who has been indicted for war crimes, was ineligible to run, but some supporters had urged him to do so anyway as an act of defiance.         "Radovan Karadzic has decided not to run in the forthcoming elections in Bosnia, despite categorical demands to do so from the party's main board," the Bosnian Serb press agency said, referring to the Serb Democratic Party.

headline: Welcome Mat Is Out For Gay Investors
abstract: Brokers and financial planners are wooing gay investors, many of whom are in dual-income households with no children and thus have substantial sums to invest; gay people also have distinct requirements in areas like estate planning; a flurry of products and services are being introduced, from a mutual fund that invests solely in gay-friendly companies to a new investment advisory firm that focuses on socially responsible investing for gay people; photos (M)

headline: 1991 BLAST IN IRAQ MAY HAVE EXPOSED 5,000 G.I.'S TO GAS
abstract: Defense Dept announces that over 5,000 US troops may have been exposed to deadly chemical weapons when battalion of US soldiers blew up Iraqi ammunition depot days after end of Persian Gulf war; announcement raises sharply number of troops who may have been exposed to sarin, deadly nerve agent, as result of demolition of Kamisiyah ammunition depot in March 1991; previously, Pentagon had suggested that only about 300 to 400 troops may have been exposed to toxic chemicals (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ROCKEFELLER CENTER PROPERTIES IS SOLD TO INVESTORS
abstract: Rockefeller Center Properties Inc. said yesterday that a group of investors led by Goldman, Sachs & Company and David Rockefeller had completed their $1.2 billion purchase of the company. The company holds the $1.3 billion mortgage on  New York landmark Rockefeller Center. Under the terms of the acquisition, the Goldman-Rockefeller group is paying about $8 a share and assuming $870 million in debt. Rockefeller Center is home to the NBC television network's broadcast studios and Radio City Music Hall.

headline: Square Pegs Stay Out Of School In Japan
abstract: Problem of school phobia in Japan discussed; last year, one in 85 junior high school students misssed at least 50 days of classes because of school phobia; there is concern that truancy rate will increase again this year, just as it has for more than 20 years; school refusers, as they are called, represent underside of Japan's vaunted education system; experts say that pressure to conform and excel can overwhelm some students (M)

headline: Nasdaq Sinks as Investors Turn to the Blue-Chips
abstract: Small-company stocks, which for more than 18 months acted as the engine of growth for the stock market, mutual funds and the economy as a whole, continued  to erode yesterday, as investors turned further away from that increasingly volatile sector of the market in favor of blue chips.         That brought the decline in the Nasdaq composite index, the most-watched barometer of high-growth companies, to 16.6 percent for the seven weeks since June 5, when the index closed at its highest lever ever. The decline is more than twice that of the Dow industrials over the same period.

headline: INTERNATIONAL NETWORK SHARES SOAR IN PUBLIC OFFERING
abstract: Shares of International Network Services soar more than 90 percent above its offering price of $16 a share, in first day of trading (S)

headline: Big Companies Ask Children How to Sell to Children
abstract: Small but growing army of child consultants are working for some of biggest companies who market goods and services to children; provide data about what they and peers love and hate in everthing from clothes and jewelry to software and music; graph; photos (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Outlook For Inflation Is Low
abstract: More expensive food led German wholesale prices up two-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Government said yesterday, while new signs of economic weakness suggested that consumer inflation would remain slow.          A report from Ifo, the economic research institute, showed that Western German business confidence in June had slipped back to March levels, shadowing prospects for immediate recovery from recession. Given the weak growth outlook,  most economists do not expect Western German consumer inflation to reach 2 percent in the next year. The rate fell to 1.2 percent in June. That overshadowed the higher-than-expected rise in June wholesale prices, led by a 17 percent rise in prices for refrigerated pork and rises for vegetables and noncitrus fruit.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: U.S. Sends Another Carrier To Bolster Mideast Forces
abstract: Pentagon dispatches second aircraft carrier to Middle East, expanding American fire power in the region as the United States prepares for new attack on Iraq; Pres Clinton vows to do 'whatever it takes' to keep Saddam Hussein from threatening his neighbors or American pilots (M)

headline: People
abstract: * Craig W. Branigan was named managing director at Landor Associates, San Francisco, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., succeeding Peter J. Harleman and Kay Stout, who were promoted to area managing director for the Americas and chief marketing and creative strategist, respectively. Mr. Branigan had been president and chief executive of the San Francisco office of Y.& R.  * Luanne Calvert was named to the new position of media director at Black Rocket, San Francisco. She had held the same post at Citron Haligman Bedecarre, San Francisco.

headline: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM ACQUIRES 3 CHEMICAL PRODUCERS
abstract: Occidental Petroleum Corp acquires three chemical producers in separate deals for total of about $145 million, including $127 million in stock; three are Laurel Industries, Natural Gas Odorizing and Augusta, Ga, silicate plant sold by Power Solicates Manufacturing Inc (S)

headline: SOUTHERN NATIONAL TO BUY FIDELITY FINANCIAL
abstract: Southern National Corp agrees to buy Fidelity Financial Bankshares Corp for $59.4 million in stock (S)

headline: Invesco Talks With AIM About Merger
abstract: Invesco PLC and AIM Management Group Inc say they are talking about merger that could result in creation of international fund manager with $144 billion in assets; those involved say it would be merger of equals, but transaction would most likely be structured in way that AIM would assume managing control of Invesco's mutual fund operation and perhaps whole company (M)

headline: U.S. Promises Arms if Muslims Join Croats
abstract: The Clinton Administration promised today to begin shipping weapons to Bosnia as early as this month if the Government here approves merging Muslim and Bosnian Croat troops into a single army.         But the $360 million in military aid that Defense Secretary William J. Perry  offered at a meeting here, tempting though it might have been, did not seal any  promises to approve the merger, which was seen as another reflection of the shakiness of the Muslim-Croat Federation that was established under the peace accords.

headline: Loss at AT&T Computer Unit Was $1 Billion Over Estimates
abstract: AT&T filing with Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with its spinoff of NCR Corp shows that AT&T's foray into computers cost it $1 billion more than previously thought; filing provides stark evidence of how NCR began losing money two years after AT&T acquired it for $7.48 billion in 1991, even as AT&T continued to pour millions of dollars into NCR; NCR as stand-alone company is thought to have current market value of $4 billion; this means AT&T's total loss on its investment would be roughly $6.8 billion (M)

headline: PROTEIN DESIGN STOCK FALLS ON DRUG TRIAL'S HALT
abstract: Shares of Protein Design Labs Inc fall almost 33 percent after company ends clinical trials of compound to treat eye condition in people infected with virus that causes AIDS; tests failed to show that compound was effective (S)

headline: Filipino Foes Meet at Talks To End Muslim Rebellion
abstract: Philippines Pres Fidel Ramos travels to battle-torn island of Mindanao and embraces Nur Misuari, leader of Moro National Liberation Front, in what many say is last step in quest for lasting peace in Philippines; final agreement between Government and guerrillas, which will be signed on Sept 2, will grant Moros some measure of autonomy; map (M)

headline: Okinawans Send Message to Tokyo and U.S. to Cut Bases
abstract: Citizens of Okinawa, in nonbinding referendum, vote overwhelmingly in favor of reduction of American military bases on island; plans by US to close some of bases noted; likely effects of referendum discussed; map; photo (M)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: St. Peter's College, Jersey City, to Big Idea, New York, to handle its account,  previously at Linett & Harrison, Millburn, N.J. Billings were estimated at $1 million. Ticketmaster Inc., Los Angeles, to the Pearlman Group, Los Angeles, to handle its account, previously in-house. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: U.S. Considers Another Evacuation of Aid Workers From Iraq
abstract: Central Intelligence Agency Dir John M Deutch tells House committee that Pres Saddam Hussein has strengthened his political control over northern Iraq; State Dept says US is considering second evacuation of aid workers in Kurdish enclave (M)

headline: In France, Leaders Brace For the Worst From Unions
abstract: Pres Jacques Chirac and his unpopular conservative Government brace for a second autumn of labor unrest over spending cuts that they insist are necessary even with French unemployment at its highest level in nearly 50 years, 12.6 percent; Chirac plans to call for a budget freeze to keep the Government deficit next year to $56.7 billion, as well as an increase in alcohol and cigarette taxes to bring down the health insurance and retirement system deficit to $9.4 billion by 1997 (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Healthy Economic Growth Is Shown With More Jobs   The economy is avoiding overheating, showing instead signs of slowing to a moderate but still healthy pace while generating no increases in inflation.    New Government data showed that the economy created 193,000 jobs in July, a somewhat slower rate than during the spring, pushing the unemployment rate for July up slightly, to 5.4 percent of the civilian work force, from 5.3 percent in June. Also, upward pressure on wages ebbed last month. Consumer spending fell during July for the first time since winter, and orders to factories fell in June for the first time in four months. $(Page 1.$)    Prices of Treasury securities surged in response to the positive economic news, pushing the yield on the 30-year bond to a four-month low of 6.73 percent. $(45.$)    Economist Links Jobs and Yields   The monthly employment report seems to have a greater effect on stock and bond markets than any other single piece of economic data. In a study to be released on Monday, Alan B. Krueger, a Princeton University economist, measures the correlation between the interest rate on the 30-year Treasury bond and job creation. $(37.$)    Wage and Health Bills Passed   Lawmakers, rushing toward a monthlong recess, resoundingly approved bills to raise the Federal minimum wage by 90 cents, to $5.15 an hour, insure safer drinking water and make health insurance portable between jobs. They then sent the agreements to President Clinton for his expected signature. $(1.$)    It's Still the Economy   More than any other issue, the economy was Bill Clinton's ticket to the Presidency four years ago. With the country struggling to climb out of a recession, Mr. Clinton campaigned as the champion of the ''forgotten middle class.'' Now he is basing his re-election campaign on a much improved economy. $(1.$)    Democrats contend that Bob Dole's tax-cutting package, expected Monday, is based on overly rosy economic predictions. The Dole camp sees its numbers as far more credible than the Democrats' assumptions. $(9.$)    World Bank Studies New Role   Taking the first step to stimulate the flow of billions of dollars in private capital to the developing world, the World Bank effectively set aside $250 million to start a new fund to guarantee new investment in poor countries against expropriation and other political risks. James D. Wolfensohn, the bank's new president, reasons that private investors would be willing to lend far more money to the developing world if their investment could be insured. The bank's executive directors like the idea, but final approval awaits a detailed plan. $(36.$)    Ford Ordered to Pay Sanctions   Ford Motor was ordered by a Dallas judge to pay $10 million in sanctions to the plaintiffs in a lawsuit related to a fatal car crash. The judge accused Ford of ''wrongful and abusive conduct'' during pretrial proceedings. $(37.$)    Steroids, a Black Market Success   Whenever the Olympic Games take the world stage, accusations about the use of performance-enhancing drugs are sure to follow. But world-class athletes -- if they take the drugs -- are not alone. An estimated 500,000 Americans, mostly young, white and male, spend $400 million a year in the black market on synthetic steroid hormones to improve their sports prowess -- or just to show off their brawn. Separately, there is a legal, medical market in the drugs. $(45.$)    Dollar Falls Slightly   The dollar ended slightly lower, settling at 1.4750 German marks, down from 1.4762 marks on Thursday, and 106.89 Japanese yen, down from 107.13 yen. $(38.$)    Heating Oil Futures Rise   Heating oil futures prices rose sharply to 58.71 cents a gallon, as traders worried about a possible winter shortage. $(38.$)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Panel Urges Queensland To Sell Off State Assets
abstract: A commission of audit set up by the government of the Australian state of Queensland has recommended that the state sell some of its assets including electricity utilities worth an estimated $9.8 billion Australian ($7.7 billion United States), surplus land, forestry operations, port authorities, the betting agency TAB and a travel agency.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Internet Future At I.B.M. Looks Oddly Familiar
abstract: IBM strategy for Internet is expected to concentrate on behind-the-scenes computer technology, in line with mainstay business; division chief Irving Wladawsky-Berger is expected to tell analysts that IBM has no designs on Internet browser wars that get public attention, believing that real money will be made as thousands of companies institute new computer networks (S)

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Pepsico Earnings Rise 20%, Meeting Analyst Predictions
abstract: Pepsico Inc. reported strength in its worldwide snack business, its domestic  soft-drink system and its international fast-food restaurant operations yesterday, in a second-quarter performance that analysts said could enable the company to return to its traditional double-digit earnings growth by the end of  the year.         Net income rose 20 percent, to $583 million, or 36 cents a share, from $487 million, or 30 cents a share, in the quarter last year, in line with analysts' expectations.

headline: Videotaping at U.S. Base in Bosnia Raises Terrorist Alert
abstract: American troops in Bosnia are placed on highest state of alert after people in civilian clothes are apprehended while videotaping American bases there; intelligence reports suggest possibility of terrorist attack (M)

headline: CAROLCO PICTURES FILES REORGANIZATION PLAN
abstract: Carolco Pictures Inc says it has filed bankruptcy reorganization plan to liquidate its assets and distribute proceeds valued at $90 million to creditors (S)

headline: Corporations are spending travel dollars cautiously these days.
abstract: Roundup of business travel news; Travel Industry Association of America forecasts business travel will drop in fall to lowest level in at least five years; Trans World Airlines apparently has not suffered fall off in business in wake of July 17 crash (M)

headline: Margeotes/Fertitta Drops an Account
abstract: Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners resigns advertising account of Starter Corp, sports apparel marketer (S)

headline: HEALTHSOURCE (HS, N)
abstract: Healthsource Inc reports second-quarter earnings fell 52 percent, to $6.49 million, down from $13.6 million in 1995 period; table (S)

headline: IRIDEX STOCK RISES ON EYE LASER APPROVAL
abstract: Stock of Iridex Corp jumps more than 15%, one day after company, which makes laser systems used to treat eye diseases, receives FDA approval to sell its Oculight laser (S)

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;E. I. DU PONT DE NEMOURS & CO. (DD,N)
abstract: Du Pont said yesterday that second-quarter earnings rose nearly 7 percent on  higher petroleum prices and higher profits from Lycra spandex fibers and plastics.         E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, based in Wilmington, Del., and the nation's largest chemical company, said earnings rose to $1 billion, or $1.78 a share, from $938 million, or $1.70 a share, a year earlier, beating the average estimate of 13 analysts surveyed by IBES International Inc.

headline: Canada Strike Against G.M. Called 'Likely' By Union Chief
abstract: The president of the Canadian Automobile Workers said today that a strike against the General Motors Corporation in Canada was "very likely" this year and that he planned to bolster the union's strike fund for a protracted showdown.         Basil E. (Buzz) Hargrove, the union's president, said in an interview today that when negotiations with the company opened on Tuesday, he planned to demand  limits on G.M.'s ability to buy more parts from independent suppliers. G.M.'s top executives have vowed not to accept limits on these purchases, known as outsourcing, and as recently as last March endured a crippling 17-day strike at  two brake factories in the United States rather than accept such restrictions.

headline: Retail Sales Fell in June; Producer Prices Up Slightly
abstract: Retail sales fell in June, while producer prices rose modestly last month, the Government reported today, in two reports that eased some concerns about inflation and interest rates.         The Commerce Department said retail sales declined two-tenths of 1 percent, to $205.2 billion last month, as demand for everything from new cars to clothing waned after several months of strength. Sales had risen a brisk eight-tenths of  1 percent in May.

headline: Bosnians Campaign on Old Hatreds
abstract: Words and ideas on which candidates in Bosnian elections are building campaigns often echo nationalist rhetoric of rallies four and five years ago that fueled ethnic tensions and led to outbreak of war; campaign by Kresimir Zubac in Croat enclave of Bugojno described; photo; map (M)

headline: Ernesto Geisel, 88, Is Dead; Eased Military Rule in Brazil
abstract: Former Pres Ernesto Geisel, Brazilian military dictator associated with gradual reopening of Brazil to outside world, dies at 88; photo (M)

headline: BELLSOUTH BEGINS BUYBACK THAT IT ANNOUNCED EARLIER
abstract: BellSouth Corp begins stock buyback that its board authorized six months ago, taking advantage of recent slide in its price to buy cheaply; BellSouth's shares have fallen 17 percent since July 3; they closed Sept 6 at $36.125, up 50 cents (S)

headline: House Panel Backs Rescue of S.& L. Fund
abstract: In a surprise move, the House Banking Committee approved a plan today that would revive the savings and loan industry's shaky deposit insurance fund by having the Federal Reserve pay part of the bill.         On a voice vote, the committee passed the bipartisan proposal to place the Savings Association Insurance Fund on stable footing, setting the stage for savings and loans to become commercial banks.

headline: Bank of France Cuts An Interest Rate
abstract: Bank of France reduces its ceiling interest rate for first time since April 25 (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Allegheny Ludlum Corp says its acquisition of Teledyne Inc for $2.25 billion in stock was approved by shareholders of both companies (S)

headline: Bosnia's Nationalist Parties Dominate Election Results
abstract: Nationalist political parties that plunged Bosnia into war four years ago dominated federal and regional legislative races, further jeopardizing hopes for unity, according to nearly complete returns made public from Sept 14 national election; Officials of Orgn for Security and Cooperation in Europe say that although they are not ready to certify vote they do not expect allocation of legislative seats to change; their tally shows that Muslim-led Party of Democratic Action takes 19 of 42 seats in House of Representatives, hard-line Serb Democratic Party takes 9 seats and Croatian Democratic Union wins 7; balance goes to smaller parties that were in opposition during war; tables; charts (M)

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Last Laos Refugees Leave Thailand Camps for U.S.
abstract: The last Hmong tribal people in Thai refugee camps started leaving for the United States today, part of an effort to close the camps and end one of the final chapters of the Indochina war.         As many as 3,000 Hmong -- rural Laotians recruited by the Central Intelligence Agency to fight Communist in the 1960's and 70's -- are being sent  to the United States this year. The first 90 left today, from the Ban Napho camp, in northeast Thailand.

headline: Mercedes-Benz Sales Increased 8% in Half
abstract: Worldwide sales for Mercedes-Benz AG are up nearly 8 percent in first half of 1996, to $25.8 billion (S)

headline: DIARY
abstract: Diary column reviews miscellaneous news in business, finance, economy and education; illus (L)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CARDINAL HEALTH TO BUY PCI SERVICES FOR $145 MILLION
abstract: Cardinal Health Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire PCI Services Inc., a pharmaceutical packaging company, for $145 million in stock, based on Tuesday's  closing price, and the assumption of $56 million in PCI debt. Cardinal Health, a distributor of pharmaceuticals based in Dublin, Ohio, would issue 2.1 million shares, exchanging 0.336 Cardinal Health share for each share of PCI. Shares of  Cardinal Health fell $2.125, to $67, on the New York Stock Exchange, while PCI shares rose $5.375, or 33 percent, to $21.50, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Listed below is a partial list of dividend meetings this week.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Fila Offers Arnell 2 New Assignments
abstract: Fila USA Inc., the athletic footwear and apparel company, has awarded the Arnell Group in New York two new North American assignments that involve women's shoes and promoting technology performance for Fila USA. Billings have not been  determined. Howe Burch, vice president for advertising and communications at Fila USA in Hunt Valley, Md., said Arnell was awarded those assignments without  a formal review. FCB/Leber Katz Partners in New York, a unit of True North Communications, continues as Fila's lead agency.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ford Reports Flat Sales, As Industry Hits Doldrums  Ford reported flat sales for July, with car sales rising modestly and those of mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks falling. Ford's announcement came after the other major auto makers also reported disappointing sales, signaling that auto sales in the United States had slowed this summer. $(Page D4.$)     Leading Economic Indicators Rise  The index of leading indicators rose a larger-than-expected five-tenths of 1 percent, to 102.9 in June, the highest level on record, a sign the economy could be regaining momentum. Separately, the Commerce Department said that the number of homes on which construction was completed in June rose four-tenths of 1 percent from a month earlier. $(D4.$)     Clinton Signs Sanctions Law  President Clinton signed a law to impose sanctions on foreign companies that invest heavily in Iran or Libya, which he described as ''supporters of terrorism,'' despite the objections of France, Germany and other trading partners. France warned that the European Union would retaliate. $(A1.$)    Holding the Chips in Private Hands  The new semiconductor agreement reached by the United States and Japan transfers some of the role played by the two Governments under their previous accord to a private group, which could make chip buyers uneasy. $(D3.$)    U.S. Order-Colonial Data to Merge  U.S. Order, which makes so-called smart phones, has agreed to merge with the Colonial Data Technologies Corporation. $(D2.$)    Dole Proposes 15% Tax Cut  Bob Dole proposed cutting taxes by 15 percent across the board, with a top rate on capital gains of 14 percent, and balancing the budget by 2002. Democrats called the plan irresponsible. $(A1.$)    Aiwa Comes Home Again  Aiwa, a Japanese electronics maker, with about 90 percent of its output abroad, is bringing part of its production back to Japan from Malaysia and other Asian countries, a result of the yen's weakening. $(D3.$)    Stock Prices Slip on Profit Taking  Even with trading enlivened by big merger deals, stocks snapped a four-day winning streak. Mild profit taking erased 5.55 points from the Dow Jones industrial average, which closed at 5,674.28. The Nasdaq composite index fell 4.39 points, to 1,120.53. $(D8.$)    Treasury securities' prices fell in quiet trading, as the market prepared for this week's sale of $39 billion in new issues. The 30-year bond's yield rose to 6.76 percent. $(D15.$)    Attitudes Change and Clothing Sales Fall  As American women's attitudes toward clothes changed in the last few years -- away from the extreme and toward clothes that could be worn both to work and to P.T.A. meetings -- many apparel companies failed to notice, and some have suffered. Sales of women's apparel in the United States fell 12 percent, from the record $84 billion set in 1989 to $73 billion last year, and some companies are only now adjusting to this jilt from women. $(A1.$)     New Chief for Penguin Books  Pearson P.L.C. named a Hollywood executive to head its Penguin Group book publishing arm and also reported a 40 percent drop in profits for the first half of the year. $(D7.$)    $1.2 Billion Offer for Iowa Utility  The MidAmerican Energy Company made a $1.2 billion offer to buy IES Industries in a deal that would bring together the two biggest utilities in Iowa. $(D2.$)

headline: CURRENCY MARKETS;Mark Surges and Dollar Falls As Germany Fails to Cut Rates
abstract: The mark surged and the dollar fell yesterday after the Bundesbank surprised  currency traders by leaving German interest rates unchanged.         Many traders had been expecting a cut, and the decision by the central bank raised concern that German rates would not move any lower.

headline: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE OVERVIEW;YELTSIN DEFEATS COMMUNIST FOE BY A SURPRISINGLY WIDE MARGIN; HEALTH ISSUE LOOMS  FOR 2D TERM
abstract: Rejecting a return to the Communist past that has defined 20th-century Russia, voters re-elected the country's first President, Boris N. Yeltsin, on Wednesday by an unexpectedly wide margin.         Mr. Yeltsin, who played a crucial role in the dissolution of the Soviet Union and the creation of the new Russian state, arose from what seemed like political oblivion to defeat his challenger, the Communist leader, Gennadi A. Zyuganov.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ALASKA AIR GROUP INC. Seattle, the holding company for Alaska Airlines Inc. and Horizon Air Industries, said it had ordered 12 Boeing 737-400 aircraft, with the option to acquire up to 12 more in a deal worth $540 million.    FRANKLIN QUEST CO., Salt Lake City, which provides training seminars, software and products, is acquiring Premier Agendas Inc., of Bellingham, Wash., and Premier School Agendas Ltd., of Abbotsford, British Columbia, for about $18 million. Both make academic and personal planners.    OLSTEN CORP., Melville, L.I., a staffing company, said its IMI Systems subsidiary had acquired Harvey Consultants Ltd. of Burton-on-Trent, England, a consulting and staffing company with annual revenues of more than $22 million. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Equity and Debt Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Acecomm Corp., Gaithersburg, Md., an initial public offering of 2.5 million shares. Furman Selz Inc.    Adeza Biomedical Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif., an initial public offering of 2.5 million shares. Prudential Securities.    Ameriking Inc., Westchester, Ill., an initial public offering of 6.4 million shares, 5.1 million in the United States and Canada. Smith Barney.    Atria Communities Inc., Louisville, Ky., an initial public offering of 5 million shares. Alex. Brown & Sons.    CCC Information Services Group Inc., Chicago, an initial public offering of 5.5 million shares. Hambrecht & Quist.    Capstar Hotel Investors Inc., Washington, an initial public offering of 9.3 million shares, 7.4 million in the United States and Canada. Lehman Brothers.    Cascade Natural Gas Corp., Seattle, 1.3 million shares. Merrill Lynch.    CD Max Inc., Reston, Va., 900,000 units, each consisting of 2 shares of common and 1 redeemable warrant. Joe Stevens.    Children's Comprehensive Services Inc., Murfreesboro, Tenn., 2.5 million shares. Montgomery Securities.    Connect Inc., Mountain View, Calif., an initial public offering of 2.75 million shares. Lehman Brothers.    Consolidated Cigar Holdings Inc., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., an initial public offering of 4.5 million shares, 3.5 million in the United States and Canada. Goldman, Sachs.    Dal-Tile International Inc., Dallas, an initial public offering of 7 million shares, 5.6 million in the United States and Canada. Smith Barney.    Dailey Corp., Conroe, Tex., an initial public offering of 4 million class A shares. Jefferies & Co.    Dura Automotive Systems Inc., Minneapolis, an initial public offering of 2.7 million shares. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.    Dynamex Inc., Mississauga, Ontario, an initial public offering of 3.1 million shares. William Blair & Co.    E Trade Group Inc., Palto Alto, Calif., an initial public offering of 4.7 million shares. Robertson, Stephens & Co.    HCIA Inc., Baltimore, 2.2 million shares. Merrill Lynch.    Haynes International Inc., Kokomo, Ind., an initial public offering of 3.9 million of shares. Paine Webber.    Humascan Inc., Cranford, N.J., 2.5 million shares. Keane Securities Co.    Jet USA Airlines Inc., Foster City, Calif., an initial public offering of 2.3 million shares and 2.3 million warrants. Whale Securities Co.    MIM Corp., Pearl River, N.Y., an initial public offering of 4 million shares. Paine Webber.    Netsmart Technologies Inc., Islip, L.I., 562,500 units, each consisting of two shares of common and one redeemable warrant. Monroe Parker Securitites.    Outdoor Systems Inc., Phoenix, 7.7 million shares. Alex. Brown & Sons.    Paracelsus Healthcare Corp., Pasadena, Calif., an initial public offering of 7 million shares, 5.6 million shares in United States and Canada. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.    Redfed Bancorp Inc., Redlands, Calif., 2.6 million shares. Montgomery Securities.    Service Experts Inc., Nashville, an initial public offering of 2.3 million shares. Equitable Securities Corp.    Telident Inc., Minneapolis, 1 million shares. R. J. Steichen & Co.    Twinlab Corp., Ronkonkoma, L.I., an initial public offering of 8 million shares, 6.4 million in the United States and Canada. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.    U.S. Transportation Systems Inc., Elmsford, N.Y., an initial public offering of 2 million units, each consisting of 1 share of common and 1 class C redeemable warrant. 1st London Securities.    Willbros Group Inc., Panama, an initial public offering of 6 million shares. Dillon, Read & Co.    Xpedite Systems Inc., Eatontown, N.J., 1.5 million shares. Bear, Stearns & Co.    Source: MCM Corporatewatch.

headline: Sale of Rest of Compuserve Is Delayed by H & R Block
abstract: H & R Block Inc will delay spinoff of its remaining 80 percent stake in Compuserve Corp, citing Compuserve's recent quarterly losses and uncertainty in on-line market as reasons for decision (M)

headline: Chechen Rebel Leader Savors Triumph in a Shattered City
abstract: Interview with Shamil Basayev, Chechen rebel leader who says he is back for good in Grozny, capital of separatist Chechnya, where Russian troops remain under siege; maps; photo (M)

headline: Lockheed Martin Picks Unit of DDB Needham
abstract: Lockheed Martin Corp names DDB Needham New York unit of Omnicom Group to handle its advertising account, which had been divided among several agencies; billings are estimated at $18 million to $20 million (S)

headline: Indonesia's Political Quake: Sense of Stability Shaken
abstract: Bomb threats forced the evacuation of several office buildings in Jakarta today, but the real explosion had already occurred: a major riot over the weekend that has shaken confidence in Indonesia's tightly controlled political order.         With an aging leader determined to maintain his monopoly on power, a restive  opposition no longer content to endorse Government policies and now the explosive riot that underscored a rising discontent, Indonesia seems to be entering a time of uncertainty as the country prepares for parliamentary elections in 1998.

headline: MOBIL IS SELLING 13 OIL AND NATURAL GAS FIELDS
abstract: Mobil Corp says it will sell 13 oil and natural gas producing fields in Gulf of Mexico, off Louisiana's shore, to Flores & Rucks Inc for $139.3 million; fields produce equivalent of 10,000 barrels of day of oil (S)

headline: Yeltsin's Ailments May Complicate Surgery
abstract: Dr Sergei Mironov, head of Kremlin medical center, says Pres Boris N Yeltsin has serious noncardiac medical problems that may complicate his coming heart operation (M)

headline: Offerings Expected This Week For Equity and Convertible Debt
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:         Adeza Biomedical Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif., an initial public offering of 2.5  million shares. Prudential Securities.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;GARDNER DENVER MACHINERY TO ACQUIRE NORAMPTCO
abstract: Gardner Denver Machinery Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Noramptco  Inc., which makes centrifugal blowers and exhausters, for an undisclosed price.  Gardner Denver, based in Quincy, Ill., will buy all of the closely held Noramptco, which markets its products under the brand names Lamson and U.S. Turbine. Gardner Denver makes industrial and oil-drilling equipment. Its 1995 revenue was $192 million. Noramptco, based in Syracuse, had 1995 revenue of $41.3 million.

headline: Arrest Warrant Lifted For Thyssen Chairman
abstract: German authorities lift arrest warrant for Dieter Vogel, chmn of Thyssen AG (S)n

headline: In Egypt, On-Screen Sex Receives Mixed Reviews
abstract: In this summer's hit movie here, three working women from a poor Cairo neighborhood fret about their meager choice of marriageable louts.         Aside from routine problems like bagging a longtime fiance seemingly allergic to commitment or warding off the boss's gropings, much of the plot of the movie, "Oh Life, You Are My Love," revolves around a shop clerk insisting that any man she marries must love her despite her lost virginity. When suitor after  suitor flees, her friends convince her that some restorative surgery will fool all future mates.

headline: Boeing Branches Out
abstract: Boeing Co has agreed to buy aerospace and weapons businesses of Rockwell International; price to Boeing is a little more than $3 billion; photo (S)

headline: Italy's Plan to Sell Communications Giant
abstract: Italian Government to sell its remaining stake in Stet SpA, telecommunications firm, next Feb or Mar, after selling or spinning off telephone equipment and publishing units (S)

headline: Chrysler Reports Strong Vehicle Sales in June
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said today that sales rose 1 percent last month to 228,828 vehicles as customers continued to snap up options-laded mini-vans and cars.         That 1 percent gain seems paltry compared with Chrysler's double-digit sales  increases earlier this year. After all, in January, Chrysler sales rose 7 percent; in February, sales jumped 20 percent; in March, they rose 8 percent; in April, they shot up 33 percent, and in May, sales rose 17 percent for a record month.

headline: Trade Body Finds Japan Overtaxes Imported Liquor
abstract: The World Trade Organization said that Japanese taxes illegally penalize imported alcoholic drinks, including Scotch whisky and cognac, and ordered Japan to end the discrimination.         The ruling, only the second on an international trade dispute by the organization since it was formed in January 1995, marks a victory for liquor exporters in Europe, the United States and Canada.

headline: 3 More Prisoners Die in Turkish Hunger Strike
abstract: Three more prisoners died today in a nationwide hunger strike by nearly 2,000 inmates in Turkey's jails, bringing the death toll to six.         The inmates, who say they are protesting beatings, inadequate medical care and forced transfers to remote places, have seized control of three large prisons. More than 50 prisoners were in critical condition in some 33 jails around the nation.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Sale of Nicotine Patch Without Prescription
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration approved the first nicotine patch for sale without prescription today to help smokers give up their habit.         The decision means that McNeil Consumer Products, a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, would be able to beat its competitors to the pharmacy shelves with a one-dose nicotine patch, Nicotrol, that smokers are supposed to use for no longer than six weeks.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japanese Fund For Loan Losses
abstract: The Japan Securities Dealers Association said yesterday that the securities industry would contribute a total 21 billion yen ($23 million) to a fund of 1 trillion yen ($920 million), which will help cover losses resulting from the dissolution of seven debt-laden housing loan companies.          Japan's four major securities houses will each contribute 5 billion yen, while 11 second-tier houses, which provided capital to the Daichi Housing Finance Company and the Nippon Housing Loan Company, will contribute a total of 1 billion yen, said Kaname Seki, a deputy chairman of the association. Japan's Finance Ministry is reported to have asked Japan's 10 leading commercial banks to contribute a total of 506 billion yen.   (Dow Jones)

headline: Good Pay, Perks and Constant Calls From Headhunters
abstract: Young professionals in Poland face explosive job market hungry for their youth and skills; are able to bounce from job to job in search of promotion, wider experience, greater responsibilities and better wages, taking advantage of surge of foreign firms; table; photos (M)

headline: Equity Offerings Expected This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Cable-Sat Systems Inc., San Jose, Calif., an initial public offering of 1 million shares and 1 million warrants. Barron Chase.    Laminating Technologies Inc., Canton, Ga., an initial public offering of 1.5 million units, each representing 1 common share, 1 class A redeemable warrant and 1 class B redeemable warrant. D.H. Blair.    Progenitor Inc., Columbus, Ohio, an initial public offering of 2.5 million shares. Vector Securities.    Q.E.P. Co., Boca Raton, Fla., an initial public offering of 1.2 million shares. Cruttenden Roth Inc.    Xox Corp., St. Paul, an initial public offering of 850,000 units, each representing 1 common share and 1 redeemable warrant. Equity Securities Trading Co.    Source: MCM Corporatewatch.

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Decline On the Big Board and the Amex
abstract: Despite the stock market's recent gyrations, bearish investors have been trimming their bets a bit, based on the open positions of short sales reported yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange.

headline: UNITED IS EXPECTED TO ORDER BOEING PLANES
abstract: United Airlines is expected to announce multibillion-dollar order for Boeing planes; analysts estimate order could be worth more than $3 billion; order is expected to include Boeing 747 planes and several Boeing 777's (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;WHIRLPOOL PLANS TO CUT 550 TO 800 JOBS IN INDIANA
abstract: The Whirlpool Corporation said yesterday that it planned to simplify its top-mount refrigerator manufacturing operations in Evansville, Ind., in a move that would eliminate 550 to 800 jobs. Whirlpool, based in Benton Harbor, Mich.,  said the actions would focus more of the production at the Evansville plant on Whirlpool's recently redesigned midsize refrigerator line. It added that it was  considering elimination of several older refrigerator models that were less popular. Layoffs could begin as early as the first quarter of 1997.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: APPLE COMPUTER INC., Cupertino, Calif., named Dale Fuller vice president and general manager of its Powerbook laptop computer division.     CARTER-WALLACE INC., New York, the pharmaceuticals and toiletries maker, named Ralph Levine president and chief operating officer, effective April 1, 1997, succeeding Daniel J. Black, who will retire.     COMPUSERVE CORP., New York, named Jerry Roest its European general manager, a new position at the company.

headline: The Chechen Buck Stops Where? Not in Kremlin
abstract: Analysis holds that only real obstacle to ending war in breakaway Russian province of Chechnya is that Pres Boris Yeltsin has shown little apparent interest in supporting national security adviser Aleksandr I Lebed or his initiative there; says Yeltsin may fear that Lebed will become too popular to control in future or may be genuinely concerned that Russia will appear weak if he acknowledges defeat; photo (M)

headline: Olivetti Shares Rise After Chairman Resigns
abstract: Shares of Olivetti SpA climb as resignation of Carlo de Benedetti as chairman seems to raise investor hopes that company will emerge from five years of losses (S)

headline: Hurricane Kills 35 and Threatens Mexico
abstract: A hurricane that began in the Caribbean killed at least 35 people in its sweep across northern Colombia and Central America and emerged today in the Pacific.         Hurricane Cesar, renamed Hurricane Douglas because of the change in oceans, was about 330 miles west of Guatemala City today.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Military Business Lifts McDonnell's Profit
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday that profits from its military aircraft operations helped lift earnings 11 percent in the second quarter, despite a strike at the company's plant in St. Louis.         The company, which also makes other aerospace products, reported profits of $188 million, or 87 cents a share, up from $169 million, or 74 cents, in the 1995 quarter.

headline: Bavaria Tightens Abortion Curbs, Clashing With Bonn Law
abstract: Regional legislators in Bavaria, Germany's most Catholic state, approve maverick laws that tighten restrictions on abortion, reviving debate on issue that, unlike situation US, had been widely viewed as settled; new state law conflicts with federal legislation in two key areas; requires women to give reason for seeking to terminate pregnancy and sets limit of 25 percent on proportion of their income doctors may earn from abortions (M)

headline: PP&L Unit Acquires Stake in British Utility
abstract: The Southern Company's international arm said today that it had sold a 25 percent stake in South Western Electricity P.L.C. of Britain for $189 million to the Power Market Development Company, a subsidiary of PP&L Resources Inc.    PP&L, whose Pennsylvania Power and Light Company supplies power to residents  in eastern Pennsylvania, said in May that it was in talks to acquire a stake in  South Western, the British regional electricity company that the Southern Company bought in October for $1.8 billion.          Southern noted that several South Western assets had previously had been sold and were not included in this transaction.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AEROSPACE GIANT TO REPURCHASE $500 MILLION IN SHARES
abstract: The Rockwell International Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy  back an additional $500 million of its common stock. The company, based in Seal  Beach, Calif., had an average of 217.3 million shares outstanding as of March 31. Rockwell stock dropped 62.5 cents, to $53.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company, which makes aerospace and semiconductor products, said that it has spent about $2.6 billion in repurchasing shares in the last 12 years.

headline: Laura Ashley Profits Soared 73% in 6 Months
abstract: Laura Ashley PLC reports pretax profit rose 73 percent in six months ended July 27 to 5.2 million pounds ($8.1 million), up from 3 million pounds in 1995 period (S)

headline: Sentencing in Credit Suisse Embezzlement
abstract: Peter Nardin, former Credit Suisse executive in New York who was to have become head of company's North American operations, has been sentenced to one year and one day in prison for embezzling $331,000 from the bank; but Nardin will not have to pay criminal fine (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Reltec of U.S. to Buy Rainford of Britain
abstract: Reltec, an electronics company controlled by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, said yesterday that it would buy the Rainford Group, a British maker of cabinets for electronic equipment, for L80 million ($124 million). Reltec said Rainford had accepted an offer of 335 pence a share. The stock closed at 340, up 25 pence. For Reltec, with headquarters in Ohio, Illinois and Texas, the acquisition expands its $513 million telecommunications business to Britain and  elsewhere in Europe.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: GEORGIA-PACIFIC SELLING 2 GYPSUM WALLBOARD PLANTS
abstract: Georgia-Pacific Corp to sell two gypsum wallboard plants to Lafarge Corp; Justice Department ordered sale, citing antitrust concerns in firm's acquisition of Domtar Inc's wallboard business (S)

headline: Eurotunnel Says Loss Narrowed in First Half
abstract: Eurotunnel PLC says it has narrowed its loss for first half as its revenue doubled and traffic picked up; Eurotunnel lost 371.7 million pounds ($577.6 million) in first half of 1996 after losing 464.5 million pounds a year earlier (S) y

headline: Economists' anti-regulatory rationale is facing a change.
abstract: Peter Passell economic scene article discusses shift in rationale of mainstream economists for opposing regulation; cites view of Peter Pitsch that likely benefits in taming corporate power pale beside costs in delaying and distorting innovation; drawing (M)

headline: Fixed-Rate Mortgage Dips
abstract: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.19 percent this week, down from 8.23 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today. It was the lowest rate since June 3, when rates averaged 8.14 percent. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate  of 6.01 percent, up from 5.97 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 7.71 percent this week, down from 7.76 percent a week earlier.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japan's Top Bureaucrat for Banking Is Out
abstract: The Japanese Finance Ministry said today that the head of its banking bureau, who has drawn criticism on several fronts, would retire this year, while the director general of its international finance bureau, who has helped the dollar  rebound against the yen, would remain at his position.         The two officials were the focus of the ministry's annual shuffling of top bureaucrats. In Japan it is the professional bureaucrats, not the politically appointed Cabinet ministers, who make many important policy decisions.

headline: Profit Triples For Lukoil Holding
abstract: Lukoil Holding, Russia's biggest oil company, says its profit tripled in first half of year to $332 million as it raised production and export of oil products (S)

headline: Beyond Plastic Surgery
abstract: To the Editor:         As a dentist who has been performing increasing numbers of cosmetic procedures on men in recent years, I take exception to the suggestion that cosmetic procedures are "faux fixes." I submit that there is nothing "faux" about the emotional damage caused by low self-esteem.

headline: Birthplace of Solidarity Is in Bankruptcy
abstract: Court declares Gdansk shipyard bankrupt, months after the birthplace of Solidarity movement in Poland said it could no longer stay afloat in free-market economy (S)

headline: Palestinians Stage a Strike, And Israel Gets the Message
abstract: Shops and bus service are shut down in Gaza Strip, West Bank and East Jerusalem in response to Yasir Arafat's call for four-hour protest against hard-line policies of new Israeli Government; photo; map; envoy from Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu meets with Arafat, possibly in response, and official negotiating session with Palestinians is moved up; Arafat has also called for all Muslims to gather for prayers and marches at Al Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem; Israelis tighten security; photo; map (M)

headline: Bertelsmann Not Selling Pay-TV Channel Stake
abstract: Bertelsmann AG ends apparent truce in battle to dominate Germany's digital television market by saying that it is unwilling to trim its stake in Premiere, pay-TV channel that is also owned by its German rival, Kirch Group (S)

headline: Stocks Given Lift by Rise In Confidence
abstract: Stocks advanced for a second consecutive session yesterday as investors regained confidence that corporate earnings growth was not slowing.

headline: BTR of Britain Plans Sale of Power Unit
abstract: BTR PLC agrees to sell its electric power unit, Hawker Siddeley Electric Power, to FKI PLC for 182.5 million pounds, or $283.8 million, in cash; BTR also announces 14 percent decrease in pretax profit for first half of 1996, before exceptional items, to 626 million pounds, or $970 million (S)

headline: Ex-I.B.M. Workers' Suit Against I.R.S. Gains
abstract: Federal judge refuses to dismiss lawsuit against IRS brought by 737 former IBM employees who contend that part of their severance payments should not have been taxed; decision allows lawsuit to proceed; case reviewed (S)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;F.C.C. Rejects Canada-to-U.S. Satellite TV Plan
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission denied an application today by Tele-Communications Inc. and Telquest Ventures to use Canadian satellites to beam television programming to American viewers.

headline: Russian Vote Sets Off Battle, This Time in Yeltsin's Camp
abstract: Two days after President Boris N. Yeltsin scored a resounding re-election victory, his top aides are involved in a bruising and very public struggle for power.         Tension between the new security chief, Aleksandr I. Lebed, and the reappointed Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, has simmered for weeks as Mr. Lebed boldly outlined his outsized ambitions, including shaping economic policy and positioning himself as Mr. Yeltsin's successor.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DEMAND FOR SATURNS EXCEEDS PRODUCTION
abstract: Saturn could sell about 50,000 more cars a year if it could produce them, the president of the General Motors Corporation's small-car unit said yesterday. While Don Hudler said Saturn continued to make improvements to increase production at its Spring Hill, Tenn., plant, he gave no indication when or if G.M. would foot the bill to expand the plant or build another. An additional 50,000 cars sold would generate more than $600 million in annual revenue. Mr. Hudler also said Saturn was studying a possible expansion of its three-model lineup. His comments came as Saturn showed off its redesigned coupe, the 1997 SC1 and SC2, to Detroit's automotive press. The company sold 285,674 cars last year, about the same as 1994, which amounted to a 10 percent share of the combined small-car and sport coupe segments. The company said sales are up about 4 percent so far this year.

headline: Sears-Whirlpool Team
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it had decided keep the Whirlpool Corporation as the sole supplier of its Kenmore washing machines, ending the biggest phase of a review of Sears vendors. Sears, the nation's largest appliance retailer, said it had wrapped up six months of negotiations with manufacturers of its Kenmore appliance lines, including laundry products, refrigerators, stoves and dishwashers. As a result of the evaluation, the Maytag Corporation's Jenn-Air unit will begin making countertop stoves for Sears. But few other changes were made in its relationships with vendors. Whirlpool has been making washing machines for Sears for 80 years.

headline: Orthodox Jews Battle Police In Jerusalem
abstract: Violent protests broke out again here today as thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews tried to block a main street as part of an increasingly bitter dispute between religious and secular Israelis.         The demonstrations, which began overnight and resumed this evening, included  clashes with some of the 2,500 riot police officers who took up positions in one of Jerusalem's most Orthodox neighborhoods in an effort to quell rising tensions over the observance of the Jewish Sabbath.

headline: Chirac, Resolute on Austerity Plan, Marks Bastille Day With Cake
abstract: Marking his second Bastille Day today as President of France, Jacques Chirac  told his disgruntled compatriots that, in effect, they couldn't have their cake  and eat it, too -- that years of high deficit spending and mismanagement meant that they would have to sweat through high unemployment and high taxes to pay off accumulated deficits for at least another year before recovery set in.         But then, perhaps mindful of the fate of Marie Antoinette, he invited thousands of young people and assorted prominent guests onto the grounds of the  Elysee Palace to eat all the cake they wanted for most of a sun-splashed afternoon, the 207th anniversary of the start of the French Revolution.

headline: Avantel of Mexico Entering Long-Distance
abstract: Avantel SA to open new fiber-optic phone lines for public use as Mexico opens long-distance phone market to competition; Avantel is owned by MCI Communications and Grupo Financiero Banamex Accival (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Rise as Worries About Earnings Ease Disappointing earnings reports from technology companies have racked the stocks  of late, so the market was happily relieved by I.B.M.'s news that its profits declined less than had been expected. Indeed, the gain in I.B.M. shares accounted for more than half of the Dow industrials' advance of 67.32 points, to 5,422.01.

headline: U.S. SURGICAL'S OFFER FOR CIRCON BECOMES HOSTILE
abstract: US Surgical Corp's $235 million offer for Circon Corp turns hostile as company says it will proceed even after Circon rejects bid; US Surgical made $18-a-share offer for Circon on Aug 2; Circon calls offer inadequate and approves 'poison pill' anti-takeover plan (S)û

headline: Unemployment in Britain Dips to a 5-Year Low
abstract: British unemployment fell in July to five-year low; jobless total fell 24,100, to 2.13 million, taking unemployment rate to 7.6 percent from 7.7 percent in June (S)

headline: If Inflation Is Tamed, Does It Have to Be Killed?
abstract: Central bankers and economists from around world meet for two-day conference in Jackson Hole, Wyo, to exult about bringing inflation to heel and question goal of achieving true price stability; main debate is whether to press for literal price stability--zero inflation--or consistently low rate of inflation, between 1 percent and 3 percent; those arguing against zero inflation say it is too costly a goal, and that absolute price stability would make it more difficult to use monetary policy to stimulate economy; others argue in favor of pressing further toward zero inflation; Federal Reserve officials have so far tended to favor goal in range of 1 to 3 percent inflation (M)

headline: Campbell Soup to Offer Mail-Order Health Meals
abstract: Campbell Soup Co will begin selling frozen mail-order meals that are designed to combat high blood pressure, high cholesterol and diabetes; program, which will be test-marketed in Ohio starting in January, was secretly developed by the company over five years in consultation with American Heart Association and American Diabetes Association; it marks first time diabetes association has allowed its name to be used with such a product; Campbell will present its new product line not only to customers but also to primary-care physicians and cardiologists, saying that it is first meal program that is clinically proven to help 60 million Americans who have high blood pressure, high blood cholesterol and high blood sugar; new line of frozen meals will be known as Intelligent Quisine, and will be delivered to customers' homes by United Parcel Service of America Inc in containers designed to keep food frozen for 48 hours (L)

headline: G.I.'s in Saudi Arabia on Alert as Plan for Attack Is Reported
abstract: American troops in Saudi Arabia have been put on the highest possible state of alert because of "concrete reasons" to fear that terrorists may be planning other attacks on military installations there, the Defense Department said today.         Pentagon officials also confirmed that they are planning to move some of the  nearly 5,000 American troops in Saudi Arabia out of urban areas to more secure locations. Nineteen American airmen were killed last month in a bomb blast outside an apartment complex near the eastern Saudi city of Dhahran.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Car Bomb in Corsica Kills Nationalist Leader
abstract: A car bomb exploded today on Corsica, a French island in the Mediterranean, killing a Corsican nationalist leader and injuring 16 other people.          The bomb went off as two nationalist party leaders pulled up in front of the security guard company that they managed, the police said. It killed Pierre Lorenzi, executive member of the Cuncolta Naziunalista Party, and partly blinded a colleague, the police and hospital workers said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow at a Record 5,838.52; Bonds and the Dollar Rally  The stock market surged to a record, keeping alive one of history's greatest bull markets and erasing a midsummer downturn that had many analysts predicting the end of good times on Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 1.2 percent, or 68.58, to 5,838.52, eclipsing its May 22 record of 5,778.    The bond market also rallied, as long-term interest rates fell below 7 percent, to 6.95. Behind the surge was economic news showing inflation in check, lessening fears that the Fed will push up interest rates. $(Page 1.$)    The dollar rose against the mark and yen, reaching two-month highs. It followed stocks and bonds upward, despite the weaker-than-expected economic data. Foreigners bought dollars in order to buy American securities. In New York the dollar edged up to 1.5134 marks. $(34.$)    Oil Futures Prices Tumble   Crude oil futures plunged with the contract for October delivery down 49 cents, to $24.51 a barrel, after tensions with Iraq eased. $(34.$)    F.A.A. Faulted on Airport Security   A newly issued Government report says that in inspecting airport security, F.A.A. agents sometimes overstated how well airports performed and made efforts to help airlines do well on the inspections. $(1.$)    In the Tobacco Economy: Alarm   Tobacco is the main cash crop in Kentucky and much of the South, and now a whiff of national politics has tobacco farmers in full alarm. Many local Democratic politicians find themselves opposing President Clinton. $(1.$)    Compuserve Backpedals on Profit   Compuserve retracted a prediction of profits made by one of its executives. Steven Stanbrook, Compuserve's president of international operations, had said in Munich that based on the strength of European operations, ''for the year as a whole we will be making a strong profit.'' $(32.$)    Japanese Economy Shrinks 0.7%   Japan's economy contracted seven-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter. It was the first time economic output had declined since 1994's final quarter, but the Government said the nation's recovery was continuing. $(32.$)    A Mistrial in California Bankruptcy   A mistrial was declared in the first criminal trial related to the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., that of the former budget director, Ronald S. Rubino. $(44.$)    Brazilian Air Travelers Restive   As Brazil moves slowly toward privatization of state-run industries and dismantling of regulation, a travelers' campaign opposing the high cost of domestic air fares appears to have struck a chord at an opportune moment. $(32.$)    Nestle Profits Advance 20%   Nestle, the world's largest food and beverage company, said its net profit rose 20 percent, to 1.35 billion Swiss francs ($1.1 billion) in the first half of 1996, but its stock price fell 10 Swiss francs to 1,413, as investors focused on stagnant trading results. Heineken, the Dutch brewer, reported a 6.1 percent profit rise. $(32.$)    The Hottest Shop in Moscow   Moscow's hottest store is suitably named Arrears. Bargain hunters rush to buy the latest booty seized by the Moscow tax police -- boxes of down coats going for the equivalent of $17, and even a 10-year-old Hungarian-made bus for $19,000. $(4.$)    Mexican Publisher Arrested   The owner of one of Mexico's biggest newspapers, El Universal, was arrested on charges of criminal tax fraud and evasion. Juan Francisco Ealy Ortiz, the owner and publisher, contended the Government was cracking down on dissent in the press. $(5.$)

headline: Bonds Drop As Fed Rate Rise Is Feared
abstract: Bond prices drop on report of pressure on Federal Reserve to raise interest rates; 30-year Treasury bond drops point, to 96 20/32, to yield 7.02 percent; graph (M)

headline: Congressman Sees Hunger On Rare Tour In North Korea
abstract: Rep Tony P Hall, ending four-day visit to North Korea, says nation is in desperate need of food and has asked United States for more aid; cites widespread hunger; says he will urge Clinton Administration and South Korea to send more aid (M)

headline: Sales of Cars and Light Trucks Slow from Torrid Pace
