abstract: Commerce Department reports sales of cars and light trucks slowed to seasonally adjusted annual rate of 14.3 million vehicles in July, down from 15.1 million in June; Ford Motor Co reports flat July sales, with car sales up 0.3 percent and sales of sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks down 0.4 percent; Chrysler Corp sets rebates for some 1997 models; graph; tables (M)

headline: FRITO-LAY SAYS THAT U.S. SEEKS DOCUMENTS IN INQUIRY
abstract: Justice Department asks Frito-Lay Inc to provide documents as part of its investigation of possible anticompetitive practices in $15 billion salty-snacks industry (S)

headline: Armenia Leader's Edge in Vote Is Cut; Crowds Call for Resignation
abstract: Pres Levon Ter-Petrossian's lead shrinks as more votes are counted in presidential election, and supporters of his opponent, former Prime Min Vazgen Manukian, demonstrate at presidential palace to demand that he resign (M)

headline: Hong Kong, Takeover Near, In Wary Dance With Destiny
abstract: Tucked among the coffin makers just off Wing Lok Street, on the edge of a hankie-sized park where old men play Chinese chess, a fading photograph shows a  waterfront site, Possession Point -- the spot where the British flag was first planted, by Capt. Edward Belcher at 8:15 A.M. on Jan. 26, 1841.         Today Possession Point -- now Hollywood Road Park -- is well inland from Hong Kong's shrinking harbor. The coffin makers lounge on low stools, smoke from their loosely fingered cigarettes drifting in the pudding-thick humidity, as they wait for their next customers and watch the last faint moments of British rule unwind.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AES PLANS TO ACQUIRE THREE POWER PLANTS IN HUNGARY
abstract: The AES Corporation, a power company based in Arlington, Va., said yesterday  that it would acquire three power plants and a coal mine, giving it an 81 percent share of Tiszai Eromu Rt., a Hungarian electricity generation company. AES said it would pay up to $143 million for the stake. If offered, AES would acquire an additional 15 percent on similar terms. The plants represent about 20 percent of the electric generating capacity in Hungary. The sale would be the first investment by a United States company in the Hungarian energy sector.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.19   5.24   5.93        3-MO. headline: Is This Fingerprint Company In for a Dusting?
abstract: Profile of Identix, Sunnyvale, Calif, company formed in 1982 to design, develop and market personal-identification systems that optically scan and analyze fingerprints; photo; chart (M)

headline: To Expand West Bank Settlements, Israelis Plan 4,000 Homes
abstract: Israeli authorities approve plans to build nearly 4,000 homes in Jewish settlements in West Bank, putting into practice Government decision to end restrictions on expanding settlements there and in Gaza Strip; Palestinians claim land allotted for new buildings was confiscated from neighboring Arab villages, but settlers assert it was bought by Jews (M)

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasuries Drop After Jobs Report
abstract: Treasury prices plunged in thin trading yesterday, after an employment report showed surprising strength, immediately raising concern that the Federal Reserve might have to raise interest rates sooner than expected.         Just two days ago, after Fed policy makers met and left rates unchanged, the  bond market was confident that it had avoided a rate increase until the next

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: * Mary Ann Packo was named president of PC Meter L.P., Port Washington, L.I., a  World Wide Web tracking service owned by NPD Group Inc. She assumes responsibilities from Steve Coffey, vice president and general manager, who was  promoted to vice chairman and chief technology officer. Ms. Packo had been executive director of Ipsos-NFO Europe, Paris, a unit of NFO Research. * Sarah Hatch, senior vice president and strategic planning director at Bates USA, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., was promoted to executive vice president and head of strategic planning. * James Meyer rejoined the New York office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, a unit of the MacManus Group, as senior vice president and executive account director in a realignment of account duties. Mr. Meyer, who will handle the Procter & Gamble health care and CPC Internationalcoei Best Foods Bakery accounts, had been senior vice president and management director on the Kellogg  Company account at the J. Walter Thompson New York unit of the WPP Group.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Springer Posts a Gain For Year's First Half
abstract: The German publishing company Axel Springer Verlag A.G. said yesterday that its profit rose 12 percent in the six months that ended on June 30, to 80.5 million marks ($54.2 million), from 72 million marks the previous year. Revenue  for the period was not reported. Springer said the rise in profit came despite a 26 percent increase in paper costs during the period and worsening advertising trends.          Axel Springer Verlag's principal operations are in newspapers, including the country's top-circulation tabloid, Bild, and the daily newspaper Die Welt. Springer also has substantial magazine and television operations.   (Dow Jones)

headline: Takeover Fight for Mobile Home Operator Intensifies
abstract: Chateau Properties Inc, object of intense takeover fight, rejects two unsolicited bids and says it has filed lawsuit seeking to block hostile bid from Manufactured Home Communities Inc, which offered to buy Chateau's stock for $26 a share in cash; Chateau also alters merger agreement it already has with ROC Communities, angering investors in Chateau; most analysts say merger agreement with ROC offers Chateau's shareholders less immediate value than Manufactured Home's offer; some analysts suggest that Manufactured Home's richer offer might lead some Chateau shareholders to sell it their shares (M)

headline: Fed Proposal Would Ease Some Regulations for Banks
abstract: Federal Reserve proposes new rules that would make it much easier for banks to make acquisition and enter new lines of business, but could make it much harder for community groups to press banks to increase doing business in low-income areas (M)

headline: Assad Doesn't See 'the Slightest Hope' of Peace in Israeli Offer
abstract: Syrian Pres Hafez al-Assad dismisses Israel's proposal for resumption of peace talks between both countries; move seems to douse glimmer of optimism raised by Israeli proposal, which was to tackle differences between Israel and Syria by resolving differences over Lebanon first; Assad has insisted that Israel first make plain its willingness to trade land for peace with Syria, step conservative new Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu has steadfastly refused to take (M)

headline: Motorola Introducing PC's With Apple System
abstract: Motorola to introduce line of personal computers equipped with Apple Computer Inc's Macintosh operating system, as companies bid to expand market for such machines at time when it is threatened by IBM-compatible computers running Microsoft Windows software; new line, called Starmax, will be priced from $1,600 to $4,000 and aimed at business customers (M)

headline: Potlatch to Close a Mill to Make Repairs
abstract: The Potlatch Corporation said today that it planned to close its pulp and paperboard mill in Lewiston, Idaho, during the fourth quarter for repairs.         A Potlatch spokeswoman, Diane Olberg, said the company did not know yet what  the cost of the closing would be.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;COMPUNET COMPUTER OF GERMANY AGREES TO BE SOLD
abstract: GE Capital Services, part of the General Electric Company, signed an agreement yesterday to buy Compunet Computer A.G., a German provider of computer services. G.E. did not disclose the price. Compunet, which employs 1,850 people, had sales of $1 billion in 1995. The company, which is closely held, specializes in helping large corporations make their computer systems work together. It is based in Kerpen, Germany, near the Belgian border.

headline: Daewoo Expects to Buy Thomson Multimedia
abstract: Daewoo Electronics Corp, South Korea's third-largest electronics maker, says it will probably buy Thomson Multimedia, consumer electronics arm of state-owned French company Thomson SA by end of the year (S)

headline: Treasury Planning to Offer Bills and Notes
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to bills and notes, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    Tomorrow, the Treasury will hold an auction of its two-year note, followed by Wednesday's auction of a five-year note.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.03 percent and a six-month bill was 5.13 percent.    In when-issued trading, the two-year note was being offered at a rate to yield 6.10 percent and a five-year note at a rate to yield 6.48 percent.    The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:     TAX EXEMPT     ONE DAY DURING THE WEEK     Dade County, Fla., $187.625 million of debt securities. Grigsby Brandford & Co.     Dormitory Authority of the State of New York, $377 million of debt securities. Smith Barney Inc.    Harrisburg, Pa., $81 million of debt securities. PNC Securities Corp.    Matagorda County Navigation District No. 1, Texas, $60 million of debt securities. Goldman, Sachs & Co.    Montana Board of Housing, $65 million of single-family mortgage revenue bonds. Paine Webber Inc.    Multnomah County School District No. 1, Ore., $96.7 million of debt securities. Seattle-Northwest Securities Corp.    New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency, $55 million of debt securities. Goldman, Sachs & Co.

headline: Real Estate Venture By 2 Swiss Companies
abstract: Union Bank of Switzerland and Swiss Life, its insurance joint venture partner, to merge their real estate management units to cut costs (S)

headline: G.E. AND SHAMROCK IN LATIN MEDIA DEAL
abstract: Pension fund of the General Electric Co and Shamrock Group, an investment firm, buy $30 million of $50 million equity offering by Latin Communications Group, owner of the Spanish-language El Diaro-La Prensa newspaper, New York (S)

headline: The Applause-O-Meter Still Thrives in Politics
abstract: Dial groups, focus groups of voters whose second-by-second reactions to convention speeches are tracked electronically using dial system, have become staple of Presidential campaigns; reactions of members of group convened by ABC News to Republican National Convention cited; photos (M)

headline: Sears to Pay $308 Million For Hardware Store Chain
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co agrees to buy Orchard Supply Hardware Stores Corp for $308 million; Orchard has 61 hardware stores in California; Sears has 115 hardware stores, none in California; under terms of offer approved by Orchard's board, Sears will pay $35 a share for all of Orchard's 8.8 million shares,; Sears will also assume about $107 million of Orchard's debt; Freeman Spogli & Co, leveraged buyout firm, has agreed to tender its 1.6 million Orchard shares; Sears currently has no plans to change name of Orchard Supply; Orchard reports its earnings for second quarter grew by 5 percent, to $5.9 million, while sales rose 11.3 percent, to $161.9 million (M)

headline: WARNACO TO SELL HATHAWAY UNIT TO CFH ACQUISITION
abstract: Warnaco Group Inc says it will sell its Hathaway men's shirt business to investor group organized by former Maine Gov John McKernan Jr, saving 675 jobs at Hathaway factories that company had intended to close; terms of cash deal not disclosed (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the so-called third market in stocks, where shares can be traded after big exchanges are closed, misidentified an employee of Jefferies & Company, the largest firm in that market. He is James McKenzie, an account executive, not Glen McIlvaine, the head of the equity desk.

headline: Bosnia's Vote: Anarchic Democracy
abstract: Prospects for smooth election in Bosnia do not look good; United Nations police monitors have spent most of last week planning how to move refugees to voting places; of Bosnia's nearly three million potential voters, as many as 150,000 are expected to cross former battle lines to vote in areas from which they were expelled during war; as many as 138,000 more refugees could be coming in from Serbia and Croatia; map (M)

headline: You Saved, but They Didn't. So Now What?
abstract: HERE'S the nightmare. You've socked away every stray penny in retirement accounts, resisting the temptation to live it up, in order to accumulate a comfy nest egg. Now it's payoff time: Hawaii beckons. But all the aging spendthrifts -- the folks who bought fishing boats instead of mutual funds -- persuade Congress to tax your savings and slash your Social Security checks in order to spread the wealth.         A far-fetched prospect in the home of the free and the land of the 401(k)? Don't be so sure. For while the baby boom generation's slowly building retirement crisis could be resolved in a variety of ways, punishing the thrifty  will always be a tempting option in a world of too many old people chasing too few condos in the sun.

headline: Dow Gains 52.90 as Fears Over Rate Rise Are Eased
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 52.90 points, to 5,659.86, with S&P 500-stock index keeping pace, up 6.24 points at 655.68; table (M)

headline: Ping-Pong Rain and Other Gimmicks
abstract: Comment on some gimmicks New York City real-estate brokers employ in their efforts to get more listings of properties for sale (M)

headline: Fed Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged
abstract: Federal Reserve Open Market Committee, in widely-expected move, leaves Federal funds rate, key short-term interest rate, unchanged at 5.25 percent; analysts comment; graph (M)

headline: In Tijuana, Border Crackdown Hurts
abstract: Business is lagging in Tijuana, Mex, which for years has been staging area for Mexicans seeking to cross US border illegally; situation is consequence of 22-month Border Patrol operation near San Diego in which hundreds of agents, ground sensors and night-vision equipment have been deployed to turn back thousands massed each night along most porous stretch of frontier; map (M)

headline: Limits Seen On Questions In Archer Case
abstract: Critics of a proposed $45 million settlement of a class action lawsuit against the Archer Daniels Midland Company and two other makers of animal feed additive may not be able to question a senior A.D.M. executive they contend was  involved in price fixing.         Federal District Judge Milton I. Shadur said that Terrance Wilson, head of the company's corn processing division, would be excused from Friday's hearing on the fairness of the settlement if Mr. Wilson indicated, through his lawyer, that he planned to invoke the Fifth Amendment's protection against being required to incriminate himself. Although the Government has been investigating  allegations of price fixing in three A.D.M. businesses since 1992, no criminal charges have been filed against the company or any person.

headline: INVESTING IT;Marvel Superheroes Take Aim at Hollywood
abstract: ON the comic book pages, there isn't much that Spiderman can't accomplish. But the superhero can't seem to solve the most pressing problem of the company that employs him, Marvel Entertainment Group.         For more than 15 years, Marvel has been waiting for Hollywood to make a Spiderman movie. It first sold an option to make a film in the late 1970's. In April, the final option expired and the movie rights to the character reverted to Marvel.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SANYO ELECTRIC CO., Osaka, Japan, said a subsidiary, Three Oceans Inc., would invest $5 million in St. Andrews Golf Corp. of Las Vegas, Nev., a subsidiary of Las Vegas Discount Golf and Tennis Inc., to help finance the construction of an entertainment park.    BROWN & WILLIAMSON TOBACCO CORP., Louisville, Ky., a subsidiary of B.A.T. Industries, said it would offer to sell the operations of its Golden Belt Manufacturing Co. unit, a cigarette materials business, separately after failing to find a buyer for the unit as a whole.    MIKASA INC., Long Beach, Calif., a utensils maker, said it would repurchase $20 million in stock for between $9.375 and $11.25 a share. The company said it would also buy back from its former chairman, Alfred J. Blake, 2.2 million shares at $8.95 each, or about $20 million.

headline: Apple Names Technology Chief and Puzzles Many
abstract: Five months after beginning his overhaul of Apple Computer Inc., Gilbert F. Amelio put in place today the final -- and, perhaps, most crucial -- piece of the new management team that hopes to return Apple to its former position as the computer industry's top technological innovator.         But in naming Apple's new chief technology officer today, Mr. Amelio left much of the industry puzzled by his choice.

headline: New Jobs for Two Agency Executives
abstract: Young & Rubicam Inc names Philippe Krakowsky to head its corporate communication department; Richard McGowan will take new position of communications director for Dentsu Y&R Partnerships in Sydney, Australia (S)

headline: World News Briefs;Protesters Fight Police in Hong Kong
abstract: Demonstrators fought with the police in Hong Kong today during efforts to clear Rennie's Mill, a shantytown that has long been the home of Nationalists who fled China.         About 100 demonstrators, demanding better compensation when their homes are demolished to make way for a housing development, blocked a road to the township as more than 100 police in full riot gear attempted to force them out. Two people were injured in the scuffle.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AETNA TO CUT 1,700 JOBS BY END OF SEPTEMBER '97
abstract: Aetna Inc. said yesterday that it planned to cut 1,700 jobs by the end of September 1997 as it stops administering Medicare fee-for-service programs. Last week, Aetna announced that it would not renew contracts with the Federal Health  Care Financing Administration, whose programs pay for services as they are rendered and allow participants to choose their own doctors. Instead, Aetna said it would focus on the growing managed-care Medicare business, in which participants are enrolled in health maintenance organizations. Employees who lose jobs could be placed with the companies receiving the new Medicare contracts, Aetna said. Aetna, based in Hartford, has 30,000 employees.

headline: GENERAL MOTORS DECISION ON PLANT TO BOLSTER EARNINGS
abstract: General Motors Corp's third-quarter earnings to increase by $250 million because of company's decision to keep open an assembly plant in Wilmington, Del, that it planned to close, and build new midsize Saturn car there beginning about 1999 (S)

headline: 3 Leaders of New Bosnia: Pulling in 3 Directions
abstract: Profiles of Bosnian Pres Alija Izetbegovic, ethnic Croat leader Kresimir Zubak and Bosnian Serb separatist Momcilo Krajisnik, apparent winners in Bosnia's three-member presidential election; photos (M)

headline: BASF and Daimler Cut Workers' Sick Pay
abstract: BASF AG joins Daimler-Benz AG in cutting sick pay for 264,000 German employees; unions threaten strikes and court action to fight reductions, which top list of deregulatory measures that industry and government say are needed to increase Germany's appeal to business (S)

headline: Chechnya Toll Is Far Higher, 80,000 Dead, Lebed Asserts
abstract: Russian national security adviser Aleksandr I Lebed, in grimmest assessment to date of death toll in war in breakaway province of Chechnya, says at least 80,000 people have been killed and some 240,000 wounded; estimates far exceed many casualty projections, that 30,000 to 40,000 people died in 21 months of conflict; photo (S)

headline: Likud Hard-Liner, in a First, Sees Arafat
abstract: Israel's new Foreign Minister, David Levy, held talks for the first time today with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, in a sign that a partnership fractured by the elections in May may be on its way to a slow mend.         The meeting resolved none of the differences that have kept the two sides apart since Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his conservative Government took power. But the fact that it occurred at all marked the crossing of a major  threshold, and both Mr. Levy and Mr. Arafat emerged with smiles and pledges of further cooperation.

headline: EXISTING LEADERS OF ETHNIC GROUPS WIN BOSNIAN VOTE
abstract: Existing leaders of three major ethnic groups are victors in Bosnian elections, leaving former enemies task of cooperating in three-member presidency to govern and restructure nation; incomplete results suggest winner with most votes is Bosnian Muslim Pres Alija Izetbegovic, who by virtue of his plurality will be chairman of presidency for its two-year term; Bosnian Serb separatist Momcilo Krajisnik, will be ethnic Serb representative, and ethnic Croat Kresimir Zubak will fill Croatian seat (M)

headline: Record labels are forcing their music on the film industry.
abstract: Media column notes that record companies are pushing their up-and-coming bands onto movie soundtracks in collusion with studios that are eager for boost from advance promotions; several recent movies featuring Stabbing Westward, Columbia Records' new industrial-rock band, noted (S)

headline: EARNING IT;For Employee-Owners of Avis, a Bittersweet Deal
abstract: IT may be No. 2 in the rental-car business, but Avis Inc. is regarded by many as the No. 1 employee-owned company. When United Airlines was sold to its employees two years ago, for example, Avis was held up as a model for getting workers to participate in the company.         Now, almost nine years after beginning their experiment, Avis's employee-owners are being asked to cash in, in the largest buyout ever of an employee-owned concern. At first glance, the payoff looks sexy. The $35 a share  in cash and stock offered by HFS Inc., the nation's biggest hotel franchiser, is nearly triple the $12.51 at which Avis's shares were valued at the beginning of  the year and nearly 60 percent more than their value in their best year, 1990.

headline: Treasury to Auction Bills This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.         By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.14 percent and a six-month bill was 5.28  percent.

headline: Antitrust Case To End for I.B.M.
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Justice Department have reached an agreement to phase out the remaining terms of a 1956 antitrust decree, the Government said today.

headline: Economic Calender
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Existing-Home Sales July    TUESDAY  Consumer Confidence Aug.    WEDNESDAY  None    THURSDAY  G.D.P. 2d Qtr.  New-Home Sales July  Prices of New Homes July  Weekly Jobless Claims    FRIDAY  Personal Income July  Factory Orders July

headline: For Many Russians, Daily Struggle Eclipses Yeltsin Issue
abstract: Ordinary Russians say daily struggle to buy food, clothing and other necessities eclipses their interest in Pres Yeltsin's health; public long accustomed to doddering Soviet leaders finds subject more amusing than troubling, even though Yeltsin represents stability (S)

headline: Voice-Recognition Software Being Introduced by I.B.M.
abstract: International Business Machines will announce new software that enables radiologists to dictate their reports directly into personal computer; new offering is latest step in long-sought goal of being able to speak directly to computer rather than type on keyboard; technology is still not at point where it can render any sentence on any subject, but it can be useful in specific disciplines like radiology, where many of same technical phrases are often repeated (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: MONDAY National City

headline: Q&A / Inder Kumar Gujral : Why India Blocks Test Ban Treaty
abstract: India has been widely criticized for blocking a nuclear test ban treaty that has taken more than two years to negotiate. On a visit to Singapore, Inder Kumar Gujral, the Indian foreign minister, discussed the issue with Michael Richardsonof the International Herald Tribune.

headline: Broader Warrants Issued for 2 Bosnian Serbs
abstract: The United Nations war crimes tribunal issued international arrest warrants today for the Bosnian Serbs' political leader, Radovan Karadzic, and their military chief, Gen. Ratko Mladic, who are charged with genocide and other crimes in the four-year Bosnian war.         The warrants oblige members of the United Nations to arrest the men if they enter their countries. But the warrants are unlikely to have any immediate effect because Western countries have not been willing to have their peacekeeping troops in Bosnia seek the two leaders out.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Plans for Chip Plant In Britain by Hyundai
abstract: The Hyundai Electronics Industries Company of South Korea said yesterday that it had decided to build a European chip plant in Britain, perhaps in Dunfermline, Scotland, where its executives have visited.The $1.3 billion plant  would make memory chips. But Hyundai has not made a final decision to go ahead with the plant.          The plant would be the second of two billion-dollar plants South Korean companies are looking to build in Britain to dodge protectionist trade barriers and lock in lower wages than they would pay at home. Last week LG Group, another big South Korean electronics maker, said it would build a $2.6 billion semiconductor and TV parts plant in Wales.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: PRO-HUSSEIN KURDS TAKE ANOTHER CITY IN NORTHERN IRAQ
abstract: Kurdish faction backed by forces loyal to Pres Saddam Hussein mount eastward offensive, overrunning city of Koi Sanjaq; thousands of Kurdish civilians and hundreds of armed guerrillas flee; officials of rival Kurdish faction, Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, which had controlled city, say forces abandoned city in face of overwhelming attack by forces of Kurdistan Democratic Party; mood of despair hangs over Sulaimaniya, Patriotic Union's last major stronghold; its leaders accuse rivals of having once again employed Iraqi armor and artillerey; fear attack may be imminent; photos; map (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article last Sunday about the regulation of home-based businesses by local governments misstated the affiliation of Ron Wohl, who discussed zoning laws that affect such businesses. He is a director of the American Association of Home-Based Businesses, not the American Home-Based Business Association.

headline: World News Briefs;14 Hurt in Knife Attack At Train Station in Japan
abstract: A man who said he had received a divine message stabbed and slashed at least  14 people today at a crowded train station in southern Japan. The police said at least two people were in critical condition.         The 21-year-old man, whose name was not disclosed, was arrested at Kokura station on the southernmost main island of Kyushu on charges of attempted murder. Among the injured was his father, the police said.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Carr-Gottstein Foods Co appoints Lawrence Haywood president and chief executive, succeeding Mark R Williams, who becomes vice chairman; Pepsico Inc names Peter M Thompson to newly created position of president and chief operating officer for international operations at its Pepsi-Cola Inc unit; Tenneco promotes Thomas C Hayes, executive director for corporation communications, to special assistant to chairman and chief executive, Dana G Mead; Turner Corp, the construction company, says Alfred T McNeill has resigned as chairman and chief executive (S)

headline: Executive Steps Up Tobacco Ad Attack
abstract: David Milenthal, chairman and chief executive at HMS Partners in Columbus, Ohio, asks American Assn of Advertising Agencies to form task force to help curb sale of tobacco products to minors; Milenthal feels advertising agencies' efforts to sell tobacco products are harming image of Madison Avenue among consumers (S)

headline: Hard Times for Minority Municipal Bond Firms
abstract: Nation's minority-owned municipal bond houses are experiencing difficult financial times; aided by Government set-aside programs, these minority firms prospered in early 1990's in one of few areas on Wall Street that was relatively open to blacks; yet as municipal bond business has shrunk over all and affirmative action comes under attack, minority firms are finding that profits are scarce, deals are drying up and many are barely holding on; situation at Pryor, McClendon, Counts & Co, MR Beal & Co and WR Lazard, Laidlaw & Luther discussed; graph (L)

headline: Malaysia Company Buys Phone Operations
abstract: Time Engineering said it would buy majority stakes in Sapura Telecommunications's pay phone and cellular phone businesses for the equivalent  of $482 million.         The companies said Time Engineering would pay for the deals by giving Sapura's parent, Sapura Holdings, 185 million new shares of its stock, for a 27  percent stake. Time is to repurchase some new shares over an undisclosed period, leaving Sapura with a stake of about 13 percent.

headline: Powerful but Ill-Defined : Rising India Middle Class
abstract: NEW DELHI—  More than fiveyears ago, when India was shaken by a foreign resources crunch, it shrugged off its socialist image, liberalized its economic policies and opened its arms to foreign capital.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Anheuser-Busch Apologizes for Ad
abstract: Anheuser-Busch Inc. apologized yesterday "to anyone who was offended" by a TV commercial that included brief film clips from the 1936 Summer Games in Berlin.          The Washington Post reported yesterday that the Holocaust Memorial Museum in  Washington had complained that those clips came from a documentary filmed for Nazi officials.

headline: Booming City, Flush With Rats and Dying Children
abstract: Kinshasa Journal: Booming City, Flush With Rats and Dying Children**Peasants from all over Zaire make their way to Kinshasa in search of better life; few find one; urban development experts say Kinshasa is city with exploding population, many slums and virtually no planning or management; map; photo (M)

headline: Market Place;A brokerage firm under scrutiny is going public.
abstract: PEDDLING penny stocks can be very profitable in a bull market.         GKN Securities, a relatively small brokerage firm that specializes in underwriting blind pools and also brings small companies to market, plans to sell its own stock to the public this week, and it has disclosed its financial statements.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;GERMAN AMERICAN BANCORP TO BUY PEOPLES OF OHIO
abstract: German American Bancorp said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Peoples  Bancorp and its National Bank and Trust Company in a stock swap worth about $21.1 million. Shareholders of Peoples Bancorp are expected to receive common stock of German American valued at about $35.56 a share. There are 593,334 shares outstanding of Peoples Bancorp. Shares of Peoples slipped 87.5 cents, to  $23.125, in Nasdaq trading. German American, based in Jasper, Ind., said it could issue as many as 659,375 shares to shareholders of Peoples Bancorp, depending on the price of German American shares during a period preceding the acquisition. Peoples, based in Marietta, Ohio, is the holding company for various banks in Ohio.

headline: It's a Clashing of the Guard (Old vs. New) at American Stores
abstract: Outlook for American Stores Co discussed in light of pressure being put on firm by former chairman Lennie Sam Skaggs, major stockholder; company reports 14 percent rise in per share earnings for second quarter ended Aug 3; chairman Victor L Lund, credited with company turnaround, says firm and its pieces are not for sale, interview; table (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates

headline: Sanyo Executive Is Freed For a Ransom in Mexico
abstract: Mamoru Konno, executive of Sanyo Video Components who was kidnapped for ransom in Tijuana, Mex, is released by captors after ransom is paid; kidnappers had demanded $2 million (S)

headline: White House Acts to Deflect Criticism of Its Iraq Policy
abstract: Pres Clinton defends his actions against Iraq and vows to keep pressure on Pres Saddam Hussein; moves on several fronts to quell grumbling by Republicans in Congress that US has not done enough, and to rally support among allies concerned that it had done too much; orders more than 3,000 additional troops to Kuwait; sends second formal message to Iraq outlining steps Hussein must take to avoid further military retaliation (M)

headline: SHARES OF FOXMEYER HEALTH TUMBLE BY 14%
abstract: Shares of Foxmeyer Health Corp fall 14 percent after company says it is in talks to sell its primary drug-distribution business to stem huge losses; shares fall $1.125, to $6.875 (S)

headline: Turner Losing Key Executive In Merger Deal
abstract: Scott Sassa, executive who led Turner Broadcasting System's aggressive expansion in entertainment industry, has reportedly decided to resign when expected merger with Time Warner Inc is completed next month; Sassa said to be dissatisfied with positions available to him in merged company, and with fact that he would no longer be reporting directly to Ted Turner (M)

headline: Cotton Prices Surge on Concerns About Rainfall From Hurricane
abstract: Futures Markets column; cotton prices surge on New York Cotton Exchange over concern that Hurricane Dolly may bring unwanted rain to southern Texas and Arizona, possibly hurting crops (M)

headline: Promises, Promises From Olin, But Its Stock May Deliver Yet
abstract: Olin Corp stock is starting to impress Wall Street analysts, especially since Donald W Griffin became chief executive and the company adopted the principles of 'economic value added'; the basic idea of EVA is that a business is not adding value by engaging in an activity unless the return on total investment from that activity exceeds the cost of capital; photo; graphs (M)

headline: U.N. Halts Deal for Iraq Oil Sales As U.S. Pledges Action on Attack
abstract: UN suspends plan to allow Iraq to sell oil to buy food and medicine as US vows to punish Saddam Hussein for military thrust against Kurds in north; US aircraft carrier and warships move northward in Persian Gulf; White House declines to specify what action will be taken; Iraq apparently expands attack, shelling at least one city, despite initial promise to withdraw from Erbil; reportedly allies with Kurdistan Democratic Party against rival Patriotic Union; photos; map; Pres Clinton confers with allies (M)

headline: Scooter Sales Thriving From Rome to Delhi
abstract: Sales of motorscooters are booming in many parts of Europe and beyond; when market revived, in 1980's, it was largely thanks to Japanese, who used combination of low-cost manufacturing skills and high-tech innovation to make scooter once again the object of Europeans' desire; yet now, European companies like Italy-based Piaggio Veicoli Europei SpA, whose $1.4 billion in annual sales makes it market leader, are faring better than ever; European companies are shipping scooters to Asian markets and winning customers in Japan itself; in India, Piaggio already turns out 250,000 scooters a year in a joint venture with local partners; last year, it began production in China; graphs; photos (L)

headline: PLASTIC-MAKING PROJECT LINKS B.P. AND DOW CHEMICAL
abstract: Dow Chemical Co and British Petroleum PLC say they jointly developed plastic-making process they plan to license (S)

headline: Credit Offerings Expected During the Week
abstract: List of upcoming Treasury financings (S)

headline: Repairing the Road To a Secure Retirement
abstract: John A Clark letter notes that average American worker doesn't save because he can't (S)

headline: A Study Sees a Down Side to Going Overseas as an Executive
abstract: Conference Board, business research group, reports that many business managers return from international assignments to find themselves out of the corporate loop; survey of 152 companies found that only 38 percent of American respondents guarantee expatriates position upon their return, compared with 74 percent of European companies that answered survey; 87 percent of American companies say most repatriated executives are not promoted when they return; often, companies leave executives in limbo, not informing them of their new assignments until their return to US; Conference Board recommends that companies make global assignments part of career planning and create mentoring programs to keep expatriates in touch with home country (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;German Will Lead BMW's British Unit
abstract: In a surprise move, BMW said today that it was naming a German, Walter Hasselkus, to take over as chief of its British unit, the Rover Group.         Mr. Hasselkus, head of BMW's successful motorcycle division, will begin the new post on Sept. 1, replacing John Towers, who stepped down June 1.

headline: HUMANA INC. (HUM, N)
abstract: Humana Inc reports second-quarter loss of $95 million, compared with earings of $45 million in quarter a year earlier; revenues grew by 50 percent to $1.61 billion, from $1.07 billion last year; chart (S)

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Florida Firm Of Bribing Brokers in Scheme
abstract: SEC accuses Florida firm of paying $447,580 in bribes to seven brokers as part of what it calls stock-promoting scheme that netted $2.6 million in illegal profits; SEC suit accuses Atlantic Capital Corp of Orlando and five of its employees and consultants of paying bribes to brokers at various firms in three states (S)1

headline: Market Place;A 250-point fall. The Big Board shuts for a half-hour. Then?
abstract: WHAT would happen if the Dow Jones industrial average fell 250 points one hectic morning?         The simple answer is that the New York Stock Exchange would close for 30 minutes and then try to reopen. Within that half-hour, the Big Board specialists would try to post indicated prices for every stock, seeking to draw in buyers to allow shares to reopen quickly.

headline: De Beers Reports Profit Rise of 18%
abstract: De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd says income rose 18.4 percent, to $482 million in six months ending June 30 from $407 million a year earlier; reports its diamond account rose to $447 million in half-year from $435 million a year earlier (S)

headline: Union Carbide and Exxon Unit in Venture
abstract: Union Carbide Corp and unit of Exxon Corp to form joint venture to improve production processes for polyethylene (S)

headline: Wattles and Kurrajong:Australia's 'Bush Tucker' Cuisine Goes Up Market
abstract: SYDNEY—  After years in the bush leagues, Australian cuisine has gone upscale.Over the past 10 years, an unparalleled array of food formerly called "bush tucker" has been elevated to Australia's finer restaurants and hotels. Along the way, it has reached a commercial scale.

headline: Justice Dept. In New Inquiry Into Microsoft
abstract: Justice Department is opening new phase of its long-running investigation of Microsoft Corp by examining company's sales practices in fast-growing market for software used to browse the Internet; neither Justice Department nor Microsoft will comment on details of Justice Department's written request for information (L)

headline: Suspending the Search For Washboard Abs
abstract: Joan Mary Macey letter says lack of visible progress toward washboard abs is fueling boredom with exercise

headline: Paxson Prepares for Deal
abstract: The Paxson Communications Corporation may sell or swap its two network-affiliated television stations here as part of a plan to expand its infomercial and radio businesses. Paxson has hired Alex. Brown & Sons to advise  on options for WPBF-TV, an ABC affiliate, and WTVX-TV, a United/Paramount Network affiliate. Paxson owns 36 TV stations dedicated to infomercials and will own 39 radio stations, 6 radio networks, and 332 billboards after completing pending deals.

headline: Crédit Suisse To Slash Jobs In Radical Restructuring
abstract: PARIS—  Having failed to achieve a merger last April aimed at creating a European banking powerhouse, Switzerland's second-biggest banking group said Tuesday that it would launch a radical reorganization, slashing 5,000 jobs and replacing its chief executive.

headline: Selling Success, Blockbuster Style
abstract: Report on booming circuit in motivational speaking, long a cornerstone of American business life; such events used to be mostly quiet and uplifting evenings with Dale Carnegie and Normal Vincent Peale; but now these seminars aimed at rousing sales representatives, entrepreneurs and execs to higher levels of business performance are fast becoming blockbuster events--complete with superstar speakers--that rival a good-sized trade show or business convention; hottest motivational mogul right now is Peter Lowe, 36-year-old Canadian missionary's son whose upstart company, Peter Lowe International, has virtually every major speaking star on its marquee; some of those who have appeared at Lowe's motivational events are Jack Kemp, Mario Cuomo, Barbara Bush, James A Baker, Willard Scott, Les Brown and William J Bratton; photos (M)

headline: Investors Say Prudential Unit Cheated Them on Restitution
abstract: Lawyers for group of former clients of Prudential Securities to sue company, contending firm cheated those investors out of full compensation, three years after company agreed to repay every client it defrauded in largest investment scandal in history; restitution fund was established in 1993 after Federal and state securities regulators charged Prudential had systematically defrauded hundreds of thousands of investors in sale of more than $8 billion worth of limited partnerships; at issue now is way in which Prudential Securities treated certain tax and accounting issues in determining how much money to award certain partnership investors (M)

headline: U.S.-Japan Flights Continue
abstract: Spokesmen for United Airlines Inc. and the Japan Airlines Company say the refusal by the Governments of the United States and Japan to approve already scheduled flights will not affect service -- at least for a week.         After talks between the Governments broke down a week ago, the United States  Department of Transportation refused to approve a weekly Japan Airlines flight from Honolulu to Hiroshima. Japan's Ministry of Transport then turned down an application by United to continue 7 of its 14 flights a week between Los Angeles and Tokyo.

headline: Canadian Rail Cutback
abstract: As part of a three-year plan to reorganize its rail network, the Canadian National Railway Company will dispose of 1,400 miles of railroad. The company said on Tuesday that the announcement was required under new legislation to make it easier for railroad companies to transfer noncore lines to short-line operators.

headline: A New Media Giant Puzzles About What To Do With Its Old Industrial Divisions
abstract: Possible spinoff or sale by Westinghouse Electric Corp of five businesses that make up its $5.5 billion industries and technology group discussed; chief executive Michael H Jordan's preference for trying to turn units around before selling them noted; graphs; photos (M)

headline: L.I. Brokerage Firm Said to Be Under Investigation
abstract: Landmark International Equities, Westbury, NY, brokerage firm, is being investigated by National Association of Securities Dealers as result of running afoul of net capital requirements and quitting as Nasdaq market-maker; firm is best known for taking public Guardian Technologies International. firm run by Oliver L North; Landmark quit making markets in seven Nasdaq-traded securities, including shares of Guardian Technologies; George Johnson, president of Hanifen Imhoff Clearing Corp, Denver, which operated as Landmark's clearing agent, says Landmark is trying to raise new capital to reopen its market-making business (M)

headline: Talks on TV Plant's Sale
abstract: Philips Electronics NV is in talks with a 'potential buyer' for its television plant in Greeneville, NC (S)

headline: Israel's New Poor: Foreign Laborers
abstract: Israel is waking up to unintended social consequences of importing workers from Asia, Africa, Arab countries, Eastern Europe and even South America to work its fields and build its apartments; realization comes after years of disparaging Palestinian workers and curbing number allowed into country; foreign workers, most admitted on temporary contracts and other entering illegally, are enveloping neighborhoods and many show no signs of leaving; country is increasingly uneasy about workers bringing wives or marrying locally and enrolling children in schools; southern Tel Aviv slum has largest concentration of foreigners in Israel; Govt of Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu seeks ways to correct problem; photo (M)

headline: Stock Market Posts Gains, Led by Advances in Bonds
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 23.67 points, to 5,689.45; table (L)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Clearance Is Seen For Sandoz-Ciba Merger
abstract: The European Commission is expected to clear the merger of the Swiss pharmaceutical giants Sandoz and Ciba-Geigy next Wednesday, but with conditions. A European Union insider declined to say what conditions were likely, but in the past the commission has demanded divestments of some operations.          Industry officials said recently that they expected the European Union Competition Commission to ask the companies to sell off small businesses in the  crop protection area. The Sandoz-Ciba merger would create a new company called Novartis.   (Reuters)

headline: De Benedetti Said to Seek Sale of His Company
abstract: Shares of Cerus SA rise in Paris as newspaper Les Echos reports the Cerus, a holding company controlled by Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti is in talks to be bought by CGIP, a French financial and industrial company (S)

headline: Tomorrow, the World Wide Web!;Microsoft, the PC King, Wants to Reign Over the Internet
abstract: As a captain of industry and the richest man in America, William H. Gates has often been compared to industrial titans of the past.         And just as the railroad tycoons of the 1800's set the gauge for the nation's railroad tracks, Mr. Gates's Microsoft Corporation seems intent, its critics say, on the modern-day equivalent: controlling many of the basic technical specifications of the global Internet.

headline: Auto Sales in June Slowed From May's Frantic Pace
abstract: Auto sales slowed from a frantic sprint to a slow jog in June, suggesting a slowdown in economic growth, economists said.         The annualized pace of sales dropped to 15.2 million cars and light trucks last month from a torrid 15.8 million in May, a downshifting that economists and Wall Street analysts greeted as a sign that the economy was settling down to a steadier pace and was less likely to overheat.

abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.63   5.28   5.86        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.19   5.14   5.30        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.38   5.26   5.30        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.88   6.94   6.18        30-YR. TREAS.
