headline: Western Claims Victory in Bid To Acquire Kansas City Power
abstract: Western Resources Inc claims victory in its hostile takeover bid for Kansas City Power and Light Co, saying Kansas City Power shareholders rejected plan to buy out Utilicorp United Inc; analysts say if the claims by Western are borne out, its $1.9 billion bid for Kansas City Power is almost assured success (M)i

headline: Reno Casino Project
abstract: Boyd Gaming Corp buys 100 acres in Reno, Nevada, for $92 million casino, hotel and entertainment complex; project will be called Sam's Town Reno (S)

headline: OFF THE RACK;Making Do With Less, Voluntarily or Not
abstract: OH, the importance of timing and the advantage of hindsight.         Because of publishing lead times, the August issues of Money and Smart Money  magazines are both heavy with articles and charts on mutual funds and the roaring bull market -- an awkward situation considering how the market behaved last week.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Data Lift Hopes For an Early Rate Cut
abstract: German money-supply growth slowed abruptly in June, the Bundesbank said yesterday, providing new evidence of a sluggish economy and fanning hopes for interest-rate cuts as soon as next week. The Bundesbank said the M-3 money supply, a leading indicator of inflation, grew at an annual rate of 9.6 percent  in June, slowing from a 10.5 percent rate in May.          Many economists said the central bank might trim its chief money market rate, the 3.3 percent securities repurchase rate, by up to 20 basis points next Thursday, its last policy-making meeting before a four-week break. The repo rate, which sets a target for overnight lending and is comparable to the United  States Federal funds rate, has been frozen since early February.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Campbell Soup Profits Rise As Revamping Is Expected  The Campbell Soup Company reported strong fourth-quarter earnings as its shares rose on speculation that the company would make an announcement today on a possible revamping. Campbell, the world's largest soup maker, announced that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 25.9 percent, to $180 million, or 73 cents a share, above expectations. The earnings included a one-time gain from the sale of the Mrs. Paul's frozen seafood business. $(Page D2.$)     Investigation at Stock Exchange  The Philadelphia Stock Exchange is investigating its chairman for investing in a small company that subsequently won a major contract with the exchange -- a contract that was the main attraction when the company sold shares to the public this year. $(D8.$)     Service Blocks 'Junk' E-Mail  America Online took the unusual step of blocking all incoming messages from five Internet sites that it said were responsible for sending millions of unsolicited E-mails. $(D18.$)    Strategic Shift at Dreyfus Funds  Dreyfus plans to introduce a service to offer investment advice to customers with as little as $10,000 in assets in an effort to attract mutual fund investors. $(D8.$)     G.M. Sales Dropped Last Month  G.M. said sales last month dropped 7.9 percent from the strong levels of a year earlier because of weak demand for large sedans and luxury cars and supply problems. $(D4.$)    Clinton to Name Health Care Panel  President Clinton will soon appoint a Federal advisory commission to study the health care industry and lay a foundation for policy initiatives and legislative proposals if the President wins a second term. $(A20.$)    Construction Spending Off 1.4%  Construction spending in July fell 1.4 percent from June, its biggest drop in five months, as building activity in the housing sector contracted for a third month. $(D4.$)    Zell in Bid for Chateau Properties  Manufactured Home Communities, which is controlled by Sam Zell, announced a hostile $387 million bid for a rival, Chateau Properties. It hopes to derail Chateau's $300 million deal for ROC Communities. $(D5.$)    Dow Industrials Gain 8.51  Blue-chip stocks ended with small gains, as investors awaited Friday's jobs report for clues as to whether the Fed will raise interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 8.51 points, closing at 5,656.90. $(D8.$)    Prices of Treasuries fell sharply, as traders awaited the labor statistics, pushing the yield on the long bond up to 7.10 percent. $(D18.$)    Art Book Publisher Put Up for Sale  Times Mirror said it was looking for a buyer for Harry N. Abrams, the art-book publisher, after it failed to meet its profit target. $(D7.$)    Oil Prices Fall  Crude oil prices fell after President Clinton said Iraqi troops appeared to be withdrawing from Kurdish areas they attacked on Saturday, easing tensions that sent oil soaring. The withdrawal would improve the prospects for a possible limited sale of Iraqi oil. Crude oil for October delivery fell 16 cents, to $23.24 a barrel. $(D15.$)    Cost Unclear on Fund Bailout  Deutsche Bank said that it was too early to say how much it would cost to bail out three funds managed by its Morgan Grenfell unit. $(D5.$)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MGM GRAND TO PUT RESORT ON BOARDWALK
abstract: MGM Grand Inc. said yesterday that it had chosen a site for a $700 million "majestic destination resort" it plans to build on Atlantic City's Boardwalk. The company, which disclosed plans to enter Atlantic City two months ago, says it will build on 30 acres next to Showboat Casino Hotel. The number of rooms and the size of the casino have not been decided. MGM, which says it needs 30 acres, must acquire most of the land. MGM has reached agreement with a shopping mall developer, the Forest City Ratner Companies, which controls a 13-acre site next  to Showboat, on a plan to include that property in the project.

headline: U.S. Weighs Lifting Curb on Arms Sales to Latin America
abstract: At the urging of Defense Secretary William J. Perry, the Clinton Administration is considering easing a decades-old ban on sales of high-technology weapons like advanced fighter jets to Latin America, raising fears of a new arms race in a region that has been relatively calm after years of military conflict and dictatorship.         Mr. Perry and major weapons makers contend that the blanket restrictions, imposed in the 1970's, are no longer warranted because democracy has spread to every country in the region except Cuba.

headline: BOMBING OF HOTEL DIMINISHES HOPES FOR ULSTER PEACE
abstract: A luxury hotel here was ripped apart early this morning when a bomb in a silver-colored jeep exploded only moments after 250 guests and wedding party revelers were evacuated.         Although there was no loss of life and injuries were slight, the device -- the first terrorist explosion in Northern Ireland since tentative stabs at peace yielded a cease-fire 22 months ago -- set off tremors of fear throughout the province.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Restated Loss Widens At Gemina of Italy
abstract: The shareholders of Gemina S.p.A., a diversified Italian holding company, approved company statements on Saturday that showed a 1995 deficit of 694.5 billion lire ($448 million) as internal auditors asked for more information on the losses. The restated accounts showed a loss 48 percent higher than the company had forecast at the end of last year after unexpected losses in its RCS  Editori publishing unit.          Those losses derailed a planned merger with Ferruzzi Finanziaria S.p.A. and  led to an investigation by Milan prosecutors into possible fraud by top Gemina executives. Gemina's internal audit committee said Saturday that the company needed to produce more information on accounting irregularities that led to unexplained losses at the Gemina Capital Markets unit, which has since been disbanded.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;Saying Yes to Small Stocks, Even After a Nail-Biting Ride
abstract: THE small-capitalization stock market has been on a roller-coaster, exploding higher at the start of the second quarter this year and then falling just as hard toward the quarter's end before recovering just a bit. So it is not surprising if investors feel a little dizzy.         Does all the activity mean investors should make equally frenetic moves? For  long-term holdings, like retirement money, a little fine-tuning is as far as investment advisers seem willing to go.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Argentine Financial Markets Hold Steady
abstract: Argentina received a much-needed vote of confidence today as its financial markets remained steady, defying dire predictions that investors would abandon the debt-pressed country after the ouster of its Finance Minister, Domingo Cavallo, last week.         The Merval index of the 28 most-traded stocks on the Buenos Aires stock exchange -- which tumbled 4.1 percent on Friday -- rose 2.8 percent today, or 14.36 points, to 519.22, in heavy trading. Argentine bonds declined only slightly today, while in New York, Argentina's benchmark Brady bonds posted modest gains. Also, foreign-exchange operators reported no major increase in exchanging pesos for dollars, as was the case Friday.

headline: Read My Lips: Oral Promises May Bind Employers
abstract: California Supreme Court rules that Andrew Lazar may sue Rykoff-Sexton Inc, which he claims dismissed him three years after enticing him to move his family from New York to Los Angeles with an oral promise that his new job would be secure; more and more states have changed their laws to be more favorable to employees to whom promises are made in a form other than a legal contract (M)

headline: Scaros & Casselman Gets a Bass Account
abstract: Crowne Plaza Hotels and Resorts names Scaros & Casselman Advertising as agency of record for international advertising; billings estimated at $20 million (S)

headline: Deal Made for Cruise Ship
abstract: British leisure and travel concern Airtours PLC says it bought cruise ship from Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd for $40 million; Airtours says purchase of ship, the Song of Norway, will enable it to keep pace with strong demand for cruise vacations (S)

headline: F.C.C. Sells Wireless Licenses for $905 Million
abstract: A Federal auction ended today with seven companies pledging $905 million for  licenses to provide the next generation of mobile telephone and data services.         The Federal Communications Commission put the 18 licenses on the auction block after two companies defaulted on license payments. The licenses fetched $30 million more in the second auction than the first, the F.C.C. said.

headline: Prudential of Britain Sells Reinsurance Unit
abstract: Prudential Corp of Britain is selling its Mercantile & General reinsurance unit to Swiss Reinsurance Co for 1.75 billion pounds ($2.7 billion)

headline: Psinet to Sell Consumer Internet Division
abstract: Psinet Inc., one of the country's largest Internet service providers, said yesterday that it would sell its consumer Internet subscriber base of about 100,000 customers and a support center to Mindspring Enterprises Inc. of Atlanta for $23 million.         The deal will allow Psinet, based in Herndon, Va., to concentrate on its more profitable corporate customers. Psinet had offered individual Internet access accounts under the Pipeline and Interramp brands.

headline: Business Inventories Drop And Growth in Sales Eases
abstract: Business inventories fell in May even as companies reported a slowdown in sales growth for the month, Government figures showed today.         Business inventories decreased one-tenth of 1 percent in May to a seasonally  adjusted $983.254 billion after rising four-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Commerce Department said. Business sales rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in May after rising a revised 1.1 percent in April.

headline: Wanted: Corporate Name. Must Evoke Speed, Power. Originality Optional.
abstract: Naming a new Internet-based company or product becomes a tricky and competitive affair after hundreds of names are registered using 'net,' 'power' and 'link'; corporate naming follows certain patterns and strategies; graph (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;IRIDEX STOCK DECLINES ON REPORT OF FLAT EARNINGS
abstract: Shares of the Iridex Corporation fell 28 percent yesterday, one day after the eye laser company said second-quarter earnings were nearly flat despite a 14.7 percent jump in sales. The results were well below the expectations of analysts. The company noted that expenses rose nearly 30 percent, but did not disclose any reasons. Iridex, based in Mountain View, Calif., said that it expected to begin  shipments of its Oculight semiconductor-based visible laser system in its second half, though the company is still working out problems that will delay international deliveries. Yesterday, Iridex shares fell to as low as $7.50 before closing at $8.25, down $3.25.

TUESDAY    Leading Indicators   July    WEDNESDAY    Construction Spending   July    THURSDAY    Sales of Leading Retailers   Aug.    New-Car Sales   Aug.    Weekly Jobless Claims    FRIDAY    Employment   Aug.

headline: Disappointing Auction Sends Bonds Lower
abstract: Treasury's one-day market rally is cut short, as traders give Government's sale of five-year notes a disappointing reception; 30-year bond slips 4/32, to price of 97 5/32; graph (M)

headline: Erasing an Opportunity
abstract: Bell Atlantic chief executive Raymond W Smith recalls first job, as 15-year-old copy boy at Pittsburgh paper; photos (S)

headline: EMPIRE BLUE CROSS SEEKING TO BECOME FOR-PROFIT GROUP
abstract: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, once one of country's biggest insurers of last resort, will seek approval from New York State to become for-profit company, bringing to close its historic role as safety net for sickest people of state; to make transformation, Empire will establish charitable foundation to provide money to help over 2.5 million New York residents who do not have health insurance; planned conversion reflects fierce competition in health care market (M)

headline: Micron Cash-Out Leaves the I.R.S. Waiting
abstract: Floyd Norris (Market Place) column discusses recent sale by J R Simplot, potato magnate, and family corporation he founded that is now controlled by his children, of 12.6 milllion shares of Micron Technologies, nearly 6 percent of company; says that by using complicated Wall Street techniques, including forward sale and equity swap, family company apparently will not pay taxes on $150 million earned from stock sale until 2003; also notes that maneuver enabled family company to retain voting rights on most of shares, which could be useful in event of proxy fight; says tax avoidance appears to be reason for structuring family company transactions; graph of Micron stock price (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY    Leading Indicators   June    New-Car Sales   July    TUESDAY    None    WEDNESDAY    Wholesale Trade   June    Consumer Borrowing   June    THURSDAY    Sales of Leading Retailers   June    Weekly Jobless Claims    FRIDAY    Producer Prices   July

headline: Cuba Strong Despite U.S. Law, Castro Says
abstract: President Fidel Castro says that Cuba is recovering from economic recession and that this is the country's answer to a United States law aimed at curbing foreign investment on the island.         In his annual speech on the anniversary of a guerrilla attack he led on an army barracks in 1953, Mr. Castro rebuked President Clinton on Friday night for  having signed into law measures aimed at tightening the American economic embargo against Cuba. Mr. Clinton's action on March 12 was the result of "political opportunism" and "constituted a lack of morality, a lack of ethics,"  Mr. Castro said.

headline: To be or not to be? To young people, it's no question, Klein says.
abstract: CK Be is a new Calvin Klein fragrance, and its campaign will use quintessential Klein imagery, with young models exposing plenty of tattooed flesh; more than $20 million ad campaign is creation of CRK Advertising, in-house agency at Klein; photo (L)

headline: Ex-Officer at Zenith Joins On-line Group
abstract: J William Grimes joins Netcast Communications Corp in new post of chairman (S)

headline: Bad Neuenahr Journal;To Tighten Germany's Belt, Take a Look at the Spa
abstract: For the last 20 minutes or so, Gerd Ruhs, still as a pharaoh's mummy, happy as a hippo, has been encased in a coating of volcanic mud whose temperatures run to 120 degrees.         Contrary to appearances, he says -- moving ever so slightly, sweating ever so much -- there is a "taste of luxury" to this and to the massages and other treatments associated with being a patient at the spa here.

headline: Price Is Lowered On Leap Offering
abstract: Leap Group lowers price a share at which agency expects to sell stock in initial public offering; company now proposes selling 4 million shares at $9 to $11 a share (S)

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Delta Beats Earnings Forecasts
abstract: The shares of Delta Air Lines fell today as the company's prediction that it  would not meet a cost-cutting goal overshadowed better-than-expected results.         Delta said that profit from operations in its fiscal fourth quarter rose 31 percent, to $328 million, or $5.77 a share, from $251 million, or $4.49, in the  corresponding period last year. The per-share results are after payment of preferred dividends.

headline: Allied Products Bought by CRH
abstract: CRH P.L.C. of Ireland said yesterday that it would acquire the Allied Building Products Corporation, a New Jersey manufacturer of building materials,  for $121 million in cash.         The acquisition, which also includes the assumption of an undisclosed amount  of debt and deferred payments, would give CRH its first distribution business in the United States. CRH, based in Dublin, makes roofing, siding and insulation products.

headline: CANADIAN PACIFIC TO SELL REALTY UNITS FOR $693 MILLION
abstract: Canadian Pacific Ltd agrees to sell its Marathon Realty and Centrixx Realty Holdings units for $693.3 million; units will be sold to newly incorporated company that will be owned equally by Oxford Properties Group Inc of Toronto and GE Capital, financial unit of General Electric Co (S)

headline: Market Place;For Digital, a Tunnel at the End of the Light
abstract: A few months ago, Robert B. Palmer, chairman and chief executive of the Digital Equipment Corporation, was saying that the company's worst days were behind it. Having bet its future on being first to market with a series of cutting-edge computer technologies, Digital seemed poised to cash in after facing extinction in the early 1990's.         But after yesterday, investors have to wonder if the company will ever reach  El Dorado -- and if it does, whether Mr. Palmer will be holding the reins.

headline: Bosnia Gears Up for Election, With 25,000 Candidates
abstract: Sejfudin Tokic, 35, a former pharmacist, went today from a seminar on running a political campaign to a meeting in the suburbs with campaign workers, then back to his office, with its broken windows and stained carpets, for another meeting.         It was opening day of the campaign for the Bosnian elections scheduled for Sept. 14, a campaign almost scuttled by a quarrel among outside powers over whether the field was ready, and then delayed by a scrimmage to wrest the Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic from office, something accomplished only Friday.

headline: What's in a Name? Oddly, City Conceives Museum
abstract: Condom, France, is accustomed to visitors who make fun of town's name; Mayor Gerard Dubrac is leading town's drive to cash in on name by building condom museum; map; photo (M)

headline: Toys 'R' Us Ordered To Pay $46 Million
abstract: Toys "R" Us Inc. has been ordered to pay $46 million plus interest to a Kuwaiti trading firm that contended that the toy retailer wrongly terminated a 1982 agreement to operate franchise stores in the Middle East.         A ruling on Friday by an arbitrator from the American Arbitration Association supported the claims made by Yusuf Ahmad Alghanim & Sons, which had bought the rights to operate the toy store franchises in 14 Middle Eastern countries.

headline: Palestinian Security Agents Ban Books by a Critic of Arafat
abstract: Palestinian Authority, adding to its growing list of human rights abuses, has banned sale of books by Edward W Said, critic of Authority head Yasir Arafat; it is unclear who ordered ban, or whther it is independent move by one of several security services set up by Arafat; services reportedly have become increasingly crude and aggressive since Authority's Mar crackdown on Islamic militants (M)

headline: World News Briefs;Landslides and Floods Kill 50 in South Korea
abstract: Landslides and floods have killed about 50 people, mostly soldiers, and left  thousands homeless in the northern part of South Korea after torrential rains over the past two days, Government officials said today.         A Defence Ministry statement said landslides killed at least 22 soldiers today; 20 soldiers were crushed to death while sleeping in their barracks on Friday.

headline: Irish Troubles Spill Over to Canary Isles
abstract: Hundreds of British and Irish tourists fought on the Spanish island of Tenerife after an argument about Northern Ireland turned into a brawl, the local police said today.         The arguments between Britons, Irish Protestants and Roman Catholics in a bar in the resort of Playa de las Americas began late Thursday night and spilled into Friday morning, they added.

headline: Fugitive Bosnian Serb Has Legal Team Ready
abstract: Radovan Karadzic may appear no closer to surrendering real power or to giving himself up to NATO forces. But the Bosnian Serb leader does seem to be preparing to confront charges that he is a war criminal by appointing lawyers to represent him at the war crimes tribunal here.         It is too early to say whether this is a sign that Dr. Karadzic is feeling vulnerable as Western pressure mounts, or whether this is a fresh attempt to mislead the international community about his intentions. But Dr. Karadzic has been forming a legal defense team that includes two American lawyers who say they plan to challenge the tribunal's procedures as biased and unfair.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Deutsche Bank Profit Rose 15% in First Half
abstract: Deutsche Bank A.G., Germany's largest bank, said yesterday that its profit rose 15 percent in the first six months of 1996 on stronger commission income and trading profits. Deutsche Bank said it earned 1.17 billion marks ($790 million) in the first half.          Commission income, less fees paid, rose 30 percent, to 3.30 billion marks. Trading profits rose 60 percent, to 1.38 billion marks. Deutsche Bank's data show that its basic lending business was soft, with interest income, less interest paid, falling 1.2 percent.   (AP)

headline: A Wretched New Class of Infected Untouchables
abstract: Indian AIDS specialists assert that AIDS patients have become India's new untouchables, along with tens of millions of Indians born into lowest rung of country's rigid caste system to spend their lives being shunned; many AIDS sufferers are driven from their communities by fearful neighbors, pushed from one hospital to another by doctors and staff members reluctant to treat them, and finally, approaching death in the AIDS ward, are left virtually to fend for themselves (M)

headline: This Ticket No Longer Costs $1 Million
abstract: Advice on investing through leading institutional funds, which have reduced minimum-purchase requirements from $1 million to no more than $10,000 (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FIRST USA TO TAKE OVER GENSAR HOLDINGS
abstract: First USA Paymentech Inc., a credit card transaction processing company, said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Gensar Holdings Inc. for $170 million. First USA Paymentech expects to take a one-time pretax charge of $15 million for costs related to the acquisition of Gensar, a company that handles electronic messages related to credit card transactions. First USA Paymentech, a unit of the credit card issuer First USA Inc. of Dallas, currently depends on outside vendors for many services that the acquisition would allow it to provide in-house. Gensar processes about 300 million transactions a year and provides services to 120,000 merchants nationwide.

headline: 'Miracle Child' and Answered Prayers
abstract: Argentines by the thousands appeal for favor of Miguel Angel Gaitan, a one-year-old baby who died of meningitis in 1966 and whose remarkably well-preserved body is displayed in a glass-top coffin in a cemetery in Villa Union; an anthropologist says Miguel Angel and other 'saints' applied to by Argentines are a vestige of an indigenous culture that is all but wiped out in Argentina; photo; map (M)

headline: A Web Guide To New York Is Acquired
abstract: City Search Inc., an Internet start-up company with national aspirations, has acquired Metrobeat, the publisher of one of Manhattan's most popular city guides on the World Wide Web.         The deal, which the companies intend to announce today, will test City Search's thesis that while the Internet may be a global communications medium, the real opportunity may be in providing useful local information.

headline: Rank: 18 of 25. Not Funds, Olympic Sailing.
abstract: Article on Mark G Holowesko, manager of Templeton's Foreign and Growth funds, who placed 18th out of 25, representing the Bahamas, in Star class division of Olympic yachting in Atlanta, Ga (L)

headline: I.M.F. May Sell Gold to Cut Debt Load of Poor
abstract: International Monetary Fund has indicated for first time that it may be willing to sell some of its $40 billion supply of gold and use proceeds as outright gift to reduce foreign debts of poorest developing countries, allowing them to improve economic growth and attract more foreign investment (L)

headline: Let the Credit Cards Compete
abstract: Article by Repr Charles E Schumer urges competition for credit card companies; says American Express, Discover and other potential credit card companies want the chance to offer their products through banks; holds current restrictions in credit card arena contradict the principles of open markets and price competition that are hallmarks of capitalist economy (L)g

headline: First-Half Profit Rose For Prudential of Britain
abstract: Prudential Corp PLC says it had 8 percent rise in first-half profit, to $655 million (S)

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;USAir and America West Report Big Earnings Gains
abstract: Two airlines, USAir and America West, reported healthy gains yesterday in second-quarter earnings.         USAir Group Inc. said its earnings increased 77.9 percent, as the airline cut capacity and filled more of the remaining seats with paying passengers. The company's net income rose to $200.8 million, or $2.71 a share, from $112.9 million, or $1.47 a share, in the second quarter last year.

headline: Rothschild Setting Up A New Fund
abstract: Wilbur L. Ross Jr. and his colleagues at Rothschild Inc. are setting up the Rothschild Recovery Fund to invest in distressed securities.         The new fund, which is offering $150 million of limited partnership interests with minimum commitments of $5 million, "will seek to provide significant returns through opportunistic investments in distressed securities and through selected financing arrangements for companies in bankruptcy proceedings," according to a copy of the private placement memorandum.

headline: Ulster March By Protestants Passes Calmly
abstract: After days of violent protests, tens of thousands of Protestants marched today, accompanied by booming fife-and-drum bands, in hundreds of generally untroubled parades to celebrate Ulster Protestantism's proudest event: the victory on July 12, 1690, of the Protestant William of Orange over his Catholic  father-in-law, King James II, at the Battle of the Boyne.         The violence began last Sunday when the police refused to allow a Protestant  Orange Order march to pass a Catholic area in Drumcree, 30 miles southwest of here. Tens of thousands of Protestants blocked roads and attacked the police until Thursday, when the police reversed the decision and allowed the march. That immediately detonated a night of Catholic violence.

headline: Much Ado About Budgeting
abstract: Deborah Stead reviews books Get a Financial Life: Personal Finance in Your 20's and 30's by Beth Bobliner and Now What?! A Guide to Jobs, Money, and the Real World by J D Heiman; photo (L)

headline: Business Travel;Hotel mini-bars are on the increase, despite their reputation for being expensive.
abstract: IN the United States, only 3 out of 10 hotel guests use mini-bars -- in Europe, it's 4 out of 10 -- largely because of overpriced snacks and drinks. And not helping matters are the irritating interruptions by staff to restock.         Unfazed by this, however, hotels are now turning mini-bars into mini-shops by offering everything from bottled water, the No. 1 seller, to logo-clad souvenirs like golf balls and T-shirts and health aids like antacids and even condoms. At  the Kahala Mandarin Hotel in Honolulu, for example, mini-bars include cameras, sunglasses, playing cards, watches, sandalwood fans, lip balm, postcards and bottles of cabernet sauvignon.

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 5/ Pinching pennies may be unfashionable, but it's the proven route to riches. By Jane Birnbaum.

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: Schedule of economic reports due out in the coming week

headline: Ulster Without a Net
abstract: For nearly two years, the Northern Ireland peace effort has been an incredible balancing act, like a team of acrobats bicycling across a high wire.  One performer is riding the bike, another sits on his shoulders and two others hang on either side. If any one leans over too far -- or if the bicycle comes to a halt -- they all fall down.         This week a new hindrance was added: the most widespread street disturbances  in 20 years in Protestant and Roman Catholic neighborhoods. They are swaying the wire perilously like bursts of wind.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: Timothy Cohrs was named to the new position of vice president and executive creative director at Lai, Venuti & Lai Advertising, Santa Clara, Calif. He had spent 18 years at the in-house agency of Gap Inc., San Francisco.

headline: AT&T to Provide Service in Britain
abstract: Turning up the heat in Europe's most competitive telecommunications market, the AT&T Corporation said Friday that it would start selling phone services to consumers in Britain for the first time this week.         Prices will be as much as 40 percent below rates offered by British Telecommunications P.L.C., the largest British carrier. AT&T said it would offer multimedia, wireless, calling cards and numbers that customers keep for life, among other services.

headline: ACKLANDS TO SELL ITS INDUSTRIAL SUPPLIES UNIT
abstract: Acklands Ltd to sell its industrial supplies division to W W Grainger Inc for about $350 million (Canadian) (US $255 million) in cash and stock (S)

headline: Cambodia's Dual Premiers Are Split on Khmer Rouge
abstract: Recent split within Cambodia's Khmer Rouge pits dissident Ieng Sary against his former partner and brother-in-law, Pol Pot, and given Government best opportunity yet to neutralize long-running insurgency; map; Ieng Sary, who was Pol Pot's deputy when as many as two million Cambodians were killed in 1970's, says he now wants reconciliation; co-Prime Min Hun Sen offers him safety guarantee, but second Prime Min, Norodom Ranariddh, likens Ieng Sary to Hitler as mass murderer beyond redemption (S)

headline: INVESTING IT;I'll Take 'Investment Strategies' for $500, Please
abstract: AS a contestant on TV's "Jeopardy," Bradley C. Plovan had all the answers. He knew the name of the composer buried next to Beethoven in Vienna ("Who was Schubert?"). He knew the title of the speech William Jennings Bryan delivered at the 1896 Democratic Convention ("What is the 'Cross of Gold' speech?"). He even  knew the nickname of Irwin Handelman, a character on the sitcom "Family Ties" ("What is 'Skippy?' ").         But when it came to deciding what to do with his $61,000 prize for his five consecutive victories on the show, Mr. Plovan, a 30-year-old Baltimore lawyer, did not have a clue.

headline: Data Network Fails, Vexing Small Business
abstract: America Online computer network crashes for most of day during faulty installation of new system software, leaving six million subscribers, including many small businesses and home-office workers, without key communications services; outage costs information publishers access fees and advertising revenues; underscores increasing importance of electronic mail to modern commerce; photo (M)

headline: An Expensive Beer for the N.A.S.D.
abstract: Article by William G Christie on study he co-authored with Paul Shultz that resulted in a Government investigation of Nasdaq market pricing practices; recent antitrust settlement by National Assn of Securities Dealers with Securities and Exchange Commission calls for the association to spend $100 million over the next five years to better police its market (M)

headline: Venture in Accord to Buy 7 TV Stations From Aflac
abstract: Ken Hawkins, William Zortman and Stephen Burr, operating as closely held corporation, Raycom Media Inc, say they will pay $485 million for seven television stations owned by Aflac Inc, parent of American Family Life Assurance Co of Columbus, Ga; stations bought from Aflac, which specializes in supplemental health insurance, are KFVS in Cape Girardeau, Mo, WAFF in Huntsville, Ala, KWWL in Waterloo, Iowa, WAFB in Baton Rouge, La, WTOC in Savannah, Ga, WITN in Washington, NC, and WTVM in Columbus, Ga (L)

headline: Seeking a Turnaround With Souped-Up Machines and a Few New Games
abstract: Nintendo Co president Hiroshi Yamauchi, who built firm into video game colossus, attempts comeback with powerful new game machine after letting Sega Enterprises Ltd and Sony Corp overtake firm's lead in new machines; Nintendo is about year late in shipping machines and has only three games ready, while there are already hundreds of games available for Sony and Sega machines; plans to restrict number of games developed to assure high quality and develop most of games by itself, at least initially; graphs; tables; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;A Shake-Up of Management At Bay Networks Is Expected
abstract: A management shake-up may be imminent at Bay Networks Inc., a computer network equipment maker that reported earnings below analysts' expectations.         Responding to widespread industry speculation that he is about to resign, Bay Networks' president and chief executive, Andrew Ludwick, confirmed that he would step down and that a succession plan was in place. But he declined to identify the successor or specify a time frame.

headline: 2 New Deals Continue Wave Of Mergers in Energy Utilities
abstract: Merger wave continues in energy utility industry; Houston Industries, electric utility, to acquire Noram Energy Corp, natural gas utility, for $2.4 billion in cash, stock and debt assumption; Delmarva Power & Light Co and Atlantic Energy Inc, which charge different electric rates, agree to merge and be run separately by new holding company; Delmarva chief executive Howard E Cosgrove will he chief executive of new firm (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BOEING ANNOUNCES $510 MILLION ORDER FROM CHINA
abstract: The Boeing Company, the world's biggest civil aircraft manufacturer, has sold three long-range 747-400 aircraft to China for $510 million, a company spokeswoman said in Beijing early today. The planes will be used by Air China, a national carrier. Air China has an option to buy two more 747's, which would raise the value of the contract to about $915 million. Boeing is continuing to discuss other possible sales to China involving 747, 777 and 737 aircraft, said the Boeing spokeswoman, Cindy Smith."We intend to be China's premier supplier," she said.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: The National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing, Daytona Beach, Fla., will open an office in New York to handle duties like sponsorship sales, marketing and licensing.

headline: TOP BOSNIAN SERB AGREES TO RESIGN
abstract: Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb political chief who led his people in a brutal war of ethnic separation, has agreed to give up political power immediately, the special United States envoy, Richard C. Holbrooke, said here today.         The agreement removes an obstacle to September's national elections in Bosnia and Herzegovina and could aid the flagging peace effort by removing from visible public life a man indicted for genocide and other war crimes.

headline: A Coke Coup in Venezuela Leaves Pepsi High and Dry
abstract: Global cola war between Coca-Cola Co and Pepsico Inc heats up in Venezuela, as Coke raids Pepsi's venerable bottling company there, and Pepsi threatens legal action; in what is viewed as an embarrassment to Pepsi-Cola and blow to company's international expansion plans, Coca-Cola Co announces that it has formed joint-venture company with Cisneros Group of Venezuela, a Pepsi bottler for five decades; Pepsi spokesman Keith D Hughes, contending that Pepsi had contractual agreement with Cisneros Group until year 2,003, says sale is illegal and Pepsi will exhaust all legal measures in Venezuela and US to insure Pepsi's rights and those of its consumers are protected (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Dow Rises 50, To Still Another Record  Even without a major news development to energize trading, the stock market continued its rally. In the session after its first close over 5,800 points, the Dow Jones industrial average briefly jumped above 5,900 and closed up 50.68 points, at 5,889.20. Other major indexes also rose, though less steeply.    Driven by a new optimism about inflation and interest rates, the Dow industrials have increased by more than 280 points in seven sessions. $(Page D8.$)    Intel shares surged in after-hours trading after the company said it expected its third-quarter revenue to exceed estimates. $(D2.$)    Crestar Plans Acquisition  Crestar Financial has agreed to buy Citizens Bancorp for about $774 million, expanding its assets by 23 percent and solidifying its position in the Washington region. $(D3.$)    I.B.M. Plans Buyout Program  I.B.M. is preparing to offer buyouts and other inducements for 3,000 to 5,000 of its employees to either leave the company or find new jobs at its fastest-growing divisions. $(D3.$)    Goldman, Sachs Profit Surges  Goldman, Sachs reported pretax profit of $589 million for the three months ended Aug. 30, a 39 percent increase from a year earlier, as one of its strongest years continues. $(D4.$)    2 to Leave Archer Daniels Board  Archer Daniels said two former executives would step down as directors, as the company continues to respond to criticism that the board is dominated by insiders. $(D3.$)    Inventories Surged in July  Stockpiles of unsold goods at American businesses soared to the highest level in more than a decade in July, suggesting that businesses were betting that a surge in demand would continue. $(D2.$)    Foundation Health in Merger Talks  Foundation Health said it was discussing a possible merger, but it would not name the other party in the negotiations. $(D19.$)    States Outlaw a Curb on Doctors  In a sign of growing concern about the practices of some health maintenance organizations, 16 states have adopted laws this year to nullify efforts by H.M.O.'s to limit what doctors can tell their patients. $(A12.$)    America Online Moves to Big Board  America Online's chief, Stephen M. Case, left, posed with Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, as America Online moved to that market from Nasdaq. The stock rose $2, but that came after a 60 percent drop since May. Market Place. $(D8.$)    A Former Exchange Chief Is Fined  Zoltan Guttman, the former chairman of the New York Mercantile Exchange, was fined $500,000 and barred from trading on commodities exchanges for five years for his role in a fictitious-trading scheme. $(D5.$)

headline: Slater Hanft Martin Gets a New Name
abstract: Slater Hanft Martin changes name to Hanft Byrne Raboy Abrams Partners with resignation of Don Slater as executive vice president and co-creative director; Adam Hanft, J Dixon Byrne, Doug Raboy and Heni Abrams will be managing partners; Allan Cohen, John Prenderast, Martin Rowe and Linda Soro are named partners (S)

headline: Exodus a Threat to Relief for Iraqi Kurds
abstract: Local employees of United States military and relief agencies prepare to leave northern Iraq; aid workers who will remain behind warn that their exodus will severely disrupt their efforts; aid workers, including Americans, Iraqi Kurds and Europeans, contend United States is exaggerating threat that Iraqi Govt poses to Kurdish region (M)

headline: Profits Rise 12.8% At Schwarz Pharma
abstract: Schwarz Pharma AG says its first-half pretax profit rose 12.8 percent, to $64.25 million, from last year (S)

headline: Patents
abstract: CPAD Technologies has patented apparatus that detects presence of explosives by vacuuming up invisible vapors and particles on outer surfaces of suitcase and analyzing their chemical content; Prof William Bertozzi patents high-intensity X-ray method of checking cargo containers for explosives; Peter W Esgro patents rural mailbox that with pull, telescopes outward from its post for ease of mail retrieval (M)

headline: Europeans Agonize Over the Mall
abstract: Powerful coalition in Western Europe is coming together to stem spread of shopping malls--coalition that includes small-store owners facing extinction, politicians fearful for the future of town centers, and environmentalists disgusted with the way automobiles chew up the landscape; while American-style suburban malls, like the Marques Avenue outlet in Troyes, France, southeast of Paris, are popular in Western Europe, national governments are bowing to anti-development pressure with laws aimed at curbing their construction; situation in Great Britain, France, Italy and Germany discussed; tables; photos (L)

headline: General Motors Gets Deadline For a Strike By Canadians
abstract: Canadian Automobile Workers union again threatens to strike General Motors unless GM drops plans to sell factories; threat is latest in series of coordinated moves by union and United Automobile Workers to derail GM's plans to slim down; Canadian union president Basil E Hargrove comments, interview (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Docks de France Agrees To Takeover by Auchan
abstract: The French retailer Docks de France S.A. succumbed yesterday to a sweetened takeover offer worth nearly $4 billion from a rival, Auchan S.A., after the company raised the offer price to 1,270 francs a share from 1,250. The bid values Docks at 19.4 billion francs ($3.84 billion).         The merger would create the fourth-largest French retailer, with sales of 117 billion francs ($23 billion). Docks and Auchan both operate hypermarkets, huge stores that sell everything from vegetables to household goods. (Reuters)

headline: Cable Concern Plans a Fight Against Nynex
abstract: For five years, Liberty Cable and Time Warner Inc. have waged a David-and-Goliath battle for cable-television customers in Manhattan. Now, David is taking on an even greater Goliath.         The new owner of Liberty Cable, the RCN Corporation, plans to announce today  that it will offer residential telephone service in New York City -- challenging the Nynex Corporation. Under the RCN brand name, the company also plans to offer expanded cable service and access to the Internet.

headline: Mansura Journal;Of College Girls Betrayed and Vile Chewing Gum
abstract: If it is true, as it is whispered here, that certain young women in this provincial capital have let their moral standards lapse, then no one wants to believe they fell prey to hormones alone. No, the cause -- the curse, it is said -- was ordinary-looking chewing gum laced with aphrodisiacs capable of transporting the most innocent female into a sexual frenzy.         The potion's source, it is firmly believed here, is an Israel bent on corrupting pure Egyptian youth.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MICROSOFT TO CONTINUE BUYING BACK ITS SHARES
abstract: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it planned to continue its stock repurchase program in the 1997 fiscal year. Microsoft repurchased about 13.5 million shares for $1.38 billion in the fiscal year that ended last Sunday. Microsoft, which is based in Redmond, Wash., said the number of shares to be acquired in the fiscal year 1997 hinged on the level of employee stock option exercises, the price of shares of Microsoft and market conditions. Microsoft's stock was down 50 cents yesterday, to $121.125 a share on the Nasdaq stock market.

headline: Dollar Gains as Fears Fade About Japanese Rate Increase
abstract: Dollar surges against Japanese yen (M)

headline: Chaos in Burundi Could Sow Misery Next Door
abstract: When Burundi's divided Government recently asked neighboring countries to send troops to help quell ethnic violence, it represented the first breakthrough in a deadly three-year stalemate between Hutu and Tutsi political leaders.         In response to Burundi's call, six heads of state met last month and agreed to create a security force from neighboring countries to protect officials, civil servants, public institutions and communications centers in the country, which is led by a Tutsi Prime Minister and a Hutu President.

headline: No Big Shifts By Magellan's New Manager
abstract: Market Place column notes Robert E Stansky has surprised Wall Street in first month as manager of Fidelity Investments' Magellan fund, nation's biggest mutual fund, by making no major portfolio changes; drop in fund's net asset value in month has exceeded drop in Standard & Poor's 500 index (M)

headline: Seeing Ad Dollars, C-Net Multiplies Web Sites
abstract: C-Net, based in San Francisco, is among most nimble of Internet companies scrambling to build brand names for the next century; it has already started services called TV.Com, Search.Com and Shareware.Com; in addition to catchy Web addresses, it has opened smaller sites instead of building one huge one; advertisers can be sold space on more than one site, and visitors are likely to spend more time with C-Net if they can bounce from site to site; C-Net went public in July, set on becoming first publishing empire with no paper products except stock certificates; photo (M)

headline: Bond Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week will include today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two- and five-year notes being auctioned Wednesday and Thursday.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.13 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was 5.26 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.23 percent, and the five-year note at 6.61 percent.

headline: KOHLBERG PLANS STAKE IN SPALDING AND EVENFLO
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co says it has agreed to buy majority stake in Spalding and Evenflo Cos, part of Cisneros Group; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Armenian Troops Move In, and Election Protest Turns Violent
abstract: Armenian soldiers fire weapons in air and beat dozens of people to disperse tens of thousands who had gathered in front of Parliament to protest presidential election of Levon Ter-Petrossian, which was marred by fraud (M)

headline: A New Tier Of Executives At Goldman
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Co reportedly plans to create managing director posts as part of a continuing reorganization; new rank would confer status and probably improved compensation for some younger and ambitious executives, without substantially expanding partnership (M)

headline: 3DO SHARES FALL ANOTHER 15% AFTER ANALYST CUTS RATING
abstract: 3DO Co shares fall another 15 percent (S)

headline: In the campaign for its new sports utility vehicle, Ford its traveling the young and haughty road.
abstract: Ford Motor Co advertising drive uses old-fashioned snob appeal in outdoorsy setting to sell firm's Expedition sports utility vehicle; ads, like vehicle itself, are oversized and bold (M)

headline: Populist's Victory in Ecuador Worries the Elite
abstract: Six years ago, as Abdala Bucaram waited out charges of corruption by fleeing  to Panama, it was Jaime Nebot, a political rival and leader of the Social Christians, who pushed for Mr. Bucaram's pardon, confident that the one-time Mayor of this city would wither at the polls.         A court pardoned Mr. Bucaram in 1990, and two weeks ago, he became Ecuador's  new President. The loser in the election? Jaime Nebot.

headline: Economic Recovery Seen as Weak in Japan
abstract: Bank of Japan's quarterly survey of business sentiment signals that nation's economic recovery has been weaker than expected, indicating that central bank is not likely to raise interest rates soon (M)

headline: SPRINT PLANS SALES THROUGH RADIO SHACK
abstract: Sprint Corp and its Sprint Spectrum wireless venture will sell range of products from cellular and paging services to traditional local and long-distance calling through Sprint stores to be set up inside Tandy Corp's Radio Shack stores (S)

headline: E-Mail, Voice Mail, Telephone, Whatever
abstract: PHoto of visitors to Macworld convention in Boston

headline: French Economy Slipped 0.4% in Second Quarter
abstract: France's economy shrank four-tenths of 1 percent in second quarter from first; consumer spending fell 1 percent in second quarter after rising 2.5 percent in the first (S)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;MCA in $2.5 Billion Sale of Shows to German TV
abstract: MCA Inc. said today that it was selling the German rights to its television shows and movies in two long-term agreements that MCA valued at about $2.5 billion.         In one 10-year, $1.5 billion contract, MCA sold to RTL, Germany's largest television network in terms of viewers, the broadcast rights to shows like "Miami Vice" and "The Rockford Files" and Universal Pictures films like "Apollo  13" and "Out of Africa."

headline: SAUDIS OFFER U.S. FULL COOPERATION IN BOMBING INQUIRY
abstract: The Defense Department said today that King Fahd of Saudi Arabia had pledged  "complete cooperation" in the investigation of the bomb attack that killed 19 American servicemen last week, even as it became clear that the Saudis did not cooperate fully with the United States after a bombing last year that killed five Americans.         After receiving the pledge from the ailing King and his senior advisers during a meeting in the western Saudi city of Jidda, Defense Secretary William J. Perry confirmed that the Saudi Government had refused earlier this year to allow the Pentagon to expand the security perimeter around the Khobar Towers apartment complex in Dhahran, site of the bombing on Tuesday.

headline: Nicaragua Said to Raise Vote Hurdles for Ex-Rebels
abstract: Nearly 300,000 Nicaraguan peasants rode on mules, trudged down mountain trails and forded rivers in recent weeks to register to vote.         They were farmers from Nicaragua's most inhospitable regions, signing up to cast ballots in the presidential election scheduled for Oct. 20 even though many found the registration drive so confusing that they suspected it was intended to discourage them.

headline: Honda, the Newest Name in Tables and Chairs
abstract: Japanese consumers may soon be able to buy Honda housewares as well as cars.          The Honda Motor Company, Japan's fourth-biggest car maker, said today that it had set up a new venture to recycle plastic bits left over from car production to make consumer items like tables and chairs and simulated wood flooring.

headline: Swedish Bank Plans A Stock Buyback
abstract: Nordbanken AB, Sweden's fourth-largest bank by assets, says it wants to buy back shares worth about $758 million, or between 15 percent and 18 percent of outstanding shares, to raise its share value before possible acquisitions (S)

headline: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
abstract: Stocks were higher here today, after Monday's selloff. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 158.06 points, or three-quarters of 1 percent, at 21,163.69. On Monday, the Nikkei fell 470.66 points.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Figure in Amazon Killing Captured After 3 Years
abstract: The cattle rancher who ordered the slaying of an activist defending the Amazon rain forest in 1988 has been arrested after more than three years as a fugitive. The rancher, Darly Alves da Silva, was arrested on Sunday near the remote Amazon town of Medicilandia, about 1,250 miles north of Sao Paulo, federal police officials said today.         Mr. da Silva was sentenced in December 1990 to 19 years in jail for ordering  the slaying of Chico Mendes, a rubber tapper and union leader who came to symbolize efforts to prevent exploitation of the Amazon rain forest. Mr. da Silva's son, Darci Alves Pereira, was convicted of carrying out the shooting and received the same sentence.

headline: Ex-S.E.C. Chief's New Firm
abstract: Richard C Breeden, former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, to form own firm, Richard C Breeden & Co (S)

headline: The Madison Avenue consolidation continues, with Lowe consuming a small New York agency.
abstract: Advertising column focuses on Goldsmith/Jeffrey Advertising, latest independent agency to be absorbed into far larger one, Loew & Partners/SMS; both Robert L Jeffrey and Gary L Goldsmith are taking powerful senior positions with Loew Partners; Jeffrey says he looks forward to working for bigger accounts with bigger resources (M)

headline: For Mutual Funds, New Political Muscle
abstract: Investment Company Institute, chief trade group for mutual fund industry, has become one of Wall Street's most powerful forces in Washington, working behind the scenes to shape legislation and doling out big campaign contributions to members of Congress; organization, which has grown with huge growth in mutual fund assets, is preparing for major changes in Social Security law, including possible diversion of some money into private-sector investments; group's effectiveness stems from early decision to accept, and help shape, Federal oversight, and avoidance of major scandals; political action committee's contributions to key members of Congress detailed; list; graph (M)

headline: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA SETS AN ACQUISITION
abstract: Royal Bank of Canada's brokerage unit, RBC Dominion Securities Inc, agrees to acquire a rival, Richardson Greenshields of Canada Ltd for $480 million (Canadian), or $350 million (SS)û

headline: Chief's Strategy for an Ailing Cruse Line
abstract: Cunard Line chief executive Peter Ward seeks to turn around sixth-largest cruise ship line, restoring profitability, reversing pattern of rudderless management and winning confidence of new owners; pursues small luxury end of market with aging fleet, risky strategy at time when rivals offer deep discounts on glitzy ships to attract middle-income customers; he comments, interview; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Hong Kong Journal;Remnants of Chiang's Army Are Routed Again
abstract: Along the pathway that tumbles down the hill between banyan and red pine trees, metal door after wood plank door is pasted with white notices in a tidy bureaucratic prose that heralds the death of one of Hong Kong's oldest distinct  communities.         "I hereby give you notice to quit and deliver up possession of the premises known as Cottage No. 23, Section 2, Tiu Keng Leng Cottage Area," a typewritten notice reads.

headline: Telemarketing: What Happens If the Phones Stop Ringing?
abstract: Thomas O'Brien letter on downside risks of telemarketing companies

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Prodigy Ends Account With Cliff Freeman
abstract: The Prodigy Services Company, the computer on-line service, and the Cliff Freeman & Partners unit of Cordiant P.L.C. in New York unexpectedly said yesterday that they had parted company after a year because of "different goals." Billings were estimated at $10 million.         The decision came two months after Prodigy was sold by the I.B.M. Corporation and Sears, Roebuck & Company to International Wireless and Groupo Carso.

headline: Conde Nast Makes Executive Changes
abstract: Conde Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications in New York makes several executive changes (S)

headline: I.B.M. Joining With Xylan to Make Switches
abstract: Struggling to tap into the fast-growing market for networking hardware, I.B.M. plans to announce today that it has entered into a broad alliance with the Xylan Corporation, a network switch maker that was one of the hottest initial public offerings this year.         Under the terms of the agreement, I.B.M. agreed to buy $30 million worth of switches made by Xylan over the next eight months, giving a huge lift to Xylan's revenues, which were about $51 million in the first half of this year.

headline: AON AGREES TO MAKE 2 ACQUISITIONS
abstract: Aon Corp to buy HFS Inc's ERA Home Warranty unit; will also buy Wesselhoeft Ahlers & Schues OHG (S)

headline: Treasury Securities Fall in Price
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities tumble; 30-year bond drops 22/32, to price of 96 15/32; yield rises to 7.03 percent, from 6.98 percent; graph (L)

headline: Roche and Bayer Are Said to Form Joint Venture
abstract: Bayer AG and Roche Holdings Ltd are said to form joint venture in United States to sell Roche's Aleve analgesic and several other nonprescription drugs; arrangement will give Roche access to Bayer's powerful sales force and customer relationships in constant struggle for shelf space in stores; Roche assumed full ownership from Aleve from Procter & Gamble Co in June (M)

headline: AVANT BUYING ANAGRAM FOR $76 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: Avant Corp says it has agreed to buy Anagram Inc for $76 million in stock (S)

abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.31   5.22   5.72        3-MO.
