headline: New Delhi Sets Dates for State Elections in Battle-Torn Kashmir
abstract: Indian Govt sets September for elections in part of Kashmir under its control; move is decisive step toward carrying out its formula for peace in territory, India's only state with Muslim majority, that has been scene of convulsive war between Indian forces and separatist Muslim guerrillas (M)

headline: Casino Looks at Iowa
abstract: Casino America Inc says it will build $70 million casino on Raccoon River near Des Moines, Iowa, if Dallas County voters approve riverboat gambling; seeks to get gambling referendum on ballot (S)

headline: People
abstract: Robert C. Erwin was named to the new position of president of GTFH Advertising, New York, a unit of Grey Advertising. He had been executive vice president and chief operating officer at Robert A. Becker/Euro RSCG, New York, a unit of Havas Advertising.    Carol Evans was named executive vice president and publisher at Chief Executive magazine, New York, a publication of Chief Executive Group. She succeeds Darcy Donaldson, who left to join Stagebill magazine, New York, as publisher, succeeding Ms. Evans, who had also been president. Stagebill is owned by the K-III Communications Corp.

headline: Dresdner Bank Posts Earnings Rise
abstract: Dresdner Bank AG reports operating earnings rose 44 percent in first half to 1.42 billion marks ($959.5 million), up from 984 million marks in 1995 period (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Malaysian Company Plans a Takeover
abstract: Konsortium Perkapalan, a Malaysian transport company, has offered $226.6 million for Pacific Basin Bulk Shipping Ltd. of Bermuda. Konsortium, which is controlled by a son of the Malaysian Prime Minister, is offering $16.22 for each Pacific Basin common share. Holders of Pacific Basin warrants will get 97 cents  a warrant after the acquisition.          Konsortium is controlled by Mirzan Mahathir, the oldest son of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. Pacific Basin's largest shareholder is Maritime Belge S.A., which has a stake of about 20 percent.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Clinton Officials Back Broadcasters On Advanced TV
abstract: Technology advisers in the Clinton Administration have sided with broadcasters and consumer electronics makers and against major computer companies, strongly endorsing the broadcasters' preferred technology format as the standard for the next generation of television.         In letters to Reed E. Hundt, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, the White House's Office of Science and Technology Policy and a senior Commerce Department technology expert argued for quick adoption of the standard favored by the so-called "grand alliance" of broadcasters and manufacturers. It is believed to be the first time the Administration has taken  a position on the proposed digital television standard.

headline: Stocks Higher in Japan
abstract: Stocks were trading higher here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 56.07 points, or about a quarter of a percent, at 21,180.97. On Friday, the Nikkei closed up 241.06 points.

headline: Technology
abstract: HUNDREDS of disputes are in progress over who owns valuable business domain names on the Internet -- those ubiquitous "acme.com" identifiers for E-mail addresses and corporate Web sites. This long-brewing controversy has pitted owners of domain names afraid of losing their names against trademark owners who contend that their marks are being compromised. And both sides now are clamoring for someone to do something. Someone, in this case, is Internic, an organization serving as the registry for the most recognized categories of Internet domains: .com, for commercial enterprises; .edu, for educational institutions; .net, for organizations that run networks, and .org, for research and nonprofit groups. Internic has registered some 400,000 names in these domains, first-come, first-served, since it was founded in 1993 through an arrangement with the federally backed National Science Foundation.          Last year Internic began charging registrants $50 a year for each name registered. Previously, Internet name disputes were rare and, invariably, had been settled cooperatively. But as commercial interest in the Internet increased, domain-name speculators and trademark lawyers descended like locusts. Speculators staked out names of well-known companies and products and began selling them back to the companies themselves. Trademark holders began sending threats to holders of domain names that came close to, or matched, their trademarks. If the domain holders didn't relinquish, the trademark owners often  would sue -- even if the trademark was for Acme Plumbing, say, and the registered name holder's business, Acme Bakery, was unrelated. And if threats didn't work, many trademark holders were also happy to threaten Internic. "Their lawyers say, 'We'll sue everyone, including you,' " said Grant  Clark, corporate counsel for the Science Applications International Corporation, which owns Internic and the company that operates it, Network Solutions Inc. According to Internic, such threats have forced it to assume that it will be sued in such circumstances -- despite the fact that Internic lawyers say it has  never performed, nor does it intend to, any kind of trademark search or verification before issuing a domain name. To deflect some of its perceived liability, Internic adopted a name-dispute policy that appears to favor trademark holders. The policy so infuriated holders of existing domain names that the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a public policy group, is actively seeking pro bono counsel to file a class action suit against both Network Solutions Inc. and the Federal Government. It's not clear how much of an effect such a suit might have. Although Internic's name registry was formed with the blessing of the National Science Foundation, Internic has no known legal authority. It was given its responsibility by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority, a clearinghouse chartered by the influential Internet Society and the Federal Network Council to coordinate how domain names are linked to the physical locations of computers on the global network. In any event, one worrisome feature for groups like the Electronic Frontier Foundation is a contract that Internic requires domain-name applicants to sign.  The contract says they must agree not to sue Internic over a name dispute. And in the event of a dispute, they must post a bond to cover Internic's legal fees. The amount of the bond, according to a lawyer for Network Solutions, could be little or nothing if the company is not named in the suit, though if the company is named, it would be higher. Another concern is that Internic overwhelmingly favors trademark owners over those with registered domain names. A trademark holder must simply inform Internic of a registered trademark that predates the registration of an Internet domain name and contend that the duplication is causing confusion or harm. These two conditions are sufficient grounds for Internic to start a dispute proceeding against the existing holder of the domain name. At the end of 30 days, the name "goes dark," or is taken off the network pending an agreement between the name holder and the trademark owner. Going dark, of course, could put a network provider, or anyone who conducts business on the Internet, out of business overnight. One such unresolved dispute involves the domain name "sylvan.com," registered with Internic by Kayvan Sylvan, a software consultant. His domain name is being  challenged by Sylvan Learning Systems Inc., which sells franchised educational services. If Mr. Sylvan and the company are unable to settle the dispute in the allotted time, Internic will take the "sylvan.com" address off the Internet until the matter is finally resolved. Internic contends that its only alternative would be the dubious one of waiting for Sylvan Learning to slap it with a lawsuit for contributing to a trademark infringement. The logical solution to this industry problem would be to indemnify Internic from trademark liability so that name disputes could be settled directly between the parties involved, through existing trademark law. Such legal protection would have to come from the Federal Communications Commission or from Congress.  Mr. Clark, the lawyer for Internic's corporate parent, said he would be "ecstatic" if Congress granted his organization immunity from lawsuits accusing  it of contributing to trademark infringement. "It would put an end to the need for the dispute policy," he said. Even Internic's biggest detractors agree. By whatever means, "Internic needs to  get out of the business of deciding who will have their domain name taken away," says Carl Oppedahl, a lawyer who had sued Internic on behalf of clients who wanted to challenge its dispute policy. "If a trademark owner doesn't like a domain name, it should go to the courts. Existing trademark law applies to the Internet, just like it does to toothpaste brands in stores."

headline: European Beachhead For Korean Ambition
abstract: Oceans away from his home base, in a dark cavernous factory here covered with decades of grime left by Communist neglect, the South Korean magnate and chairman of the Daewoo Group, Kim Woo Choong, sees the future. He walks the aisles of antiquated metal pressing machines, unruffled by the thunderous noise  or the disheveled Polish auto workers peering at their new boss.         "I can see a change in attitude already," said the silver-haired Mr. Kim, who is betting big on his ability to transform easygoing Polish job habits into crisp Korean style.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Interest Rates Cut by Canada
abstract: The Bank of Canada cut key short-term interest rates today, citing a sluggish economy and an inflation rate near the bottom of the central bank's target range.         The cut, which surprised many investors, followed the release today of weaker-than-expected retail sales and inflation data.

headline: Scalpers, Weather and Luck Mar Carrier's Visit to Dublin
abstract: The Irish, who have historically turned their backs to the surrounding sea, watching as the Vikings and other invaders created all the island's major ports, have been coming to Dublin Bay by the tens of thousands in recent days to see the largest warship ever to drop anchor in these waters.         The aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy arrived here Tuesday on a good-will mission arranged by Jean Kennedy Smith, Ambassador to Ireland, to mark Independence Day.

headline: Has Esquire Gone Out of Style?
abstract: Edward Kosner would probably miss his office. The blond-wood rolling desk chairs that glide noiselessly up to the glass coffee table. The ample display space for his collection of classic model cars, like the 1941 Lincoln Continental and the 1947 Chrysler Town & Country. The airy privacy that allows him to lean back on his black leather couch and listen to tapes of Portuguese love songs undisturbed.         Yet, over the last few months, people in the magazine business, concerned about Esquire's thinning spine and declining circulation, have been murmuring that Mr. Kosner may not be editor in chief of Esquire magazine much longer, and  that Hearst Magazines is shopping Esquire around.

headline: Desperate Kurds Find No Way Out of Iraq
abstract: United States has decided to help only its current Kurdish employees to escape from northern Iraq; Kurds who worked for Western agencies in the past feel abandoned and fearful of what will happen to them if Saddam Hussein and his forces return to north; Iraqi Government has warned that promised amnesty for Kurds will not apply to those who worked for foreigners, especially the Americans; map (M)

headline: Investment Firms Talk Of Merging
abstract: LGT Asset Management, a mutual fund and private banking unit of the Liechtenstein Global Trust, said yesterday that it was in talks to acquire Chancellor Capital Management, a New York-based institutional investment management firm.         Chancellor said it welcomed the overtures and hoped to announce an agreement  soon. The acquisition talks were first reported yesterday in The New York Post.

headline: North Koreans Slip Into South In Submarine
abstract: Group of North Korean troops reportedly lands on South Korean beach, entering country and setting off vast manhunt (S)

headline: Saudi Bombing Sets Off Alarm at Base in Turkey
abstract: It is more than a thousand miles from Incirlik to Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, but  the 3,700 American troops based here felt shock waves from the truck bomb that killed 19 of their comrades in Dhahran last week.         The moment that news of the blast reached Incirlik, the senior American commander here, Col. John Barry, ordered all troops and families to stay on the  base. Before lifting the order two days later, he increased patrols around the base perimeter, closed all entrances except the main gate and imposed a more rigorous system of identity checks. He also sent bomb-sniffing dogs into almost  every edifice under his control and onto many of the three-dozen high-powered jet fighters here.

headline: Short Interest Up on Nasdaq
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers reports open positions of short sales on Nasdaq rose 6.4 percent in month ended Aug 15; uncovered short positions totaled 1.17 billion shares, up from 1.10 billion in previous month; tables (L)

headline: DIARY
abstract: Bob Dole and Jack Kemp, campaigning in New Jersey, receive dubious response to Republican tax-cut proposal (S)

headline: Pope, in Hungary, Causes Renewed Speculation About His Health
abstract: Pope John-Paul II sometimes seems withdrawn and passive during two-day visit to Hungary, prompting new concerns about his health (S)

headline: MGM's Tortured Tale, Part III: Kerkorian Gets Studio for $1.3 Billion
abstract: PARIS—  A storybook ending it is not. But the $1.3 billion sale of the legendary Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer by an ailing French state bank to a group led by one of America's most eccentric billionaire investors is certainly a twist worthy of Tinsel Town.

headline: Visa Expands Ties With Omnicom Unit
abstract: Visa International expands its relationship with its US agency of record, the BBDO New York unit of the Omnicom Group, by awarding that shop the assignment to create projects aimed at presenting a unified world image for Visa brand (S)

headline: DIARY: THE OLYMPICS;What Cashless Society?
abstract: For all the talk of microchips, Web sites, hand-recognition systems and other technology, the arrival of the Olympic Games also means a festival of cash. Just to make sure that visitors have enough in hand to pay for all the liquids that doctors recommend be consumed in the Atlanta climate -- as well as the huge variety of official Olympic merchandise -- rolling automatic teller machines are being provided.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Keds Corp., Lexington, Mass., a unit of the Stride Rite Corp., to Foote, Cone & Belding, San Francisco, a unit of True North Communications, for a line of children's footwear to be introduced early next year. Billings have not been determined.    Care New England, Providence, R.I., to Leonard/Monahan Inc., Providence, as the first agency to handle advertising for the health care service system. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Olympics Stung By Technology's False Starts
abstract: Atlanta's Olympic organizers, who had promised the most technologically sophisticated Games ever, were scrambling today to repair their most basic information systems.         Two days into competition, the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games was still unable to feed competition results to its own Internet site or to news agencies, preventing newspapers, radio and television from publishing and broadcasting up-to-date results.

headline: Measuring Riches In Ideas, Not Gold
abstract: Rebecca Goldstein, writer and novelist who won $285,000 MacArthur 'genius' award, comments on her philosophy about having money (S)â

headline: ANTITRUST LAWSUIT FILED AGAINST GENERAL ELECTRIC
abstract: Justice Dept's antitrust division sues General Electric Co, charging that company's licensing agreements thwart competition in market for servicing medical equipment; at issue is whether hospitals and clinics that have licensed GE's proprietary diagnostic software to service their own GE-made devices should be allowed to offer similar diagnostic services to other hospitals (S)

headline: Europe Gives Cold Shoulder To Clinton On Cuba Law
abstract: President Clinton's decision to suspend for six months that part of a law allowing lawsuits against foreign companies that use confiscated United States property in Cuba got only a lukewarm welcome today from the 15-nation European Union.         European officials warned of a new dispute with the United States over similar proposed legislation that would affect European investments in Libya and Iran.

headline: An Insider Gets Rich On Trades, And Walks
abstract: Market Watch column on Federal appeals court ruling overturning James H O'Hagan's conviction for insider trading; Minneapolis lawyer used inside information about Grand Met to purchase stock in Pillsbury, Grand Met's takeover target, and made $4 million; appeals court finds action was unethical but not illegal because it did not involve trading in actual client, Grand Met; SEC may appeal (S)

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS
abstract: Lowriders, the street-hugging cars with hydraulic lifts, have become the top export to Japan from Los Angeles's inner city, enjoying a bad-boy cachet among some young Japanese, reports the Los Angeles Times. There are about 2,000 to 3,000 lowriders cruising Japanese streets, compared with 75,000 in the United States.

headline: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;Education Technology recruits a masterful marketer of games to be its leader.
abstract: IT may be a sign of the times when the former president of Sega of America, Thomas Kalinske, leaves his job -- as he announced earlier this month -- to join a start-up called Education Technology L.L.C.         What could it mean when the master salesman of Sonic the Hedgehog takes the top job at a company set up to create and buy companies that sell educational technology?

headline: Pioneer Electronics To Offer Early Retirement
abstract: Pioneer Electronic Corp says it will offer early retirement to 650 workers in attempt to cut costs; company expects to lose $107.4 million in current fiscal year (S)

headline: 2 Reports Show More Strength in the Economy
abstract: Conference Board reports index of leading indicators rose .05 percent, June, to record 102.9, after rising revised 0.2 percent in May; graph; table; Commerce Department reports number of homes on which construction was completed in June rose 0.4 percent to seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.398 million, up from revised 1.392 million in May (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Interpolis Insurance, Amsterdam, to McCann-Erickson Amsterdam, a unit of the Interpublic, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $15 million.    Children's National Medical Center, Washington, to Eisner & Associates, Baltimore, as its first agency of record. Billings were estimated at $1 million.    Ricomm Systems Inc., Marlton, N.J., to Zinbarg & Stone, Paramus, N.J., as the first agency of record for the software company. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

headline: Bond Prices Slip as Traders Wait on Fed
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities dip slightly in quiet session, as market participants await Federal Reserve meeting on interest rates; graph (M)

headline: Jordan Again Leads Athlete-Endorsers
abstract: Basketball star Michael Jordan, for sixth consecutive year, tops list of 'most wanted' athletes in terms of product endorsements, which is compiled annually by The Sports Marketing Letter, a newsletter based in Westport, Conn; newsletter reports Jordan will earn $38 million in endorsements from August 1996 through July 1997, increase of $3 million from corresponding period a year earlier (S)

headline: Be, a novel start-up, can offer software to Apple beyond conventional systems.
abstract: Technology column describes how Jean-Louis Gassee and his Be Inc could offer Apple Computer Inc relatively risk-free bridge between its tarnished past and potentially brighter future; Be Inc has developed software that is first operating system to be designed from scratch with technique called object-oriented programming, which allows key modules of software code to be used and reused as basic building blocks of the system; Apple's engineers worked to help Gassee's fledgling company move Be software to Power Macintosh; photo (M)

headline: P.L.O. Forces Said to Have Tortured Prisoner
abstract: A Palestinian prisoner in a West Bank jail was beaten by Palestinian P.L.O. security forces and is brain dead, a human rights group said today.         The Jerusalem-based group, Land and Water Establishment, said in a statement  that Mahmoud Jumayal, 26, was on life-support in a hospital in the West Bank town of Ramallah.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: G.M. Presents Offer In Labor Negotiations  General Motors made its first comprehensive contract offer to the United Automobile Workers union, as national labor contract negotiations continued at all three Detroit auto makers.    G.M. officials did not release details of their offer. But by making a specific proposal now, G.M. is able to stake out its position before the U.A.W. reaches a deal with Ford, which the union has chosen as its negotiating target to set a pattern for the industry. $(Page D2.$)    Productivity Rose in 2d Quarter  Companies operated more cheaply and efficiently during the second quarter than first reported, largely because wage costs were not rising as rapidly as estimated. A revised report showed that productivity actually rose, instead of falling slightly. $(D2.$)    Demand Grows For Chips  Demand for computer chips rose slightly last month, but was still down from last year. The Semiconductor Industry Association's book-to-bill ratio, which measures new orders against shipments, rose to 0.90 in August from a revised 0.86 in July. $(D4.$)    2 Energy Companies in Venture  The Coastal Corporation and Westcoast Energy said they would combine their natural gas and electricity marketing operations, joining the industry trend toward consolidation. $(D2.$)    Reagan Aide Criticizes Tax-Cut Plan  Murray L. Weidenbaum, a major architect and defender of Ronald Reagan's 1981 tax cuts, broke ranks with Republicans and warned against the reductions proposed by Bob Dole, their Presidential nominee. $(D2.$)    Bonds Fall on Fed Officials' Words  The prices of Treasury securities sagged after comments by Federal Reserve officials led to heightened anxiety over the likelihood of the Fed's increasing interest rates. The yield of the 30-year Treasury bond climbed to 7.11 percent from 7.07. $(D16.$)    The dollar hit its highest levels in nearly two months against the German mark and the Japanese yen, rising on continued expectations of increased American interest rates. $(D13.$)    Stocks were mixed. The Dow industrials fell, 6.66 points, to 5,727.18, but broader indexes were mostly higher. The Nasdaq composite rose 0.72 point, to 1,149.43. $(D6.$)    Village Voice Editor Resigns  Karen Durbin, the editor of The Village Voice, said she was resigning over differences with the weekly newspaper's publisher. Neither Ms. Durbin nor the publisher, David Schneiderman, would explain their differences. $(B3.$)    Out of the Fire, Into the Frying Pan  A growing number of people are trading the corporate world for the kitchen, seeking creative fulfillment, satisfaction in their work, greater mobility and, if they start their own businesses, control over their lives. Though these people may make considerable financial sacrifices, jobs are plentiful. In the next 10 years, restaurants and hotels are expected to need 500,000 more chefs, cooks and other kitchen workers. $(C1.$)    Slowdown Seen in Business Travel  Business travel this fall will drop to its lowest level in at least five years, the Travel Industry Association of America forecasts. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. $(D5.$)    Soros Backs Change in Drug Policy  George Soros, the billionaire investor, has made personal donations of nearly $500,000 to two ground-breaking state ballot initiatives, in California and Arizona, that would legalize the medical use of marijuana. $(A12.$)

headline: Netanyahu and Arafat, and the Political Burdens of Their Stubbornness
abstract: News analysis of deadly clashes between Israeli soldiers and Palestinian demonstrators and police; questions whether Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu or Yasir Arafat are still in control, as their elaborate brinksmanship goes awry and rock-throwing escalates to full-scale gunfights across West Bank and Gaza; Arafat's hesitation to meet with Netanyahu now reflects expectation of more violence when huge crowds of Palestinians gather for funerals of their new 'martyrs' and prayers at mosques; Netanyahu is under intense pressure to make some substantive gesture, most obvious being to close exit of pedestrian tunnel to Western Wall in Jerusalem, whose opening set off rioting; Israeli aide warns that doing so would mean bowing to violence (S)

headline: Effort in U.N. To Salvage Test-Ban Pact
abstract: Australia, taking the lead in international campaign to keep alive the hope of a nuclear test-ban treaty, asks that special session of United Nations General Assembly be convened on Sept 9 to act on agreement; plan, which circumvents formal conference procedure, could allow treaty to be opened for signing if it passes General Assembly (S)

headline: PFIZER PLANS TO BUY BACK UP TO $2 BILLION OF STOCK
abstract: Pfizer Inc says it will buy back as much as $2 billion of common stock in next two years (S)

headline: Assassin, in Appeal, Calls Rabin a Traitor
abstract: The convicted killer of the Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin told the country's Supreme Court today that the man he shot was a traitor, while his lawyers suggested that a second gunman had committed the murder.         Yigal Amir, the 26-year-old religious Jew who killed Mr. Rabin in November in an effort to halt the steps toward peace between Israel and the Palestinians, asked the three-judge court to overturn his murder conviction but expressed no remorse.

headline: S.& L.'s Had Record Profits in 2d Quarter
abstract: Office of Thrift Supervision reports United States savings and loan industry earned record $1.89 billion in second quarter, industry's best profit margin in 37 years (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MATTEL EXPECTS DISAPPOINTING SALES AND EARNINGS
abstract: The toy maker Mattel Inc. said yesterday that its sales and net income for the second quarter would be about the same as last year, meaning that they would fall short of expectations. Mattel, which makes the Barbie doll, said, however,  that it still expected an increase of at least 15 percent in its earnings for the year. The stock of Mattel fell by $3.125 a share, to $26, on the New York Stock Exchange. In the second quarter of last year, the company, which is based in El Segundo, Calif., reported a profit of $67.5 million, or 24 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by First Call were expecting earnings of around 26 cents a share in the latest quarter. A spokesman for Mattel declined to comment  on reasons for the disappointing results.

headline: Final U.S. Approval for Big Rail Merger
abstract: Federal Surface Transportation Board gives final regulatory approval to Union Pacific Corp's proposed $5.4 billion acquisition of Southern Pacific Rail Corp (S)

headline: Retailers Had Mixed Results During August
abstract: Retailers report mixed results during August; Goldman, Sachs retail composite index gains 3.7 percent in August, compared with nine-tenths of 1 percent in August 1995; many in industry note August's declining role in back-to-school season; there is inconsistency in nearly every segment, an indication that same-store sales are increasingly becoming difficult way to measure how groups or even individual retailers are doing; this is dismaying to Wall Street, where favorite quality in retailer is consistency; graph (M)

headline: Murdoch and Germany's Kirch Take Aim at a $5 Billion Marke : 2 Media Giants Seal European TV Alliance
abstract: PARIS—  Rupert Murdoch and Leo Kirch, two of the world's most potent media tycoons, joined forces on Monday in a surprise alliance that will try to dominate Europe's biggest pay-television market.

headline: King's Serial Thriller Rules Best-Seller Lists
abstract: Short books in Stephen King's 6-part series The Green Mile are monopolizing number of slots on best-seller lists, hurting chances and sales of rival books; photos (M)

headline: Technology: CONNECTIONS;'Independence Day' is the least of it; alien encounters and invasions are everywhere.
abstract: HAVE you any unusual scars or marks? Ever awakened at night startled? Have you experienced a self-esteem problem or had the feeling of being watched? Any unusual nose bleeds? Or compulsive or addictive behavior? Have you ever been afraid of your closet? Or heard strange humming or pulsing sounds? Do you have a difficult time trusting other people, especially authority figures?         If so, neurosis may be the least of your problems. According to one site on the World Wide Web, (http:// www.cybergate.com/ufonline/ 52questi.htm) you may have had an alien encounter.

headline: TCI Is Seeking Music Company
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc, nation's largest cable company, has offered to buy digital music programmer DMX Inc through new corporation to be formed by TCI; TCI already owns about 45 percent of DMX's shares outstanding (S)

headline: France Moves to Rescue Troubled Lender
abstract: A year after rescuing one troubled lender, the French Government moved today  to salvage another, allowing shareholders of Credit Foncier de France S.A. to sell their battered stock at more than twice the market price.         Under the plan, the state-run Caisse des Depots Consignations will pay 70 francs a share for Credit Foncier, an offer that values Foncier at $527 million.

headline: A new campaign is trying to restore Sharper Image's edge.
abstract: Advertising column describes new advertising campaign for Sharper Image, catalogue and retail merchant that flourished in 1980's by purveying high-priced toys for the status-conscious; consumer perception turned dull in 1990's, and financial performance has suffered; Goodby, Silverstein & Partners has been hired to create campaign to change attitudes about Sharper Image products; advertising shop has history of using humor to help alter attitudes about products perceived as outdated; photo (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: First Chicago NBD Corp appoints William Elliott 3d as its top technology officer (S)

headline: Technology's Growth Is a Challenge to Systems Managers
abstract: Corporate computer specialists are running as fast as they can -- and it is still not fast enough. And the way Frank Calabrese sees it, the World Wide Web is the culprit.         The information technology manager at the Bose Corporation is responsible for choosing the computers and software used by the company. He is the one who is supposed to be the first to read the latest computer magazines. But it never happens. Who has time, when it takes all day to figure out what software his company's self-taught experts have pulled in from the World Wide Web that day?

headline: Iraqi Offensive Into Kurdish Zone Disrupts U.S. Plot to Oust Hussein
abstract: Saddam Hussein's assault on Kurdish zone in northern Iraq has undermined covert operation by Central Intelligence Agency aimed at overthrowing Iraqi leader, senior Clinton Administration officials say; handful of CIA officers recently fled country as Iraqi forces occupied Erbil; Pres Clinton expanded covert operation in Jan, signing secret order directing CIA to provide weapons, organize some military training and install some intelligence-gathering equipment for fractious groups seeking to unseat Hussein (M)

headline: ICN WINS A ROUND IN SHAREHOLDER LAWSUIT
abstract: ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc wins legal round when Federal jury rejects seven claims of securities fraud in class-action shareholder lawsuit pending since 1987 (S)

headline: Flaw Said to Be Found in Microsoft's Browser
abstract: Group of Princeton University computer researchers say that they found potentially serious computer flaw in Microsoft Corp's Internet Explorer 3.0 Web Browser; software, which has been available on Internet from Microsoft's World Wide Web site since Aug 13, has already been downloaded by 1.3 million computer users worldwide; Microsoft says that it is correcting the problem (L)

headline: Russian Surgeons Deliver A Grim Report on Yeltsin
abstract: Russian doctors begin to paint grim picture of a seriously ill Boris N Yeltsin, in sharp contrast to statements by Kremlin about health of Russian President; Renat S Akchurin, Russian surgeon who is to operate on Yeltsin, tells ABC News that Yeltin suffered a heart attack before presidential runoff election in July, confirming longstanding rumors; these comments follow those of Sergei Mironov, head of Kremlin medical center, who states that Yeltsin has serious medical problems that may complicate his planned bypass surgery (M)

headline: Home Improvement: On TV, on Line
abstract: Do-it-yourself craze in recent years has fostered success of hardware store chains and created side industry in television programming; now, home-improvement suppliers are beginning to make their mark on the Internet, often tied to home-improvement TV programs such as This Old House; drawing (M)

headline: Schroders of Britain Posts 35% Profit Rise
abstract: British merchant bank Schroders PLC says pretax profit rose 35 percent in first half of 1996; Schroders earned 115.9 million pounds in first half, up from 85.6 million pounds in first half of 1985 (S)7

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PETCO AGREES TO ACQUIRE PET NOSH FOR $16 MILLION
abstract: Petco Animal Supplies Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Pet Nosh Inc., a closely held operator of pet food and supply stores in the New York area, for about $16.6 million in Petco stock. Petco said it would issue about 615,000 shares of its common stock to acquire all the outstanding shares of Pet  Nosh. Based on Petco's closing price of $27 on Monday, the transaction is valued at about $16.6 million. Petco shares were up 50 cents yesterday, at $27.50, in Nasdaq trading. Pet Nosh operates eight pet food and supply stores in New York,  New Jersey and Connecticut. It had sales of about $26 million for the latest 12  months. With the addition of Pet Nosh, Petco will operate 75 stores on the East  Coast and 274 stores nationally.

headline: Japan's Machine Orders Surge in Sign of Recovery
abstract: Private industry machine orders, Japan's leading indicator of capital investment, surged 13.6 percent in July from June, despite concern that economicy recovery has stalled; orders rose 22 percent from July 1995, to 1.1852 trillion yen ($10.8 billion) (S)

headline: WESTERFED BUYING SECURITY BANCORP FOR $44 MILLION
abstract: Westerfed Financial Corp says it will buy Security Bancorp for about $44 milion in cash and stock (S)

headline: ST. PAUL MAY SELL MINET GROUP INSURANCE UNIT
abstract: St Paul Cos weighs selling its Minet Group insurance brokerage unit (S)

headline: Taking In the Sites;Catching the Atlanta Games on Line
abstract: For casual fans of sports like gymnastics, basketball and track, the Olympics on network television are considered a good break from summer reruns. But for serious fans of the equestrian competition or weight lifting, NBC's 171.5 hours  of coverage can be agony -- hours wasted wearing a hole in the living room carpet waiting for a fleeting glimpse of a triumph or failure.        Though nothing is quite like seeing a dramatic race to the finish line, the Internet can at least provide quick results and analysis of even the most obscure sports -- and often with pictures. The question is which of the multitude of Olympic sites to visit.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FHP INTERNATIONAL TO SPIN OFF MEDICAL MANAGEMENT UNIT
abstract: The FHP International Corporation said yesterday that it planned to spin off  the Talbert Medical Management Corporation, its physician practice management company, to shareholders. Talbert generates more than $450 million in annual revenues and serves more than 300,000 patients. Talbert would continue to serve  FHP members after the spinoff, which is expected by the end of the year. FHP, based in Fountain Valley, Calif., said it planned to focus on its health maintenance organizations and insurance businesses. Shares of FHP rose $2.125, to $24.125, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM SELLS STAKE IN OILFIELDS TO CONGO
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had sold royalty  stakes in three oilfields in Congo to the African nation for $215 million. Occidental, which is based in Los Angeles, acquired the interests in the offshore fields for $150 million in 1993. The interests entitled Occidental to a share of the Government's portion of oil from the developments. Occidental's net production in the Congo was 9,000 barrels a day in 1995, 3.2 percent of the company's total worldwide production of 278,000 barrels.

headline: Atlanta Sees Games As a Great Sales Tool
abstract: Atlanta's politicians and business executives are parlaying 1996 Olympic Games into city's greatest corporate recruiting tool ever; their goal is to grab enough new offices, factories and corporate headquarters to complete Atlanta's transformation from regional outpost to global business nexus; hundreds of visiting executives and their spouses are being treated like royalty, with posh hotel accommodations, prime Olympic tickets and intimate chats with top Georgia politicians; results are promising: 15 companies have decided to bring Georgia another 2,000 jobs so far, and there have been many pledges from investors; Atlanta has gained so many civic improvements in preparation for Olympics that even some members of International Olympic Committee have bristled; best measure of host city's success might be long-term development and new jobs; by this standard, others have faltered; Atlanta officials are confident they will not; brief sketches of how other cities have fared after being Olympic host city; photos; charts (L)

headline: Love, Death and Cover-Up Charges in a Mexican State
abstract: Rosalinda Vargas, client of slain lawyer Norberto Flores, and his widow, Maria Mendez de Flores, continue drive in Guerrero State, Mex, against leading politician, Jose Ruben Robles, whom they say ordered slaying; Flores represented Vargas in child-support suit against Robles, who now positions self to run for governor; photo (M)5

headline: The Liberation of Dilbert
abstract: Geoffrey James article says the popularity of the comic strip Dilbert attests to the oppressiveness of the American workplace; says electronic-elite companies like Microsoft, Compaq, Sun Microsystems and Hewlett-Packard are showing the way to a more humane and satisfying way of working by honoring and encouraging employee individuality and diversity (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Olivetti Sells Shares In Acorn Computer
abstract: Olivetti S.p.A. of Italy said yesterday that it had sold 14.7 percent of Acorn Computer Group P.L.C. to Lehman Brothers Inc. on Friday. Lehman did not disclose how much it paid, but at current market prices the sale would have brought about L33.5 million ($52 million) to Olivetti, which has been posting losses.          The purchase, representing 13.25 million of the British computer company's shares, reduced Olivetti's stake in Acorn to about 31.2 percent from 78.5 percent two years ago. Lehman said it intended to resell the shares to investors.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Trump Shows a Different Profile;His New Business Style Puts the Deal Ahead of Ego
abstract: Donald J. Trump was in his element. Striding through the garish Trump Taj Mahal casino here, he was shaking hands with awestruck customers and gabbing nonstop with a reporter who was struggling to keep up, when he stopped at a table of intense poker players and, like a seasoned entertainer, stole the show.         "Hey, now here's the man you want to beat," Mr. Trump said, raising a smile from a dour man in a black shirt, black beard and black fedora whom, he later acknowledged, he had never met before. "O.K., who's winning here?"

headline: Renaissance Hotels To Bozell Agency
abstract: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA: Renaissance Hotels and Resorts subsidiary of Renaissance International Hotels Inc selects Bozell Worldwide to handle its account; billings estimated at $10 million to $12 million (S)

headline: Salvadoran War Zone to Get New Life as Park
abstract: Work is under way to convert Guazapa, site of heavy fighting in El Salvador's civil war, into tourist attraction that is to be part historic memorial, part nature preserve and part theme park; plan is backed by former guerrillas, who have been trickling back to area and seek new livelihoods, and by Government, which sees it as potential moneymaker; map; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Envoy in Bosnian City To Discuss Election Impasse
abstract: US Asst Sec of State John Kornblum arrives in divided Bosnian city of Mostar, where separatist Croats still refuse to honor results of recent municipal elections; getting Croats to honor local elections is seen as crucial for national elections in September; map (M)

headline: El Salvador's Stolen Children Face a War's Darkest Secret
abstract: El Salvador Disappeared Children's Search Assn, private investigative program, is forcing country to confront one of darkest secrets of its civil war, namely, disappearance of hundreds of children who were kidnapped by Saladoran military during attacks on peasant settlements suspected of harboring guerrillas; is reuniting children with families years after end of civil war, which lasted from 1979 to 1992; has registered, since founding in 1994, 323 alleged instances of children who were taken by Army troops or separated from families in battle zones; photo (M)

headline: Japanese Stocks Higher
abstract: Japanese stock trade higher, with Nikkei index up 36.78 points, to 20,203, at midday (S)

headline: Pacificare Will Buy FHP, Its Health Care Rival
abstract: Pacificare Health Systems Inc to buy FHP International Corp for $2.1 billion in cash and stock; table (M)

headline: Britain Says Scientists Find Disease Can Pass From Cow to Calf
abstract: British Government reports scientific experimentation shows mad-cow disease, thought to be transmitted through contaminated feed, can also be passed directly from cow to calf; findings of seven-year study could complicate efforts to eradicate disease, which has crippled Britain's $6.5-billion-a-year beef industry; explain why cows in Britain have continued to develop disease despite ban on potential contaminants in cattle feed (M)

headline: EARNING IT;On 'The Price Is Right,' Her Weight Wasn't
abstract: HOLLY HALLSTROM, a model for 19 years on "The Price Is Right," knows that television game-show models must stay slim to stay on the air.        She also said that the 14 extra pounds she put on last year -- causing her 5-feet 10-inch frame to carry 151 pounds -- gave the show the right to keep her  off the air, but only until she lost the weight.

headline: Three Minicomputer Pioneers Who Are Now Aging Quite Nicely
abstract: They are among the elders of the computer industry now, three men who, in fierce competition with each other, made the machines that ushered in the era of minicomputers -- a quaint name for hardware that when compared with today's chihuahua-sized laptops is about as "mini" as a St. Bernard.         The men who, more than anyone, created the minicomputer industry more than two decades ago were C. Gordon Bell, 62, who spent 23 years at Digital Equipment; Tom West, 56, who, after 24 years, is still with Data General, and Horace Tsiang, 54, who left Wang Laboratories in 1990 after 21 years.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BACHMAN INFORMATION COMPLETES CADRE TAKEOVER
abstract: Bachman Information Systems Inc. completed the acquisition of the closely held Cadre Technologies Inc. yesterday for $27.3 million. Under terms of the agreement, the companies formed a newly named entity called Cayenne Software Inc. Based on Bachman Information's closing price on Thursday of $6.625, the acquisition is valued at $27.3 million. The acquisition creates a company that is among the 50 largest independent software companies in the world, the companies said. Cayenne, based in Burlington, Mass., will have annual sales of about $70 million. Bachman Information develops and markets data base design software. Cadre Technologies, of Providence, R.I., makes software for personal computer networks installed by corporations.

headline: Cost-Cutting Pays Off as Kmart Reports a Profit
abstract: Kmart Corp, after 13 disappointing quarters, reports earnings in second fiscal quarter ended July 31 rose to $34 million, up from year-earlier loss of $54 million; turnaround chiefly reflects huge cost cutting by chief executive Floyd Hall; sales fell 1.5 percent; graph; table (M)

headline: Perelman Deal for King World Is Expected
abstract: After months of on-again, off-again negotiations, New World Communications Group Inc., the broadcasting company, is set to acquire King World Productions Inc., the production company that distributes "The Oprah Winfrey Show," "Jeopardy" and "Wheel of Fortune," according to several people close to the discussions.         Boards of the two companies are expected to meet as early as today to approve a deal valued at $1.48 billion in which King World shareholders would swap their shares -- which closed Friday at $39, up $2.75 -- for shares in New World, which rose 43.75 cents to close at $15.375 a share.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Target Plans to Stop Sales Of Tobacco, Citing Costs   The Target chain said it would stop selling cigarettes because it was costing too much to keep them out of the hands of minors. The decision by Target, the nation's third-largest discounter, is the first time such a large retail chain has stopped selling tobacco. But the move is expected to have little impact on the availability of cigarettes. $(Page D4.$)    The board of Philip Morris voted to increase the regular quarterly dividend, continuing a 30-year string of increases. $(D4.$)    Curbs on tobacco marketing threaten to dry up a source of funds for auto racing. $(B15.$)    Block Delays Compuserve Spinoff  H & R Block will delay the spinoff of its remaining 80 percent stake in Compuserve, citing the on-line service's recent quarterly losses and uncertainty in the industry. $(D2.$)    New Rules for Networks of Doctors  The F.T.C. and the Justice Department issued new guidelines making it easier for doctors to band together and form their own networks and other joint ventures to compete with insurance companies and health maintenance organizations. Such collaborations now often run afoul of Federal antitrust law. $(A22.$)    Hilton-Ladbroke Deal Expected  Hilton Hotels is expected to announce that it has concluded a joint marketing agreement with Ladbroke, the British company that owns the Hilton Hotel chain overseas. $(D4.$)    Drug Makers' Earnings Disappoint  Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz, which are merging to form a huge drug maker, reported earnings that disappointed analysts. $(D5.$)    Blue Chips Edge Up in Light Trading  Led by I.B.M., the Dow industrials rose a scant 1.11 points, to 5,712.38, in light trading. The Nasdaq composite rose 4.86 points, to 1,153.88, but the S.& P. 500 was off 1.59, to 664.81. $(D6.$)    Traders gave the Government's sale of five-year notes a disappointing reception, halting a one-day improvement in Treasury prices and pushing the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond up to 6.98 percent. $(D16.$)    Japan's Economy Remains Weak  A Japanese central bank survey of business sentiment signaled that economic recovery had been weaker than expected. $(D5.$)    Support for Lloyd's Plan Grows  Lloyd's of London said more of its investors had agreed to its rescue plan. $(D5.$)    Deal for Little, Brown Unit  The Dutch publishing house Wolters Kluwer plans to buy a Little, Brown unit. $(D3.$)    Ambitious Egg Farmer Or Capitalist Villain?  For decades, Jack DeCoster was an emblem of hard work and ambition in Turner, Me., a self-made multi-millionaire who started out with 125 hens, and created an agricultural empire: Five million hens producing 23 million brown and white eggs a week. But questions about working conditions have turned Turner's hometown-boy-made-good into one of capitalism's villains. $(A18.$)    Medical Journal Drug Controversy  The New England Journal of Medicine ran an editorial favorable to a new weight-loss drug that was written by authors paid by the drug's maker, Interneuron Pharmaceutical. The Journal's editor said she suspected ''a misunderstanding.'' $(D18.$)

headline: In Charleston, S.C., Saks Fifth Avenue is the latest to open in the historic district.
abstract: Saks Fifth Avenue has opened store in Charleston, SC, historic district, joining number of other major retailers that have recently opened stores in city's downtown (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FOUNDER OF INDIVIDUAL TAKES LEAVE AND SHARES FALL 37%
abstract: The shares of Individual Inc. plunged 37 percent yesterday after its founder  and chief executive, Yosi Amram, took a leave amid a debate with the company's board about the pace of acquisitions. Individual, an electronic information services company, also said two board members had resigned. Shares of the company, a provider of personalized information services, which is based in Burlington, Mass., fell $3.50, to $6, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: President of Silicon Graphics Decides to Resign
abstract: Thomas A Jermoluk resigns as Silicon Graphics Inc president and chief operating officer to become @Home Corp chairman, president and chief executive; Jermoluk succeeds Will Hearst, who will become @Home vice chairman; Silicon Graphics says chairman and chief executive Edward R McCracken will assume Jermoluk's duties; posts stronger-than-expected earnings for fiscal fourth quarter ended June 30; table (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PRECISION CASTPARTS BUYS AE TURBINE COMPONENTS
abstract: The Precision Castparts Corporation of Portland, Ore., said yesterday that it had bought the assets of AE Turbine Components Ltd. from T & N P.L.C. of Britain for $63.6 million in cash. AE Turbine makes turbine blades and castings for aircraft-engine and gas-turbine manufacturers. Precision Castparts makes castings for the aerospace, automotive and medical industries. Shares of Precision Castparts rose $1.50, to $40.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. T & N, an auto parts maker, said it sold AE Turbine because it did not fit with T &  N's other operations.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Psion Ends Talks To Acquire Amstrad
abstract: Psion P.L.C. pulled out of talks to buy Amstrad P.L.C., a British computer maker, because the sides could not agree on a price, the companies said yesterday. Psion, a consumer electronics company, said in June that it was discussing a bid of no less than 200 pence a share that would value Amstrad at L234 million ($363 million).          Shares of Amstrad closed down 15 percent, or 29 pence, at 160, after the news was released through the London Stock Exchange. The news came four days after Amstrad publicly denied that talks with Psion had encountered a snag.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Netscape Moves To Raise Stakes In Browser War
abstract: Netscape Communications Corp to release new version of its Navigator Internet software; Netscape has negotiated deals with 26 electronic publishers, to allow users of its newest version of web-browser software to get preferential treatment from those information services; users will get free 'home delivery' of broad array of news and sports information; Netscape's browser will gather information requested by user and deliver it, in form of Web pages, to user's electronic mail in-box on Netscape home page; release of Netscape Navigator 3.0, rushed to market week after Microsoft Corp introduced its own Internet Explorer 3.0, sets stage for critical showdown between most powerful software company in world and small but fast-growing upstart that seeks to dominate networked computing just as Microsoft dominated desktop computing (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Chevron Corp, San Francisco, says it plans to lay off 250 workers in East San Francisco Bay area (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PATRIOT AMERICAN HOSPITALITY INC., Dallas, a real estate investment trust, said its joint venture with Doubletree Corp. of Phoenix had agreed to buy three Holiday Inn hotels in Tallahassee, Fla., Miami and Chicago for a total of $32 million.     INTEGRATED HEALTH SERVICES INC., Owings Mills, Md., a health care provider, acquired Century Health Services Inc. of Murfreesboro, Tenn., a provider of home nursing and therapy services, for undisclosed terms.     HAUSER CHEMICAL RESEARCH INC., Boulder, Colo., said it was negotiating with potential buyers of its money-losing Ironwood Evergreens unit and expected to close on an agreement by December.     OFFICEMAX INC., Cleveland, the office supply retailer, will accelerate its expansion plans, by opening 95 to 100 superstores this year and increase next year's openings to 125 to 150 stores.

headline: Stocks Resume Drop as Rally Fails to Hold
abstract: A morning rally in stocks faded yesterday and share prices closed broadly lower amid renewed investor concerns about corporate profits. Most major market  indexes, including the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq composite index, fell to their lowest closing levels since January.         Technology stocks were hard hit, as were stocks in many companies whose profits are particularly sensitive to economic growth. With bond prices rallying yesterday, it appears that many investors are worrying that the economy will stall, despite rapid growth earlier this year.

headline: AT&T Assails a Study by Economist
abstract: AT&T mounts major counterattack against book by economist Paul W MacAvoy which contends that long-distance telephone market has functioned since 1990 as oligarchy, with AT&T setting rates which give carriers profit margins of more than 60 percent; AT&T reportedly pressured co-publisher, American Enterprise Institute, to also put out study countering MacAvoy's arguments; MacAvoy himself has had ties to Baby Bells, and critics note he did not include AT&T's vast ad expenses in calculating costs; MacAvoy and AT&T spokesman Peter Pitsch comment; photo (M)

headline: But Questions Persist On Risks of Reinsurance
abstract: Lloyd's of London 'names,' individuals who pledge their assets to back insurance policies sold at Lloyds, are expected to approve plan to restore British insurance market to solvency by shifting billions of dollars of liabilities to Equitas, newly formed reinsurance firm; will pay up to $150,000 each to help capitalize Equitas and Lloyds will contribute some 3.2 billion pounds (almost $5 billion), freeing it of liability for claims arising from outstanding policies written before 1993; policyholders and insurance experts worry Equitas, even with $19.5 billion in reserves, will not have adequate resources; Lloyds chief executive Ron Sandler holds Equitas is 'extremely unlikely' to fail, interview; diagram; drawings; photo (L)

headline: CIA Chief Says Saddam Is Stronger After Showdown With U.S.
abstract: WASHINGTON—  Saddam Hussein has emerged strengthened from his recent confrontation with the United States, the CIA director, John Deutch, said Thursday.

headline: Behind the Fading of a Onetime Software Star
abstract: Edmark Corp, onetime star in field of educational software, has seen its shares drop ever since Walt Disney Co decided to enter children's software market; Edmark's situation reflects risks smaller players face when real heavyweight, such as Disney, presses offensive in war for market share; Sally Narodick, who is credited with much of Edmark's early success, has resigned as chief executive and chairman, and company might be put up for sale; photo; graph (M)

headline: Charles Is Said to Offer Diana Huge Settlement
abstract: Will they let her keep her title? Will she be evicted from her rent-free home in Kensington Palace? And, perhaps most importantly: when Diana, the Princess of Wales, concludes her long and drawn-out divorce from her husband, Prince Charles, the heir to the English throne, how rich will she be?         It has been four months since Diana announced that she had finally agreed to  divorce her estranged husband, the Prince of Wales, and two and a half months since negotiations over a settlement reached an apparent deadlock. So slowly have the proceedings dragged on that Prince Charles's mother, Queen Elizabeth II, was recently moved to demand that her son move a little faster to find a resolution.
